title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Reinforcement Learning using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its performance is highly dependent on the choice of hyperparameters. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization framework, 'BO-Reinforce', which efficiently tunes hyperparameters for DRL algorithms. By leveraging the probabilistic nature of Bayesian optimization, BO-Reinforce adaptively adjusts the search space and explores the most promising regions. Experimental results on several benchmark tasks demonstrate that BO-Reinforce significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both optimization efficiency and final performance, while requiring minimal domain knowledge and human intervention.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Traditional cost-based optimization techniques often fail to capture complex data distributions and workload patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans. We design a deep Q-network that learns to predict the optimal join order and indexing strategy based on query characteristics and database statistics. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Decentralized Agent Coordination using Graph Neural Networks for Smart City Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Effective traffic management in smart cities relies on coordinated decision-making among autonomous agents. This paper presents a decentralized agent coordination framework based on graph neural networks (GNNs), which leverages real-time traffic data and agent interactions to optimize traffic flow. Our approach integrates GNN-based agent embeddings with a distributed constraint optimization algorithm to facilitate scalable and adaptive coordination. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate significant reductions in travel time and congestion compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Accessibility Features for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their accessibility features often fall short for visually impaired users. This paper presents an empirical study examining the usability of current voice assistants among visually impaired individuals. We identify key pain points and propose a set of design guidelines for creating more inclusive voice assistants. Our contributions include (1) a taxonomy of accessibility features, (2) a user-centered approach to designing voice assistant personas, and (3) a prototype system that integrates our proposed features. Results from a user study demonstrate significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for adaptive traffic signal control. We model the traffic network as a Markov game, where each traffic signal is an autonomous agent learning to optimize traffic flow. Our approach, called 'MATraffic', uses a decentralized deep Q-network to learn cooperative policies among agents, taking into account local traffic conditions, pedestrian and cyclist presence, and real-time traffic signal timings. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that MATraffic reduces congestion, travel times, and emissions compared to traditional fixed-time signal control methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Improving Retrieval Accuracy
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it can significantly impact retrieval accuracy. This paper proposes a neural semantic embedding-based query expansion approach, dubbed 'NeuroQE', which leverages the power of deep learning to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. We employ a graph-based neural network to learn dense vector representations of words and phrases, which are then used to compute semantic similarity scores for expansion term selection. Experimental results on several benchmark IR datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Ad-Hoc Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a popular technique to improve retrieval performance, but it often relies on handcrafted rules or traditional machine learning methods. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach to query expansion, which learns to generate context-aware and semantically enriched query representations. Our approach, dubbed 'DeepQE', leverages a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query expansion and document ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Adaptation
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, as models often struggle to adapt to novel tasks with limited data. This paper presents a novel deep meta-learning approach, 'TaskAware', which learns to adapt to new tasks by leveraging task-aware learning representations. Our method integrates a task-encoder module that captures task-specific knowledge and a meta-learner that generates task-adaptive weights. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that TaskAware outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, achieving improved accuracy and robustness in the presence of task diversity.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for People with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gesture recognition systems that adapt to the abilities and needs of individuals with motor impairments. Our system, called 'AdaptaGest', uses a machine learning model to learn the user's gesture patterns and adapt the recognition algorithm in real-time. We evaluate AdaptaGest with a user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments and show that it outperforms existing systems in terms of accuracy and user satisfaction. We also contribute a new dataset of gesture recordings from individuals with motor impairments, which can be used to train and evaluate future gesture recognition systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but existing methods suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that leverages multi-scale graph representations to improve node classification efficiency. HGAN adaptively selects relevant nodes and features at each hierarchy level, reducing the computational cost while maintaining accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate HGAN's superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and running time.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must work together to achieve a common goal. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoopMARL', which enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task allocation in dynamic environments. We introduce a novel communication mechanism that allows agents to share task-related information and adapt to changing circumstances. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that CoopMARL outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, existing methods often struggle with scalability and flexibility in dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework, which leverages local and global graph attention mechanisms to allocate tasks to agents. HGAT learns to prioritize tasks based on agent capabilities, task dependencies, and environmental constraints, and adaptively adjusts allocation strategies as the system evolves. Experiments on a range of multi-agent scenarios demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing conditions.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach using multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We introduce a hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) to model agent-agent and agent-task interactions, and a decentralized Q-learning algorithm to learn optimal task allocation strategies. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized methods and achieves near-optimal performance compared to centralized solutions.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but users with visual impairments are often excluded from these experiences. This paper presents an inclusive VR interface design framework that incorporates audio-haptic feedback and sonification techniques to facilitate navigation and interaction for visually impaired users. We conducted user studies with 20 participants and found that our design significantly improves task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. Our framework provides a foundation for creating accessible VR experiences that can benefit a broader range of users.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Multi-Task Learning for Explainable AI Decision-Making
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI systems in high-stakes applications has raised concerns about their interpretability and trustworthiness. This paper proposes a novel multi-task learning framework, 'HATMI', that integrates hierarchical attention mechanisms to jointly learn predictive models and provide explanations for AI decision-making. Our approach leverages task-specific attention weights to identify relevant features and generate contextualized explanations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATMI outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both predictive performance and explanation quality, enabling more transparent and accountable AI systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial for deploying multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) in real-world applications. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) framework that learns to identify relevant agents and their interactions, providing interpretable insights into MARL decision-making. HAN consists of two stages: a local attention module that highlights critical agents, and a global attention module that aggregates information across agents. We evaluate HAN on a variety of cooperative and competitive MARL environments, demonstrating improved explainability and performance compared to state-of-the-art MARL algorithms.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'DRL-TA', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. We propose a novel, graph-structured neural network that learns to represent agent capabilities, task requirements, and environment constraints, enabling agents to adaptively allocate tasks based on real-time observations. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms state-of-the-art, centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and success rate.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience and engagement in VR. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, employing a mixed-methods approach to investigate the impact of avatar personalization on user immersion, satisfaction, and behavioral intention. Our results show that users who interacted with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, reported greater sense of presence, and demonstrated increased willingness to continue using VR. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Designing Adaptive Trigger-Action Programming for People with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Trigger-action programming (TAP) has revolutionized end-user programming, but existing systems often neglect the needs of people with visual impairments. This paper presents 'AccessibleTAP', a novel adaptive TAP framework that leverages multimodal interaction, machine learning-driven inference, and real-time feedback to facilitate accessible programming. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with visual impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in programming speed, accuracy, and user satisfaction. Our results inform the design of more inclusive and adaptive TAP systems that can empower a broader range of users.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized task allocation for autonomous agents using distributed constraint optimization. We propose a hybrid framework that combines constraint programming with multi-agent negotiation to efficiently allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. Our approach leverages the concept of constraint relaxation to handle conflicting constraints and enables agents to adapt to dynamic changes in the environment. Experimental results on a simulated robotics platform demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing task allocation latency and improving overall system performance.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Dynamic Task Allocation in Edge Computing Environments
paper_abstract: Edge computing has given rise to novel applications requiring autonomous decision-making in dynamic environments. This paper presents a decentralized agent-based framework for efficient task allocation in edge computing. We introduce a novel coordination mechanism, 'AgentSync', that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to changing resource availability and task priorities. Our approach enables agents to learn from experience, negotiate, and adjust their strategies in real-time to minimize latency and maximize throughput. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentSync in reducing task completion times by up to 35% in simulated edge computing scenarios.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Real-Time Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time database systems (RTDBS) require efficient query optimization techniques to ensure timely data retrieval under multi-version concurrency control (MVCC). Existing approaches focus on transactional overhead reduction, neglecting the impact of version management on query performance. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCC-Opt', which leverages version histograms and expiration times to prune unnecessary version accesses. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that considers both data freshness and query latency. Experimental results on a real-world RTDBS benchmark demonstrate that MVCC-Opt reduces average query response time by up to 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: PARAGON: A Parallel Query Optimization Framework for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data centers, but optimizing query execution in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents PARAGON, a novel parallel query optimization framework that leverages both statistical and machine learning-based techniques to identify optimal query plans. PARAGON integrates a cost-based optimizer with a deep reinforcement learning module that learns to predict query execution times and adapt to changing workload characteristics. Experimental results on a 16-node cluster demonstrate that PARAGON outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query execution time and improves system throughput by 2.2x.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to balance precision and recall, particularly when users submit short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. We demonstrate that DeepQE can effectively capture contextual dependencies and generate high-quality expansion terms, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Our experiments on the TREC ad-hoc retrieval benchmark show that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for short and noisy queries.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision making often involves complex interactions and trade-offs between agents. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture to model agent interactions and provide explainable decision-making. HAN consists of two levels of attention: intra-agent attention to capture local agent behaviors and inter-agent attention to model global interactions. We evaluate HAN on a real-world autonomous vehicle dataset and demonstrate improved decision-making performance and interpretability compared to existing approaches. Our results have significant implications for Explainable AI (XAI) in multi-agent systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on opaque AI models, hindering trust and explainability. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables transparent and interpretable decision-making in multi-agent settings. By integrating attention mechanisms across agent hierarchies, our approach captures subtle dependencies and relationships between agents, improving the overall decision-making process. Experimental results on a real-world autonomous vehicle dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of decision quality and explainability, while reducing the need for explicit feature engineering.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Databases
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of RDF data models in various domains, efficient query processing over distributed RDF databases has become a pressing concern. This paper presents a novel approach to scalable query optimization, dubbed 'DistriQP', which leverages graph-based query decomposition and dynamic task scheduling to minimize network communication overhead. Our experimental evaluation on the popular WatDiv benchmark demonstrates that DistriQP outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time and scales to large-scale distributed RDF deployments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task with numerous applications in finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. While deep learning models have shown promising results, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to identify the root cause of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global patterns in time series data to detect anomalies. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that highlights the most relevant features and time steps contributing to the anomaly score. Experimental results on four real-world datasets demonstrate the superior performance of HAN compared to state-of-the-art methods, while providing insightful explanations for the detected anomalies.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large volumes of data. However, query optimization in such systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We formulate query optimization as a Markov Decision Process and employ a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for query execution. Our approach is able to adapt to changing database workloads and outperforms traditional rule-based optimization techniques. Experimental results on a distributed database benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems are crucial for personalized services, but traditional methods struggle with large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model complex user-item relationships. HGAT learns to represent users and items as hierarchical graph structures, enabling efficient and scalable recommendation generation. Our experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-time Entity Disambiguation in Large-Scale Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches struggle with scalability and real-time performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'EDIN', which leverages a combination of graph-based and machine learning-based methods to efficiently resolve entity ambiguities. Our approach exploits the structural properties of knowledge graphs to prune the search space and employs a learned ranking model to prioritize candidate entities. Experimental results on large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that EDIN achieves an average speedup of 3.5x over state-of-the-art disambiguation methods while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has shown promise in solving complex tasks, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to provide explainable MARL policies. Our approach enables the identification of crucial agents, actions, and states that contribute to the team's decision-making process. We evaluate HAN on a set of cooperative and competitive MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial step in many information retrieval applications, including open-domain question answering and dialogue systems. However, the computational cost of dense passage retrieval methods hinders their deployment in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation framework, 'HierDoc', which leverages a multi-resolution grid-based index to efficiently prune irrelevant passages. We demonstrate that HierDoc achieves significant speedups over state-of-the-art methods while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy on several benchmark datasets.

title: Graph-Based Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed database systems, query optimization is critical to minimize latency and improve performance. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach to query optimization, which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to identify optimal execution plans. We propose a hierarchical graph decomposition method that reduces the complexity of query optimization and enables the identification of parallelizable sub-queries. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate a significant reduction in query latency and improvement in system throughput compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have transformed the way people interact with technology, but their benefits are often inaccessible to older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant, 'CARE', tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted contextual inquiries and co-design workshops with caregivers and older adults to identify design requirements. Our prototype incorporates cognitive support features, such as simplified dialogue flows, visual feedback, and emotional support. A pilot study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more accessible voice assistants.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning on knowledge graphs has gained popularity with the emergence of large-scale datasets. However, existing methods suffer from high computational costs and poor scalability. In this paper, we propose a novel framework, 'HATKE', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph regions for each task. Our approach reduces the number of model parameters and accelerates training by learning shared, task-agnostic graph embeddings. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATKE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both efficiency and accuracy.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Temporal Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale, time-evolving graph data. However, existing query optimization techniques are often ineffective for real-time analytics workloads, leading to poor performance and high latency. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'Tempo', which leverages graph structural properties and temporal dependencies to generate efficient query plans. We propose a cost-based optimization approach that incorporates a probabilistic model of query execution times, enabling Tempo to adapt to dynamic workloads and data distributions. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that Tempo outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 5x in terms of query latency and throughput.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a crucial task in human-computer interaction. However, existing methods often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that incorporates explainable attention mechanisms to recognize emotions from multimodal data. We introduce a novel hierarchical fusion strategy that selectively weights and combines attention weights from different modalities. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful attention visualizations that elucidate the emotional cues exploited by the model.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) poses significant challenges due to the inherent complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages both intra-modal and inter-modal relationships to improve emotion recognition. Our approach employs a bottom-up attention mechanism to selectively focus on salient features within each modality and a top-down attention scheme to integrate information across modalities. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and SEMAINE datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our HAN model, achieving state-of-the-art performance in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs.

title: Holonic Agent-Based Architecture for Decentralized Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel holonic agent-based architecture for decentralized resource allocation in smart grids. The proposed framework leverages the concept of holons to model complex energy distribution systems, enabling autonomous decision-making and adaptability to changing environmental conditions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through a case study on a real-world smart grid scenario, showcasing improved resource allocation efficiency and reduced energy losses compared to traditional centralized control strategies.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Dense Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant information. We propose a novel approach, Hierarchical Dense Passage Retrieval (HDPR), which leverages hierarchical dense representations to capture both local and global contextual information. Our experiments on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that HDPR significantly outperforms existing dense retrieval methods, achieving state-of-the-art results on both datasets. We also show that HDPR can be seamlessly integrated with existing ODQA architectures, leading to improved end-to-end performance.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a massive corpus to answer a given question. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) framework that significantly improves the efficiency of passage retrieval in ODQA. Our approach leverages a two-stage retriever: a coarse-grained retriever uses a lightweight dense embedding to filter out irrelevant passages, and a fine-grained retriever uses a more computationally expensive dense embedding to rank the remaining passages. We demonstrate that HDR achieves a 3x speedup over state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods while maintaining comparable accuracy on several ODQA benchmarks.

title: Emotive Avatar-Based Feedback for Enhancing Online Learning Engagement
paper_abstract: Online learning platforms often struggle to replicate the emotional connections and instant feedback of traditional classrooms. This paper presents 'Empath', an emotive avatar-based system that provides personalized, affective feedback to learners. Our approach leverages machine learning-driven sentiment analysis and embodied cognition principles to create a more immersive and engaging learning experience. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates that Empath significantly increases learner motivation, self-efficacy, and overall satisfaction, particularly for learners with anxiety or emotional difficulties.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized the field of deep learning, but existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention NAS (HGA-NAS), a novel framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to efficiently search for optimal architectures. By hierarchically modeling the architecture search space as a graph, HGA-NAS can capture complex relationships between different sub-structures and reduce the search cost by up to 3x compared to state-of-the-art methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGA-NAS on several benchmark datasets, achieving competitive performance with significantly reduced computational resources.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn agent interactions and task dependencies. Our approach, called GNN-TA, uses a decentralized GNN architecture to infer task assignments based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GNN-TA in simulated environments, showing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional optimization-based methods.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complex and nuanced nature of patent documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to improve the retrieval performance. We employ a pre-trained language model to generate semantic embeddings for patent documents and then use these embeddings to expand the initial query. Our experiments on a large patent dataset show that the proposed approach significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Modal Database Systems
paper_abstract: With the increasing prevalence of multi-modal data, conventional query optimization techniques are no longer effective in handling complex queries. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MMO', which leverages machine learning and graph-based methods to efficiently process queries in multi-modal database systems. MMO incorporates a hybrid cost model that combines estimates of CPU, I/O, and memory usage to accurately predict query execution times. Experimental results on a real-world multi-modal dataset demonstrate that MMO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and leverage a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for generating efficient query plans. Our approach, called 'RL-Opt', outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of execution time and resource utilization. We evaluate RL-Opt on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate its scalability and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Node Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label node classification is a fundamental problem in graph-based data analysis, where each node can have multiple labels. Existing methods often suffer from label correlations and node feature heterogeneity. We propose a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages both node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to capture complex dependencies between labels and nodes. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of macro-F1 score and label-wise accuracy, especially for nodes with multiple labels.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval (IR) due to the complexity of user queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepExpander', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize the selection of expansion terms. We model the query expansion process as a Markov decision process and use a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that DeepExpander significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing the computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a crucial task in many applications, including finance, healthcare, and energy. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in this domain, they often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that provides explainable time series forecasting. Our approach leverages a hierarchical structure to capture long-term dependencies and attention mechanisms to identify relevant features. We evaluate our model on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to provide accurate forecasts while generating meaningful feature importance scores. Our results show that HAN outperforms existing baselines and provides valuable insights into the forecasting process.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This paper presents a participatory design study involving 20 older adults (ages 65-85) to identify the barriers and opportunities in designing accessible conversational interfaces. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and concise language, visual feedback, and explicit error handling. We propose a set of design guidelines and a novel interface framework, 'EasyChat', which incorporates these insights. A usability evaluation with 12 older adults shows that EasyChat improves conversational flow and reduces user frustration compared to existing interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation and Execution for Autonomous Agents Using Blockchain-based Reputation Systems
paper_abstract: In large-scale multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation and execution are critical for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized framework for task allocation and execution using blockchain-based reputation systems. Our approach leverages smart contracts to incentivize agents to behave reputably, and a probabilistic model to predict agent performance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated disaster response scenario, where agents must coordinate to rescue stranded individuals. Experimental results show that our framework outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate, response time, and robustness to malicious agents.

title: Distributed Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Real-Time IoT Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation mechanisms to ensure real-time processing and minimize latency. This paper presents 'DARA', a distributed agent-based framework that leverages decentralized decision-making to allocate resources in IoT systems. We model the resource allocation problem as a multi-agent decision-making process, where each agent represents an IoT device. We propose a novel negotiation protocol that enables agents to exchange information and negotiate resource allocations in real-time. Experimental results show that DARA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of response time, resource utilization, and adaptability to dynamic changes in IoT system topology.

title: Context-Aware Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval systems rely on simplistic bag-of-words representations, neglecting the rich contextual relationships within documents. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that captures both local and global contextual dependencies in document graphs. Our model learns to attend to salient entities, concepts, and relationships, yielding improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and WikiQA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Enhancing Query Representation with Hyperbolic Geometry for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional vector space models in information retrieval (IR) often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. We propose a novel approach, HyperQuery, which leverages hyperbolic geometry to represent queries in a more expressive and compact manner. By exploiting the properties of hyperbolic space, HyperQuery enables more efficient and effective document retrieval, particularly for complex queries with multiple entities and relationships. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and query latency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Document Representation Learning for Faceted Search
paper_abstract: Faceted search is a crucial component of modern search engines, enabling users to filter search results by various attributes. However, existing document representation methods are limited in their ability to effectively capture faceted information. This paper proposes a novel document representation learning framework, 'FacRep', which incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to model faceted relationships. We demonstrate that FacRep significantly improves the performance of faceted search tasks, achieving an average gain of 12.5% in precision and 15.2% in recall compared to state-of-the-art methods on a benchmark dataset.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Limited Supervision
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval tasks often suffer from limited supervision, leading to ineffective query representations. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE-LS', which leverages a combination of keyword extraction and generative adversarial networks to improve retrieval performance. NQE-LS learns to expand queries with relevant terms, even in the presence of sparse and noisy supervision. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain over state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Reality Interfaces for People with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: People with motor disabilities face significant barriers when interacting with virtual reality (VR) systems. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework that enables users to navigate and manipulate virtual objects using only their eye movements. We developed a machine learning model that accurately predicts user intent from eye-tracking data and integrates it with a VR interface. Our user study with 15 participants with motor disabilities shows that our approach significantly improves task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach for autonomous traffic signal control. We model the traffic signal control problem as a Markov game, where each agent represents a traffic signal and learns to optimize its control policy in a decentralized manner. Our approach, called Decentralized Multi-Agent Q-Network (DMAQN), utilizes a Q-network to approximate the action-value function and a consensus algorithm to share information among agents. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that DMAQN outperforms traditional centralized control methods and other MARL approaches in terms of reducing congestion and travel time.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This study investigates the design of inclusive voice assistants for this demographic, focusing on multimodal interaction. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, exploring the effects of speech rate, tone, and visual feedback on task completion and user experience. Our results show that a slower speech rate and warm tone significantly improve task success, while visual feedback enhances user confidence. We provide design recommendations for creating more accessible voice assistants, highlighting the importance of inclusive design for older adults.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous task allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We propose a hierarchical framework that integrates a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers, enabling agents to learn optimal task assignments and execution strategies. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, coordinating exploration is crucial to achieve optimal policies. Existing methods often rely on heuristic-based strategies or assume prior knowledge of the environment. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphAttention-Explore', which leverages graph attention networks to learn coordinated exploration policies. Our method represents the environment as a graph, where agents are nodes, and edges encode their relationships. We demonstrate the efficacy of GraphAttention-Explore in several complex multi-agent tasks, showcasing improved exploration efficiency and policy performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Adaptive Trust Mechanisms for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust is a critical component for effective task allocation. This paper proposes an adaptive trust mechanism, 'TrustAdapt', which dynamically updates trust values based on agent behavior and performance. TrustAdapt integrates reputation-based trust with a novel probabilistic trust model, allowing agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and optimize task allocation. We evaluate our approach through extensive simulations, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing trust-based mechanisms.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Lexical Semantic Indexing
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. Existing methods often employ bag-of-words or dense retrieval techniques, which may not effectively capture lexical semantic relationships. This paper proposes Lexical Semantic Indexing (LSI), a novel passage indexing approach that incorporates contextualized word embeddings and graph-based clustering. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that LSI improves passage retrieval accuracy by 12.5% compared to state-of-the-art methods, while reducing the indexing time by 30%. We also show that LSI enables more efficient question answering by reducing the number of passages required for answer extraction.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper explores the design of gesture-based interfaces that cater to older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants to identify the challenges they face when interacting with existing gesture recognition systems. Our findings indicate that current systems often neglect the needs of this population, leading to frustration and disengagement. We propose a novel framework, 'GESTALT', which incorporates adaptive gesture recognition, personalized feedback, and error correction mechanisms. Our evaluation demonstrates that GESTALT significantly improves the interaction experience and reduces cognitive load for older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Column Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing environments, where multiple organizations share a single database instance. However, this architecture poses significant challenges to query performance, particularly for complex analytical workloads. In this paper, we propose a novel column store indexing approach that leverages the characteristics of multi-tenant workloads to optimize query performance. Our approach, called CSI-MT, selectively partitions and indexes columns based on tenant-specific access patterns, resulting in improved query response times and reduced storage overhead. Experimental results on a real-world multi-tenant database system demonstrate that CSI-MT outperforms traditional row-store indexing by up to 30% and reduces storage requirements by up to 25%.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Adaptive Thresholding for Real-time Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Real-time information retrieval (IR) systems require efficient document filtering to combat information overload. This paper proposes an adaptive thresholding approach, 'AdaFilter', which dynamically adjusts the filtering threshold based on the query's semantic context. Our method leverages a deep learning-based query representation model to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and incorporates a feedback mechanism to refine the threshold over time. Experimental results on the TREC News Track dataset demonstrate that AdaFilter improves filtering accuracy by 12.5% and reduces latency by 30% compared to state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Adaptive Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but its adoption is hindered by user discomfort and fatigue. Haptic feedback has been proposed as a solution, but its effectiveness is highly dependent on the feedback type and intensity. This paper presents a user study evaluating the impact of adaptive haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We propose a novel haptic feedback system that adjusts its intensity and type based on the user's physiological responses, such as heart rate and skin conductance. Our results show that adaptive haptic feedback significantly improves user satisfaction and reduces discomfort, while also enhancing the sense of presence in VR.

title: Co-Designing Conversational Agents with Children for Inclusive Play
paper_abstract: Conversational agents are increasingly being used in educational and therapeutic settings, but their design often neglects the needs and perspectives of children. This paper presents a co-design methodology that engages children in the design of conversational agents, focusing on inclusive play experiences. We conducted a series of workshops with children aged 8-12, using participatory design techniques to elicit their ideas and preferences for conversational agents. Our findings highlight the importance of emotional intelligence, playfulness, and adaptability in agents, and inform the development of a novel agent architecture that incorporates these features. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through a case study on a conversational agent for children with autism.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explanations for Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks. However, the lack of transparency in DRL policies hinders trust and adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based approach to providing explanations for DRL policies. Our method, dubbed 'HierExplain', leverages attention mechanisms to identify crucial state features and action components contributing to the policy's decision-making process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierExplain in a range of Atari games and a real-world autonomous driving scenario, showcasing its ability to generate intuitive and relevant explanations.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are widely used in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query performance remains a daunting task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively adjust query execution plans in response to changing workload conditions. Our framework, 'RL-Qopt', uses a deep Q-network to select the optimal join order, indexing strategy, and data replication scheme for each query. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database benchmark demonstrate that RL-Qopt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 35% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper introduces a novel decentralized approach using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks to agents. Our algorithm, called DecentraTA, leverages a hierarchical clustering method to group agents into clusters, reducing the problem size and enabling faster computation. We evaluate DecentraTA on a set of benchmark problems, demonstrating improved solution quality and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized task allocation algorithms.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) are increasingly used in complex applications, but task allocation remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'DRL-TA', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in heterogeneous MAS. We propose a novel actor-critic architecture that incorporates graph attention mechanisms to capture agent interactions and task dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms traditional optimization methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization, while adapting to dynamic agent availability and task priorities.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management requires efficient coordination among multiple agents, such as traffic lights and vehicles. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize the coordination of multi-agent systems in real-time traffic scenarios. We introduce a decentralized, hierarchical framework that combines graph neural networks with multi-agent deep Q-networks to learn cooperative policies. Our experiments demonstrate significant improvements in traffic flow and reduction in congestion compared to traditional, rule-based approaches. The proposed framework has the potential to revolutionize urban traffic management and pave the way for more efficient and sustainable transportation systems.

title: Efficient Explainability for Graph Neural Networks via Attention-based Feature Importance
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based applications, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper presents a novel approach to explainability in GNNs, dubbed 'AttentiveImportance', which leverages attention mechanisms to identify salient features contributing to node representations. We demonstrate that our method outperforms existing feature importance techniques in terms of Faithfulness, Monotonicity, and Sparsity, while being computationally efficient. Experimental results on molecular graphs and social networks demonstrate the effectiveness of AttentiveImportance in providing actionable insights into GNN decision-making processes.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving system-wide objectives. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to dynamic environments and agent capabilities. We introduce a decentralized Q-learning approach, where agents learn to select tasks based on their expected rewards and communicate with neighbors to avoid conflicts. Simulation results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system throughput, while also promoting fairness and robustness in the face of agent failures.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehouses using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehouses require efficient query optimization to meet stringent performance requirements. This paper proposes a novel adaptive query optimization framework, 'AQOR', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to dynamically adjust query plans based on workload patterns and system resource utilization. AQOR employs a hybrid approach combining model-based and model-free reinforcement learning to balance exploration and exploitation. Our experiments on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that AQOR outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, remains a challenging task in affective computing. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of each modality to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules that adaptively weight features from each modality, followed by a fusion layer that combines the outputs. Experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score of 0.83 across six emotions.

title: Entity Disambiguation with Graph Attention Networks for Knowledge Graph Construction
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph construction is a crucial step in many artificial intelligence and natural language processing applications. Entity disambiguation (ED) is a key challenge in this process, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in the text. This paper proposes a novel approach to ED using graph attention networks (GATs) that leverages the structural information in the knowledge graph. Our model, called GAT-ED, learns to attend to relevant nodes and edges in the graph to disambiguate entities. We evaluate GAT-ED on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification with Heterogeneous Graphs
paper_abstract: Graph attention networks (GATs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks. However, existing GATs are limited by their inability to handle heterogeneous graphs, which are common in real-world applications. This paper proposes HetGAT, a novel graph attention mechanism that efficiently learns node representations in heterogeneous graphs. HetGAT leverages a hierarchical attention architecture that adaptively aggregates features from different node types, enabling effective node classification. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HetGAT outperforms existing GAT variants and achieves competitive performance with state-of-the-art methods.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interfaces for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the potential of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) to enhance user experience. We designed a gestural interface that leverages users' bodily movements to interact with virtual objects, fostering a sense of agency and immersion. Our user study reveals that embodied interaction significantly improves task performance, reduces cognitive load, and increases user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems that take advantage of embodied cognition principles to create more engaging and effective user experiences.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based neural network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of each modality to recognize emotions more accurately. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific encoders, a multi-modal fusion module, and a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weighs the importance of each modality. Experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice-based interfaces for this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our findings inform the development of a novel interaction framework, 'ElderVoice', which incorporates features such as personalized vocabulary adaptation, error forgiveness, and multimodal feedback. A usability study with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice-based interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have garnered significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages graph-based representation learning to model complex relationships between users, items, and their attributes. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant graph structures to generate interpretable recommendations. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient decision-making policies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that decomposes the decision-making process into a high-level task planner and a low-level motion controller. We introduce a novel task representation based on graph neural networks, enabling the planner to reason about abstract tasks and objectives. The motion controller is trained using a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm with a curated reward function that balances safety, efficiency, and comfort. Simulation results demonstrate that our HRL framework outperforms flat reinforcement learning baselines in various urban driving scenarios.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but users with motor disabilities often face significant barriers to adoption. This paper presents a novel, inclusive VR interface design framework that accommodates users with diverse motor abilities. We conducted a participatory design study with 20 participants with motor disabilities, resulting in a set of actionable guidelines for designing accessible VR interfaces. Our framework incorporates adaptive gesture recognition, personalized interaction modes, and real-time feedback mechanisms. A usability study with 30 participants demonstrates that our framework significantly improves VR interaction experiences for users with motor disabilities, enabling them to fully engage with VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for open-domain question answering. However, its query retrieval performance is often hindered by the vocabulary mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach to address this issue. HQE leverages a hierarchical neural network to learn a multi-granular representation of the query, which is then used to expand the original query with relevant terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQE significantly improves the retrieval effectiveness of DPR models, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of recall and MRR.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Neural Networks for Real-time Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Real-time information retrieval (IR) systems require efficient document filtering to retrieve relevant documents from a large corpus. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepFilter', that leverages deep neural networks to filter documents in real-time. DeepFilter uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to model the relevance of documents to a given query, and a novel indexing technique to reduce the computational overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale IR dataset demonstrate that DeepFilter outperforms traditional filtering methods in terms of precision and recall, while achieving a significant reduction in filtering time.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex systems, multiple agents with diverse capabilities and objectives need to coordinate to allocate shared resources efficiently. This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning framework, 'CoRLA', which enables heterogeneous agents to learn cooperative strategies for multi-resource allocation. We introduce a novel attention-based architecture that integrates agent-specific knowledge graphs, facilitating the exchange of information and the formation of coalitions. Experimental results on a simulated supply chain management scenario demonstrate that CoRLA outperforms traditional distributed optimization methods in terms of resource utilization and system stability.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework for autonomous agents using reinforcement learning. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process and develop a multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to learn optimal task assignments. Our approach enables agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and task requirements, while minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results in a simulated robotic swarm scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Entity Retrieval
paper_abstract: Entity retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, and query expansion is a crucial step to improve the retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion by leveraging knowledge graph embeddings. We introduce a neural network-based model that learns to embeddings of entities and their relationships, and uses them to expand the query with relevant entities and keywords. Our approach is able to capture the semantic relationships between entities and improve the retrieval performance. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and show significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering or simple term weighting schemes, which may not effectively capture the nuances of natural language. We propose a novel approach, 'RL-QE', that leverages reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query expansion strategy. Our method uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy that selects the most informative terms to add to the original query, based on the reward signal of improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and NDCG.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating accessible gestural interfaces tailored to older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops and usability studies to identify key design principles and guidelines for reducing cognitive load and improving gestural recognition accuracy. Our proposed interface, 'EasyGesture', incorporates simplification strategies, visual cues, and personalized feedback to facilitate intuitive gesture interaction. A pilot study with 20 older adults with mild cognitive impairments demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing gestural interfaces.

title: Emotional Intelligence in Human-Computer Interaction: A Deep Learning Approach to Recognizing User Affective States
paper_abstract: This paper presents an innovative deep learning framework for recognizing user affective states in human-computer interaction. Our approach leverages multimodal fusion of facial expressions, speech patterns, and physiological signals to accurately detect emotions such as joy, sadness, and frustration. We propose a novel attention-based neural network architecture that adaptively weighs the importance of different modalities based on the user's context. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in emotion recognition, with a mean accuracy of 92.1% across six emotions. Our work has significant implications for developing emotionally intelligent interfaces that can provide personalized support and enhance user experience.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the varying importance of each modality in different contexts. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features at multiple levels of abstraction. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark datasets, outperforming existing multi-modal fusion methods by up to 12% in terms of emotion recognition accuracy. We also demonstrate the interpretability of our model through attention visualization, providing insights into the emotional cues extracted from each modality.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Multi-Modal Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Current information retrieval systems struggle to effectively retrieve relevant results when dealing with multi-modal queries, such as those combining text and images. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, dubbed 'QE-Multi', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to jointly model textual and visual features. By generating context-aware expansions, QE-Multi improves retrieval performance on a benchmark dataset by 15.2% compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we demonstrate the effectiveness of QE-Multi in a real-world application, retrieving relevant product images from an e-commerce platform.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on Eye Movement Patterns and User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but traditional input methods can be cumbersome and limiting. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction in VR, focusing on the relationship between eye movement patterns and user experience. We conducted a user study involving 30 participants, analyzing their eye movements and subjective feedback while interacting with a VR environment. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can significantly reduce user fatigue and improve overall experience, especially for tasks requiring precision and accuracy. We also identify key eye movement patterns that can inform the design of more intuitive and user-friendly VR interfaces.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments often require forming coalitions to achieve complex tasks. However, existing approaches are limited by scalability and adaptability issues. This paper presents a novel distributed coalition formation algorithm, 'DCFA', that leverages local information exchange and adaptive decision-making to form efficient coalitions in real-time. We evaluate DCFA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and coalition stability compared to centralized and static coalition formation methods.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Collective Inference
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in data integration and cleaning, where the goal is to identify the correct entity (e.g., person, organization, location) referred to by an ambiguous mention. This paper presents a novel graph-based collective inference approach that leverages the relational structure between entities to improve disambiguation accuracy. Our approach, 'GraphDisamb', uses a probabilistic graphical model to jointly disambiguate entities and their relationships, and incorporates a scalable iterative inference algorithm to handle large datasets. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphDisamb outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and scalability.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Efficient Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing scale and complexity of distributed database systems necessitate efficient query optimization techniques to minimize response times and improve system throughput. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and dynamic plan refinement. We introduce a cost-sensitive neural network that predicts query execution times based on historical workload patterns and system resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our approach reduces average query response times by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Maintenance of Materialized Views in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Materialized views (MVs) are a crucial optimization technique in distributed database systems, as they enable fast query processing by pre-computing and storing intermediate results. However, maintaining MVs in the presence of frequent data updates and schema changes becomes a significant challenge. This paper presents 'MV-Fresher', a novel maintenance algorithm that leverages incremental view maintenance and adaptive sampling to reduce the overhead of MV updates.
