Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system demonstrates that MV-Fresher achieves up to 60% reduction in maintenance cost and 30% improvement in query performance compared to traditional approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing queries across multiple nodes remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the query plan as a graph and leverage GNNs to learn a representation of the query that captures its structural properties. Our approach, called GNN-QO, outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time and reduces the number of joins required by up to 25%. We evaluate GNN-QO on a real-world dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in optimizing complex queries.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the presence of multiple modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model the relationships between modalities. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical graph structure to capture emotions at multiple scales and utilizes attention weights to selectively focus on relevant modalities. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods, achieving an average F1-score of 84.2% across six emotions.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Traditional query optimizers rely on rule-based approaches, which can be inefficient and suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based query optimizer, 'ML-QO', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans. We demonstrate that ML-QO outperforms traditional optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization. Our approach is particularly effective in handling complex queries and large datasets, making it suitable for modern big data applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed In-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: In-memory databases have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics, but query optimization remains a significant challenge, especially in distributed settings. This paper presents 'QuickOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and graph-based models to efficiently explore the query optimization space. We propose a distributed, asynchronous optimization algorithm that adapts to changing data distributions and query workloads. Experimental results on a cluster of 16 machines show that QuickOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time, while reducing optimization overhead by 75%.

title: Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a hierarchical neural query expansion (HNQE) framework that learns to generate context-aware query expansions. HNQE employs a novel attention-based query encoder and a hierarchical query expansion generator, which captures both local and global dependencies in the query. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%. We also provide insights into the interpretability of HNQE's learned expansions.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion for Short Text Queries using Word Embeddings and Co-occurrence Analysis
paper_abstract: Short text queries are common in search engines, but their brevity hinders effective query expansion. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages word embeddings and co-occurrence analysis to better capture the semantic context of short queries. We introduce a graph-based method to identify related terms and phrases, which are then weighted using a density-based clustering technique. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for queries with fewer than five terms.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification is a challenging problem in graph-structured data, where a model must generalize to new classes with limited labeled examples. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAT-GNN) that leverages both local and global graph structure to learn transferable node representations. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant nodes and subgraphs, enabling the model to adapt to new classes with few examples. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAT-GNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification tasks, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular in modern data management, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for efficient query optimization in distributed relational databases. We model the database as a graph, where nodes represent relations and edges represent joins. We then leverage graph algorithms to identify optimal query execution plans, reducing the search space and improving query performance. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have gained popularity for their scalability and ease of use. However, optimizing query performance in multi-tenant environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'OptiMT', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and graph-based techniques to minimize query latency and resource contention. We introduce a hierarchical query clustering approach that identifies opportunities for shared execution and caching, resulting in improved throughput and reduced tail latency. Experimental evaluation on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrates OptiMT's ability to achieve up to 3x query performance improvements compared to state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Recurrent Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual controllers for user input, limiting immersion and causing fatigue. We propose a novel gaze-based interaction method using deep recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to infer user intentions from eye movements. Our approach, 'Gaze2Act', leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent layers to learn a mapping between gaze patterns and corresponding actions in VR. We evaluate Gaze2Act on a publicly available eye-tracking dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user experience compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph traversal and the need to minimize communication overhead. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph summarization, vertex-centric query rewriting, and dynamic join ordering to reduce query latency and improve system scalability. Experimental results on a range of graph benchmarks demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the inherent complexity of human emotions and the need for interpretability. We propose a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, providing explainable emotion recognition. Our HAN consists of three stages: modality attention, feature attention, and emotion prediction. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and explainability, providing insights into the emotional cues that drive the recognition process.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud-based applications, but optimizing query performance in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize query plans based on runtime statistics and feedback from the database. Our experiments on a real-world multi-tenant database system show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, particularly in specialized domains where domain-specific knowledge is essential. This paper presents a neural QE approach, NeuroQE, which leverages domain-adversarial training to adapt to diverse domain-specific corpora. Our model incorporates a novel attention-based query-document interaction mechanism, enabling more effective expansion of query terms. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the varying importance of different modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that adaptively weights and fuses modalities to recognize emotions more accurately and efficiently. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules, a hierarchical fusion mechanism, and a multimodal emotion recognition module. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the lives of older adults, but current designs often neglect their unique needs and abilities. This study employs a participatory design approach, involving 20 older adults in the co-design of a voice assistant tailored to their requirements. We identify key design considerations, including clear and simple voice prompts, flexible dialogue flows, and minimal error handling. Our findings inform the development of a prototype voice assistant, which is evaluated through a usability study with 30 older adults. Results show significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to existing commercial voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Multimodal Fusion for Explainable AI Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has become crucial for trustworthy decision-making in high-stakes applications. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion framework, 'HAFEX', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to integrate and weigh diverse input modalities (vision, language, and audio). Our approach generates interpretable importance scores for each modality, facilitating insights into the AI decision-making process. We evaluate HAFEX on a multimodal medical diagnosis dataset, demonstrating improved performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art fusion methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Interpretable Time-Series Forecasting with Multivariate Dependencies
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting with multivariate dependencies is a crucial task in various applications, including finance, healthcare, and climate modeling. However, existing methods often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying relationships between variables. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates both local and global attention mechanisms to capture complex dependencies. Our approach enables interpretable forecasting by providing attention weights that highlight the most influential variables and time steps. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HAN over state-of-the-art methods in terms of forecasting accuracy and interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. While deep learning models have shown promising results, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying causes of anomalies. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates self-attention mechanisms to identify anomalous patterns in time-series data. Our approach enables feature-level and temporal-level explanations of the detected anomalies, providing insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies while offering interpretable results.

title: Designing Intuitive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Elderly Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel, gesture-based interface designed to support elderly adults with cognitive impairments. Our approach leverages a participatory design methodology, involving co-creation sessions with caregivers and individuals with dementia. We develop a gesture recognition system that is adaptable to varying levels of cognitive ability, incorporating machine learning-based error correction and personalized feedback mechanisms. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in interface usability and user satisfaction compared to traditional touch-based interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in decentralized settings where agents have limited communication and partial knowledge of the environment. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective task allocation strategies in a distributed manner. Our method, called GNN-TA, represents the agent-environment interaction as a graph and uses GNNs to learn a joint policy that optimizes task allocation and execution. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that GNN-TA outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environment conditions.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Hierarchical Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with query ambiguity, leading to suboptimal document ranking. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-DF', which leverages term co-occurrence patterns to disambiguate queries and improve filtering efficiency. By representing queries as hierarchical graphs, HQE-DF effectively captures semantic relationships between terms and documents, enabling more accurate filtering of irrelevant documents. Our experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and filtering effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Resource Optimization
paper_abstract: Efficient task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and constraints need to optimize resource utilization in real-time. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'MARTA', which enables agents to learn task allocation policies that adapt to dynamic environments and resource availability. Our approach integrates graph neural networks with DRL to represent complex agent interactions and resource dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated manufacturing scenario demonstrate that MARTA outperforms traditional optimization methods in terms of resource utilization, task completion time, and overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented NoSQL databases have gained popularity in big data analytics due to their ability to efficiently store and query large amounts of data. However, indexing mechanisms for these databases remain inadequate, leading to poor query performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'ComboIndex', which leverages the columnar storage layout to create a hybrid index that combines the benefits of B-tree and bitmap indexes. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset shows that ComboIndex outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in query execution time while reducing storage overhead by 25%.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Neural Ranking Models for Passage Retrieval in Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems rely on effective passage retrieval to provide relevant answers to users' queries. While neural ranking models have shown promising results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, their performance in conversational search remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of various neural ranking models, including BERT-based and graph-based architectures, for passage retrieval in conversational search. Our experiments on a large-scale conversational search dataset reveal that neural ranking models can significantly outperform traditional retrieval methods, but their performance varies greatly depending on the conversation context and query type. We provide insights into the strengths and weaknesses of each model and discuss implications for future research in conversational search.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of relational database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and overall system efficiency. However, traditional optimization techniques often struggle to keep up with the complexity and scale of modern distributed databases. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, where the optimizer learns to navigate the vast space of possible execution plans through trial and error. We design a custom reward function that incorporates both query latency and resource utilization, and demonstrate significant performance improvements on a real-world distributed database benchmark. Our approach is scalable, flexible, and adaptable to changing workload patterns.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has garnered significant attention in recent years due to the proliferation of multimodal data on social media platforms. However, most existing approaches rely on early fusion or simple concatenation of modalities, neglecting the complex interactions between them. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that explicitly models the inter-modal relationships and captures fine-grained sentiment cues from text, image, and audio modalities. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in improving sentiment analysis performance, especially in scenarios where modalities exhibit conflicting sentiments.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The advent of neural information retrieval (NIR) models has led to significant improvements in search engine performance. However, the query expansion component remains a bottleneck, often relying on traditional term-based methods. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'NeuroExp', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate semantically rich expansions. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant terms and phrases from the query context, resulting in improved retrieval effectiveness and efficiency. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of NeuroExp over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Design on User Trust in Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) are increasingly integrated into daily life, but user trust remains a significant hurdle to widespread adoption. This study investigates the effect of anthropomorphic design elements on user trust in VAs. We conducted a between-subjects experiment with 120 participants, exposing them to either an anthropomorphized or non-anthropomorphized VA. Results show that users who interacted with the anthropomorphized VA reported higher trust and perceived the VA as more relatable and competent. However, we also found that these effects were mitigated when users experienced errors or inconsistencies in the VA's responses. Our findings provide insights for designers and developers seeking to establish trust with VA users, highlighting the importance of balancing anthropomorphic design with system reliability and transparency.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Latent Semantic Hashing with Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Latent semantic hashing (LSH) is a popular technique for efficient document retrieval. However, traditional LSH methods rely on hand-crafted features and suffer from limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepLSH', which integrates deep neural networks with LSH to leverage the power of learned representations. We design a neural network architecture that learns to project documents into a compact binary space, enabling fast similarity search and retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepLSH outperforms state-of-the-art LSH methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and query efficiency.

title: Dynamic Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics in distributed database systems is crucial for various applications, including financial forecasting and IoT monitoring. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the dynamic nature of data and workloads. This paper presents 'DynaOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to adapt to changing data patterns and system conditions. DynaOpt incorporates a feedback loop that continuously monitors query performance and adjusts optimization strategies to minimize latency and improve throughput. Experimental results on a distributed database benchmark demonstrate that DynaOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of average query response time.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent task allocation, a challenging problem in distributed artificial intelligence. We introduce HGN-Allocator, a hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) framework that efficiently allocates tasks to agents in large-scale systems. Our method leverages the hierarchical structure of the agent communication graph to learn task-dependent representations and perform task allocation in a scalable manner. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGN-Allocator on several real-world task allocation benchmarks, achieving significant improvements in allocation efficiency and solution quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Cooperative Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach for real-time traffic signal control. We design a decentralized framework, 'TrafficSync', where multiple agents, each responsible for a single intersection, learn to coordinate their actions to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. Our method leverages a graph attention mechanism to capture complex traffic patterns and a novel reward function that promotes cooperation among agents. Experimental results using real-world traffic data from Pittsburgh, PA, demonstrate that TrafficSync outperforms state-of-the-art traffic signal control methods, reducing average travel times by 23% and decreasing congestion by 18%.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Efficient Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The sheer volume of web data necessitates efficient retrieval mechanisms in modern search engines. This paper presents a novel adaptive re-ranking framework, 'ARIA', which leverages contextual information and user behavior to optimize retrieval performance. ARIA incorporates a neural ranking model that dynamically adjusts its weights based on user click-through rates and dwell times, thereby improving the ranking of relevant documents. Experimental results on a large-scale web dataset demonstrate that ARIA achieves significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain compared to state-of-the-art re-ranking methods.

title: Designing Emotional Avatars for Stress Reduction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in reducing stress and anxiety, but existing VR systems often lack emotional support. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'EmoAvatar', an emotional avatar that provides empathetic responses to users' affective states in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating that EmoAvatar significantly reduces users' stress levels and improves their overall VR experience. Our findings highlight the importance of emotional support in VR and provide guidelines for designing emotionally intelligent avatars that can mitigate stress and anxiety.

title: EyeGazeType: A Gaze-Based Text Entry System for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges in interacting with computers. This paper presents EyeGazeType, a novel gaze-based text entry system that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to enable efficient and accurate typing. EyeGazeType uses a convolutional neural network to detect and classify gaze patterns, allowing users to type at a rate of 15 words per minute with an accuracy of 95%. We evaluate EyeGazeType with 20 participants with motor impairments and demonstrate significant improvements in typing speed and accuracy compared to existing gaze-based systems.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Systems for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent system (MAS) architecture for real-time traffic management. We propose a hierarchical framework where agents at different levels of abstraction collaborate to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. Our approach leverages advanced sensing technologies and distributed optimization algorithms to scale up to large urban networks. Evaluation on a simulated traffic network demonstrates significant improvement in travel times and reduced congestion compared to traditional centralized approaches. We also discuss the challenges and opportunities of integrating MAS with emerging transportation technologies such as autonomous vehicles.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents possess different capabilities and expertise. We leverage graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective task assignments, capturing complex dependencies and interactions between agents and tasks. Our approach, termed 'GNN-Allocator', is designed to operate in real-time, adapting to changing task requirements and agent availability. Experimental results demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized allocation methods, showcasing the potential of GNN-based approaches in large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, but the lack of transparency in modern deep learning models hinders their adoption. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global temporal dependencies to improve forecasting accuracy. The key innovation is the incorporation of attention weights as a means to provide interpretable insights into the model's decision-making process. We evaluate HAN on several real-world datasets, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods while facilitating model explainability through visualized attention patterns.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Neural Networks on Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in data integration, but it becomes increasingly challenging when dealing with large-scale distributed databases. This paper presents a novel approach to entity disambiguation using graph-based neural networks, which can efficiently handle massive datasets and scale horizontally. Our method, dubbed 'GraphDis', leverages the power of graph convolutional networks to model complex relationships between entities and their contextual information. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphDis outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency, while being capable of handling distributed data sources.

title: Designing Accessible Visualizations for Users with Color Vision Deficiency
paper_abstract: Color is a ubiquitous attribute in data visualization, but it can create barriers for individuals with color vision deficiency (CVD). This paper presents a human-centered design approach to create accessible visualizations for users with CVD. We conducted a series of user studies to identify effective color palette design principles and developed a novel algorithm to automatically generate CVD-friendly color schemes. Our evaluation shows that the proposed approach improves the accuracy and efficiency of data comprehension for users with CVD, while also enhancing overall user experience.

title: Coordinating Task-Oriented Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating task-oriented autonomous agents in complex environments. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn both high-level task decomposition and low-level action execution policies. Our method, called HRL-TA, leverages a two-level hierarchy of agents, where higher-level agents focus on task allocation and lower-level agents execute tasks using reinforcement learning. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate that HRL-TA outperforms traditional flat reinforcement learning and manual task assignment methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Gradient-based Methods
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly compromise their performance. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to detect such attacks using gradient-based methods. We develop a gradient-based anomaly detection algorithm that identifies abnormal input patterns by analyzing the gradient distribution of the network's activations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting various types of adversarial attacks, including FGSM and PGD. Our method achieves high detection accuracy and outperforms existing state-of-the-art detection techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Document Ranking for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models for information retrieval often suffer from high computational complexity and inadequate document representation. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based document ranking framework, 'HADRank', which leverages both local and global contextual information to improve retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. HADRank employs a two-stage attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant document regions and encode them into a compact, dense representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, but existing approaches often rely on single modalities, such as facial expressions or speech. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multimodal inputs from facial, vocal, and textual cues to recognize emotions in real-time. Our HAN model employs a bottom-up attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the Multimodal Emotion Recognition Challenge (MERC) dataset. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving user experience and affective computing applications.

title: Embracing Embodiment: Investigating the Role of Anthropomorphic Avatars in Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but designing effective VR experiences remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the role of anthropomorphic avatars in enhancing user experience in VR. We conducted a user study to investigate how the presence and customizability of avatars influence user engagement, sense of presence, and emotional response. Our results show that users who interacted with customized avatars reported higher levels of engagement and sense of presence, and exhibited increased emotional arousal. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR systems and propose a set of guidelines for incorporating avatars in VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) are crucial for building trust in AI-driven decision-making. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for ERS, which learns to focus on relevant user and item features to generate interpretable recommendations. Our approach involves a two-stage attention mechanism: (1) item-level attention to identify influential features, and (2) user-level attention to weigh the importance of item features for each user. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art ERS models in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have proven effective in various AI applications, but their scalability remains a major bottleneck. This paper presents HGRAN, a novel hierarchical graph attention network architecture that learns multi-relational knowledge graph embeddings at scale. HGRAN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures complex relationships between entities and their context, while reducing computational complexity through a novel sparse attention mechanism. Our experiments on large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that HGRAN achieves state-of-the-art performance in link prediction and entity classification tasks, while being orders of magnitude faster than existing methods.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization with Gaussian Processes
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their success heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization approach that leverages Gaussian processes to efficiently search for optimal hyperparameters. Our method, 'GP-Hyper', adaptively balances exploration and exploitation by modeling the hyperparameter space as a probabilistic function. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GP-Hyper on several benchmark datasets, achieving competitive results with existing methods while reducing the number of evaluations by up to 50%. Our approach is particularly useful for large models and limited computational resources.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-agent Cooperation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve common goals in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in AI research. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that enables agents to learn cooperative strategies in complex, partially observable environments. HGAT combines graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical reinforcement learning to model agent interactions and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our experiments demonstrate that HGAT outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in several multi-agent benchmarks, including pursuit-evasion and resource allocation tasks.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Knowledge Graph Completion
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph completion is a crucial task in AI, but it becomes increasingly challenging when faced with limited training data. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical graph structures to learn effective representations for few-shot knowledge graph completion. HGAT combines graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical clustering to adaptively select relevant nodes and edges, enabling the model to generalize well to unseen entities and relations. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot knowledge graph completion methods, achieving significant improvements in both link prediction and entity disambiguation tasks.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing approaches struggle to scale to complex, dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture, which integrates graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model complex agent interactions. HGAN enables agents to selectively focus on relevant neighboring agents and learn hierarchical representations of the environment. We evaluate HGAN on a range of MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive conversational interfaces tailored to this population. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 older adults with cognitive impairments, identifying key challenges and preferences in interacting with conversational systems. Our findings inform the development of a novel interface framework, 'EasyChat', which incorporates features such as simplified language, visual cues, and error tolerance. A usability evaluation with 15 participants demonstrates improved engagement and task completion rates using EasyChat compared to a standard conversational interface.

title: Cooperative Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Dynamic IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to increasingly complex network dynamics, necessitating adaptive resource allocation strategies. This paper proposes a novel cooperative agent-based framework, 'IoT-CoRA', which leverages decentralized decision-making and multi-agent coordination to optimize resource allocation in dynamic IoT networks. We introduce a hierarchical agent architecture that integrates machine learning-based predictive modeling and distributed constraint optimization techniques. Experimental results demonstrate that IoT-CoRA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of network throughput, latency, and energy efficiency.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Hashing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are crucial for efficient querying of large-scale data repositories. However, the high communication overhead between nodes can significantly slow down query processing. This paper presents a novel hierarchical hashing scheme, 'HierHash', which reduces query latency by up to 30% compared to existing state-of-the-art methods. HierHash leverages a hierarchical indexing structure to prune unnecessary node communications, resulting in improved query efficiency and fault tolerance. We evaluate HierHash on a real-world dataset and demonstrate its scalability and effectiveness in various query scenarios.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of the underlying infrastructure. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'RL-Optimizer', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed databases. Our approach uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy that maximizes query performance while minimizing resource utilization. We evaluate RL-Optimizer on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and resource efficiency compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DistroOpt', which leverages statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to efficiently optimize queries in distributed relational databases. DistroOpt uses a hierarchical model to capture the complex relationships between query patterns, data distribution, and system resources, and applies a reinforcement learning strategy to adapt to changing workloads. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that DistroOpt outperforms existing query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of data distribution and network topology. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize query plans based on feedback from the database system. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Traditional approaches rely on manual tuning or simple heuristics, which often fail to adapt to changing workloads and system dynamics. In this paper, we propose a novel query optimization framework based on deep reinforcement learning. Our approach learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database system and receiving rewards based on execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource consumption.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) as it enables understanding of agent interactions and decision-making. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework that incorporates attention mechanisms at both the agent and system levels. Our approach enables the identification of critical agent interactions and provides interpretable explanations for joint policy decisions. Experimental results on a variety of MARL benchmarks demonstrate improved explainability and competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art MARL methods.

title: Scalable Graph Neural Networks for Real-time Traffic Prediction
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic prediction is crucial for intelligent transportation systems. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown promise in this domain, their scalability remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'GTS', a novel GNN architecture that leverages hierarchical graph clustering and parallelized message passing to achieve scalability. We demonstrate GTS's effectiveness on large-scale traffic networks, achieving 15% improvement in prediction accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods while reducing computational overhead by 60%. Our approach enables real-time traffic prediction and has implications for urban planning and autonomous vehicles.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as text, audio, and video, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the need to integrate information from diverse sources. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for explainable emotion recognition. Our approach utilizes a stacked architecture with modality-specific attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features from each modality. We also introduce an interpretable emotion representation scheme, enabling the model to provide insightful explanations for its predictions. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving state-of-the-art performance and providing meaningful explanations for emotion recognition.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Accented Speech Recognition
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their speech recognition capabilities often struggle with accented speech, leading to frustration and exclusion. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to improve the recognition of accented speech in voice assistants. We conducted a series of studies with 30 participants from diverse linguistic backgrounds, analyzing their interactions with popular voice assistants. Our findings highlight the importance of phonetic adaptation, language modeling, and user feedback in enhancing recognition accuracy. We propose a novel framework, 'AccentAware', which integrates these insights and demonstrates a significant improvement in recognition rates for accented speech.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a crucial task in natural language processing, but it becomes increasingly challenging when dealing with multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, and audio). This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that effectively integrates and weighs the contributions of different modalities. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules and a hierarchical fusion layer, enabling it to capture both local and global relationships across modalities. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.3% in sentiment accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy has become a prevalent architecture in cloud-based database systems, where multiple tenants share the same physical infrastructure. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel optimization framework, 'TenantAware', which leverages statistical models to capture tenant-specific query patterns and resource utilization. We propose a hybrid approach that combines traditional cost-based optimization with machine learning-based prediction, enabling the database to adapt to changing workloads and resource constraints. Experimental evaluation on a real-world multi-tenant database system demonstrates significant performance improvements and reduced resource overhead.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a crucial task in information retrieval, where query expansion is a key technique to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, leveraging dense vector embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our method, dubbed 'EmbedExpan', learns a joint embedding space using a combination of word2vec and doc2vec, enabling efficient query expansion through vector operations. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvement in mean average precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Bayesian Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has become a crucial step in deep learning model development. However, the search process can be computationally expensive and requires a significant amount of labeled data. This paper introduces a Bayesian meta-learning approach, dubbed 'BaNAS', which leverages knowledge from previous search tasks to efficiently explore the architecture space. By learning a probabilistic model of the search space, BaNAS can adapt to new tasks with limited data and computational resources. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that BaNAS outperforms state-of-the-art NAS methods in terms of search efficiency and final model performance.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in smart homes, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by usability issues and inaccessible design. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key challenges and preferences. Our findings inform the development of 'EasyVoice', a voice assistant tailored to older adults' needs, with features such as simplified syntax, audio feedback, and personalized assistance. A usability study with 20 older adults demonstrates that EasyVoice outperforms existing voice assistants in terms of accessibility, usability, and user satisfaction.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-time Analytics in Column-store Databases
paper_abstract: Modern column-store databases are optimized for analytical workloads, but query optimization remains a bottleneck for real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'Raptor', which leverages machine learning models to predict optimal join orders and indexing strategies. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that integrates with the Raptor framework to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves an average speedup of 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers, making it suitable for real-time analytics applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Framework
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their usability and accessibility for older adults remain limited. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework, 'ElderVoice', which integrates speech, vision, and gesture recognition to facilitate more natural and inclusive interactions. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults and found that ElderVoice significantly improved task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only assistants. Our framework's adaptive dialogue management and personalized feedback mechanisms also helped to reduce cognitive load and user frustration.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using Hierarchical Self-Organizing Maps
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is crucial in various applications, including predictive maintenance and financial forecasting. This paper proposes a novel approach using Hierarchical Self-Organizing Maps (HSOMs) to detect anomalies in multivariate time series data. Our method leverages the strengths of SOMs in clustering and dimensionality reduction, while incorporating a hierarchical structure to handle complex patterns and anomalies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation mechanisms. This paper proposes a decentralized agent-based framework for allocating resources in IoT networks. Our approach leverages autonomous agents that negotiate and adapt to dynamic changes in the network. We introduce a novel auction-based mechanism that utilizes reinforcement learning to optimize resource allocation, leading to significant improvements in network throughput and latency. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in various IoT scenarios, including smart cities and industrial automation.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the complexities of natural language queries. Query expansion (QE) techniques can improve retrieval effectiveness, but existing methods rely on hand-crafted rules or limited training data. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn query reformulation strategies. Our method uses a Markov decision process to model the QE process and trains an agent to select optimal expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance over state-of-the-art QE methods.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR interfaces often pose significant accessibility barriers for this population. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'CognitiveEase', a novel VR interface that incorporates accommodations for cognitive impairments, such as simplified menu systems, audio cues, and gesture-based input. We conducted a user study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to existing VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, as it helps to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'NeuroXpand', which learns to generate high-quality expansion terms from a large corpus of text data. NeuroXpand leverages a combination of word embeddings and attention mechanisms to identify relevant context and relationships between terms, outperforming traditional methods based on pseudo-relevance feedback and document clustering. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a hierarchical architecture that combines a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers, enabling agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and heterogeneous capabilities. Our experiments demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system efficiency compared to traditional optimization-based approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Word Embeddings for Biomedical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Biomedical information retrieval (BIR) systems often struggle to capture the nuances of domain-specific terminology, leading to suboptimal query results. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using word embeddings, tailored to the biomedical domain. Our method, BioQE, leverages pre-trained word2vec models to identify semantically related terms and incorporates them into the original query. We evaluate BioQE on the TREC 2019 CDS dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming traditional query expansion techniques. The proposed approach has the potential to enhance the accuracy and relevance of search results in biomedical information retrieval systems.

title: Scalable Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics and decision-making. However, indexing mechanisms for efficient query processing remain a bottleneck. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'HyperCube', which accelerates multi-dimensional range queries by exploiting the hierarchical structure of main-memory data. HyperCube employs a hybrid approach that combines a compact, cache-friendly representation of the index with a dynamic, adaptive partitioning scheme. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate a 3-5x improvement in query performance compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods, while reducing memory footprint by up to 30%.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to resolve ambiguity in entity references. Existing approaches rely on hand-crafted features or graph-based methods, which suffer from scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'KG-Embed', which leverages knowledge graph embeddings to disambiguate entities. We exploit the structural properties of knowledge graphs to learn dense vector representations of entities and their context, enabling efficient disambiguation. Experimental results on large-scale datasets demonstrate that KG-Embed outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and scalability.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper introduces a novel approach to this problem using multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). We propose a decentralized MARL framework, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on its local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach uses a hierarchical graph neural network to model the agents' communication and a deep Q-network to learn the task allocation policy. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and agent utility.

title: Query-Adaptive Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional neural ranking models for information retrieval often rely on exhaustive document encoding, leading to increased computational costs. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive neural ranking framework, 'QNRF', which dynamically selects relevant document snippets based on query semantics. By incorporating a query-dependent attention mechanism, QNRF significantly reduces the number of required document encodings while maintaining retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that QNRF achieves state-of-the-art efficiency gains without compromising ranking accuracy.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems have become increasingly popular for indexing large-scale document collections. However, query efficiency remains a significant challenge, particularly in systems with high node counts. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HiDIR', which partitions the document collection into a hierarchical structure of indices. We demonstrate that HiDIR reduces query latency by up to 37% compared to existing flat indexing methods, while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on a real-world DIR system show that HiDIR scales efficiently to handle large query volumes and provides improved fault tolerance.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Gaming
paper_abstract: The use of personalized avatars in virtual reality (VR) gaming has gained significant attention in recent years. However, there is a lack of understanding of how these avatars impact user engagement. This paper presents a study that investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR gaming. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR game with varying levels of avatar personalization. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, particularly among players who strongly identify with their avatars. We also found that the level of personalization affects user behavior, with more personalized avatars leading to increased exploration and social interaction.

title: Query-Driven Latent Semantic Indexing for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Latent semantic indexing (LSI) is a popular technique for dimensionality reduction in information retrieval. However, traditional LSI methods often suffer from high computational costs and mediocre retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel query-driven LSI approach, 'QDL', which leverages the query context to adaptively select the most informative latent dimensions. By incorporating a sparse coding scheme and a query-dependent weighting strategy, QDL achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QDL outperforms state-of-the-art LSI variants, especially for short queries and high-dimensional document collections.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, forming coalitions is a crucial task to achieve common goals. However, finding the optimal coalition structure is an NP-hard problem. This paper presents a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to distributedly form coalitions in multi-agent systems. We propose a decentralized, asynchronous algorithm that allows agents to learn effective coalition formation strategies through self-play. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent relationships and deep Q-networks to learn optimal coalition formation policies. Experimental results on various multi-agent scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in forming coalitions that achieve better system-wide performance compared to traditional methods.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management has the potential to significantly reduce congestion and emissions in urban areas. This paper proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HMaRL', which coordinates the actions of multiple autonomous vehicles and traffic signals to optimize traffic flow. We design a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) to model the complex interactions between agents and the environment. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that HMaRL outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods and other multi-agent reinforcement learning approaches in terms of average travel time and emissions reduction.

title: Multimodal Emotion Recognition using EEG and Facial Expression Analysis for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling systems to respond empathetically to users. This paper presents a novel multimodal approach that combines electroencephalography (EEG) and facial expression analysis to recognize emotions. Our proposed framework, 'EmoSync', uses convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to extract features from EEG signals and facial images, which are then fused using a gated recurrent unit (GRU) network. We evaluate EmoSync on a dataset of 100 participants and achieve an accuracy of 92.1% in recognizing four emotions: happiness, sadness, anger, and fear. Our results demonstrate the potential of multimodal emotion recognition in enhancing HCI experiences.

title: Optimizing Join Operations in Distributed Relational Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Join operations are a fundamental component of relational databases, but their optimization remains a challenging task, especially in distributed environments. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages machine learning to optimize join operations in distributed relational databases. We propose a framework that uses reinforcement learning to adaptively select the most efficient join order based on the database schema, data distribution, and query workload. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art join optimization techniques, achieving up to 3x improvement in query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Sparse Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but often rely on dense vector representations that incur high computational costs. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'SparseQE', which leverages sparse embeddings to reduce the dimensionality of query representations while preserving their semantic meaning. We introduce a sparse autoencoder-based method to learn compact query embeddings that are optimized for retrieval tasks. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SparseQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques while reducing the computational overhead of neural retrieval models.

title: Cooperative Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Route Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach for optimizing route planning in autonomous vehicle (AV) fleets. We propose a decentralized policy gradient method, 'CoopRoute', which enables AVs to learn from shared experiences and adapt to dynamic traffic patterns. By incorporating a graph-based communication framework, CoopRoute facilitates knowledge sharing among agents, leading to improved route efficiency and reduced congestion. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulation demonstrate the effectiveness of CoopRoute in minimizing travel time and fuel consumption.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Data warehousing has become a crucial component of business intelligence, enabling organizations to make informed decisions based on historical and real-time data. However, the sheer volume and velocity of modern data streams pose significant challenges to indexing and query performance. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, 'RT-Index', which leverages a combination of in-memory caching, column-store indexing, and adaptive sampling to optimize query response times for real-time data warehousing. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that RT-Index outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of data freshness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems often struggle to capture the nuances of biomedical queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic relationships between medical concepts. Our model, MedQE, uses a combination of word embeddings and graph attention mechanisms to generate high-quality expansion terms. Experimental evaluations on the TREC CDS dataset demonstrate that MedQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to trust their predictions. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) for explainable time-series anomaly detection. Our HAN model incorporates multi-scale attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant temporal and spatial patterns, enabling the identification of anomalous subsequences. We evaluate our approach on three real-world datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting anomalies while providing visual explanations for the predictions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification on graph-structured data is a fundamental problem in many applications, but it often suffers from limited labeled data. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages the hierarchical structure of graphs to improve few-shot node classification. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and graphs at different scales, and a meta-learning framework to adapt to new graph tasks with few labeled nodes. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification, especially when the labeled data is extremely scarce.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper presents a decentralized approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to allocate tasks to agents in a distributed manner. Our proposed framework, 'DAGAT', utilizes a novel message-passing algorithm that integrates agent capabilities, task requirements, and communication constraints to compute optimal task assignments. Experimental results on a simulation platform demonstrate that DAGAT outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and system scalability.

title: EyeGazePath: A Novel Gaze-Based Interaction Technique for Improving Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various fields, but users with motor disabilities often face significant barriers to access. This paper presents EyeGazePath, a novel gaze-based interaction technique that leverages machine learning to predict user intentions and enable seamless navigation in VR environments. Our approach addresses the limitations of existing gaze-based systems by incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights multiple gaze features. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates that EyeGazePath outperforms state-of-the-art gaze-based methods in terms of accuracy, speed, and user satisfaction.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of accurately retrieving relevant products from massive catalogs. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach that incorporates product category, user search history, and query intent analysis to disambiguate user queries. Our approach leverages a neural network-based query representation model to capture semantic relationships between query terms and product attributes. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and efficiency compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing large-scale graph data, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize query plans for distributed graph databases by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution time. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention for Long-Sequence Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Long-sequence time series forecasting is crucial in various applications, such as climate modeling and financial analysis. However, existing methods often struggle with capturing long-range dependencies and suffer from quadratic computational complexity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HiAttn', which leverages a hierarchical representation of the input sequence to selectively focus on relevant segments. HiAttn reduces the computational complexity to linear while achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. We demonstrate the efficacy of HiAttn in forecasting tasks, including weather and stock price prediction.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the task allocation problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and preferences need to form coalitions to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a decentralized coalition formation algorithm that leverages preference elicitation and graph theory to identify stable and efficient coalitions. Our approach incorporates a novel mechanism for handling conflicting preferences and ensuring fairness among agents. Experimental results demonstrate that our algorithm outperforms existing decentralized coalition formation methods in terms of coalition stability, task completion rate, and fairness metrics.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years. However, most existing approaches rely on simplistic feature attribution methods, neglecting complex user-item relationships. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) for ERS, which models user-item interactions as a hierarchical graph structure. HiGAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant user and item features, generating explanations in the form of feature importance scores. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Robustness of Deep Neural Networks to Adversarial Attacks through Bayesian Neural Network Ensembling
