paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability in critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to enhance the robustness of DNNs against such attacks using Bayesian neural network ensembling (BNNE). We demonstrate that BNNE can improve the model's resistance to attacks by averaging predictions from an ensemble of Bayesian neural networks, each with a different prior distribution. Experimental results on popular image classification datasets show that our approach achieves state-of-the-art robustness to adversarial attacks while maintaining competitive accuracy on clean data.

title: Optimizing Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on effective query expansion to retrieve relevant documents. Recent neural retrieval models have shown promising results, but their query expansion mechanisms are often limited by the quality of the input queries. This paper proposes a novel optimization framework, 'QE-Opt', which leverages reinforcement learning to dynamically adapt query expansion strategies for neural retrieval models. Our approach incorporates a reward function that balances precision and recall, and we demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that QE-Opt can improve the mean average precision by up to 12% on the TREC-CAR dataset.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing VR systems often fail to accommodate their unique needs. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create inclusive VR experiences for this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults, caregivers, and clinicians to identify key accessibility barriers and opportunities. Our findings inform the development of a novel VR framework, 'EmpathVR', which incorporates cognitive support features, such as simplified interfaces and audio cues, to facilitate engagement and enjoyment. A pilot study with 20 older adults demonstrates improved user experience and cognitive engagement compared to existing VR systems.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Augmented Reality-Based Museum Exhibits
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) is increasingly used in museum exhibitions to enhance visitor engagement. However, current gestural interfaces often fail to consider the diverse needs and abilities of visitors. This paper presents an adaptive gestural interface framework, 'ARtivate', which uses machine learning-based user modeling to personalize the interaction experience. ARtivate incorporates a real-time gesture recognition system, a user profiling module, and a dynamic interface adaptation engine. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that ARtivate significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces cognitive load, and enhances overall exhibit exploration.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has shown promise in various applications, but existing methods often struggle to scale to large teams and complex tasks. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables efficient and effective cooperation among agents. Our HAN module incorporates both inter-agent and intra-agent attention mechanisms, allowing agents to selectively focus on relevant teammates and task components. We evaluate our approach on a range of MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning agents often struggle to provide interpretable decision-making processes, hindering their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to generate explainable policies. Our approach learns to focus on relevant state features, action sequences, and temporal dependencies, producing a hierarchical representation of the decision-making process. We evaluate HAN on a suite of Atari games and demonstrate significant improvements in both policy performance and interpretability over existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, especially when dealing with limited labeled data. This paper introduces a novel meta-learning approach that leverages self-supervised contrastive learning to improve the adaptability of few-shot learners. Our method, MetaCon, uses a contrastive loss to learn a generic feature extractor that can be fine-tuned with a few labeled examples for a new task. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaCon on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in few-shot image classification tasks. Furthermore, our approach shows improved robustness to domain shifts and outperforms existing methods in low-data regimes.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Multimodal Information Retrieval with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MMIR) tasks, such as image-text retrieval, are becoming increasingly popular. However, existing approaches struggle to effectively model the complex relationships between different modalities. This paper proposes a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'HybridGNN', which integrates graph neural networks (GNNs) with traditional retrieval models. HybridGNN learns to represent multimodal data as a graph, capturing both intra-modal and inter-modal relationships. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on two MMIR benchmarks, achieving significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with limited query context. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to inject semantic meaning into the query representation. Our method, KG-Expan, uses a graph attention network to learn entity relationships and generate expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on the TREC CAR dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for verbose and ambiguous queries.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in safety-critical domains. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at both the feature and decision levels. Our approach enables the identification of relevant state features and action sequences contributing to the agent's decision-making process. Experimental results on a set of Atari games demonstrate that HAN-based DRL agents not only achieve competitive performance but also provide insightful explanations for their actions.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems often struggle with query performance due to the complexity of data distribution and indexing. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing approach, 'DynaIndex', which dynamically adjusts the index structure based on query patterns and data distribution. DynaIndex leverages machine learning-based query prediction and adaptive sampling to optimize index creation and maintenance. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database show that DynaIndex achieves an average of 30% improvement in query response time compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Co-Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular, but individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers to using these systems. This paper presents a co-design approach to creating accessible gesture-based interfaces, involving individuals with motor impairments throughout the design process. We investigate the use of machine learning-based gesture recognition algorithms adapted for motor-impaired users, and evaluate our approach through a user study with 20 participants. Our results show significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction, demonstrating the importance of inclusive design in HCI.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, it is essential to ensure that older adults with cognitive impairments can fully participate in VR experiences. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR interfaces tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with older adults with cognitive impairments and caregivers, resulting in the development of a novel VR interface that incorporates cognitive support features, such as simplified navigation and error forgiveness. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to a standard VR interface.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a human-centered design approach to create accessible conversational interfaces tailored to this population. We conducted interviews and usability studies with 20 older adults with mild cognitive impairments, identifying key challenges and design recommendations. Our proposed interface, 'CogChat', incorporates features such as simplified language, visual cues, and error forgiveness. Evaluation results show that CogChat significantly improves usability and reduces frustration for older adults with cognitive impairments, enabling them to more effectively interact with conversational systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Cultural and Linguistic Biases
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their language processing capabilities often perpetuate cultural and linguistic biases. This paper presents a mixed-methods study on the impact of cultural and linguistic biases on voice assistant interactions. We conducted a survey of 500 participants from diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds, followed by a usability study of three popular voice assistants. Our results show that existing voice assistants struggle to recognize and respond to non-standard dialects and accents, leading to frustration and exclusion. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, including culturally-sensitive language models and adaptive error correction mechanisms.

title: Efficient Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems (MAS), where agents with different capabilities need to be assigned to tasks to optimize system performance. This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We propose a hierarchical DRL framework that learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, task requirements, and system constraints. Our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and system adaptability to changes in task requirements or agent availability. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in complex, heterogeneous MAS.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making under Uncertainty
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) rely on sophisticated decision-making algorithms to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'UncerAV', that learns to make robust decisions under uncertainty. By incorporating probabilistic uncertainty estimation and risk-aware reward functions, UncerAV outperforms state-of-the-art DRL methods in simulated AV environments. We demonstrate improved safety and efficiency in scenarios involving pedestrian interactions, roadwork, and adverse weather conditions.

title: Investigating the Impact of Animated Transitions on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, creating engaging and intuitive interfaces is crucial. This study explores the effect of incorporating animated transitions on user engagement in VR environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR interface featuring either static or animated transitions between tasks. Our results show that animated transitions significantly enhance user engagement, reducing task completion time and increasing overall satisfaction. We also identify key animation characteristics that influence user behavior, providing guidelines for VR interface designers.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Route Optimization
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) require efficient route planning to minimize travel time and energy consumption. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework for AV route optimization. Our approach combines a high-level route planner with a low-level motion controller, using a hierarchical policy gradient method to optimize both route selection and motion control. We evaluate our framework on a realistic simulation environment and demonstrate significant improvements in travel time, energy efficiency, and safety compared to traditional graph-based methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have become increasingly prevalent in human-computer interaction, but their performance often degrades for individuals with motor disabilities. This paper presents an inclusive gesture recognition framework that adapts to the unique abilities and needs of users with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning-based approach that leverages a dataset of gestures from individuals with various motor disabilities, and introduces a novel feature extraction technique that emphasizes robustness to variability in movement patterns. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval that aims to refine user queries to better match relevant documents. Traditional methods rely on term co-occurrence and frequency-based approaches, which often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships. This paper proposes a novel neural embedding-based query expansion framework, 'NEQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to encode query terms and documents into dense vector spaces. We demonstrate that NEQE significantly improves retrieval effectiveness by incorporating contextualized semantic information, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing VR systems often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences, focusing on haptic and auditory feedback mechanisms. We conduct a user study with 20 visually impaired participants, evaluating the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing user engagement and navigation. Our results demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction, highlighting the potential of our framework to promote inclusive VR design.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Self-Organizing Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using self-organizing agents in dynamic environments. We propose an agent-based framework that leverages local interactions and decentralized decision-making to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Our approach utilizes a multi-objective optimization strategy to balance task completion time, resource utilization, and agent autonomy. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient task allocation and robustness to environmental disturbances.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Coordinating task allocation in multi-agent systems is a complex problem, particularly in decentralized settings. This paper presents a novel auction-based mechanism, 'DASM', which enables agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We leverage a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves (VCG) auction design to ensure truthfulness and efficiency, while incorporating a novel 'task clustering' technique to reduce communication overhead. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that DASM outperforms existing decentralized methods in terms of allocation efficiency and fairness.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Multi-Agent Systems using Blockchain-based Reputation Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust management is crucial for facilitating cooperation and preventing malicious behavior. This paper presents a decentralized trust management framework that leverages blockchain technology to establish a tamper-proof reputation mechanism. Our approach enables agents to maintain a transparent and immutable record of their interactions, allowing them to assess the trustworthiness of their peers. We evaluate our framework using a simulated multi-agent environment and demonstrate its effectiveness in promoting cooperation and penalizing malicious behavior.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Re-Ranking for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in modern information retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to re-rank candidate expansion terms. Our method, dubbed 'DeepExpan', combines a BERT-based language model with a learning-to-rank framework to optimize the selection of expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepExpan significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving an average of 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in multi-modal sentiment analysis, but their lack of interpretability hinders their deployment in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates explainable attention mechanisms to identify salient features in both visual and textual modalities. Our approach leverages a hierarchical fusion strategy to combine modality-specific attention weights, enabling the model to focus on relevant regions of interest in images and sentences. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our HAN model in improving both predictive performance and model interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Medical Diagnosis
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in AI-driven medical diagnosis, where model interpretability can facilitate trust and understanding of life-critical decisions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to explain the diagnosis process. Our approach leverages feature importance scores to identify key biomarkers and highlight relevant patient information, enabling clinicians to understand the rationales behind AI-driven diagnoses. We evaluate HAN on a large-scale electronic health record dataset, demonstrating significant improvements in diagnosis accuracy and explainability compared to existing deep learning models.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This study investigates the effect of personalized avatar embodiment on user experience in virtual reality (VR) environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR system using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly enhance user engagement, presence, and overall satisfaction, particularly among individuals with high self-identity scores. We also found that the sense of agency and body ownership are crucial factors in determining the effectiveness of personalized avatars. The findings have implications for the development of VR systems that aim to provide immersive and engaging experiences.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) that aims to enhance the querying process by adding relevant terms to the original query. Traditional QE methods rely on manual feature engineering and often suffer from limited scalability. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages the power of neural networks to learn effective query representations. Our approach combines a query encoder with a term importance predictor to generate high-quality expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to cooperative task allocation for multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We present a decentralized framework, 'CATALYST', that enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task allocation in complex, dynamic environments. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a multi-agent deep Q-network to learn optimal task allocation strategies. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of CATALYST in improving overall system performance and adaptability compared to traditional, hand-coded allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. However, traditional methods suffer from either limited vocabulary coverage or increased computational complexity. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE', which leverages document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain. We also show that NQE is computationally efficient and can be easily integrated into existing retrieval systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Question Answering
paper_abstract: Explainable AI techniques have gained significant attention in recent years, particularly in question answering tasks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that provides interpretable explanations for the question answering process. Our approach employs a multi-stage attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant context and question tokens, facilitating the generation of faithful explanations. Experimental results on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate that our HAN model achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing meaningful explanations for the predicted answers.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Design on User Trust in Intelligent Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: As intelligent virtual assistants (IVAs) become increasingly pervasive, it is essential to understand how design elements influence user trust. This study investigates the effect of anthropomorphic design on user trust in IVAs, leveraging a mixed-methods approach combining surveys, interviews, and usability testing. Our findings suggest that anthropomorphic design elements, such as facial features and conversational tone, can positively impact user trust, but only when balanced with transparency and clear functionality. We propose a framework for IVA designers to optimize trustworthiness while minimizing the risks of anthropomorphism.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems with Workload-Aware Partitioning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization that leverages workload-aware partitioning to minimize resource contention among tenants. Our method, called 'PartiOpt', uses machine learning-based workload forecasting to dynamically adjust partitioning schemes and optimize query plans. Experimental results on a real-world cloud database show that PartiOpt reduces average query latency by up to 35% and improves resource utilization by 25% compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel distributed task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems. The proposed approach leverages graph attention networks to learn effective representations of agent capabilities and task requirements. We develop a decentralized algorithm that allows agents to negotiate and allocate tasks in a distributed manner, taking into account communication constraints and resource limitations. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing overall system latency compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Individuals with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and pronunciation, often struggle to interact with these systems effectively. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible voice assistants tailored to the needs of individuals with dysarthria. We propose a multi-modal input method combining speech recognition with gesture-based input, and develop a personalized error correction mechanism that adapts to the user's speech patterns. A user study with 20 participants with dysarthria demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Expansion on Neural Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have demonstrated state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc search tasks. However, their effectiveness is often limited by the quality of the input query. Query expansion techniques aim to enrich the original query by incorporating relevant terms, but their impact on neural retrieval models remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of various query expansion methods on multiple neural retrieval architectures. Our experiments reveal that judiciously applied query expansion can lead to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for queries with limited context. We provide insights into the factors influencing the effectiveness of query expansion and discuss implications for future research.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture the semantic intent behind user queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using neural semantic graphs, which model the relationships between query terms and relevant concepts in a knowledge graph. Our method, dubbed 'NeuQE', leverages graph attention mechanisms to identify the most informative expansion terms and integrates them into a re-weighted query representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging reinforcement learning to optimize task assignment and execution. We introduce a hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) to model agent interactions and task dependencies, enabling agents to learn distributed policies that adapt to dynamic environments. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization, making it suitable for real-world applications such as autonomous robotics and smart cities.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using machine learning techniques. We develop a graph neural network-based model that learns to predict the optimal query plan based on the graph structure and query patterns. Our experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with query drift and limited training data. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'PRF-NeuRank', which leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to adaptively refine the query representation. By incorporating a neural-based relevance scoring function, PRF-NeuRank effectively identifies relevant terms and documents, leading to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, outperforming existing query expansion methods and showcasing its potential in real-world search applications.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution in DDS remains a challenging problem. In this paper, we propose a novel adaptive query optimization approach, 'AQORL', that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query execution plans. AQORL uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan based on real-time system workload, data distribution, and query patterns. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that AQORL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x and reducing query latency by 30%.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to allocate tasks to autonomous agents in a distributed manner. Our method, called 'DRL-TA', uses a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn task allocation policies that maximize system utility and minimize communication overhead. We evaluate DRL-TA in a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate its superiority over traditional methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but the role of embodiment in shaping user experience remains poorly understood. This study investigates how the level of embodiment in VR affects users' sense of presence, engagement, and cognitive load. We designed an experiment where participants performed a series of tasks in a VR environment with varying levels of embodiment, from simple controllers to full-body tracking. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to higher presence and engagement, but also increases cognitive load. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and provide recommendations for optimizing the user experience.

title: Explainable Query Reformulation for Effective Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on effective passage retrieval to provide accurate answers. However, existing query formulation methods often fail to capture the nuances of the question, leading to suboptimal passage retrieval. This paper proposes an explainable query reformulation framework, 'ERRQ', which leverages a novel attention-based query encoder and a passage-centric relevance predictor. Our approach generates interpretable query reformulations that better capture the question intent, resulting in significant improvements in passage retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on the HotPotQA and NaturalQuestions datasets demonstrate the efficacy of ERRQ in enhancing ODQA performance.

title: Real-time Human-AI Collaboration for Efficient Decision-Making in High-Stakes Environments
paper_abstract: In high-stakes environments, human decision-makers often rely on intuition and experience to make critical decisions. This paper proposes a real-time human-AI collaboration framework that leverages the strengths of both humans and AI systems. Our approach, 'HybridMind', integrates a cognitive modeling component to capture human decision-making biases and a machine learning module to provide data-driven recommendations. We evaluate HybridMind in a simulated emergency response scenario, demonstrating improved decision accuracy and reduced response time compared to human-only or AI-only decision-making approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often struggle with vocabulary mismatch, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn optimal expansion strategies. Our approach, dubbed 'RL-QE', uses a neural agent to iteratively select expansion terms based on their expected reward, measured by the predicted relevance of the expanded query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Inductive Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in node classification tasks. However, they often struggle to generalize to unseen graphs or nodes. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages graph structural information and node features to improve inductive node classification. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs, enabling more accurate predictions on unseen nodes. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art GNN models in inductive node classification tasks, achieving improved accuracy and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the inherent complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model the intricate relationships between modalities. Our approach learns to weigh the importance of each modality and captures contextual dependencies through hierarchical graph attention. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal data.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the development of autonomous negotiation strategies for multi-agent systems operating in dynamic environments. We propose a novel framework, 'DynaNeg', which integrates probabilistic reasoning with game-theoretic analysis to enable agents to adapt their negotiation tactics in response to changing environmental conditions. Our approach leverages Markov decision processes to model the uncertain environment and learn optimal policies for negotiation. Experimental results in a simulated supply chain management scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of DynaNeg in achieving improved negotiation outcomes and increased robustness to environmental uncertainties.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has revolutionized autonomous vehicle control, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders trust and reliability. This paper presents a novel explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which leverages model-agnostic techniques to provide interpretable insights into DRL policies. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant state features, enabling the generation of human-understandable explanations for vehicle control decisions. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving environment demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Explain in improving safety, transparency, and trust in DRL-based autonomous vehicles.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Learning Models against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can have significant consequences in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to robustness analysis using Bayesian neural networks (BNNs). We leverage the probabilistic nature of BNNs to quantify the uncertainty of the model's predictions and detect adversarial examples. Our method, 'BayesDefend', is shown to outperform state-of-the-art defenses against a range of attacks, including PGD and CW attacks, on multiple benchmark datasets. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the robustness guarantees provided by BayesDefend, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving the reliability of deep learning models.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on large-scale time-series data is crucial in various applications, such as IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, existing indexing techniques are often limited by their inability to handle high ingestion rates and diverse query patterns. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'TSIX', which leverages a combination of hierarchical Bloom filters and adaptive sampling to achieve efficient query processing and low memory footprint. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that TSIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of query latency and throughput while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Query Optimization for Real-time Analytics on Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships in modern data-driven applications. However, query optimization for real-time analytics on large-scale distributed graph databases remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphStorm', which leverages a combination of graph partitioning, caching, and adaptive query rewriting to minimize query latency. We evaluate GraphStorm on a real-world social network dataset and demonstrate an average query performance improvement of 3x compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Evolutionary Game Theory
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the distributed task allocation problem in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have varying capabilities and task requirements. We propose an evolutionary game-theoretic approach, where agents adapt their strategies based on payoffs from previous interactions. Our algorithm, called EvoTask, incorporates a novel mutation operator that exploits the structure of the task graph to improve allocation efficiency. Simulation results on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that EvoTask outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time, communication overhead, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Semi-structured Data using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization for distributed semi-structured data remains a challenging problem. Existing approaches rely on heuristics or manual tuning, leading to suboptimal performance. We propose a novel framework, 'RL-QOpt', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for distributed semi-structured data. RL-QOpt uses a deep Q-network to learn from query execution experiences and adapt to changing data distributions. Experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of distributed graph databases, as it directly impacts query performance and system scalability. However, existing optimization techniques rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, leading to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for distributed graph databases. We design a custom environment and reward function to train an agent that learns to select efficient query plans based on graph topology, data distribution, and system workload. Our experiments on several real-world graph datasets demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Efficient task allocation is crucial for multi-agent systems, but centralized approaches can be brittle and vulnerable to single points of failure. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to enable autonomous agents to adaptively allocate tasks based on their capabilities and environmental conditions. We introduce a novel algorithm, 'DARA', which utilizes a decentralized Q-learning approach to optimize task allocation in real-time. Experimental results demonstrate that DARA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Emotion Regulation in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in treating anxiety disorders by simulating real-world scenarios, but user engagement and emotional response remain significant challenges. This paper presents 'EmpathyBot', an embodied conversational agent (ECA) that employs nonverbal cues, emotional intelligence, and empathetic feedback to facilitate emotion regulation in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating that EmpathyBot significantly increased user engagement, reduced anxiety, and improved emotional awareness compared to traditional VR exposure therapy. Our results inform the design of ECAs for mental health applications and highlight the potential of VR-based interventions for emotion regulation.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Traditional learning-to-rank methods in information retrieval (IR) often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HNR, which leverages a tree-based architecture to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. HNR learns to aggregate local ranking signals from sibling nodes, enabling fast and accurate retrieval of top-ranked documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNR outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational overhead by up to 40%

title: Evaluating the Impact of Visual Feedback on Gesture-Based Authentication in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture-based authentication in virtual reality (VR) is gaining popularity, but the role of visual feedback in enhancing security and usability remains understudied. We investigate the effect of different visual feedback types on the performance and user experience of gesture-based authentication in VR. Our user study involving 40 participants reveals that providing real-time visual feedback of gesture trajectories can significantly improve authentication accuracy and reduce error rates. However, we also observe a trade-off between security and usability, as more detailed feedback can compromise gesture secrecy. Our findings inform the design of more effective and user-friendly gesture-based authentication systems for VR applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agent Teams using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Autonomous agent teams are increasingly used in various applications, such as search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and smart cities. However, efficient task allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a decentralized approach to task allocation using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). We propose a novel DCOP algorithm that leverages local communication and negotiation among agents to allocate tasks, taking into account their capabilities, preferences, and constraints. Experimental results using a simulated urban search and rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms centralized methods in terms of solution quality, scalability, and adaptability to dynamic changes.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (QA) tasks require models to reason over multiple sentences or documents to answer a question. While recent advances in transformer-based models have improved performance, they often lack interpretability. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to selectively focus on relevant information. Our approach leverages a novel graph-based attention mechanism to model relationships between sentences and entities. Experimental results on the HotPotQA dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing interpretable explanations for its answers.

title: Eye-Gaze Guided Attention Mechanism for Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel attention mechanism for multimodal human-computer interaction that leverages eye-gaze information to disambiguate user intent. Our approach, 'EyeGuide', integrates a deep neural network-based eye-tracking model with a multimodal fusion framework to enable more accurate and efficient human-computer interaction. We evaluate EyeGuide on a dataset of 30 users performing various tasks on a multimodal interface and demonstrate a significant reduction in error rates and improvement in interaction speed compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Range Queries in Distributed Time-Series Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed time-series databases (DTSDBs) are increasingly used for large-scale IoT and sensor data management. Efficient range query processing is crucial for many applications, but existing indexing techniques are either too space-consuming or sacrifice query performance. This paper presents 'RITree', a novel, distributed indexing approach that adapts to the underlying data distribution and query patterns. RITree constructs a hierarchical tree structure, where each node represents a compact, lossy summary of the data. Experimental evaluation on a real-world DTSDB deployment shows that RITree reduces query latency by up to 5x and storage overhead by 3x compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Designing Accessible Chatbots for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: The increasing popularity of chatbots has led to a growing concern about their accessibility for older adults. This study investigates the design of multimodal chatbots that cater to the needs of older adults, focusing on speech, text, and gesture-based interactions. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, aged 65-85, to evaluate the usability and user experience of three chatbot prototypes. Our results highlight the importance of adaptive dialogue management, clear visual cues, and intuitive gesture recognition for enhancing accessibility. We provide design implications for creating inclusive chatbots that support healthy aging and social inclusion.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Network-based Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a neural network-based QE approach, dubbed 'NeuroQE', which leverages dense embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. NeuroQE employs a multi-task learning framework, jointly training a query-document similarity model and a term-term similarity model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to mimic human-like dialogue, but often struggle to capture the nuances of user intent. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages dialogue history and user preferences to refine search queries. CAQE incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the importance of contextual features, including named entities, sentiment, and domain knowledge. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational search dataset show that CAQE significantly improves retrieval accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Label Imbalanced Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification tasks often suffer from class imbalance, where certain labels have a significantly lower number of instances. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that addresses this issue by learning to focus on relevant labels and instances. Our approach consists of a label-aware attention module that selectively weights labels based on their importance and a instance-aware attention module that adaptively aggregates features from similar instances. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of macro F1-score and label-wise accuracy, especially in scenarios with severe class imbalance.

title: Unifying Multi-Modal Interaction for Embodied Agents using Graph-Based Attention
paper_abstract: Embodied agents, such as robots and virtual assistants, require effective multi-modal interaction to understand and respond to human commands. This paper proposes a novel graph-based attention mechanism, 'GraphAttention', which integrates visual, auditory, and linguistic cues to improve agent understanding. Our approach models each modality as a node in a graph, allowing the agent to selectively focus on relevant inputs and capture complex contextual relationships. We evaluate GraphAttention on a benchmark dataset of human-robot interactions, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Real-time Data Integration for IoT Sensor Networks using In-Memory Data Grids
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT sensor networks has led to an explosion of data generation, posing significant challenges for real-time data integration and processing. This paper proposes a novel in-memory data grid architecture, 'IoT-Grid', designed to handle high-volume, high-velocity IoT data streams. By leveraging distributed in-memory caching and parallel processing, IoT-Grid achieves orders-of-magnitude performance improvements over traditional disk-based data integration approaches. We evaluate IoT-Grid using a large-scale industrial IoT dataset and demonstrate its ability to support real-time data analytics and machine learning workloads.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel explainability framework, 'RL-EX', which leverages model-based reinforcement learning to generate human-interpretable explanations for DRL policies. RL-EX integrates a model-based RL component that learns a dynamics model of the environment and a generative model that produces explanations in the form of natural language and visualizations. Our experiments on Atari games and real-world robotics tasks demonstrate that RL-EX provides faithful and informative explanations without compromising policy performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. However, most existing methods suffer from a lack of interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying causes of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework, which integrates both local and global attention mechanisms to identify anomalies in time series data. Our approach enables the identification of relevant features and time segments contributing to anomaly detection, thereby providing explainability. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies while outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and interpretability.

title: EyeGaze+: Enhancing Eye-Tracking-Based Interface for People with Severe Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with severe motor impairments face significant challenges in interacting with digital systems. Eye-tracking-based interfaces offer a promising solution, but they often struggle with accuracy and reliability. This paper presents EyeGaze+, a novel interface that leverages machine learning algorithms to improve the performance of eye-tracking systems. Our approach incorporates a personalized calibration process, adaptive gaze estimation, and real-time feedback mechanisms. We evaluate EyeGaze+ with a group of participants with severe motor impairments and demonstrate significant improvements in interface accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a given question. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture for passage retrieval, which models the graph structure of the corpus and captures long-range dependencies between passages. Our approach leverages a coarse-to-fine retrieval strategy, where the HGNN first identifies relevant clusters of passages and then refines the ranking within each cluster. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art passage retrieval performance, improving upon strong baselines by 12.5% in terms of recall@10.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Learning-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it directly affects the relevance and quality of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, which leverages the strengths of both language models and semantic embeddings. Our proposed method, 'DeepQE', uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively expand query terms based on their contextual importance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Deep Neural Network-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data in IoT Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in time series data, making anomaly detection a critical task. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-ADNet', which leverages the strengths of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) to detect anomalies in time series data. Our approach incorporates a hybrid encoder-decoder architecture that captures both local and global patterns in the data, improving detection accuracy and reducing false positives. Experimental results on real-world IoT datasets demonstrate the superiority of TS-ADNet over state-of-the-art methods, showcasing its potential for real-time anomaly detection in IoT systems.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Agent Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-agent autonomous systems (MAAS) are increasingly prevalent in real-world applications, but their complexity necessitates novel control strategies. This paper proposes a hierarchical deep reinforcement learning (HDRL) framework for MAAS, where each agent learns to coordinate with its peers while adapting to dynamic environments. Our HDRL architecture consists of two levels: a high-level policy network that determines agent roles and a low-level controller network that executes primitive actions. We evaluate the proposed approach on a simulated drone swarm scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and robustness to agent failures compared to flat RL baselines.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents for Efficient Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, task allocation among autonomous agents is crucial for efficient problem-solving. This paper presents a novel framework, 'DynaTask', which leverages a combination of machine learning and multi-agent systems to optimize task allocation. DynaTask uses a graph neural network to model agent-agent interactions and task dependencies, and a distributed constraint optimization algorithm to allocate tasks in real-time. We evaluate DynaTask in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved response times and resource utilization compared to existing approaches.

title: Exploiting Graph Neural Networks for Efficient Query Optimization in Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial step in relational database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'GQN', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to optimize query plans. We represent the query plan space as a graph, where nodes correspond to query operators and edges represent dependencies between them. By training a GNN to predict the optimal query plan, we demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and memory usage compared to traditional optimization techniques. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark show that GQN outperforms state-of-the-art optimization algorithms by up to 3.5x.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of optimizing resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, 'CloudOptimizer', which learns to allocate resources efficiently based on historical workload patterns and real-time monitoring data. Our DRL model incorporates a hierarchical architecture with both global and local decision-making components, enabling it to adapt to changing workload conditions and minimize resource waste. Experimental results on a real-world cloud computing dataset demonstrate that CloudOptimizer achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and reduces energy consumption compared to traditional heuristics.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Retrieval of Semi-Structured Data in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing volume of semi-structured data in distributed systems has created a need for efficient retrieval mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach that combines the benefits of inverted indexing and graph-based indexing. Our approach, called HybridIndex, utilizes a distributed architecture to index semi-structured data and supports efficient query processing. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HybridIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques in terms of query response time and scalability.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) environments require intuitive and accurate gesture recognition systems to provide immersive experiences. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gesture recognition systems that leverage machine learning and sensor fusion techniques. Our proposed system, 'AdaGest', uses a combination of computer vision, inertial measurement unit, and electromyography sensors to recognize gestures in real-time. We evaluate the performance of AdaGest in a VR-based gaming scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and latency compared to existing state-of-the-art systems.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Dense Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient retrieval of relevant passages from a massive corpus to answer user queries. This paper presents DPR-PRF, a novel dense retrieval model that integrates passage retrieval and passage re-ranking into a single, end-to-end trainable framework. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global contextual information, enabling more accurate passage retrieval and re-ranking. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that DPR-PRF outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a 15% improvement in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy and a 20% reduction in inference time.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization that leverages machine learning and graph-based models to identify efficient query plans. Our approach, called 'DistOpt', uses a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group queries based on their characteristics and then applies a reinforcement learning framework to learn the optimal query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DistOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques in terms of execution time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, textual, and acoustic features to predict sentiment scores. Our HAN model consists of three stages: modality-specific attention, cross-modal interaction, and sentiment fusion. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that learns to focus on relevant regions in images and utterances, enabling explainable multimodal sentiment analysis. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance and providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency with Context-Aware Indexing for Real-Time Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The proliferation of real-time data sources has underscored the need for efficient query processing in information retrieval systems. This paper presents a novel context-aware indexing technique, 'CAI', which leverages query patterns and user behavior to optimize index structures for real-time query answering. CAI incorporates a probabilistic modeling framework to capture the uncertainty of user queries and adaptively adjusts the index layout to minimize query latency. Experimental evaluation on a large-scale news dataset demonstrates that CAI reduces query response times by up to 47% compared to traditional indexing methods, while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Improved Retrieval in Short-Text Document Collections
paper_abstract: Short-text document collections pose significant challenges for information retrieval systems due to the limited context and sparse term frequencies. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages both local and global context to improve the retrieval performance. Our method first identifies topic-specific query aspects and then expands them using a weighted combination of term embeddings and graph-based centrality measures. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, especially for short-text queries.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Efficient Query Expansion in Neural Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have revolutionized information retrieval by leveraging dense vector representations. However, these models often struggle with query expansion, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes an adaptive re-ranking framework, 'AdaQE', which dynamically adjusts the query expansion process based on the retrieval context. By incorporating a reinforcement learning-based controller, AdaQE learns to optimize the trade-off between query representation and document similarity. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art neural retrieval models.

title: Investigating the Impact of Cognitive Load on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely on accurate gesture recognition to provide immersive experiences. However, the cognitive load imposed by VR interfaces can affect users' gesture performance. This study examines the relationship between cognitive load and gesture recognition accuracy in VR. We designed a series of experiments using a custom-built VR setup and performed gesture recognition tasks under varying cognitive load conditions. Our results show that increased cognitive load significantly degrades gesture recognition accuracy, particularly for complex gestures. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more intuitive and robust VR interfaces.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an increasing need for efficient resource allocation in IoT networks. This paper proposes a decentralized agent-based approach for resource allocation, where each device is represented by an autonomous agent that negotiates with other agents to allocate resources. We introduce a novel negotiation protocol, called 'ARA', which leverages game-theoretic principles to achieve fair and efficient resource allocation. Our experimental results demonstrate that ARA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of resource utilization and network latency, while also providing robustness against node failures and malicious agents.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Cooperative Agents using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems require efficient task allocation strategies to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to allocate tasks among agents in a distributed setting. We design a decentralized, asynchronous framework where agents learn to optimize their task assignments based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional auction-based methods.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Intelligent traffic signal control is crucial for efficient urban transportation. This paper presents a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HMA-ATSC', for autonomous traffic signal control. HMA-ATSC consists of a central coordinator agent and multiple local agents, each responsible for a traffic intersection. The coordinator agent learns to optimize traffic signal timings at the network level, while local agents adapt to real-time traffic conditions. We evaluate HMA-ATSC on a realistic urban traffic simulator and demonstrate significant reductions in travel time, congestion, and emissions compared to traditional fixed-time signal control and state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has become increasingly important with the proliferation of multimedia data on social media platforms. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that effectively integrates visual, acoustic, and textual features to improve sentiment analysis performance. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant multimodal features, and a sentiment-aware fusion strategy to combine the outputs from each modality. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both single-modal and multimodal settings, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 5.2%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Interpretable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media platforms has severe consequences for individuals and society. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture for fake news detection. Our model leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between news articles, users, and their social connections. We introduce an interpretable attention-based explanation module that identifies the most influential users and news articles contributing to the classification decision. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that our HGNN outperforms state-of-the-art fake news detection methods while providing transparent and actionable insights into the decision-making process.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents for efficient resource allocation in complex systems. We propose a decentralized deep reinforcement learning framework, 'CADRAL', which enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for allocating resources in real-time. CADRAL uses a hierarchical architecture to integrate local and global decision-making, and is shown to outperform traditional optimization methods in simulations of large-scale resource allocation problems. We evaluate CADRAL in a case study on smart grid energy management, demonstrating improved efficiency and adaptability in dynamic environments.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing gesture-based interfaces for older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving participatory design workshops, usability testing, and gesture recognition experiments. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptive gesture recognition, personalized feedback, and intuitive visual cues in promoting accessibility and user satisfaction. We propose a novel gesture-based interface framework, 'EasyGesture', which incorporates machine learning-driven gesture classification and real-time adaptation to user abilities. Our evaluation demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user experience for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique to improve the effectiveness of information retrieval systems. However, traditional methods rely on shallow semantic representations and often suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DSE-QE', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense semantic embeddings for queries and documents. We demonstrate that these embeddings can be effectively used to expand queries and improve retrieval performance. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that DSE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Semantic Query Expansion for Image Retrieval using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Image retrieval systems often rely on textual queries, which can be limited by the user's vocabulary and context. This paper proposes a novel semantic query expansion approach using deep reinforcement learning, which learns to generate context-aware and semantically rich queries. Our method, dubbed 'SQR', leverages a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the query expansion process, leveraging both visual and textual features from the images. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that SQR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving up to 25% improvement in retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranker for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to improve the retrieval effectiveness by reformulating the original query. This paper proposes a neural re-ranker based query expansion approach, which leverages the semantic relationships between the query terms and the documents to generate effective expansion terms. Our model, named NeuralExpansion, employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture the contextual information and a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the expansion process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuralExpansion outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-Scale Image Datasets using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Clustering large-scale image datasets remains a challenging task due to the curse of dimensionality and computational complexity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'DeepHier', which leverages the representational power of deep neural networks to learn a hierarchical structure of image clusters. We introduce a new loss function that encourages the formation of compact and well-separated clusters, and demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepHier on several benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that DeepHier outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodiment in Virtual Reality-based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction in virtual reality (VR) environments. While advances in machine learning have improved recognition accuracy, the impact of embodiment on gesture recognition remains understudied.
