This paper presents an empirical study examining the effect of embodiment on gesture recognition in VR. We conducted a user study with 40 participants, manipulating the level of embodiment in a VR-based gesture recognition task. Our results show that increased embodiment significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy, particularly for complex gestures. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more effective and intuitive VR-based interfaces.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that are accessible and usable by individuals with motor disabilities. We conducted a series of user studies to identify the challenges faced by individuals with motor impairments when interacting with gesture-based systems. Based on our findings, we developed a set of design guidelines and a prototype system that incorporates machine learning-based gesture recognition, adaptive feedback, and personalized customization. Our evaluation results show significant improvements in user performance and satisfaction compared to existing gesture-based interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents learn to allocate tasks autonomously using deep reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'Dec-TARL', utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent maintains its own policy and value functions, and communicates with its neighbors to achieve collective task allocation. We evaluate Dec-TARL in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional centralized approaches. Our results show that Dec-TARL can effectively handle dynamic task arrivals, agent failures, and communication constraints, making it a promising solution for real-world multi-agent systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Source Data Integration using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Complex query optimization is a critical challenge in multi-source data integration, where data is sourced from diverse, autonomous systems. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach for efficient query optimization, leveraging graph neural networks to model data dependencies and correlations. Our method, called GraphOpt, incorporates a two-stage optimization strategy that first identifies optimal data sources and then generates an execution plan. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, reducing query execution time by up to 40% while maintaining result accuracy.

title: Query-driven Document Expansion for Improved Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has achieved state-of-the-art results in open-domain question answering by leveraging dense vector representations of passages. However, DPR models often struggle to retrieve relevant documents when the query lacks sufficient context or contains ambiguous terms. This paper proposes a query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which generates additional context-aware passages from the top-retrieved documents. Our experiments on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that QDE significantly improves the retrieval performance of DPR models, especially for queries with low lexical overlap with the relevant documents.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on simplistic weighting schemes or ignore contextual information. This paper presents a novel approach, ContextQE, which leverages context-aware embeddings to capture the nuanced relationships between query terms and their surrounding context. By integrating these embeddings into a neural ranking model, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets. Our experiments show that ContextQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly in scenarios with ambiguous or polysemous query terms.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Graph Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it can significantly impact the relevance and ranking of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep graph embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed GraphQE, represents the query and document graph as a heterogeneous graph, and then applies a graph neural network to learn dense embeddings. These embeddings are used to expand the original query with relevant terms, resulting in improved retrieval performance. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, especially in scenarios with limited query context.

title: Efficient Graph Attention Networks for Real-time Traffic Forecasting
paper_abstract: Accurate and real-time traffic forecasting is crucial for intelligent transportation systems. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown promise in this domain, they often suffer from high computational complexity and neglect the importance of node attention. This paper introduces 'GraphAttentionFlow', a novel GNN architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on relevant nodes and edges in the traffic graph. We propose a parallelizable attention scheme that reduces computational overhead by 30% compared to existing GNN models. Experiments on a large-scale traffic dataset demonstrate that GraphAttentionFlow outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of forecasting accuracy and inference speed.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning via Uncertainty-Aware Policy Regularization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive successes in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability in safety-critical applications. This paper presents a novel approach to enhance the adversarial robustness of DRL agents by incorporating uncertainty-aware policy regularization. We introduce a new regularization term that encourages the policy to be more cautious in regions of high uncertainty, thereby reducing the attack surface. Experimental results on several benchmark environments demonstrate that our method significantly improves the robustness of DRL agents against a range of adversarial attacks, while maintaining their performance in the absence of attacks.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) enables organizations to make timely business decisions by analyzing fresh data. However, RTDW systems face the challenge of optimizing complex queries under tight latency constraints. This paper presents 'RapidQuery', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and identify optimal query plans. We propose a hybrid approach that combines traditional query optimization techniques with deep learning-based cost estimation models. Experimental results on a real-world RTDW benchmark demonstrate that RapidQuery outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query latency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranking for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often suffer from lexical mismatch and semantic ambiguity. This paper proposes a neural re-ranking approach, 'NeuQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to capture nuanced context and semantics. NeuQE reformulates the QE problem as a ranking task, where the model predicts the relevance of expansion terms based on their semantic similarity to the original query. Experiments on standard TREC datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art QE methods. We also show that NeuQE can be efficiently integrated into existing retrieval pipelines, making it a viable solution for large-scale search engines.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Neural IR Systems
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (IR) models have shown promising results in document ranking tasks. However, they often rely on dense document embeddings, which can lead to scalability issues and slow query response times. This paper presents a novel approach to generate query-adaptive document embeddings, termed 'QADE', which dynamically adjusts the embedding space based on the query context. Our method leverages a graph attention mechanism to selectively highlight relevant document regions, enabling faster and more accurate retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC CAR dataset demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art neural IR models while reducing the average query latency by 30%

title: Embedding-based Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines struggle to provide accurate results due to the ambiguity and diversity of user queries. We propose a novel embedding-based query expansion approach, 'QUEE', which leverages pre-trained language models to capture semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. QUEE generates a set of expanded queries that are semantically close to the original query, and then uses a supervised ranking model to re-rank the retrieved documents. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that QUEE improves the mean average precision by 12% compared to traditional query expansion methods, while reducing the computational overhead by 30%.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has shown immense potential in various fields, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR game using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results indicate that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, reduced cognitive load, and improved overall satisfaction. We also explore the role of avatar customization on user identity and self-presence in VR. This research has implications for the design of VR systems, particularly in applications such as education, therapy, and entertainment.

title: Enabling Personalized Accessibility in Virtual Reality through Eye-Tracking and Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with disabilities. However, current VR systems often lack personalized accommodations, hindering their adoption. This paper presents a novel approach to enable personalized accessibility in VR using eye-tracking and machine learning. We develop a deep learning model that analyzes eye movement patterns to detect user preferences and abilities, and adaptively adjusts the VR environment to provide tailored support. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates. We discuss the implications of our approach for promoting inclusivity in VR and future directions for research.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval to improve the retrieval performance. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and fail to capture the semantic relationships between words. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense semantic embeddings for query terms. We introduce a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize the retrieval performance and semantic similarity between words. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods by 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness in Multi-Task Learning with Transformers
paper_abstract: Recent advances in transformer-based architectures have led to impressive performance gains in multi-task learning settings. However, these models remain vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'TransAdv', which leverages task-specific adversarial examples to improve the robustness of transformer-based multi-task models. We demonstrate that TransAdv achieves state-of-the-art results on a suite of benchmark datasets, while providing robustness guarantees against a range of adversarial attacks. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, where robustness is critical.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Feedback for Enhanced User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has immense potential for immersive experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'GazeFlow', a novel framework that leverages gaze tracking and machine learning to provide personalized, real-time feedback to users in VR environments. GazeFlow adaptively adjusts the feedback intensity and type based on the user's gaze patterns, fostering increased engagement and immersion. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that GazeFlow significantly improves user satisfaction and reduces cognitive load compared to traditional feedback mechanisms.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Gradient-Based Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing NAS methods are often computationally expensive and require significant resources. This paper proposes a novel gradient-based meta-learning approach, 'MetaNAS', which leverages the concept of meta-learning to efficiently search for optimal neural architectures. By learning a meta-model that adapts to various architecture search tasks, MetaNAS reduces the computational cost of NAS by an order of magnitude while achieving competitive performance on several benchmark datasets.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-based Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face challenges when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive gesture-based interfaces that can accommodate users with varying levels of motor ability. Our approach leverages machine learning-based gesture recognition and real-time adaptation to provide personalized interaction experiences. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction. The proposed framework has implications for enhancing accessibility in various applications, including gaming, virtual reality, and healthcare.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Limited Labels
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task, particularly when labels are scarce. We propose a novel hierarchical meta-learning approach, 'MetaHier', which leverages a nested few-shot learning framework to adapt to new tasks with limited labels. Our method learns to generate task-specific priors and adaptively updates the model parameters using a hierarchical attention mechanism. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that MetaHier outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot classification methods, achieving competitive performance with only a few labeled examples.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Learning-based Eye Tracking
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces often require manual input, which can be cumbersome and detract from the immersive experience. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for VR, leveraging deep learning-based eye tracking to infer user intentions. We propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture that accurately predicts gaze points from eye movement data, and integrate it with a VR platform to enable hands-free interaction. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional manual input methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Models for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in patent retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual thesaurus construction or simplistic term weighting. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep neural models to learn semantic representations of patent queries and documents. We propose a hierarchical attention-based neural network that captures both local and global context in patent texts, and demonstrate its effectiveness in enhancing query expansion for patent retrieval tasks. Experimental results on a large-scale patent corpus show significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Gaze-based Intention Recognition for Adaptive Interface Personalization
paper_abstract: This paper introduces GRIP, a novel gaze-based intention recognition framework for adaptive interface personalization. GRIP utilizes a combination of convolutional neural networks and graph-based attention mechanisms to infer user intentions from eye movement patterns. We evaluate GRIP on a dataset of 50 users interacting with a web-based interface and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional rule-based personalization approaches. The proposed framework has implications for enhancing user experience in various applications, including web browsing, gaming, and assistive technologies.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback and Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it can significantly improve the retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback and deep neural networks. Our method uses a BERT-based neural ranking model to generate a set of pseudo-relevant documents, which are then used to extract expansion terms. We evaluate our approach on several standard TREC datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art query expansion methods, including RM3 and SCOPE. Our results show that the proposed approach can achieve up to 25% improvement in mean average precision over the baseline.

title: Efficient Out-of-Distribution Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to making overconfident predictions on out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, which can lead to catastrophic failures in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach to detect OOD inputs efficiently. Our method, called Meta-OOD, learns to adapt to new OOD scenarios by leveraging a few labeled examples from the target distribution. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Meta-OOD on multiple benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in detecting OOD inputs while requiring significantly less computational resources than existing methods.

title: Designing Emotive Avatars for Enhancing User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current avatar designs often fail to elicit emotional responses from users. This paper presents an investigation into the role of emotive avatars in enhancing user engagement in VR environments. We propose a novel framework for designing avatars that incorporate subtle emotional cues, and evaluate its effectiveness through a user study. Results show that users exhibit increased emotional arousal and engagement when interacting with emotive avatars, compared to traditional, neutral avatars. Our findings have implications for the design of future VR systems that aim to facilitate deeper user connections and more immersive experiences.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on Temporal Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly important for real-time analytics in various domains. However, existing indexing techniques for temporal graphs are either inefficient or ineffective for handling large-scale dynamic graphs. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, called Temporal Graph Index (TGI), which leverages a combination of graph partitioning, temporal segmentation, and incremental indexing. Our experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that TGI outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x in terms of query performance and 3x in terms of indexing time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process of AI models. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for ERS, which learns to selectively focus on relevant user and item features. Our approach leverages multi-hop attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between users, items, and their corresponding attributes. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explainability.

title: Optimizing Subquery Processing in Column-Store Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Column-store databases have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to efficiently store and query large amounts of data. However, optimizing subquery processing in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to optimize subquery processing in column-store databases. We present a predictive model that learns from historical query patterns and optimizes subquery execution plans to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate significant performance improvements over traditional optimization techniques.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for dynamic task allocation in smart grids. The framework, called MATRA, models the interactions between agents as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process. MATRA uses a hybrid approach that combines centralized planning with decentralized execution, enabling efficient allocation of tasks to agents in real-time. We evaluate MATRA on a simulated smart grid environment and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced energy consumption compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data analysis. However, existing graph neural networks (GNNs) often suffer from scalability issues and poor performance on large graphs. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical graph representations and attention mechanisms to improve node classification. HGAT learns to focus on relevant subgraphs and adaptively aggregates features from different layers, resulting in improved performance and efficiency. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in comparison to state-of-the-art GNNs.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis in social media is a challenging task due to the complexity of integrating heterogeneous data sources. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities, such as text, images, and videos, to infer sentiment. Our approach leverages a stacked attention mechanism to model intra-modality and inter-modality relationships, enabling the capture of nuanced sentiment cues. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our HAN architecture in improving sentiment analysis accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large volumes of data. However, query optimization in such systems remains a challenging task. Traditional query optimizers rely on heuristics and rule-based approaches, which may not always lead to optimal query plans. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to learn the optimal query plan. Our approach, called 'RLQO', uses a deep Q-network to learn the query optimization policy from a large dataset of queries and their corresponding execution plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that RLQO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Self-Organizing Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must adapt to dynamic environments and allocate tasks efficiently. This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework, 'SOATA', which leverages self-organizing agents to optimize task allocation in real-time. SOATA integrates a distributed auction-based mechanism with a self-organizing neural network that learns to predict task requirements and agent capabilities. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that SOATA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation approaches in terms of task completion rate, latency, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown remarkable performance in information retrieval tasks, but they often suffer from the vocabulary mismatch problem. To address this, we propose a novel query expansion method that leverages contrastive learning to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our approach, dubbed 'ConEx', learns to contrast the query representation with a set of relevant and non-relevant documents, resulting in a more accurate and diverse set of expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ConEx significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, leading to improved retrieval performance and robustness.

title: Multimodal Fusion for Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Embodied cognition posits that the mind is shaped by sensorimotor experiences. Virtual reality (VR) offers a unique platform to explore this concept, but current systems lack a comprehensive understanding of multimodal fusion. We propose a novel framework, 'EmboVR', which integrates visual, auditory, and haptic cues to create a more immersive and embodied experience. Our system leverages machine learning to predict user intentions and adapt the simulation accordingly. A user study demonstrates improved cognitive performance and presence in VR compared to traditional unimodal approaches.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem, especially in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-MA', that enables agents to coordinate and adapt to changing task requirements. Our approach combines a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers, allowing agents to learn effective task assignment strategies while responding to unexpected events. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HRL-MA significantly improves task completion rates and reduces response times compared to traditional decentralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data Warehouses using Hybrid Indexing
paper_abstract: As data warehousing applications continue to grow in complexity, query optimization remains a critical performance bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'FlexiCube', which combines the benefits of traditional B-tree indexing with the scalability of bitmap indexing. We develop a cost-based optimization framework that dynamically selects the most effective indexing strategy based on query workload characteristics and data distribution. Experimental evaluations on a real-world dataset demonstrate that FlexiCube achieves up to 3.5x speedup in query execution time compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Neural Networks for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of digital information has led to an increased demand for efficient and scalable information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach for document filtering, which significantly reduces the computational overhead of traditional retrieval methods. Our model, called 'DocFilter', learns a hierarchical representation of documents and queries, enabling efficient filtering of irrelevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DocFilter achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computation time by up to 75%.

title: Hierarchical Agent-Based Modeling for Real-Time Traffic Flow Prediction
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical agent-based modeling approach for real-time traffic flow prediction. Our method, dubbed 'AgentFlow', leverages the strengths of both macroscopic and microscopic traffic modeling by recursively decomposing the traffic network into smaller, interacting agent-based sub-models. This hierarchical structure enables the capture of complex traffic dynamics at multiple scales, while reducing computational overhead. We evaluate AgentFlow on a large-scale urban traffic dataset, demonstrating significant improvements in prediction accuracy and computational efficiency compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Retrieval Networks for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search often relies on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep neural retrieval networks to learn robust query representations. Our method, called 'NeuralQE', integrates a transformer-based encoder with a relevance-based feedback mechanism to generate high-quality expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuralQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Semantic Indexing for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed systems face significant challenges in efficiently retrieving relevant documents from large-scale repositories. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical semantic indexing (HSI) approach that leverages both local and global context to improve document retrieval performance. Our method utilizes a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group semantically similar documents, followed by a distributed indexing scheme that reduces query latency. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that HSI outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods in terms of precision, recall, and query response time.

title: Efficient Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Contrastive Regularization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of interpretability hinders its widespread adoption. This paper addresses the explainability challenge in DRL by introducing a novel contrastive regularization technique, dubbed 'ExploCE'. Our approach encourages the policy network to learn a compact and informative representation of the state-action space, which enables the generation of meaningful explanations for the agent's decisions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ExploCE on a range of Atari games, showcasing improved transparency and performance compared to existing explanation methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to scale to large, complex datasets. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to learn robust, hierarchically-organized representations for few-shot classification tasks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in various few-shot learning scenarios, including cross-domain and cross-task settings.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it helps to alleviate the vocabulary mismatch problem. However, existing QE methods often rely on handcrafted rules or superficial keyword extraction. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'QE-DRL', which learns to expand queries by optimizing a reward function that balances retrieval effectiveness and efficiency. Our approach leverages a neural query encoder and a reinforcement learning agent that interactively refines the query representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QE-DRL outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the factors that influence social presence in VR environments is crucial. This study explores the role of embodiment in fostering social presence in VR, examining how the level of bodily representation and agency affects users' sense of co-presence and engagement with virtual agents. Our results show that higher levels of embodiment lead to increased social presence, but also reveal individual differences in response to varying levels of embodiment. The findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to facilitate social interaction and collaboration.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Task Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created a need for efficient task allocation strategies that can adapt to dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARA', that learns to allocate tasks to IoT devices in a decentralized manner. MARA utilizes a graph neural network to model the communication topology of the IoT network and employs a decentralized actor-critic algorithm to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that MARA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and energy efficiency.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings and Hashing
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in data integration and knowledge graph construction. However, existing approaches struggle to scale to large datasets with millions of entities. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding method that leverages hashing to efficiently disambiguate entities. Our approach, called GraphHash, represents entities as compact binary codes, enabling fast similarity searches and reducing the computational complexity of entity disambiguation. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphHash outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and scalability.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that affects the overall performance and efficiency of the system. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that utilizes reinforcement learning to learn optimal task assignment strategies. Our approach, called 'RL-TA', enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing task requirements and system dynamics. We evaluate RL-TA using a simulation-based approach and demonstrate its superiority over traditional task allocation methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and system robustness. The proposed framework has applications in various domains, including robotics, smart grids, and autonomous vehicles.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks through Topological Denoising
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based applications. However, they are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can manipulate node features or graph structures to mislead the model. This paper proposes a novel topological denoising framework, 'GraphShield', to enhance the robustness of GNNs against such attacks. By learning to identify and remove noisy nodes and edges, GraphShield improves the model's resistance to perturbations while preserving its performance on clean data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in defending against various types of attacks.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities must collaborate to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model agent relationships and task dependencies. HGAT learns to allocate tasks by inferring hierarchical graph structures that reflect agent capabilities and task requirements. Experimental results on a variety of multi-agent task allocation benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Adaptive Contextualized Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages adaptive contextualized word embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Our approach dynamically updates the word embeddings based on the query context, allowing for more effective expansion of the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Visual Feedback on Gesture Recognition Accuracy in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition is a crucial component in virtual reality (VR) systems, but existing methods often rely on machine learning models that can be brittle to variations in user input. This paper investigates the effect of visual feedback on gesture recognition accuracy in VR. We design a novel visualization framework that provides users with real-time feedback on their gestures, and conduct a user study to evaluate its impact on recognition accuracy. Results show that our approach improves recognition accuracy by 12.5% compared to baseline methods, and also reduces user fatigue and cognitive load. Our findings have implications for the design of more effective and user-friendly VR interfaces.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing poses significant challenges in terms of query optimization, particularly in scenarios involving high-volume and high-velocity data streams. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach, 'SmartOpt', which leverages query patterns and historical optimization data to predict optimal query plans. We develop a scalable framework that integrates with popular data warehousing systems, demonstrating improved query performance and reduced latency in experiments with real-world IoT datasets.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making under Uncertainty
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) require robust decision-making systems to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HierRL', which learns to prioritize tasks and adapt to uncertainty in real-time. Our approach integrates a high-level planning module with a low-level control policy, leveraging probabilistic graphical models to reason about uncertainty. We demonstrate HierRL's effectiveness in simulated and real-world AV experiments, showcasing improved safety and efficiency in diverse weather and traffic conditions.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants that cater to the unique requirements of older adults. We conducted a series of user studies and interviews to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed framework, 'ElderVoice', incorporates simplified voice commands, personalized feedback, and multimodal interaction to enhance usability and accessibility. A pilot study with 30 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning to coordinate multi-agent systems in dynamic task allocation scenarios. We propose a novel framework, 'MACTOR', which utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn effective task assignment and scheduling policies. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and incorporate domain knowledge into the learning process. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management domain demonstrate that MACTOR outperforms traditional optimization methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity in recent years, but their retrieval performance can be limited by the quality of the query representation. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach that leverages word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms. We propose a two-stage framework that first generates a set of expansion candidates using a neural language model, and then ranks these candidates based on their proximity to the query representation in the embedding space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach yields significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Efficient Incremental View Maintenance for Dynamic Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Data warehouses are increasingly used to support real-time analytics, but maintaining materialized views in the presence of frequent data updates remains a significant challenge. We propose a novel incremental view maintenance algorithm, 'DynaView', which leverages a combination of data sampling and machine learning-based change detection to minimize the overhead of view maintenance. Our approach is designed to adapt to dynamic data distributions and varying update frequencies, ensuring efficient and accurate view refreshment. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DynaView outperforms existing methods in terms of maintenance cost and view freshness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to adaptively select and weight expansion terms. Our approach uses a double-deep Q-network to learn a policy that balances the trade-off between query drift and relevance improvement. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gestural interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in various devices, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with motor impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive gestural interfaces for this population. We conducted a comprehensive study involving 30 participants with motor impairments, identifying key challenges and preferences. Our proposed interface, 'EasyGesture', incorporates adaptive gesture recognition, personalized feedback, and accessible navigation. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction compared to traditional gestural interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Real-time Traffic Flow Prediction
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic flow prediction is crucial for optimizing urban transportation systems. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promise in modeling complex traffic patterns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that integrates multi-scale graph attention mechanisms to capture both local and global traffic dependencies. We evaluate HGAT on a large-scale traffic dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in prediction accuracy and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art GNN-based methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to hierarchical task allocation for multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a two-level framework, where a high-level agent allocator assigns tasks to teams of agents, and a low-level agent controller optimizes task execution. Our method, Hierarchical Task Allocation with Deep Q-Networks (HTA-DQN), leverages the strengths of both centralized and decentralized control. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HTA-DQN outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, response time, and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Task Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has become increasingly popular in computer vision, but it often suffers from task interference and high computational costs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that efficiently addresses these challenges. Our HAN leverages task-specific attention weights to selectively focus on relevant features and adaptively adjust the shared representation across tasks. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art MTL methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the need to integrate heterogeneous data sources. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN model incorporates a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights modalities based on their emotional relevance, leading to improved performance and interpretability. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in recognizing emotions from multi-modal data.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has immense potential to enhance the lives of people with disabilities, but existing VR interfaces often neglect their needs. This paper presents an accessible VR interface framework, 'IncluVR', which integrates multimodal input mechanisms, personalized adaptive feedback, and real-time accessibility analytics. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants with disabilities, revealing significant improvements in user experience, task completion rates, and subjective satisfaction. Our approach enables VR systems to better accommodate diverse user needs, promoting inclusivity and equity in VR-based applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we present a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems. Our approach leverages reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn optimal task assignment strategies in real-time. We introduce a graph-based representation of the agent-task interaction space, which allows agents to share information and coordinate their actions. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient task allocation and improved system performance. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method, showing its convergence properties and robustness to agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., speech, text, vision) is crucial in human-computer interaction. Existing methods often suffer from scalability issues due to the complexity of fusing and processing large amounts of heterogeneous data. We propose Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. HGAT adopts a hierarchical architecture to efficiently process multi-modal data, enabling it to handle large datasets and varying input lengths. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the superior performance and efficiency of HGAT compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Incremental View Maintenance over Dynamic Graphs using Distributed Hash Tables
paper_abstract: Dynamic graphs are ubiquitous in modern applications, necessitating efficient view maintenance techniques. We propose 'DynaHash', a novel incremental view maintenance approach that leverages distributed hash tables (DHTs) to process graph updates in parallel. DynaHash ensures consistency and minimizes communication overhead by exploiting the inherent structure of the graph. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate a significant reduction in view maintenance time compared to existing solutions, while achieving high accuracy and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates audio, textual, and visual features to recognize emotions. Our HAN model uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, and a fusion layer to combine the modality-specific representations. Experiments on the IEMOCAP dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an accuracy of 84.2% and an F1-score of 83.5% for emotion recognition.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, but existing methods often rely on simplistic term weighting schemes or require extensive manual tuning. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding approach, 'CAQE', which leverages semantic relationships between query terms and their surrounding context to generate more informative expansion terms. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CAQE on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art expansion techniques. Our approach is also shown to be more efficient and scalable, making it suitable for real-world search applications.

title: Boosting Retrieval Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems via Hierarchical Query Segmentation
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face scalability challenges as the volume of indexed data grows exponentially. This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize query processing in DIR systems by segmenting queries into a hierarchical structure. Our method, called HierSeg, leverages query clustering and segment ranking to reduce the number of nodes involved in query processing, thereby improving retrieval efficiency. Experimental results on a large-scale text dataset demonstrate that HierSeg achieves significant reductions in query latency and communication overhead compared to traditional query processing techniques.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current VR interfaces often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents 'EchoVR', a novel VR interface designed specifically for users with visual impairments. EchoVR uses 3D audio cues, haptic feedback, and voice commands to enable users to navigate and interact with virtual environments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion times and user satisfaction compared to traditional screen-reader-based approaches. Our work contributes to the development of inclusive VR experiences that can benefit users with visual impairments.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a popular technique to improve retrieval performance, but it often relies on manual feature engineering and heuristics. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense embeddings of queries and documents. We develop a novel attention-based mechanism to adaptively select expansion terms based on the query context and document relevance. Experiments on several TREC datasets demonstrate that NQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Indexing for Distributed Time-Series Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and velocity of time-series data generated by IoT devices and sensors have posed significant challenges for efficient storage and querying in distributed databases. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, called TS-Tree, which leverages a combination of hierarchical clustering and compact bitmap representations to reduce storage overhead and improve query performance. Our experiments on a large-scale sensor dataset demonstrate that TS-Tree outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval rely on handcrafted features and shallow neural networks, limiting their ability to capture complex document structures and relationships. We propose a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture, which models documents as hierarchical graphs of entities, concepts, and keywords. Our approach learns to rank documents by aggregating node and edge features, enabling the capture of semantic relationships and contextual information. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art models, making HGNN a promising solution for large-scale information retrieval applications.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have become increasingly popular, but query optimization remains a significant challenge, particularly in multi-tenant environments. This paper presents 'OptiMT', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution plans and adapts to workload changes. OptiMT incorporates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group tenants with similar query patterns, reducing the optimization search space. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that OptiMT achieves up to 35% improvement in query response times and 25% reduction in resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art results in node classification tasks, but their scalability remains a major challenge. This paper presents H-GCN, a hierarchical graph neural network architecture that leverages a novel graph coarsening technique to reduce the computational complexity of GNNs. We demonstrate that H-GCN can efficiently process large-scale graphs with millions of nodes, while maintaining competitive performance with existing methods. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that H-GCN outperforms existing GNN architectures in terms of both accuracy and scalability.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information. However, the lack of personalized avatars in VR environments can lead to a sense of disconnection and affect the overall user experience. This paper investigates the impact of personalized avatars on user experience in VR. We designed and implemented a VR system that generates personalized avatars based on user preferences and demographic data. Our user study involving 30 participants shows that personalized avatars significantly improve user engagement, presence, and overall satisfaction in VR environments. We also discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems.

title: Designing Emotion-Aware Virtual Assistants for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have become ubiquitous, but their lack of emotional intelligence can lead to frustration and abandonment, particularly among people with disabilities. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'EmpaCare', a novel virtual assistant that incorporates emotional awareness and empathetic responses. We conducted a user study with 30 participants with disabilities, demonstrating that EmpaCare significantly improved user satisfaction and engagement compared to traditional virtual assistants. Our findings highlight the importance of emotional intelligence in human-computer interaction and pave the way for more inclusive and supportive virtual assistants.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Input Preprocessing
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. This paper proposes a novel input preprocessing technique, dubbed 'AdverGuard', to robustify DNNs against such attacks. AdverGuard applies a series of transformations to the input data, including pixel-wise masking and feature-space whitening, to suppress the effects of adversarial perturbations. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdverGuard can improve the robustness of DNNs against various types of attacks, including FGSM and PGD, while maintaining their accuracy on clean data.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, aiming to minimize query execution time. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics and exhaustive search, which can be suboptimal and time-consuming. We propose a novel framework, 'DeepQOpt', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans. By modeling the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process, we train a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for selecting the best query plan. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Deep learning-based recommenders have achieved remarkable success, but their opacity hinders user trust and limits their applicability. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) that incorporates both item and user graph structures to generate personalized recommendations. HiGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant items and users, enabling interpretable recommendations. Our experiments on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that HiGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing transparent and explainable results.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have varying capabilities and tasks have diverse requirements. We design an auction-based mechanism that enables agents to bid on tasks based on their self-assessed capabilities and preferences. Our approach incorporates a novel bid validation scheme to prevent strategic manipulation and ensure truthfulness. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents while minimizing communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to allocate tasks efficiently by modeling agent interactions and task dependencies. Our HAN model consists of two levels of attention: intra-agent attention for task feature extraction and inter-agent attention for task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated robotics environment demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing task allocation methods in terms of allocation quality, communication cost, and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: EyeTracker: A Gaze-Based Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual input methods, which can be cumbersome and detract from the immersive experience. This paper presents EyeTracker, a novel gaze-based interface that leverages eye movement data to infer user intent and facilitate seamless interaction with virtual objects. Our approach employs a machine learning model to classify gaze patterns and detect fixation points, enabling users to select and manipulate objects with their eyes. We evaluate EyeTracker through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have varying capabilities and tasks require diverse skills. We propose a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a task allocation policy that optimizes system-wide performance. Our method, called GNN-TA, represents the agent-task graph as a heterogeneous graph and utilizes GNNs to learn complex relationships between agents and tasks. Experimental results on a realistic simulation platform demonstrate that GNN-TA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) are crucial for building trust with users. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention (HGA) framework that captures complex relationships between users, items, and attributes. HGA learns to selectively focus on relevant graph neighborhoods and attributes, generating interpretable explanations for recommended items. Our experiments on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HGA outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complex nature of graph queries and the need to minimize communication costs in distributed systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages graph structural properties and statistical models to predict query execution costs. We introduce a distributed query planning algorithm that adaptively adjusts to changing data distributions and system workloads. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning to decentralized multi-agent task allocation in dynamic environments. We propose a novel framework, 'MALTA', which enables agents to learn task allocation strategies through interactions with their peers and the environment. MALTA utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to predict the task allocation outcomes and adjusts its strategy accordingly. Experimental results on a simulated search and rescue scenario demonstrate that MALTA achieves improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional, centralized approaches.

title: Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, as it directly affects the relevance of retrieved documents. Traditional methods rely on heuristics or manual tuning, which can be suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QL-Expander', that leverages reinforcement learning to learn optimal query expansion policies. We model query expansion as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select expansion terms that maximize the expected retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QL-Expander outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalized Pronunciation Adaptation for Users with Speech Disorders
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but users with speech disorders often face difficulties communicating with these systems. This paper presents a novel approach to personalized pronunciation adaptation, enabling voice assistants to better understand and respond to users with speech impairments. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and developed a machine learning-based model that adapts to individual pronunciation patterns. Results show significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more inclusive and accessible voice assistants.

title: EyeGazePath: A Gaze-Driven Navigation Model for Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces often rely on manual navigation methods, which can be slow and fatiguing. This paper introduces EyeGazePath, a novel navigation model that leverages users' gaze patterns to infer their navigational intent. Our approach combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a Markov chain model to predict the user's desired navigation path. We evaluate EyeGazePath in a VR environment and demonstrate significant reductions in navigation time and effort compared to traditional methods. Our findings suggest that gaze-driven navigation can enhance the overall VR user experience.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Individuals with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have revolutionized human-computer interaction, but individuals with disabilities often face barriers in using these systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that accommodate diverse abilities and needs. We conduct a mixed-methods study, involving surveys, interviews, and usability testing with 50 participants with disabilities. Our findings inform the development of a set of design guidelines and a proof-of-concept voice assistant, 'AccessibleVoice', which incorporates features such as personalized speech recognition, multimodal input, and real-time transcription. Our evaluation shows that AccessibleVoice significantly improves the user experience and satisfaction of individuals with disabilities.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Dialogue Response Generation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for generating contextually relevant and interpretable responses in multi-modal dialogue systems. Our approach leverages both textual and visual features to model user intent and sentiment. We propose a dual-attention mechanism that captures both intra-modal and inter-modal relationships between input modalities. Experimental results on a large-scale dialogue dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in generating coherent and diverse responses, while providing insights into the reasoning process through attention visualization.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gestural Feedback in Virtual Reality for People with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to provide immersive experiences for people with visual impairments, but the lack of visual feedback can hinder their ability to interact with virtual objects. This paper investigates the effectiveness of gestural feedback in VR for individuals with visual impairments. We designed a VR system that uses haptic, auditory, and vibrotactile feedback to convey spatial information and conducted a user study with 20 participants. Our results show that the gestural feedback significantly improves the participants' ability to navigate and interact with virtual objects, and that the combination of haptic and auditory feedback is more effective than vibrotactile feedback alone.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Network-based Keyword Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval to improve the retrieval performance of ad-hoc search systems. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion by leveraging deep neural network-based keyword embeddings. Our method, dubbed 'QE-Embed', represents keywords as dense vectors in a high-dimensional space, capturing semantic relationships between terms. We demonstrate that QE-Embed outperforms traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain. Furthermore, we show that QE-Embed is efficient and scalable, making it suitable for large-scale search applications.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it bridges the gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for query expansion, which learns to select optimal expansion terms by interacting with a simulated retrieval environment. Our approach, 'RL-Expander', employs a hierarchical policy network to balance exploration and exploitation, and demonstrates significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned expansion strategies and their correlation with retrieval performance.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize many aspects of our lives, but existing gesture recognition systems often fail to accommodate users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel approach to personalized gesture recognition, leveraging a combination of machine learning and computer vision techniques. Our system, ' GestureFit', uses a wearable sensor array to capture user gestures and adapts to individual movement patterns, enabling more accurate and inclusive VR experiences. We evaluate GestureFit on a dataset of users with varying abilities, demonstrating significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Networks with Attention-based Query Encoding
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, Attentive Query Encoder (AQE), for efficient document retrieval. AQE employs a attention-based query encoding mechanism to selectively focus on relevant query terms and incorporate contextualized term embeddings. We demonstrate that AQE outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models on several benchmark datasets, including TREC-CAR and Robust04, while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%. Experimental results show that AQE achieves significant improvements in ranking effectiveness, particularly for queries with ambiguous or Bursty terms.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Coordination using Graph Attention Networks for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems, such as robot swarms and smart grids, rely on efficient multi-agent coordination to achieve complex tasks. Graph attention networks (GATs) have shown promise in modeling agent interactions, but their computational complexity hinders real-time applications. This paper proposes a novel, hierarchical GAT architecture that leverages agent clustering and sparse attention mechanisms to reduce computational overhead while preserving coordination performance. Experimental results on a simulated drone swarm demonstrate that our approach achieves a 3x speedup over existing GAT-based methods while maintaining comparable coordination quality.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Explainable Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial for real-world deployment of autonomous systems. This paper presents Hierarchical Explainable Reinforcement Learning (HERL), a novel framework that integrates hierarchical reinforcement learning with model-based explanations. HERL utilizes a hierarchical policy to decompose complex tasks into simpler sub-tasks, while an explainable model is learned to provide insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving environment demonstrate that HERL achieves improved task performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach for ad-hoc retrieval, leveraging deep learning-based document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'EmbEx', represents documents as dense vectors in a high-dimensional space, enabling the identification of relevant expansion terms through vector similarity calculations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, when compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph Attention Networks for Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI systems in safety-critical domains has raised concerns about their vulnerability to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel approach for detecting adversarial attacks in time-series data using graph attention networks (GATs).
