We demonstrate that GATs can learn to identify subtle patterns in the graph-structured representation of time-series data, enabling the detection of sophisticated attacks. Our experiments on a real-world power grid dataset show that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detecting adversarial attacks, with an F1-score of 0.95. The proposed method has significant implications for the development of robust AI systems in domains such as smart grids and industrial control systems.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Healthcare Interfaces
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to revolutionize healthcare interfaces, but their design often neglects the needs of diverse user populations. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive ECAs that can effectively communicate with patients from varying cultural, linguistic, and ability backgrounds. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, which informed the development of a set of design guidelines for ECAs that promote empathy, trust, and understanding in healthcare interactions. Our evaluation shows that ECAs designed using our framework can significantly improve patient engagement and satisfaction, particularly for underserved populations.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous networks is a challenging task due to the varying node types and relationships. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages the hierarchical structure of networks to capture local and global dependencies. HGAT employs a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges, enhancing the representation learning of nodes. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art graph neural network models in node classification tasks, especially in networks with diverse node types and sparse connections.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) is a popular technique for ensuring transactional consistency in distributed databases. However, query optimization in MVCC systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCOpt', which leverages a combination of static and dynamic analysis to identify optimal query execution plans. MVCOpt incorporates a probabilistic model of transaction conflicts and adapts to changing workload patterns to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Experimental evaluation on a distributed database prototype demonstrates that MVCOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of average query response time.

title: Deep Query Expansion using Meta-Learning for Ad-Hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using meta-learning, which enables the IR system to adapt to new queries and domains with limited training data. Our method, 'MetaQE', learns to generate query expansions by training a meta-model on a diverse set of IR tasks. We evaluate MetaQE on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems have become increasingly prevalent in AI applications, but understanding the decision-making processes of these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable multi-agent cooperation. Our approach leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to identify relevant interactions between agents and their environment, providing insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a series of complex multi-agent tasks demonstrate the efficacy of HAN in improving cooperation and interpretability. We further provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed architecture, establishing connections to game theory and social network analysis.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become a promising platform for various applications, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR interfaces. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, utilizing a novel avatar personalization framework that incorporates machine learning-based facial feature analysis. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, with participants exhibiting higher levels of presence, enjoyment, and self-reported motivation. We also discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR interfaces.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but current VR systems often pose significant accessibility barriers. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key design principles, including simplified navigation, intuitive interface design, and personalized cognitive support. Our evaluation shows that our framework improves user engagement, reduces frustration, and enhances overall VR experience quality for older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must coordinate to allocate tasks efficiently. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to learn coordination strategies for task allocation. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MARL-TA', which enables agents to learn from their interactions and adapt to changing environment conditions. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional optimization-based approaches in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodied Cognition in Gesture-based Interfaces for Older Adults
paper_abstract: This study explores the application of embodied cognition principles to the design of gesture-based interfaces for older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65-75, examining how gestures that mimic real-world actions can improve cognitive load and user experience in a smart home control system. Our results show that embodied cognition-based gestures reduce error rates by 35% and increase user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture sets. We discuss implications for designing inclusive and accessible interfaces that leverage the cognitive benefits of embodied cognition.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Semantic Embeddings for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval systems rely on bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Semantic Embeddings for Retrieval (HSE-R), which leverages hierarchical semantic graphs to learn dense vector representations of documents and queries. HSE-R outperforms state-of-the-art methods on multiple benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and efficiency. We also propose a novel query expansion technique that adaptively incorporates semantic context from the hierarchical graph, further enhancing performance.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface framework, 'AccessibleMotion', designed to improve the usability and accessibility of touchscreen devices for visually impaired users. We introduce a machine learning-driven gesture recognition engine that adapts to individual users' motor abilities and preferences, enabling more accurate and efficient interaction. Our user study with 20 visually impaired participants demonstrates significant improvements in navigation speed and accuracy compared to existing assistive technologies.

title: Scalable Graph Database Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between data entities. However, optimizing query execution plans for graph databases remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize graph database query execution. Our method, 'GraphRL', learns to select the most efficient query plan by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query performance. We evaluate GraphRL on several real-world graph datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Reasoning
paper_abstract: Multimodal reasoning tasks, such as visual question answering, require models to integrate and reason about information from different modalities. While deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack transparency and interpretability. This paper presents a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and regions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on several benchmark datasets, achieving improved performance and providing insights into the decision-making process through visualized attention maps.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Gradient-based Methods
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have shown remarkable success in various machine learning tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about their reliability. This paper investigates the robustness of DNNs against gradient-based attacks, including Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) and Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM). We propose a novel framework for evaluating the robustness of DNNs by analyzing the gradient distribution of the input data. Our experiments on the CIFAR-10 dataset demonstrate that our method can effectively identify the most vulnerable DNN architectures and provide insights into the design of more robust models.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Efficient Retrieval in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from multiple sources. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query reformulation, dubbed 'DeepQR', which learns to rewrite queries to better match the indexed representations of documents in each source. We leverage a hierarchical neural network architecture to model the semantic relationships between query terms and document representations, and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to traditional query expansion techniques. Experimental results on a large-scale DIR dataset show that DeepQR reduces the average retrieval time by 35% while improving the mean average precision by 12%.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Explainable AI
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and reliability. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks using explainable AI techniques. We develop a method to generate interpretable heatmaps that highlight the regions of the input data most influential in the model's predictions. By analyzing these heatmaps, we can identify anomalous patterns indicative of adversarial attacks. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting attacks with high accuracy and robustness.

title: Transforming Multimodal Interaction with Embodied Conversational Agents in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have revolutionized human-computer interaction in virtual reality (VR). This paper presents a novel framework for multimodal interaction with ECAs in VR, enabling users to engage in more natural and intuitive conversations. We introduce a machine learning-based approach to recognize and respond to users' gestures, facial expressions, and speech, creating a more immersive and interactive experience. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in user engagement, task completion rates, and overall satisfaction compared to traditional text-based interfaces.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Context-Aware Dialogue Management for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their dialogue management systems often fail to accommodate users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel context-aware dialogue management approach that adapts to the needs of users with disabilities. Our system incorporates a probabilistic user model that infers user preferences and abilities from conversation history and sensor data. We evaluate our approach using a Wizard-of-Oz study with 30 participants, including users with visual, hearing, and motor impairments, and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. Our findings inform the design of more inclusive voice assistants that can better support users with diverse abilities.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc information retrieval, as it significantly impacts the retrieval performance. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and statistical models, which often fall short in capturing complex semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'DeepQE', which learns to expand queries by modeling the semantic interactions between words in the query and the document collection. Our experiments on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) is crucial for developing empathetic AI systems. Existing approaches often rely on single-modal inputs, neglecting the rich emotional cues present in multi-modal data. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in HCI. Our HAN model employs a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights modalities based on their emotional relevance. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art single-modal and early-fusion methods, achieving a 12.5% improvement in emotion recognition accuracy.

title: Adversarial Attack-Resistant Neural Networks through Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can lead to catastrophic consequences in safety-critical applications. This paper presents a novel defense mechanism, 'HRL-Defend', which leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning to train attack-resistant neural networks. Our approach involves training a hierarchical policy that learns to detect and respond to adversarial attacks in a game-theoretic framework. Experimental results on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that HRL-Defend outperforms state-of-the-art defense methods in terms of robustness and accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in dynamic networks is a challenging task due to the constantly changing graph structure and lack of labeled data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global graph features to improve node classification performance. HGAT consists of a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant nodes and their features at each layer, and a novel graph-based regularization term that encourages the model to learn consistent representations across different graph snapshots. Experimental results on several real-world dynamic networks demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in node classification, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Incentivized Information Sharing
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent planning, individual agents often possess unique information that can significantly impact collective decision-making. However, agents may be reluctant to share their knowledge due to concerns about information leakage or exploitation. This paper introduces a novel framework, 'InfoShare', which incentivizes agents to share their information by deploying a reputation-based mechanism that rewards trustworthy behavior. We demonstrate that InfoShare leads to improved collective performance and enhances the overall robustness of the multi-agent system. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario showcase the effectiveness of our approach in promoting cooperative information exchange.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of planning for multi-agent systems in environments with incomplete information. We propose a hierarchical task network (HTN) planning framework that integrates probabilistic reasoning and decision-theoretic planning to handle uncertainty. Our approach leverages a novel representation of incomplete information as probabilistic constraints, enabling agents to reason about the likelihood of task success. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, showcasing improved plan quality and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Hierarchical Graph Indexing for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: As the volume of data grows, efficient information retrieval (IR) systems are crucial for various applications. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph indexing technique, 'HierG', designed to accelerate query processing in large-scale IR systems. HierG leverages graph-based indexing to prune the search space, reducing the number of candidate documents and improving query response times. We evaluate HierG on the TREC Web Track dataset and demonstrate significant performance gains compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving an average query speedup of 3.2x.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph-based Attention Mechanisms for Explainable AI
paper_abstract: As AI models become increasingly ubiquitous, it is essential to develop robust defenses against adversarial attacks. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks using graph-based attention mechanisms. Our method, dubbed 'GraphGuard', leverages the structural relationships between input features to identify suspicious patterns indicative of adversarial tampering. We demonstrate the efficacy of GraphGuard on a range of benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art detection performance with improved explainability. Furthermore, we provide theoretical insights into the robustness of GraphGuard against adaptive attacks, laying the foundation for_future research in this area.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component in task-oriented dialogue systems. While neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance, their lack of interpretability hinders trust and reliability. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) for DST, which incorporates both utterance-level and turn-level attention mechanisms. We introduce a novel hierarchical encoding scheme that captures the compositional structure of dialogue utterances, enabling the model to focus on relevant context when updating the dialogue state. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms existing DST systems while providing transparent and explainable state tracking.

title: Robustness Enhancement of Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning using Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has shown remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. This paper proposes a novel transfer learning-based approach to enhance the robustness of DRL against adversarial attacks. We demonstrate that by transferring knowledge from a pre-trained policy to a target policy, we can significantly improve the robustness of the target policy against a range of attacks. Our experiments on popular DRL benchmarks show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of robustness and convergence rate.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the underlying semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. To address this, we propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to incorporate semantic knowledge into the retrieval process. Our method, dubbed 'KG-Exp', represents queries and documents as dense vectors in a shared knowledge graph space, enabling the capture of nuanced relationships between entities and concepts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that KG-Exp significantly improves retrieval performance, particularly for queries with ambiguous or rare terms.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in modern data-intensive applications. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HiIDX', which leverages the hierarchical structure of the data distribution to minimize query latency. We demonstrate that HiIDX outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time, while maintaining similar storage overhead. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that HiIDX is particularly effective for range queries and aggregation operations.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various applications, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for anomaly detection in time-series data. HGAT leverages the graph structure of time-series data to capture complex dependencies and relationships between different variables. The proposed model consists of two components: a graph attention module that learns to focus on relevant nodes and a hierarchical clustering module that identifies anomalies at multiple scales. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to noise.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-robot interaction, but existing approaches often rely on a single modality (e.g., facial expressions or speech). This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal inputs (vision, audio, and physiological signals) to recognize emotions in real-time. Our HAN architecture consists of modality-specific attention modules and a hierarchical fusion layer, enabling the model to selectively focus on relevant modalities and capture complex emotional patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale human-robot interaction dataset demonstrate improved emotion recognition accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art uni-modal and early-fusion approaches.

title: Graph-Based Indexing for Efficient Query Optimization in Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are widely used in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query execution remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GRIX', which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to efficiently prune the search space. By exploiting the correlations between query predicates and join orders, GRIX reduces the number of possible execution plans, leading to improved query performance and reduced latency. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that GRIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query throughput and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn agent-agent and agent-task relationships. Our approach, called GNN-TA, uses a distributed GNN architecture to enable agents to communicate and negotiate task assignments in a decentralized manner. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that GNN-TA outperforms traditional centralized and auction-based approaches in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for High-Dimensional Text Data using Adaptive Density-Based Methods
paper_abstract: High-dimensional text data poses significant challenges to traditional clustering algorithms. This paper presents a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'ADWISE', which adapts density-based methods to the inherent structure of text data. ADWISE employs an efficient node-splitting strategy that leverages local density estimates to identify clusters at varying scales. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ADWISE outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods in terms of clustering quality, robustness to noise, and computational efficiency.

title: Real-time Document Re-ranking using Hierarchical Query Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Conventional retrieval models often rely on static document representations, which fail to capture nuanced query semantics and contextual relationships. This paper presents a novel real-time document re-ranking framework, HQE-Rerank, which leverages hierarchical query embeddings to capture multi-level query intent. Our approach combines a coarse-grained query encoder with a fine-grained document encoder, enabling efficient and effective re-ranking of top-k retrieved documents. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that HQE-Rerank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of precision and recall, while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Graph-Based Hierarchical Clustering for Multi-Modal Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Contrastive learning has emerged as a powerful paradigm for self-supervised learning, but its application to multi-modal data remains challenging. This paper proposes a novel graph-based hierarchical clustering approach, 'GraphCon', which integrates graph neural networks with contrastive learning to learn robust representations from multi-modal data. We demonstrate that GraphCon can effectively capture complex relationships between modalities, leading to improved performance on downstream tasks such as image-text retrieval and zero-shot classification. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that GraphCon outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in multi-modal contrastive learning.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Multi-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Query optimization remains a crucial challenge in modern database systems, particularly for high-dimensional data. This paper presents a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HIDX', which leverages a combination of clustering and space-filling curves to efficiently prune the search space. We demonstrate that HIDX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques, such as R-trees and quad trees, on a range of real-world datasets, achieving up to 3x speedup in query response times. Additionally, our approach is shown to be robust against data skew and variability, making it suitable for large-scale database applications.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Customizable Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has seen significant growth in recent years, but user experience remains a major challenge. This paper investigates the role of customizable avatars in enhancing user engagement and immersion in VR environments. We designed a user study with 120 participants, who interacted with a VR platform using either a default or customized avatar. Our results show that customized avatars lead to increased user satisfaction, reduced cybersickness, and improved task performance. We also identify key design factors influencing avatar customization, including facial resemblance, body shape, and attire. Our findings have implications for the development of more inclusive and effective VR systems.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management systems require efficient coordination among multiple agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'DMARL-ATM', which enables autonomous vehicles to learn cooperative policies for traffic signal control and lane changing. We introduce a novel Graph Attention Network (GAT) architecture to model agent interactions and a decentralized Q-learning algorithm to update policies based on local observations. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that DMARL-ATM outperforms traditional rule-based systems and centralized reinforcement learning approaches in terms of reduced travel time and increased network throughput.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Modeling
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are becoming increasingly popular for handling large-scale data-driven applications. However, optimizing queries in DDS remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel graph-based modeling approach for efficient query optimization in DDS. We model the distributed database as a graph, where nodes represent data fragments and edges represent communication costs. Our approach utilizes graph algorithms to identify optimal query execution plans that minimize communication overhead and improve query response time. Experimental results on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing query optimization techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Cultural Bias in Speech Recognition Systems
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their speech recognition systems often perpetuate cultural biases, leading to inaccurate or unfair interactions with users from diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds. This paper presents an empirical study investigating the cultural bias in three popular voice assistants, identifying significant disparities in recognition rates for accents and dialects from underrepresented groups. We propose a framework for designing inclusive voice assistants, incorporating culturally sensitive training data and adaptive language models that can better serve diverse user populations.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational agents is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for multi-modal emotion recognition, which integrates linguistic, acoustic, and visual features from user interactions. Our HAN model consists of a feature-level attention mechanism to selectively weight modality-specific features and a conversation-level attention mechanism to capture contextual dependencies. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal emotion dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from conversations, achieving a 12.5% improvement in F1-score compared to the best baseline model.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Word Embeddings for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task due to the limited context and semantic information. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, NeuralQE, which leverages neural word embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. Our method adapts the Word2Vec model to learn dense vector representations of words in the query and document collections. We then use a sparse matrix factorization technique to efficiently compute the similarity between the expanded query and documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuralQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, especially for short queries.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Cooperation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve a common goal in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in AI research. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables efficient cooperation among agents. HAN uses a bottom-up attention mechanism to aggregate local observations, and a top-down attention mechanism to guide global decision-making. We evaluate our approach on a simulated search-and-rescue task and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and success rate compared to existing methods. Our results show that HAN is robust to varying environmental conditions and agent failure rates.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Older Adults: A Study on Social Presence and Trust
paper_abstract: This paper explores the role of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in enhancing social presence and trust among older adults. We designed and evaluated an ECA system, 'ElderCare', which incorporates multimodal cues, such as gaze, gesture, and prosody, to simulate human-like interactions. Our user study with 30 older adults revealed that ElderCare increased feelings of social presence and trust compared to a text-based interface. We also identified design implications for ECAs to effectively support older adults, including the need for clear and concise communication, personalized engagement, and adaptability to individual cognitive and physical abilities.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality for Enhancing User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in Virtual Reality (VR) environments, focusing on its impact on user experience. We designed a VR-based experiment to examine how users' bodily movements and gestures influence their interaction with virtual objects. Our results show that incorporating embodied cognition principles into VR design can lead to improved spatial awareness, reduced cognitive load, and enhanced user engagement. We propose a novel framework for embodied cognition-driven VR interface design, which can be applied to various domains such as education, entertainment, and healthcare.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification remains a challenging problem in graph-based machine learning, where only a limited number of labeled nodes are available for training. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global graph structures to improve few-shot learning. HGAT uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and nodes, enabling the model to generalize better to unseen classes. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 12.5% on 5-shot node classification tasks.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval that aims to refine the original query to better capture the user's intent. Traditional methods rely on term co-occurrence and frequency-based approaches, which often fail to capture semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based query expansion method, dubbed 'QNLP', which leverages the semantic capabilities of pre-trained language models to generate expanded queries. We evaluate QNLP on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach also shows robustness to query ambiguity and ambiguity, making it a promising solution for real-world IR applications.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Contextualized Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, aims to improve retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, leveraging deep learning-based contextualized embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. Our method, dubbed QE-DEEP, integrates BERT-based embeddings with a graph-based ranking model to select the most informative expansion terms. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QE-DEEP outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Document Indexing for Real-time Query Expansion in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face significant challenges in efficiently indexing large document collections and expanding user queries in real-time. This paper presents a novel document indexing approach, called 'Dexi', which leverages a hierarchical graph-based data structure to facilitate fast and accurate query expansion. Dexi utilizes a distributed clustering algorithm to group semantically similar documents, enabling efficient query routing and reduction of network latency. Our experiments on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that Dexi outperforms existing indexing techniques in terms of query response time and relevance, while maintaining a comparable storage overhead.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering for High-Dimensional Data using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but its application to high-dimensional data is often limited by the curse of dimensionality. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn a hierarchical representation of the data, enabling efficient clustering of high-dimensional datasets. Our method, DeepHier, uses a stacked autoencoder to learn a compact and hierarchical embedding of the data, which is then used for clustering. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepHier outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and scalability, while providing interpretable clustering results.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Explainability in natural language processing (NLP) remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that provides interpretable explanations for NLP tasks. Our architecture combines local and global attention mechanisms to identify relevant input features and context-dependent relationships. We evaluate HAN on sentiment analysis and question-answering tasks, demonstrating improved performance and transparency compared to existing state-of-the-art models. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as customer service chatbots and language translation systems.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hyperbolic Attention for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering over knowledge graphs (KGs) has seen significant progress with the advent of graph neural networks. However, existing methods often struggle to model complex relationships and scale to large KGs. This paper introduces HyperQA, a novel framework that leverages hyperbolic attention mechanisms to efficiently embed KGs in a learnable, hierarchical space. We demonstrate that HyperQA outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving improved answer accuracy and reduced computational overhead. Furthermore, we provide theoretical analyses and ablation studies to justify the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coordinating agents to allocate resources efficiently is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that enables agents to learn cooperative policies for real-time resource allocation. Our approach consists of two layers: a high-level layer that uses a decentralized actor-critic method to learn resource allocation policies, and a low-level layer that employs a model-free deep Q-network to adapt to changing environmental conditions. We evaluate our approach on a realistic grid management scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization and allocation efficiency compared to traditional decentralized approaches.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) systems require efficient query optimization to ensure low latency and high throughput. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We propose a DRL framework that learns to optimize queries by interacting with the RTDW system and receiving rewards based on query performance. Our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by adapting to changing workload patterns and exploiting opportunities for parallelism. Experimental results on a realistic RTDW benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in query response time and system throughput.

title: Efficient Incremental View Maintenance for Real-time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing requires efficient view maintenance to support timely decision-making. Existing incremental view maintenance techniques suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper presents a novel approach, 'IVM-Forest', which leverages a hierarchical forest of indices to expedite view maintenance. IVM-Forest adaptively reorganizes the index forest in response to data updates, ensuring that view maintenance queries are executed efficiently. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that IVM-Forest outperforms state-of-the-art techniques by up to 50% in terms of maintenance time while providing accurate query results.

title: Designing Emotionally Intelligent Virtual Assistants for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have transformed human-computer interaction, but their lack of emotional intelligence hinders their effectiveness for people with disabilities. This paper presents an emotionally intelligent VA framework, 'EmpaVA', which incorporates affective computing, natural language processing, and machine learning to recognize and respond to users' emotional states. We conducted a user study with 30 participants with disabilities, demonstrating that EmpaVA significantly improves user satisfaction, trust, and task completion rates compared to traditional VAs. Our findings inform the design of more empathetic and inclusive VAs.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Microblog Retrieval with Limited Supervision
paper_abstract: Microblog retrieval poses unique challenges due to the brevity and noisy nature of tweets. This paper introduces 'DQE-Lite', a deep query expansion framework that leverages limited supervision to improve retrieval effectiveness. Our approach combines a neural query expansion module with a novel attention-based tweet representation model, enabling the capture of subtle semantic relationships between query terms and tweet contents. Experimental results on the TREC Microblog 2011-2014 datasets demonstrate that DQE-Lite outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% relative improvement in mean average precision.

title: EmoGlass: Affective State Recognition using Computer Vision and Deep Learning on Wearable Devices
paper_abstract: Wearable devices have become ubiquitous, but their potential for affective state recognition remains underexplored. This paper presents EmoGlass, a novel system that leverages computer vision and deep learning to recognize emotional states from facial expressions, head movements, and physiological signals captured by a smart glasses prototype. Our approach integrates a convolutional neural network (CNN) for facial feature extraction, a recurrent neural network (RNN) for temporal modeling, and a multimodal fusion strategy to combine heterogeneous sensor data. Evaluations on a dataset of 100 participants demonstrate EmoGlass's ability to accurately recognize five emotional states (happiness, sadness, anger, fear, and surprise) with a mean F1-score of 0.83.

title: Real-time Human-Robot Collaboration using Reinforcement Learning and Vision-based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Human-robot collaboration (HRC) has the potential to revolutionize industrial manufacturing and healthcare. However, existing HRC systems rely on pre-programmed instructions or explicit communication, limiting their flexibility and adaptability. This paper presents a novel HRC framework that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) and vision-based gesture recognition to enable real-time collaboration. Our approach uses a deep RL algorithm to learn a shared policy between a human and a robot, allowing them to adapt to changing tasks and environments. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework in a series of experiments involving assembly tasks and show significant improvements in task completion time and accuracy compared to traditional HRC methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology continues to advance, understanding the role of embodiment in shaping user experiences is crucial. This study investigates how embodiment affects social presence in VR, a critical factor in social interactions and collaboration. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with either an embodied or non-embodied virtual agent, and measured social presence using a mixed-methods approach. Our results show that embodiment significantly enhances social presence, and that this effect is moderated by individual differences in anthropomorphism and spatial awareness. The findings have implications for the design of VR-based social interfaces and future research on human-computer interaction.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: As real-time analytics becomes increasingly important in modern data-driven applications, distributed column-store databases must optimize query performance to keep up with the growing volume and velocity of data. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to predict query execution times and optimize query plans in real-time. We propose a cost-based optimization approach that incorporates data distribution, query patterns, and system resource utilization to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a large-scale benchmark dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query throughput and latency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Relational Databases using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, distributed relational databases face significant query performance challenges. This paper presents an adaptive indexing framework for optimizing query execution in distributed relational databases. Our approach dynamically monitors query workloads and adjusts indexing strategies to minimize query latency and maximize resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our adaptive indexing technique achieves up to 30% improvement in query performance compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media has severe consequences on public opinion and democracy. Existing fake news detection methods often rely on handcrafted features or shallow neural networks, which are limited in capturing complex graph structures and relationships between news articles. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) that leverages the graph structure of news articles and their propagation patterns on social networks. HAGNN learns to identify fake news by hierarchically aggregating attentive features from both local and global graph structures. Our experiments on a large-scale fake news dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin, achieving an F1-score of 92.1%.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Cooperative Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized cooperative learning framework, 'CoopLearn', that enables agents to learn from each other and allocate tasks dynamically. We introduce a novel graph neural network-based approach that captures agent relationships and task dependencies, allowing agents to make informed decisions without a centralized controller. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate that CoopLearn outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system adaptability.

title: Augmenting Gesture-Based Interfaces with Deep Learning for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular in various applications, including gaming, virtual reality, and smart home devices. However, existing systems often struggle to accurately recognize and interpret complex gestures. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep learning techniques to augment traditional gesture recognition systems. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract spatial and temporal features from gesture data, followed by a recurrent neural network (RNN) to model the dynamics of user gestures. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale gesture dataset and demonstrate significant improvement in recognition accuracy and user experience compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents possess diverse capabilities and resources. We propose a decentralized approach based on distributed constraint optimization, which enables agents to negotiate and allocate tasks while respecting their individual constraints. Our method leverages a novel constraint propagation mechanism to reduce the search space and improve solution quality. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient task allocation while minimizing communication overhead.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, NSE-QE, which leverages neural semantic embeddings to enrich query representations. By learning dense vector representations of words and entities, NSE-QE can effectively capture contextual dependencies and semantic relationships between query terms. Experimental results on several standard benchmark datasets demonstrate that NSE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in terms of precision, recall, and MAP.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Platooning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for autonomous vehicle platooning. We propose a novel coordination mechanism that enables vehicles to learn cooperative strategies for improving fuel efficiency, reducing traffic congestion, and enhancing safety. Our method, called MARPLE, incorporates a graph neural network to model interactions between vehicles and a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework to optimize platooning decisions. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that MARPLE outperforms traditional rule-based platooning methods and achieves significant improvements in fuel efficiency and travel time.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are critical for modern data-intensive applications, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper explores the use of learned index structures to optimize query execution in distributed environments. We propose a novel approach, 'DistributedLearnedIndex', which leverages machine learning models to predict query access patterns and adaptively reorganize data storage. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DistributedLearnedIndex achieves up to 3x query performance improvement compared to traditional indexing techniques, while minimizing storage overhead.

title: Efficient Online Index Maintenance for High-Performance Transactional Databases
paper_abstract: Online index maintenance is crucial for high-performance transactional databases, as it directly impacts query latency and system throughput. This paper presents 'OIMax', a novel online index maintenance algorithm that leverages statistical models to predict update patterns and adaptively reorganize index structures. OIMax incorporates a novel cost model that accounts for the trade-off between index maintenance overhead and query performance. Experimental results on a real-world transactional workload show that OIMax outperforms state-of-the-art online indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query throughput and 25% in terms of index maintenance overhead.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Social Interactions
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to facilitate social interactions for people with disabilities. However, existing ECAs often fail to account for diverse communication styles and abilities. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'IncluBot', an ECA that leverages multimodal input (speech, gaze, and gesture) to engage users in inclusive conversations. We conducted a user study with 30 participants with varying abilities, demonstrating that IncluBot increased user engagement and perceived social presence compared to traditional text-based interfaces. Our findings inform the development of more inclusive and accessible ECAs that can benefit individuals with disabilities.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Temporal Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in DRL using Temporal Graph Convolutional Networks (TGCTs). Our method leverages the graph structure of the environment to capture temporal dependencies and identify anomalous patterns indicative of attacks. We evaluate our approach on a suite of Atari games and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting various types of attacks, including ones with high semantic similarity to legitimate inputs.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model complex agent-interaction dynamics. Our approach, dubbed 'Agent-GCN', learns a distributed representation of agent capabilities and task requirements, enabling agents to make informed decisions about task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that Agent-GCN outperforms traditional decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition in conversational agents is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of input modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, acoustic, and linguistic features to recognize emotions in human-agent interactions. Our HAN model employs a bottom-up attention mechanism to selectively focus on salient features at each modality, and a top-down attention mechanism to weigh the importance of each modality. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset show that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion approaches, achieving a 12.5% improvement in emotion recognition accuracy.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for adaptive traffic signal control. We model each traffic signal as an autonomous agent that learns to optimize traffic flow through real-time communication with neighboring agents. Our approach, dubbed 'Traffic Harmony', leverages graph neural networks to capture complex traffic patterns and adapts to changing traffic conditions. Experiments on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that Traffic Harmony reduces congestion by 23% and travel times by 17% compared to traditional fixed-time signal control methods.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) is becoming increasingly popular, but the impact of personalization on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effects of personalized VR experiences on user engagement, satisfaction, and cognitive load. We designed and implemented a VR platform that incorporates user profiling, adaptive difficulty adjustment, and real-time feedback. Our user study involving 120 participants shows that personalized VR experiences lead to significant improvements in user engagement and satisfaction, but also increase cognitive load. We provide insights into the design of personalized VR systems that balance user experience with cognitive demands.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Bayesian Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial task that enables agents to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a decentralized Bayesian learning approach for coalition formation, where agents learn to form coalitions based on their individual preferences and uncertain environment. We introduce a novel Bayesian network structure that models the agents' preferences and uncertainty, and develop an efficient inference algorithm to compute the coalition formation probability. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in forming optimal coalitions and adapting to changing environment conditions.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Scalable Unsupervised Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Unsupervised representation learning has seen significant advances with the rise of deep clustering algorithms. However, existing methods often struggle to scale to large datasets, limiting their applicability in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'HierScale', which leverages a multi-resolution representation learning framework to efficiently discover clusters at varying granularities. By recursively applying a lightweight clustering module, HierScale achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing computational cost by an order of magnitude. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierScale in unsupervised image classification and anomaly detection tasks.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning Agents
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents have achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but their opacity hinders trust and interpretability. This paper presents a novel model-agnostic explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which leverages attention mechanisms and feature importance scores to provide insightful explanations for DRL agent decisions. Our approach is evaluated on several Atari games and a real-world robotics control task, demonstrating significant improvements in explanation fidelity and efficiency compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification in graph-structured data remains a challenging task, particularly when dealing with limited labeled instances. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages both node and graph-level attention mechanisms to adaptively focus on relevant subgraphs and node features. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in few-shot node classification tasks. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the attention patterns learned by HAGNN, offering insights into the underlying graph structure and feature importance.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of heterogeneous document collections, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE', which leverages both semantic and syntactic relationships between terms to construct a robust query representation. By recursively expanding the query through a hierarchical graph, HQE can better accommodate the diversity of document structures and contents. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments face the challenge of adapting to changing task requirements and constraints. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network planning framework that enables agents to efficiently replan and reconfigure their tasks in response to environment changes. Our approach leverages a hierarchical decomposition of tasks into smaller sub-tasks, allowing agents to focus on the most critical tasks while maintaining flexibility to adjust to changing circumstances. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing agent response times.

title: Explainable Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles (AVs) become increasingly prevalent, ensuring their decision-making processes are transparent and trustworthy is crucial. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'XRL', which incorporates explainability techniques to shed light on the decision-making process of AVs. XRL employs a hierarchical policy architecture, where a high-level policy selects among multiple low-level policies, each responsible for a specific driving scenario. We propose a model-agnostic explanation method, 'AV-Explainer', which generates visual and textual explanations for the AV's actions. Experimental results on a simulated driving environment demonstrate that XRL outperforms state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods in terms of both driving performance and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable performance in node classification tasks, but their scalability remains a major concern. This paper proposes Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical representations to reduce the computational complexity of GNNs. HGAT combines multi-scale graph attention with a hierarchical pooling mechanism, allowing it to effectively capture long-range dependencies and node relationships. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGAT on several large-scale graph datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 50%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking is a crucial component of conversational AI systems, requiring the integration of multiple modalities such as speech, text, and vision. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between dialogue elements. HGAT learns to dynamically weight and combine modality-specific features, outperforming state-of-the-art models on the DSTC2 benchmark. We also propose a new evaluation metric, Modality-Aware F1, to better capture the nuances of multi-modal dialogue state tracking.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-TA', designed to efficiently allocate tasks in dynamic environments. MARL-TA integrates a hierarchical decomposition of the task allocation problem with a decentralized, actor-critic architecture. We introduce a novel exploration strategy that adapts to changing environment conditions, allowing agents to learn effective task allocation policies in real-time. Experimental results in a simulated robotic warehouse scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gesture recognition systems that adapt to the motor abilities of individuals with motor impairments. Our system, 'AdaptiveGest', uses a machine learning-based framework to learn the characteristic movement patterns of each user and adjust the recognition threshold accordingly. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with varying levels of motor impairment and found that AdaptiveGest outperformed existing gesture recognition systems in terms of accuracy and user satisfaction. Our results demonstrate the potential of adaptive gesture recognition systems to improve the accessibility of human-computer interfaces for individuals with motor impairments.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) requires reasoning over multiple entities and relations in a knowledge graph. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding method, 'Hop2Vec', which learns to represent entities and relations in a vector space that captures their semantic and structural properties. Hop2Vec uses a graph attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations during the embedding process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Hop2Vec on several MHQA benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art results and outperforming existing methods by a significant margin.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Enhance Accessibility for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their speech-centric interfaces often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a multimodal framework, 'AccessibleVA', which integrates computer vision, gesture recognition, and haptic feedback to create a more inclusive voice assistant. We conducted a user study with 30 participants with varying abilities, demonstrating that AccessibleVA significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces. Our approach has implications for enhancing accessibility in smart homes, healthcare, and education.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning has numerous applications in areas such as robotics, logistics, and smart cities. However, the complexity of planning tasks increases exponentially with the number of agents, making it challenging to scale to real-world problems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task network (HTN) framework for efficient multi-agent planning. Our approach decomposes complex tasks into smaller subtasks, allowing agents to coordinate and execute plans more effectively. We develop a set of heuristics to guide the decomposition process and demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through experiments on a range of multi-agent planning scenarios.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Explainable AI
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses a significant threat. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'AdvDet', that leverages explainable AI techniques to detect adversarial attacks in DRL. We introduce a attention-based mechanism that identifies the most influential state features contributing to the agent's decision-making process. By analyzing the feature importance, we detect anomalies indicative of adversarial attacks. Experimental results on popular DRL benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of AdvDet in detecting attacks while maintaining the agent's performance. Our approach has significant implications for the development of robust and secure DRL systems.

title: Designing Accessible Augmented Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has the potential to revolutionize the way people with visual impairments interact with their environment. However, existing AR interfaces are often inaccessible to this population due to their reliance on visual cues. This paper presents the results of a user-centered design study aimed at creating accessible AR interfaces for users with visual impairments. We identify key design principles and guidelines for tactile and audio-based AR interactions, and evaluate the effectiveness of our approach through a series of usability studies. Our findings highlight the importance of incorporating accessibility considerations into the early stages of AR interface design.

title: Optimizing Join Order Selection for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The join order selection problem is a critical component of query optimization in distributed database systems. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize join order selection. We formulate the problem as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques, achieving an average reduction of 30% in query execution time. We also analyze the applicability of our approach to various database systems and provide insights into the learned policy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a crucial task in natural language processing, but existing methods often struggle to effectively integrate multimodal data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that captures complex relationships between text, image, and audio features. Our approach employs a multi-level attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and learns to weigh their importance adaptively. Experiments on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of accuracy and inference speed, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to be assigned to tasks with different requirements. We propose a novel auction-based mechanism that leverages the agents' bids to determine the optimal task allocation. Our approach ensures that tasks are allocated efficiently, taking into account the agents' preferences and capabilities, while minimizing the overall system cost. We evaluate our mechanism through simulations and demonstrate its effectiveness in achieving better task allocation outcomes compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the heterogeneity of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between modalities. HGAT learns to hierarchically aggregate features from each modality and selectively focus on relevant modalities for emotion recognition. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, achieving an improvement of 7.2% in F1-score.

title: Query Optimization for Scalable Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships between data entities. However, query optimization for graph databases remains a challenging problem, especially for large-scale graphs. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a neural network-based agent that learns to select optimal query execution plans based on graph characteristics and query patterns. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Multimodal Fusion for Embodied Conversational Agents in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in virtual reality (VR) have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction. However, creating ECAs that can engage users in a natural and intuitive manner remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion framework that combines speech, gesture, and gaze cues to enable more expressive and responsive ECAs. Our approach leverages a deep neural network to integrate these modalities and generate context-dependent responses. We evaluate our framework in a VR-based conversational scenario and demonstrate improved user engagement and perceived agent intelligence compared to unimodal or naive multimodal approaches.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for storing and processing large amounts of data. However, indexing techniques used in centralized systems are often inefficient in distributed settings, leading to poor query performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'Distributed Hash Indexing' (DHI), which leverages the distributed nature of the system to improve query efficiency. DHI uses a combination of hash functions and Bloom filters to reduce the number of nodes involved in query processing, resulting in significant performance improvements. Experimental evaluations on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DHI outperforms existing indexing techniques in distributed database systems.

title: Designing Adaptive Haptic Feedback for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
