paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but users with disabilities often face barriers to immersion. This paper presents 'HapAxis', a novel framework for adaptive haptic feedback in VR. HapAxis leverages machine learning to dynamically adjust vibration intensity, frequency, and pattern based on user preferences, task requirements, and real-time biometric feedback. Our user study with 30 participants, including individuals with visual and motor impairments, demonstrates significant improvements in task performance, user satisfaction, and overall accessibility. The HapAxis framework can be integrated into existing VR systems, enhancing the inclusive potential of VR technology.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Stochastic Optimization
paper_abstract: We address the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to coordinate to accomplish multiple tasks. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that utilizes stochastic optimization to efficiently allocate tasks to agents. Our approach combines a distributed consensus protocol with a probabilistic task assignment strategy, enabling agents to adapt to changing task requirements and agent availability. Experimental results demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing centralized and distributed task allocation methods.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning via Constrained Policy Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but its brittleness to adversarial attacks hinders its deployment in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel constrained policy optimization framework, 'ARPO', which incorporates adversarial robustness into the policy learning process. By formulating the policy optimization problem as a constrained Markov decision process, ARPO ensures that the learned policy is not only optimal but also resilient to a wide range of adversarial perturbations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ARPO on several benchmark environments, showcasing its ability to withstand attacks while maintaining competitive performance.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We consider the problem of decentralized multi-agent planning under incomplete information, where agents must make decisions based on partial observations of the environment. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines deep reinforcement learning with decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (DEC-POMDPs). Our method, called DRL-DEC, uses a neural network to learn a policy for each agent that maximizes the collective reward while adapting to the uncertainty of the environment. Experimental results on a variety of benchmark domains demonstrate that DRL-DEC outperforms existing methods in terms of scalability and solution quality.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Dynamics
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Task Network (HTN) planning framework for Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) operating in uncertain environments. We introduce a probabilistic task representation that captures the uncertain dynamics of individual agents and their interactions. Our approach leverages a decentralized partial observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) to coordinate agent actions and achieve complex tasks. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, where agents must adapt to changing environmental conditions and uncertain sensor readings.

title: Real-time Object Detection with Efficient Attention Mechanism for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems, requiring real-time performance and high accuracy. This paper proposes a novel attention mechanism, 'EagleEye', which selectively focuses on regions of interest in the input image, reducing computational cost while maintaining detection accuracy. We leverage a lightweight neural network architecture and a novel attention weighting scheme, enabling our system to operate at 30 frames per second on embedded hardware. Experiments on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that EagleEye achieves state-of-the-art performance on object detection tasks while reducing computational overhead by 35%.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Search Engines
paper_abstract: Traditional search engines rely on exact keyword matching, resulting in suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Neural Ranking (HNR) model for efficient document filtering. HNR leverages a two-stage architecture, where a coarse-grained neural filter eliminates irrelevant documents, followed by a fine-grained ranking module that refines the search results. We demonstrate the efficacy of HNR on several benchmark datasets, showcasing significant improvements in retrieval precision and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Networks for Explainable Planning in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems rely on planning algorithms to accomplish complex tasks. However, the lack of explainability in these algorithms hinders trust and accountability. This paper presents HTN-X, a hierarchical task network framework that integrates planning and explanation generation. HTN-X employs a novel graph-based planning approach that exploits the structural relationships between tasks to produce interpretable plans. We demonstrate HTN-X on a real-world autonomous driving scenario, showcasing its ability to generate transparent and concise explanations for plan execution. Experimental results indicate that HTN-X outperforms state-of-the-art planning methods in terms of plan quality and explanation fidelity.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: We propose a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for distributed resource allocation in complex systems. Our approach, named 'DMA-RL', utilizes a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share knowledge and coordinate their actions in a decentralized manner. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DMA-RL in a simulated smart grid environment, where it achieves improved resource allocation efficiency and resilience compared to traditional centralized methods. Furthermore, we provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of DMA-RL and analyze its robustness to agent failures and communication delays.

title: Exploring Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper investigates the susceptibility of GNNs to node-level perturbations and proposes a novel attack strategy, GraphAttacker. We develop a reinforcement learning framework to learn perturbation strategies that maximize the misclassification rate. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphAttacker can significantly degrade the performance of GNNs, highlighting the need for robustness measures in graph-based AI applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) models often rely on complex neural networks, making it challenging to interpret their decision-making processes. We present HANA, a Hierarchical Attention Network architecture that enables explainable VQA by identifying relevant regions in the image and questions. Our model consists of a question-guided attention mechanism that selects relevant objects and a hierarchical reasoning module that contextualizes object interactions. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that HANA outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing visualizations that illustrate the reasoning process.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. However, existing methods often rely on hand-crafted features and struggle to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NeuroXPand', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense document embeddings. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that adapts to the query context, allowing the model to focus on relevant document aspects. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that NeuroXPand outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in many real-world applications, but traditional methods often struggle with long-term dependencies and high-dimensional data. This paper introduces HATS (Hierarchical Attention-based Time-Series forecasting), a novel deep learning framework that leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant time-steps and feature dimensions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HATS on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational complexity by up to 40% compared to existing methods.

title: Eyebit: A Gaze-Driven Interface for Accessible Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant barriers to participating in virtual reality (VR) experiences. This paper presents Eyebit, a novel gaze-driven interface that enables users to interact with VR environments using only their eye movements. Our approach leverages a machine learning-based gaze tracking system and a contextual understanding of the VR scene to accurately infer user intent. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating that Eyebit achieves a 3.5x increase in interaction speed and a 2.2x reduction in error rate compared to traditional gaze-based interfaces. Our results have significant implications for expanding access to VR experiences for individuals with motor impairments.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Heuristic-Based Coalition Formation
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and resources need to cooperate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel approach based on heuristic-based coalition formation, which leverages graph theory and machine learning to identify optimal coalitions of agents for task allocation. Our approach is evaluated using a simulated environment and shows significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization compared to existing decentralized task allocation methods.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Anomaly Detection in Industrial Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in industrial time series data is crucial for ensuring process efficiency and preventing costly downtime. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'AnomRL', which leverages the strengths of both model-based and data-driven approaches. AnomRL uses a hybrid actor-critic architecture to learn a policy for identifying anomalies in real-time, combining the benefits of accurate modeling and adaptability to changing process conditions. Experimental results on a large-scale industrial dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of AnomRL in detecting anomalies with high precision and recall, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of database systems, but traditional cost-based optimization techniques can be ineffective in distributed database settings. This paper explores the application of learned index structures to accelerate query optimization in distributed databases. We propose a novel framework, 'Lido', which leverages machine learning models to predict query execution times and optimize query plans. Experiments on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that Lido outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time, while reducing optimization overhead by up to 50%.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various node classification tasks. However, existing methods often overlook the hierarchical structure present in many real-world graphs. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to capture hierarchical dependencies between nodes. Our approach consists of two stages: (1) a bottom-up node representation learning phase, and (2) a top-down attention-based node classification phase. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms existing GNN models, especially on graphs with complex hierarchical structures.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Entity Disambiguation in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in data integration and retrieval, particularly in distributed databases where data freshness and consistency are paramount. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'EDIndex', which enables real-time entity disambiguation by efficiently indexing and querying large-scale datasets. EDIndex leverages a combination of Bloom filters, graph-based clustering, and parallel processing to reduce the computational overhead and improve the accuracy of entity disambiguation. Experimental results on a large-scale synthetic dataset demonstrate that EDIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of accuracy.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using multi-agent deep reinforcement learning. We propose a novel algorithm, 'MATRL', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task allocation in complex, dynamic environments. MATRL utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our experiments on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that MATRL outperforms traditional, centralized methods in terms of task completion time and team efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have been widely adopted for various AI applications. However, existing methods often neglect the complex relationships between entities. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) to learn multi-relational knowledge graph embeddings. HGAT employs a hierarchical architecture to capture both local and global dependencies among entities, and a relational attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant relationships. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in link prediction, entity classification, and question answering tasks.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) has traditionally relied on single-modal inputs, such as facial expressions or speech. However, humans communicate emotions through multiple modalities, including verbal and non-verbal cues. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates and selectively focuses on relevant modalities to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN model consists of three stages: intra-modal attention, inter-modal attention, and fusion. Experimental results on a multi-modal emotion dataset demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art single-modal and early-fusion approaches, achieving an F1-score of 0.83.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Conversational Search using Context-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to facilitate more natural and interactive search experiences. One key challenge lies in effectively capturing the user's intent and context. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach that leverages context-aware embeddings to better understand the nuances of conversational queries. Our method, dubbed 'ConverseExpand', jointly learns to represent queries, user context, and knowledge graph entities in a shared vector space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ConverseExpand on a large-scale conversational search dataset, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance and user satisfaction.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding in dynamic environments is a challenging problem that arises in various applications, including autonomous vehicles and robotics. This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning approach, called DMAP, that learns to optimize agent trajectories in real-time. We propose a novel graph attention mechanism that captures the complex interactions between agents and the environment, and develops a hierarchical policy that balances global exploration and local exploitation. Experimental results on a set of simulated scenarios demonstrate that DMAP outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of efficiency, safety, and adaptability.

title: Designing Accessible and Adaptable Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with disabilities. However, current VR interfaces often lack adaptability and accessibility features, limiting their usability. This paper presents a novel framework, 'AccessibleVR', which incorporates a range of adaptive and customizable interface elements to accommodate diverse user needs. We conducted a user study with participants with varying disabilities, demonstrating significant improvements in usability and user satisfaction compared to standard VR interfaces. Our findings inform the development of more inclusive and accessible VR experiences.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely on accurate and intuitive user input methods. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction approach using deep learning techniques. Our method, named 'GazeNet', leverages a convolutional neural network to predict user intent from eye gaze patterns. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and demonstrated that GazeNet achieves an average accuracy of 92.1% in identifying intended virtual objects. Furthermore, our approach reduces the latency of traditional ray-casting methods by 35%. The proposed system has the potential to enhance the overall VR experience and facilitate more natural human-computer interaction.

title: Query-Adaptive Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in information retrieval, where the goal is to resolve ambiguous entities in a query to their corresponding entities in a knowledge graph. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive approach using graph-based neural networks, which learns to adapt to the query context and incorporate semantic relationships between entities. Our model, QADE, leverages a heterogeneous graph attention mechanism to jointly model entity mentions, query context, and knowledge graph relationships. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12% relative improvement in disambiguation accuracy.

title: Deep Metric Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Prototypes
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when dealing with novel classes. This paper proposes a new deep metric learning approach, 'HierProto', which leverages hierarchical prototypes to improve few-shot classification performance. Our method learns to represent each class as a hierarchical structure of prototypes, capturing varying levels of abstraction and semantic similarity. Experimental results on popular benchmarks, including mini-ImageNet and Fewshot-CIFAR100, demonstrate that HierProto outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant gains in accuracy and robustness.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, it is essential to design voice-based interfaces that are accessible and usable by older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an intelligent conversational agent that accommodates the unique needs of this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with caregivers and older adults to identify key design requirements, including simplification of dialogue flows, personalized feedback mechanisms, and error tolerance. Our prototype, 'EasyTalk', was evaluated in a usability study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-TA', which enables agents to learn task allocation policies in a decentralized manner. HRL-TA combines a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers, allowing agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. We evaluate HRL-TA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural word embeddings to model semantic relationships between query terms. Our method, QE-NWE, uses a deep neural network to learn a dense representation of the query context, which is then used to generate a set of expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QE-NWE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Data Replication Strategies for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDBS) are critical for modern applications, but data replication strategies significantly impact their performance. This paper presents a novel replication strategy, 'ReplicaFlow', which leverages graph-based modeling to optimize data placement and reduce network latency. We develop an efficient algorithm to identify optimal replica locations and demonstrate its effectiveness through extensive simulations on real-world workloads. Results show that ReplicaFlow outperforms existing strategies by up to 35% in terms of average response time and 25% in terms of overall throughput.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Neural Ranking Models for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant products from massive catalogs. Traditional ranking models often rely on hand-crafted features, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'NRM-ec', which leverages deep learning techniques to learn hierarchical representations of products and queries. We introduce a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes ranking and product attribute prediction tasks. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that NRM-ec outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of precision, recall, and query latency.

title: Enhancing Multimodal Interaction with Embodied Conversational Agents in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in virtual reality (VR) have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction. However, current ECAs often lack realistic nonverbal cues, leading to decreased user engagement and trust. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework that incorporates gesture recognition, facial expression analysis, and natural language processing to create more empathetic and responsive ECAs. We evaluate our approach through a user study, demonstrating improved user experience and increased sense of presence in VR environments.

title: Eye-Gaze Based Authentication for Public Displays using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Public displays are increasingly prevalent in urban spaces, but their security is compromised by the lack of user authentication mechanisms. This paper proposes an eye-gaze based authentication system using deep learning. We design a convolutional neural network (CNN) that learns to identify users based on their eye movements on a public display. Our approach leverages a novel gaze-tracking method that exploits the display's built-in camera and ambient light sensors. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate a significant improvement in authentication accuracy and speed compared to traditional password-based methods.

title: Neural Retrieval with Query-Aware Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to effectively capture the nuanced semantics of user queries, leading to subpar retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel neural retrieval framework, 'QADE', which leverages query-aware document embeddings to better align query-document similarities. We introduce a dual-encoder architecture that jointly learns query and document representations, incorporating a novel attention mechanism to focus on relevant query terms. Experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc search benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines and showcasing the potential of QADE for real-world search applications.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults Using Machine Learning-based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible interfaces that cater to older adults. Gestural interfaces have shown promise, but their adoption is hindered by the complexity of gesture recognition. This paper proposes a machine learning-based approach to recognize gestures from older adults, using a novel dataset of elderly-specific gestures. We investigate the effectiveness of various deep learning architectures and explore the impact of age-related factors on gesture recognition accuracy. Our results demonstrate a significant improvement in recognition rates, paving the way for more accessible gestural interfaces that can be used by older adults.

title: EyeMovement-Based Adaptive Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to provide an optimal user experience due to the limitations of traditional input methods. This paper proposes an innovative eye movement-based adaptive interface (EMAI) that leverages gaze tracking and machine learning to dynamically adjust the VR environment according to the user's visual attention. Our approach integrates a convolutional neural network to classify eye movement patterns and predict user intentions, enabling the system to proactively offer personalized assistance and optimize interaction. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion time, and overall VR experience quality.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinating autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) framework that enables agents to reason about their own and other agents' actions, observations, and goals. Our approach leverages a novel belief-space planning algorithm that efficiently computes, communicates, and updates agents' policies. Experimental results in a robotic search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in achieving coordinated behavior and improving overall team performance.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding human-robot collaboration in immersive environments is crucial. This paper investigates the effect of embodiment on human trust and performance in VR-based human-robot teams. We designed an experiment where participants, embodied as avatars, collaborated with a robot to complete a task in a simulated warehouse environment. Our results show that embodied participants exhibited higher trust and better performance compared to non-embodied participants, particularly when the robot provided explanations for its actions. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of future VR-based human-robot collaboration systems.

title: EmoReact: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Framework for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling systems to respond empathetically to users. This paper presents EmoReact, a novel multimodal framework that integrates facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in real-time. We propose a hierarchical fusion approach that leverages the strengths of each modality, achieving an average F1-score of 0.92 on a benchmark dataset. EmoReact is designed to be adaptable to various HCI applications, including affective computing, social robots, and virtual assistants.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with digital information. However, current VR systems often neglect the complex interplay between the user's body and the virtual environment. This paper presents an embodied cognition framework for VR, which incorporates gestural input, proprioceptive feedback, and spatial awareness to enhance user experience. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through a user study, showing improved task performance, increased user engagement, and reduced cognitive load. Our findings have significant implications for the design of future VR systems, highlighting the importance of embodied cognition in creating immersive and intuitive interfaces.

title: Efficient Multi-Version Concurrency Control for Real-Time Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time database systems require efficient concurrency control mechanisms to ensure predictable and reliable performance. This paper presents a novel multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) algorithm, 'RT-MVCC', which leverages a hybrid approach combining optimistic and pessimistic concurrency control techniques. RT-MVCC reduces the overhead of version management and abort handling, resulting in improved system throughput and responsiveness. Experimental evaluations on a real-time database benchmark demonstrate that RT-MVCC outperforms existing MVCC algorithms in terms of transaction latency and throughput under high-contention workloads.

title: Self-Organizing Agent Networks for Adaptive Resource Allocation in IoT Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper introduces a novel approach to adaptive resource allocation using self-organizing agent networks. Our framework, SOAR, leverages decentralized decision-making and multi-agent coordination to optimize resource utilization in dynamic IoT environments. We evaluate SOAR through simulations and experiments on a real-world IoT testbed, demonstrating improved resource allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning with Limited Labeled Data
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years due to its ability to learn from limited labeled data. However, existing methods often struggle to generalize to unseen classes and require a large amount of labeled data for training. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages both labeled and unlabeled data to improve few-shot learning performance. Our approach uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and instances, and a consistency regularization term to encourage the model to produce consistent predictions across different augmentations of the input data. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, especially in scenarios with limited labeled data.

title: Enhancing Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly prevalent in modern data processing pipelines, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics or rule-based systems, which can be suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DeepQO', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to adaptively select optimal query plans. We formulate query optimization as a Markov Decision Process and train a deep Q-network to learn a policy that maximizes query performance. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that DeepQO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their usability for older adults with cognitive impairments remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an accessible voice assistant, 'EASE', tailored to the needs of this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving interviews, surveys, and usability testing to identify key design requirements. EASE incorporates features such as simplified language processing, personalized feedback, and multimodal interaction. Our evaluation results show that EASE significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing commercial voice assistants.

title: EyeCare: A Gaze-Based Interactive System for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: This paper presents EyeCare, a novel gaze-based interactive system designed to assist visually impaired users in navigating digital interfaces. By leveraging advancements in eye-tracking technology and machine learning, EyeCare enables users to interact with graphical user interfaces using only their gaze. Our system incorporates a novel calibration mechanism that adapts to the user's visual impairment, ensuring accurate and reliable gaze tracking. We evaluate EyeCare through a user study involving 20 visually impaired participants, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional assistive technologies.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become integral to smart home technologies, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create an inclusive voice assistant that caters to this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify usability challenges and preferences. Our findings inform the development of 'ElderVoice', a voice assistant that incorporates adaptive speech recognition, personalized prompts, and multimodal output. A usability evaluation with 30 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Decentralized Agent Coordination via Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in decentralized environments is a challenging problem, especially when agents have conflicting goals or limited communication. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages multi-agent deep reinforcement learning to achieve coordination in such scenarios. We propose a decentralized actor-critic framework, where each agent learns to predict the actions of its neighbors and adjusts its policy accordingly. Experimental results on a variety of benchmarks demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized coordination methods in terms of convergence speed and solution quality.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Efficient Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in this area, they often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Neural Network (HGNN) architecture that leverages a hierarchical graph representation to reduce the computational complexity of anomaly detection. Our approach combines a local graph attention mechanism with a global graph pooling strategy to identify anomalies in time-series data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-time Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a critical task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in text. Existing approaches often rely on expensive graph-based methods or require significant computational resources. This paper presents a novel indexing scheme, 'KG-Index', that enables real-time entity disambiguation by leveraging the structural properties of knowledge graphs. We propose a hierarchical indexing framework that prunes the search space and reduces the number of candidate entities, resulting in significant speedups without sacrificing accuracy. Experimental results on popular knowledge graphs demonstrate the effectiveness of KG-Index in achieving high accuracy and efficiency.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'DTRA', where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their individual capabilities and the system's global goals. DTRA utilizes a hierarchical architecture, comprising a graph neural network for task representation and a deep Q-network for action selection. We evaluate DTRA in a simulated robotic swarm scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional methods. Our approach enables efficient and adaptive task allocation in dynamic, large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Semantic Hashing for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval systems face the challenge of efficiently filtering out irrelevant documents from large collections. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepHashIR', which leverages deep semantic hashing to learn compact binary representations of documents. By exploiting the semantic relationships between documents, our approach reduces the dimensionality of the feature space and enables fast filtering using Hamming distance computations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepHashIR outperforms state-of-the-art filtering methods in terms of both precision and recall, while achieving significant speedups.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Neural Ranking Models in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but their computational complexity and memory requirements hinder their adoption in large-scale search systems. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'NeuIndex', that facilitates efficient query processing and reduces memory footprint for neural ranking models. We introduce a dimensionality reduction technique that preserves the ranking semantics of the neural model, enabling fast and accurate retrieval of top-k documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuIndex achieves significant speedups and memory savings while maintaining retrieval effectiveness.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems often struggle to capture the nuances of complex biomedical queries. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to improve query expansion in MIR. Our method, dubbed 'MedEmb', uses a multi-layer perceptron to learn dense vector representations of medical concepts, which are then used to expand queries. Experiments on the TREC Genomics track dataset demonstrate that MedEmb significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision.

title: Designing Inclusive Augmented Reality Interfaces for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize assistive technology, but existing AR systems often neglect the needs of visually impaired users. This paper presents 'Aria', an inclusive AR interface that leverages 3D audio and haptic feedback to facilitate spatial awareness and object recognition. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 20 visually impaired participants, revealing that Aria significantly improved their navigation and interaction experience compared to traditional screen-reader-based approaches. Our findings inform the design of accessible AR interfaces that can empower visually impaired individuals in various aspects of daily life.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial task in distributed database systems, as it directly impacts the performance and scalability of modern data-intensive applications. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We design a DRL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database environment, leveraging a combination of exploration and exploitation strategies to balance query cost and optimization time. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graph Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF graph databases in data-intensive applications has created a need for efficient query optimization techniques. This paper presents a novel approach, 'RDF-QOpt', which leverages graph decomposition and parallel processing to optimize SPARQL queries in distributed RDF settings. We propose a cost-based optimization framework that incorporates query rewriting, predicate reordering, and join optimization, achieving significant performance improvements over existing state-of-the-art approaches. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate RDF-QOpt's ability to reduce query execution time by up to 70% while maintaining result accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in dynamic graphs is a challenging task due to the evolving graph structure and node attributes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that captures node representations at multiple scales. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and time steps, enabling effective node classification in dynamic graphs. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods, particularly in scenarios with frequent graph updates.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to improve the quality of life for individuals with motor disabilities. However, existing systems often fail to account for individual differences in motor abilities, leading to poor recognition accuracy. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive gesture recognition that incorporates physiological and behavioral data to personalize the recognition model. We propose a machine learning-based framework that adapts to the user's abilities and preferences over time, using a combination of electromyography and computer vision data. Our evaluation with 20 participants with motor disabilities shows that our approach improves recognition accuracy by up to 30% compared to traditional gesture recognition systems.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a fundamental problem in artificial intelligence. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning to enable effective coordination among agents. Our method, called HRL-Coord, consists of a high-level coordinator that learns to allocate tasks to agents and a set of low-level agents that learn to execute tasks using reinforcement learning. We conducted experiments in a simulated robotic soccer domain and demonstrated that HRL-Coord outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of coordination efficiency and task completion rate.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) require efficient coordination to navigate complex traffic scenarios. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'GAT-MA', which leverages graph attention mechanisms to model interactions between AVs and their environment. GAT-MA learns to optimize vehicle trajectories, reducing congestion and improving overall traffic flow. We evaluate our approach on a realistic traffic simulator, demonstrating improved performance over baseline methods in various urban traffic scenarios.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Accessibility Features for Users with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their usability for individuals with dyslexia remains largely unexplored. This study investigates the accessibility of popular voice assistants for users with dyslexia, focusing on the impact of phonological awareness, decoding, and fluency on interaction outcomes. We propose a set of novel accessibility features, including audio-based spell checking, real-time vocabulary simplification, and personalized linguistic adaptation. User studies with 30 participants with dyslexia demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction when these features are integrated. Our findings inform the design of more inclusive voice assistants that cater to the diverse needs of users with dyslexia.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed IR Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (IR) systems face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from a massive, geographically dispersed corpus. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. HQE adaptively expands the query using a hierarchical clustering of term co-occurrences, reducing the search space and improving retrieval precision. Our experiments on a large-scale, distributed IR testbed demonstrate significant performance gains over traditional query expansion methods, with average precision improvements of up to 23% at top-10 recall.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Expansion for Improving Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short queries. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document expansion approach, QADE, which selectively incorporates relevant terms from the top-retrieved documents to re-weight the query. Our method leverages a neural ranking model to estimate the relevance of each term and adaptively adjusts the expansion based on the query's semantic meaning. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with AI-Driven Index Selection for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management systems. However, optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge, particularly in the presence of complex queries and dynamic workloads. This paper introduces 'AI-Index', a novel framework that leverages machine learning to select optimal indexes for distributed databases. By analyzing query patterns and workload characteristics, AI-Index identifies the most effective index configurations, resulting in significant improvements in query performance and resource utilization. Experimental evaluations on a real-world distributed database demonstrate the efficacy of AI-Index in reducing query latency by up to 40% compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Passage Retrieval for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel neural passage retrieval approach, 'NeuPass', to enhance query expansion. NeuPass leverages a dense passage retriever to identify semantically similar passages, which are then used to expand the original query. We demonstrate that NeuPass outperforms traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Scalable Graph Neural Networks for Efficient Node Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node representation learning, but their scalability remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach, 'GraphLite', which leverages graph clustering and sparse attention mechanisms to reduce computational complexity. We demonstrate that GraphLite achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including ogbn-products and ogbn-papers100M, while reducing training time by up to 75%. Our approach is particularly effective for large-scale graphs, enabling efficient node representation learning for real-world applications such as recommendation systems and social network analysis.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient coordination among agents to achieve global objectives. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn coordinated task allocation strategies. We design a decentralized, partially observable Markov decision process framework, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach is able to adapt to changing task requirements and agent capabilities, outperforming traditional optimization-based methods in simulated experiments.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coordinated exploration is crucial for efficient learning and optimal decision-making. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'CoEx', that enables agents to learn coordinated exploration strategies in complex, partially observable environments. Our approach integrates deep Q-networks with a novel attention mechanism that facilitates communication and coordination among agents. Experimental results on a suite of multi-agent benchmarks demonstrate that CoEx significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of exploration efficiency and task completion rates.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for real-time traffic management using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'TrafficCTRL', where each agent learns to optimize traffic signal control policies in a distributed manner. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic patterns and incorporates a reward function that balances traffic flow, safety, and fairness. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulation platform demonstrate that TrafficCTRL outperforms traditional optimization methods and achieves significant reductions in travel time and congestion.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown impressive performance in information retrieval tasks, but their effectiveness relies on the quality of the query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to adaptively refine the query representation. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroExp', iteratively generates synthetic relevance labels and uses them to update the query representation, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on a range of benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of NeuroExp in improving the retrieval quality, especially for queries with limited relevance feedback.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, aiming to refine the user's original query to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic relationships between words and phrases. Our model utilizes a combination of word embeddings and convolutional neural networks to identify relevant expansion terms, and we demonstrate its superiority over traditional methods on several benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that DeepQE achieves significant improvements in mean average precision and recall, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has led to a surge in resource allocation challenges. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARLA', which enables distributed resource allocation in IoT networks. MARLA utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to optimize its local resource allocation policy while coordinating with neighboring agents to maximize global network efficiency. We evaluate MARLA on a large-scale IoT network simulator, demonstrating significant improvements in resource utilization and network throughput compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification with Limited Labels
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks have shown remarkable success in node classification tasks, but their performance degrades significantly when labeled data is scarce. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that adaptively selects the most informative nodes and their corresponding labels to learn more effective node representations. HGAT leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism that aggregates node features at multiple scales, enabling the model to capture both local and global structural patterns. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in limited labeled data regimes.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodiment in Virtual Reality-Based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current gesture recognition systems often rely on abstracted representations of the user's body. This paper explores the concept of embodiment in VR-based gesture recognition, examining how the user's sense of bodily presence affects their interaction with virtual objects. We designed and evaluated a novel VR system that incorporates a 3D avatar and haptic feedback, demonstrating significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user experience compared to traditional controller-based approaches. Our findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and immersive VR interfaces.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to allocate tasks in a distributed manner. We propose a decentralized DRL framework, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach leverages graph attention networks to model inter-agent dependencies and incorporates a distributed exploration strategy to improve adaptability in dynamic environments. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and agent coordination compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Query Graphs for Efficient Semantic Search
paper_abstract: Semantic search has become increasingly important in modern information retrieval systems. However, existing approaches often rely on flat query representations, which can lead to inefficient query processing and suboptimal results. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical query graphs (HQGs) to model complex semantic relationships between query entities. We develop a graph-based neural network that learns to compress and refine HQGs, enabling efficient query optimization and effective semantic matching. Experimental results on a large-scale knowledge graph dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search accuracy and query processing speed compared to state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their hyperparameter tuning remains a challenging and time-consuming process. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization method, 'BO-Hyper', which leverages a probabilistic surrogate model to efficiently explore the hyperparameter space. We introduce a new acquisition function that balances exploration and exploitation, and demonstrate its effectiveness in tuning hyperparameters for various deep learning architectures. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that BO-Hyper outperforms existing methods, achieving better model performance with significantly reduced computational cost.

title: Co-Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (IR) systems face the challenge of efficient query processing across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel co-indexing technique that leverages the structure of the underlying data to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. By partitioning the index into smaller, interconnected components, our approach enables parallel query processing and minimizes inter-node communication. Experimental results on a large-scale IR dataset demonstrate that our co-indexing method achieves significant performance gains over traditional distributed indexing techniques, making it suitable for real-time query processing in modern IR systems.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Ad-hoc Search in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search in heterogeneous information networks (HINs) is a challenging task due to the complexity of relationships between entities. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-HIN', that leverages graph neural networks to capture the contextualized relationships between entities in the query and the HIN. Our approach learns to expand the query by incorporating relevant entities and their relationships, resulting in improved retrieval performance and efficiency. Experimental results on three real-world HIN datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of NQE-HIN compared to state-of-the-art ad-hoc search methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Adaptive Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel distributed task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, which integrates adaptive coalition formation with task assignment. Our approach, called ACTA, enables agents to dynamically form coalitions based on their capabilities, task requirements, and environmental factors. ACTA uses a decentralized, graph-based optimization algorithm to allocate tasks to coalitions, minimizing overall system cost and latency. We evaluate ACTA through extensive simulations, demonstrating its superiority over existing task allocation methods in terms of system performance, adaptability, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings for Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in constructing large-scale knowledge graphs, but existing methods struggle to handle the complexity and scalability of real-world datasets. This paper presents a novel approach, GraphDE, which leverages graph-based embeddings to model the semantic relationships between entities and their contexts. By incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism, GraphDE can effectively capture long-range dependencies and disambiguate entities with high accuracy. Experimental results on two large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that GraphDE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while maintaining a linear computational complexity.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on the impact of gesture-based interaction on cognitive load and user experience. We designed a VR system that incorporates hand-tracking technology and gesture recognition, allowing users to manipulate virtual objects using natural hand movements. In a user study with 30 participants, we found that gesture-based interaction reduced cognitive load and improved task performance compared to traditional controller-based input. Furthermore, our results suggest that embodied cognition plays a significant role in enhancing user engagement and overall VR experience.

title: Efficient Storage and Query Optimization for Large-Scale Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Large-scale graph databases have become increasingly popular in various domains, such as social networks, recommendation systems, and knowledge graphs. However, efficient storage and query optimization for these databases remain significant challenges. This paper proposes a novel graph storage scheme, 'GraphZip', which leverages graph partitioning and compression techniques to reduce storage overhead. We also develop a query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', that utilizes graph structural properties to prune unnecessary query patterns and accelerate query execution. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves significant storage savings and query performance improvements compared to existing graph database systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Disease Diagnosis
paper_abstract: Explainable AI is crucial in medical diagnosis, where model interpretability can inform treatment decisions. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) for disease diagnosis, which integrates graph neural networks with attention mechanisms to identify relevant symptoms and their relationships. HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models on a benchmark electronic health records dataset, achieving an F1-score of 0.92. We demonstrate the model's explainability through visualizations of attention weights, providing insights into the diagnosis process. Our approach has potential applications in clinical decision support systems, enabling healthcare professionals to make more informed decisions.

title: Deconfliction of Autonomous Agents in Real-World Scenarios using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in real-world scenarios often face conflicts due to shared resources, conflicting goals, or limited visibility. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to adaptively learn deconfliction strategies in complex, dynamic environments. Our approach leverages a novel reward function that incorporates both individual and collective performance metrics, promoting cooperation and adaptation among agents. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in reducing conflicts by up to 75% compared to traditional rule-based methods, while improving overall task efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) that aims to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'SemExpan', which leverages semantic embeddings to learn the relationships between query terms and expand the query with relevant keywords. We employ a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query expansion and relevance ranking, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of SemExpan over traditional query expansion methods.

title: EyeTracking-based Adaptive Gaze Guidance for Improving User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to provide an optimal user experience due to the complexity of visual stimuli and individual differences in visual attention. This paper presents a novel EyeTracking-based Adaptive Gaze Guidance (ETAGG) system that uses machine learning to predict and guide the user's gaze in real-time. ETAGG leverages a deep learning model to analyze the user's eye movements and adaptively adjusts the visual cues, reducing visual discomfort and improving task performance. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates a significant reduction in visual fatigue and a 25% increase in task completion speed compared to state-of-the-art gaze-based systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by difficulties in speech recognition, navigation, and comprehension. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework, 'EasySpeak', which integrates visual, auditory, and tactile cues to facilitate more accessible and engaging interactions. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates, user satisfaction, and cognitive load reduction. Our findings inform the design of more inclusive and supportive voice assistants, enabling older adults to fully benefit from smart home technologies.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional time series data is a crucial task in various fields, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-Anomaly', which leverages the strengths of autoencoders and convolutional neural networks to detect anomalies in high-dimensional time series data. TS-Anomaly uses a multi-scale convolutional architecture to capture temporal and spatial patterns in the data, followed by an autoencoder-based anomaly scoring mechanism. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that TS-Anomaly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Task Allocation in Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-robot systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires coordinating heterogeneous agents with varying capabilities and constraints. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn a decentralized task allocation policy. Our method, called 'HeteroAgent', uses a graph neural network to model the interactions between agents and a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework to learn a coordination strategy. Experiments in a simulated warehouse environment demonstrate that HeteroAgent outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has been increasingly used in various applications, but its user interface remains a significant bottleneck. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction for AR, focusing on user experience and performance. We designed and implemented a gaze-based AR system and conducted a user study with 24 participants. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can significantly reduce task completion time and improve user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based methods. We also identify several design implications and future research directions for gaze-based AR interfaces.

title: Eliciting User Preferences through Embodied Conversational Agents in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in virtual reality (VR) have shown great potential for human-computer interaction. However, understanding user preferences in these environments remains a challenge. This paper presents a novel framework for eliciting user preferences through ECAs in VR. We employ a combination of natural language processing, sentiment analysis, and machine learning to analyze user interactions with ECAs. Our approach enables the identification of users' implicit preferences, which are often difficult to articulate explicitly. We evaluate our framework in a VR-based shopping scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving user satisfaction and experience.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of renewable energy sources and decentralized energy management systems in smart grids necessitates efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper proposes a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents using reinforcement learning, enabling real-time optimization of energy distribution and consumption. Our framework, 'AgentRL', leverages a multi-agent deep Q-network to learn optimal policies for agent coordination, taking into account uncertain renewable energy sources, variable demand, and grid constraints. Experimental results using real-world energy consumption data demonstrate improved efficiency and reduced energy waste compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing gestural interfaces that adapt to the unique abilities and needs of each user. Our system, dubbed 'Gesto', employs a machine learning-based framework to recognize and learn from user gestures, dynamically adjusting the interface to accommodate varying levels of motor control. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates that Gesto significantly improves task completion times and reduces user frustration compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Autonomous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is critical for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'AgentGNN', that utilizes graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a task allocation strategy for heterogeneous autonomous agents. By modeling agent interactions as a graph, AgentGNN can capture complex dependencies and allocate tasks based on agent capabilities, task priorities, and environmental constraints. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentGNN outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Systems
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational systems is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction. However, existing approaches often rely on single-modal inputs (e.g., text or speech) and neglect the complexities of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal inputs (text, speech, and facial expressions) to recognize emotions in conversations. The HAN model employs a hierarchical structure to capture both local and global dependencies across modalities, and an attention mechanism to selectively focus on informative regions. Experiments on a large-scale conversational dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions, especially in cases of ambiguity or conflicting cues.

title: Scalable Bayesian Neural Networks for Real-Time Image Classification
paper_abstract: Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) offer a promising approach to image classification by providing uncertainty estimates and improved robustness. However, their computational cost and memory requirements hinder their deployment in real-time applications. This paper presents 'BayesNet', a scalable BNN architecture that leverages a hierarchical variance decomposition and a novel, efficient sampling scheme. We demonstrate BayesNet's performance on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy and uncertainty estimates while reducing computational overhead by an order of magnitude.

title: Hierarchical Document Clustering with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval (IR) systems struggle to efficiently cluster large document collections, leading to suboptimal query performance. This paper introduces 'HIRCL', a novel hierarchical document clustering approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize clustering structures. By framing clustering as a Markov decision process, our DRL agent learns to adaptively select clustering granularity and merge policies, resulting in significant improvements in clustering quality and query response times. Experimental evaluation on several benchmark datasets demonstrates the effectiveness of HIRCL in reducing mean average precision errors by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art clustering methods.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Dense Indexing for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) has witnessed significant progress with the advent of dense passage retrieval (DPR) models. However, existing approaches suffer from high computational costs and memory requirements, limiting their scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense indexing (HDI) framework that accelerates passage retrieval by 3.5x while maintaining comparable accuracy to state-of-the-art DPR models. We introduce a hierarchical clustering strategy that groups semantically similar passages, enabling efficient indexing and querying. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HDI in reducing inference latency and improving overall ODQA performance.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Hierarchical Graph Rewiring
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable performance on various graph-based tasks. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks on graph structures has raised concerns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph rewiring approach to enhance the robustness of GNNs against adversarial attacks. Our method iteratively identifies and rewires critical edges in the graph to reduce the impact of perturbations.
