Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in robustness metrics, including attack success rate and perturbation tolerance, while maintaining competitive performance on clean data. We also provide theoretical insights into the connection between graph rewiring and GNN's robustness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents' decision-making processes can have significant impacts on the environment and other agents. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that enables explainable multi-agent reinforcement learning. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between agents and their environments, while hierarchical abstraction enables the identification of high-level decision-making patterns. Experimental results on a real-world traffic management scenario demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both task performance and explainability.

title: Deep Hierarchical Clustering for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical clustering approach, dubbed 'DeepHiClu', for unsupervised anomaly detection in such data. DeepHiClu leverages a multi-scale temporal encoder to extract robust representations of the time series data, and a hierarchical clustering module to identify anomalies at multiple granularity levels. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepHiClu on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, task allocation among agents is a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel approach that combines deep reinforcement learning with graph-based task allocation methods. Our algorithm, called 'ADAPT', uses a decentralized, asynchronous framework to enable agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that ADAPT outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to environmental uncertainty.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for heterogeneous autonomous agents using reinforcement learning. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process, and propose a multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm that enables agents to learn cooperative policies. Our approach leverages the strengths of each agent type and adaptively adjusts to changes in the environment. Experimental results demonstrate improved task completion efficiency and robustness compared to traditional auction-based methods in a variety of complex scenarios.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In heterogeneous multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to varying agent capabilities, diverse task requirements, and decentralized decision-making. This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework, 'HTA', which leverages graph neural networks to model agent and task relationships. HTA enables agents to learn from their interactions and adapt to dynamic task arrivals, ensuring efficient and scalable task allocation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HTA through extensive simulations, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Robust Explainability for Medical Image Classification using Adversarial Attacks
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in medical image classification, but their lack of transparency hinders trust in critical healthcare applications. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'MedXA', which leverages adversarial attacks to improve the explainability of medical image classification models. We develop a generative framework that creates perturbed images to simulate real-world variations, and use these to train an explainer model that provides robust feature importance scores. Experimental results on a large dataset of chest X-rays demonstrate that MedXA outperforms existing explainability methods in terms of fidelity and interpretability, while maintaining high classification accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-powered Clinical Decision Support
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI-driven clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) has raised concerns about their interpretability and trustworthiness. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages explainable AI techniques to improve the transparency of CDSSs. Our HAN model integrates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant patient information and provide contextualized explanations for predicted diagnoses. Experimental results on a large-scale electronic health record dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing model interpretability while maintaining high diagnostic accuracy.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning using Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex control tasks, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns for real-world deployment. This paper proposes a novel approach to generating adversarial attacks on DRL agents using model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML). We adapt MAML to learn a meta-policy that can adapt to different DRL models and environments, thereby circumventing the need for model-specific knowledge. Experimental results on popular DRL benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing the robustness of state-of-the-art DRL algorithms.

title: Gaze-based Authentication using Deep Learning on Egocentric Videos
paper_abstract: Egocentric videos offer a unique opportunity for gaze-based authentication, which can provide an additional layer of security for wearable devices. This paper presents a deep learning framework that leverages spatiotemporal features from egocentric videos to authenticate users based on their gaze patterns. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network to extract features from the videos and a recurrent neural network to model the temporal dependencies of the gaze data. Experimental results on a dataset of 50 users show that our approach achieves an accuracy of 95.6% and outperforms existing methods by at least 10%. We also demonstrate the robustness of our approach against various types of attacks.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Oriented Storage
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing requires efficient query processing to support timely decision-making. This paper proposes a novel column-oriented storage scheme, 'ColumnSpark', which leverages data compression, caching, and parallel processing to accelerate query performance. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that dynamically selects the most efficient storage layout and query execution plan based on query patterns and data characteristics. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that ColumnSpark outperforms traditional row-oriented storage by up to 5x in query response time and 3x in storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Phrase Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval has long been a challenging task in information retrieval, and query expansion (QE) is a crucial technique to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages deep learning-based phrase embeddings to capture semantic relationships between phrases. Our method, called Phrase2Vec, uses a neural network to learn vector representations of phrases from a large corpus, which are then used to expand the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that Phrase2Vec outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is critical for achieving collective goals. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-TA', which combines a high-level planning module with low-level execution agents. The planning module learns to allocate tasks based on agent capabilities and task dependencies, while the execution agents learn to optimize their actions using deep Q-networks. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that HRL-TA outperforms traditional centralized planning methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data Using Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution is crucial for efficient data retrieval in modern database systems. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages neural networks to optimize query plans for multi-dimensional data. Our framework, 'NeuroOpt', learns to predict optimal query execution plans by modeling the intricate relationships between query components, data distributions, and system resources. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that NeuroOpt outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 40% in terms of query execution time, while maintaining competitive plan quality.

title: Visualizing Cognitive Load in Human-AI Collaborative Decision-Making
paper_abstract: As AI systems increasingly support human decision-making, understanding cognitive load is crucial for effective collaboration. This paper presents a novel, multimodal approach to visualize cognitive load in real-time, leveraging EEG, eye-tracking, and mouse interaction data. We introduce a cognitive load modeling framework that integrates machine learning and signal processing techniques to detect cognitive workload, mental fatigue, and attention allocation. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates the efficacy of our approach in enhancing human-AI collaboration, improving decision accuracy by 23%, and reducing cognitive load by 17%. The proposed framework has implications for designing more effective and human-centered AI systems.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Deep Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient allocation of tasks to agents with varying capabilities. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep graph neural networks (DGNNs) to learn a task allocation policy that can scale to large numbers of agents and tasks. Our method, called GraphTask, leverages graph-based representations of agent capabilities and task requirements to learn a hierarchical allocation strategy. Experimental results on a simulated robotic warehouse environment show that GraphTask outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of allocation efficiency and adaptability to changing task requirements.

title: Investigating the Effects of Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown immense potential in various domains, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of haptic feedback on user engagement in VR environments. We designed a VR game that incorporates multiple levels of haptic feedback, from basic vibrotactile to more sophisticated electroencephalography-based feedback. Our user study involving 30 participants reveals that haptic feedback significantly enhances user engagement, measured through metrics such as completion rate, time spent, and subjective experience. We also identify specific haptic feedback types that are more effective in different VR scenarios.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on IoT Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of time-series data, necessitating efficient indexing techniques for real-time analytics. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'TS-Index', which leverages a combination of symbolic aggregation and piecewise approximation to enable fast query processing. We demonstrate that TS-Index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of storage efficiency, while maintaining high accuracy for common analytical queries. Experiments on real-world IoT datasets validate the efficacy of TS-Index in supporting real-time analytics.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is critical for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized approach using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to allocate tasks in a distributed manner. We propose a novel HRL framework, 'Distributed Agent Scheduling' (DAS), which consists of a high-level task allocator and low-level agent controllers. DAS enables agents to learn task-specific skills and adapt to changing environments while ensuring global optimality. Experimental results on a swarm robotics platform demonstrate that DAS outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized methods in terms of task completion rate and system scalability.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems (DIRS) are crucial for large-scale search engines, but processing complex queries remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an adaptive re-ranking framework that leverages query log analysis and machine learning to optimize query processing in DIRS. Our approach dynamically adjusts the ranking model based on query patterns, reducing the need for expensive re-execution and improving overall system efficiency. Experimental results on a large-scale query dataset demonstrate significant reductions in processing time and improved result quality compared to existing re-ranking methods.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-modal emotion recognition systems have gained popularity in recent years, leveraging advances in computer vision, natural language processing, and audio analysis. However, their robustness to adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the vulnerability of multi-modal emotion recognition systems to adversarial attacks. We propose a novel attack framework, 'EmoAttack', which generates targeted perturbations to manipulate the emotional state classification of a given input. Our experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmoAttack can successfully deceive state-of-the-art models, highlighting the need for robustness evaluation and defense strategies in this domain.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation is a complex problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must coordinate to achieve a common goal. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoopMARL', which leverages graph neural networks to learn cooperative policies. We introduce a hierarchical reward function that encourages agents to form coalitions and allocate tasks efficiently. Experimental results on a variety of cooperative task allocation scenarios demonstrate that CoopMARL outperforms existing methods in terms of solution quality and computation time.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants and chatbots, are increasingly prevalent in everyday life. However, people with disabilities often face significant barriers in interacting with these systems. This paper presents the design and evaluation of AccessChat, a novel conversational interface that incorporates accessibility features to support users with disabilities. We employed a participatory design approach, working closely with individuals with disabilities to identify and address usability challenges. Our evaluation demonstrates that AccessChat significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction for participants with disabilities, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in HCI.

title: Hierarchical Self-Supervised Representation Learning for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and facial expressions, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the lack of large-scale annotated datasets. This paper presents a novel hierarchical self-supervised representation learning framework, HierEmo, which leverages the inherent structure of multimodal data to learn robust and transferable emotion representations. Our approach involves a two-stage training process, where a shared encoder is first pre-trained on a large-scale multimodal dataset using a self-supervised contrastive loss, and then fine-tuned on a downstream emotion recognition task using a small amount of labeled data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HierEmo in improving emotion recognition accuracy and robustness to missing modalities.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, which involves ranking documents based on their relevance to a given query. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for efficient document ranking. Our approach consists of a high-level policy that selects a subset of documents to evaluate, and a low-level policy that determines the ranking of the selected documents. We employ a reinforcement learning objective that maximizes the expected cumulative discounted reward, where the reward function is based on the relevance of the ranked documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HRL approach outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of both effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for autonomous traffic control. We propose a novel framework, 'MARL-ATC', which enables multiple autonomous vehicles to learn and adapt to dynamic traffic scenarios in real-time. By leveraging decentralized learning and communication protocols, MARL-ATC improves traffic flow and reduces congestion in complex urban environments. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that MARL-ATC outperforms traditional centralized control methods and achieves significant reductions in travel time and fuel consumption.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the quality of life for older adults by enabling intuitive control of smart home devices. However, current systems often fail to account for age-related physical and cognitive decline. This paper presents an inclusive design approach that incorporates participatory design workshops, user studies, and machine learning-based gesture recognition algorithms tailored to the needs of older adults. Our system achieves a 25% improvement in gesture recognition accuracy compared to existing systems, and user studies demonstrate increased user satisfaction and accessibility.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the quality of search results. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query expansion, leveraging word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. We introduce a graph convolutional network that learns to represent queries and documents as nodes in a graph, enabling the integration of contextual information and semantic similarity measures. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Enhancing Deep Retrieval Models with Hierarchical Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to effectively capture complex query intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Query Graphs (HQS), which represents queries as a hierarchical composition of entities, attributes, and relationships. We integrate HQS into a deep retrieval model, demonstrating significant improvements in ranking accuracy and robustness to query variation. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, particularly for complex, multi-entity queries.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Dense Passage Embeddings for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense passage embedding (HDPE) approach, which leverages a two-level hierarchical framework to represent passages at both sentence and document levels. Our experiments on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that HDPE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art dense passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% increase in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy while reducing indexing time by 30%. We also show that HDPE is robust to varying passage lengths and can be easily integrated with existing ODQA pipelines.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. We introduce a novel hierarchical architecture that combines a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers, allowing agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Experimental results using a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing agent idle time.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents in a distributed environment is a challenging problem, particularly when agents have conflicting goals and constraints. This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent coordination using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). We propose a hierarchical DCOP framework that enables agents to reason about their local constraints and objectives, while also considering the global system constraints. Experimental results on a team-based robotics scenario demonstrate that our approach improves upon existing decentralized coordination methods in terms of solution quality and computation time.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is crucial for distributed database systems, where join order enumeration plays a significant role in determining query performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Jasper', which leverages graph neural networks to learn the optimal join order from query patterns and database statistics. Jasper outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of query execution time and scalability, particularly for complex queries involving multiple joins. We evaluate Jasper on a real-world database benchmark and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing query latency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Database Query Optimization
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and sensors has led to an exponential increase in time-series data, necessitating efficient query optimization techniques for real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel indexing scheme, 'TSIndex', which leverages a combination of piecewise aggregation and hierarchical clustering to accelerate range and aggregation queries. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that TSIndex outperforms existing indexing methods, achieving an average query speedup of 3.5x while reducing indexing overhead by 40%. We also propose an adaptive indexing framework that dynamically adjusts to changing data distributions, ensuring robust performance under varying workloads.

title: Improving Explainability in Deep Neural Networks using Hierarchical Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their lack of transparency and interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HierAttn', that improves the explainability of deep neural networks. HierAttn disentangles the feature importance across multiple levels of abstraction, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the decision-making process. We evaluate HierAttn on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving the accuracy of feature importance attribution and model interpretability.

title: Real-time Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines struggle to accurately retrieve relevant products due to the ambiguity of user queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to real-time query expansion using reinforcement learning. Our method, 'RL-QE', learns to automatically generate context-aware query expansions by interacting with the search engine and receiving feedback in the form of user click-through rates. We demonstrate the efficacy of RL-QE on a large-scale e-commerce dataset, showing significant improvements in search accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, called MARL-TA, leverages a decentralized framework where each agent learns to optimize its task allocation policy based on local observations and rewards. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that enables agents to selectively focus on relevant tasks and teammates, leading to improved scalability and adaptability in dynamic environments. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation benchmarks demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods and state-of-the-art machine learning approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to allocate tasks efficiently. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We introduce a Markov decision process (MDP) formulation that captures the decentralized nature of the problem and use deep Q-networks to learn the policy. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated environment and shows significant improvements in terms of task allocation efficiency and adaptability to changing environments compared to traditional decentralized algorithms.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Robot Planning
paper_abstract: Robot planning in complex environments often relies on learned models that are difficult to interpret. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that learns to plan robot trajectories while providing explainable decision-making. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant objects and relations in the environment, enabling the robot to adapt to changing circumstances. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGAT in a variety of robotics tasks, including object manipulation and navigation, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of planning efficiency and interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient control policies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for autonomous vehicle control, which decomposes the control problem into a hierarchy of tasks. Our approach combines a high-level policy for route planning with low-level policies for motion control, enabling efficient exploration and exploitation of the environment. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our HRL framework in a realistic simulation environment, achieving improved fuel efficiency and reduced computational overhead compared to flat reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document embedding approach, 'HDE', which captures both local and global semantic relationships within documents. Our method represents documents as a hierarchy of embeddings, where each node corresponds to a passage or section. This allows for more accurate and efficient retrieval of relevant passages, reducing the computational cost of downstream answer extraction. Experimental results on the SQuAD-Open dataset demonstrate significant improvements in passage retrieval accuracy and ODQA performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Neural Retrieval Models in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of neural retrieval models in ad-hoc search systems has led to a significant performance gap between traditional keyword-based retrieval methods and neural methods. This gap is primarily due to the expensive computations required for neural ranking models. In this paper, we propose a novel query optimization framework, 'NeuroOpt', that leverages the structural properties of neural networks to reduce the computational overhead. NeuroOpt employs a hierarchical pruning strategy to eliminate irrelevant documents and a novel caching mechanism to minimize redundant computations. Our experiments on a large-scale ad-hoc search dataset demonstrate that NeuroOpt achieves an average speedup of 3.2x over state-of-the-art neural retrieval models while maintaining comparable retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems rely on handcrafted features and linear ranking models, which struggle to capture complex document relationships. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which integrates document embeddings, contextualized language models, and self-attention mechanisms. We demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art IR models on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency. Our extensive experiments also reveal the importance of incorporating hierarchical structures and contextualized embeddings in neural IR models.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management systems. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using graph-based indexing. Our method, called GraphOpt, leverages the graph structure of the database to identify optimal query plans. We demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time. Furthermore, we show that our approach is highly scalable and adaptable to changing database workloads.

title: Optimizing Query Workloads on Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are widely used in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query workloads remains a challenging task. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans in distributed database systems. We design a Markov decision process (MDP) that models the query optimization problem and propose a deep Q-network (DQN) based algorithm to learn the optimal query execution plans. Experimental results on a real-world datasets show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component in task-oriented dialogue systems. Existing approaches struggle to effectively incorporate multi-modal inputs (e.g., text, speech, and vision) and often rely on complex, manually-designed feature engineering. We propose a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HierarTrack', which learns to selectively focus on relevant input modalities and contextual information. Our approach leverages a hierarchical encoder to capture both local and global dependencies, enabling more accurate DST. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ dataset demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of joint goal accuracy and overall dialogue success rate.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforced Neural Ranking Models for Diverse Search Results
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often rely on fixed rules or statistical methods, which may not capture the nuances of user intent. We propose a novel approach, 'NERD', that leverages reinforced neural ranking models to learn adaptive query expansion strategies. NERD integrates a deep reinforcement learning framework with a neural ranking model, allowing it to optimize query expansion for diverse search results. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NERD outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of search result diversity and relevance, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Symbolic Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can have severe consequences in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel framework for robustness analysis of deep neural networks using Bayesian neural symbolic learning. Our approach combines the strengths of symbolic methods and Bayesian neural networks to identify vulnerabilities in the decision-making process of deep models. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, including ImageNet and CIFAR-10, and show that it can detect adversarial attacks with high accuracy. Our framework provides a promising direction for developing more robust and trustworthy AI systems.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Queries using Hierarchical Embeddings in Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems struggle to effectively handle multi-modal queries, which combine text, images, and other media. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Embeddings for Multi-Modal Retrieval (HEMMR), which leverages hierarchical representations to jointly model and embed different modalities. Our method enables efficient retrieval of relevant documents by projecting multi-modal queries into a unified semantic space. Experiments on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HEMMR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Interpretable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Recent advances in AI-powered emotion recognition systems have relied heavily on deep learning models, which often suffer from a lack of interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates multi-modal input from facial expressions, speech, and text. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, enabling more accurate and interpretable emotion recognition. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance with improved Explainability and Transparency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it enhances the retrieval performance by incorporating relevant terms into the original query. However, existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not effectively capture the semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages neural networks to learn a dense representation of query terms and expands the query using a learned similarity metric. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Trust in Human-Robot Collaboration
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly collaborate with humans in shared workspaces, understanding the factors that influence trust is crucial. This study explores the role of embodiment in human-robot collaboration, examining how the physical presence and anthropomorphic design of robots affect users' trust and cooperation. Our user study involves 120 participants interacting with either an embodied or non-embodied robot in a collaborative task, with results showing that embodiment significantly enhances trust and task performance. We discuss the implications for designing more effective and trustworthy human-robot collaboration systems.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using Multi-Scale Convolutional Autoencoders
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is crucial in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, existing methods often struggle with high-dimensional data and varying anomaly scales. We propose a novel approach, 'MSCAE', which leverages multi-scale convolutional autoencoders to learn hierarchical representations of time series data. Our method can effectively identify anomalies at different scales and reduce false positives. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of MSCAE over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Optimal Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of allocating resources efficiently to meet dynamic user demands. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'CloudOpt', which learns to optimize resource allocation in cloud data centers. CloudOpt leverages a hierarchical architecture consisting of a deep Q-network and a resource allocation policy, which adaptively adjusts to changing workload patterns and resource availability. Experimental results on a real-world cloud workload dataset demonstrate that CloudOpt achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response times, and energy efficiency compared to state-of-the-art heuristics.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Large-Scale Collections
paper_abstract: As document collections continue to grow, traditional query expansion techniques suffer from scalability issues, leading to decreased retrieval efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HyQE', which leverages a two-level indexing architecture to reduce the dimensionality of the query space. By adaptively selecting expansion terms from a hierarchical representation of the document collection, HyQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and speed. Experiments on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HyQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, with a 25% increase in mean average precision and a 3x reduction in query processing time.

title: Hybrid Ranking Model for Context-Aware Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval (IR) often neglect the contextual information of the query. This paper proposes a novel hybrid ranking model, 'HybridRank', which integrates both semantic and contextual features to improve the accuracy of document retrieval. We employ a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query-document relevance and query-context similarity. Experimental results on the TREC-NEWS dataset show that HybridRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in computer vision, where models must adapt to new classes with limited labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical meta-learning approach, which leverages both task-level and class-level adaptability. Our method, called Hierarchical Adaptive Metric Learning (HAMLET), learns to generate task-specific metrics and class-specific prototypes in a hierarchical manner. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAMLET outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, especially in settings with limited labeled data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed database systems, multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) enables high availability and concurrency, but introduces query optimization challenges. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCCOpt', which leverages graph-based modeling and reinforcement learning to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. We propose a dynamic version selection strategy that adapts to workload changes and explores the tradeoff between query performance and data freshness. Experimental results on a distributed database prototype demonstrate that MVCCOpt outperforms existing optimization techniques by up to 35% in query latency and 25% in system throughput.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for efficient resource allocation in smart grids. We model the problem as a cooperative game, where agents representing different grid nodes learn to optimize their resource allocation strategies to minimize energy losses and maximize overall grid stability. Our approach combines deep Q-networks with a communication protocol that enables agents to share knowledge and adapt to changing grid conditions. Experimental results on a realistic grid simulation platform demonstrate improved resource allocation efficiency and resilience compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Scalable Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification via Graph Sampling
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable performance in node classification tasks. However, their computational complexity and memory requirements scale poorly with large graphs. This paper introduces 'GraphSample', a novel graph sampling strategy that reduces the computational cost of GNNs while preserving their predictive power. By adaptively sampling nodes and their neighbors, GraphSample achieves a speedup of up to 10x compared to state-of-the-art GNNs on large-scale graph datasets. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphSample on several benchmark datasets, including citation networks and social networks.

title: Attention-based Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become increasingly reliant on complex models, often sacrificing interpretability for improved performance. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding approach, 'KEGRA', which leverages attention mechanisms to incorporate domain-specific knowledge into recommendation models. By learning to attend to relevant entities and relationships in the knowledge graph, KEGRA provides transparent and explainable recommendations. Experimental results on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of KEGRA in improving recommendation accuracy while enabling model interpretability.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Resource Allocation in Decentralized Environments
paper_abstract: Decentralized systems often rely on autonomous agents to allocate resources efficiently. However, coordinating these agents to achieve global optimality remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel decentralized coordination mechanism, 'AdapCo', which enables agents to adapt their resource allocation strategies based on local observations and peer-to-peer communication. We prove that AdapCo converges to a Nash equilibrium under mild assumptions and demonstrate its effectiveness in a series of simulations, showcasing improved resource utilization and reduced conflict rates compared to existing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: Deep learning models for multi-label classification often struggle to provide interpretable results. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant input features and labels. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to model label correlations and generate label-wise attention weights. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing insight into the decision-making process through attention visualization.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Sparse Domains
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods struggle with sparse domains, where relevant documents are scarce. We propose a query-driven document expansion approach to improve retrieval efficiency in such scenarios. Our method leverages a neural ranking model to generate pseudo-relevant documents, which are then used to augment the original query. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain, especially for tail queries. We also show that our approach is robust to varying levels of sparsity and outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multiple evaluation metrics.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) with heterogeneous storage face significant challenges in optimizing query performance. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'HetOpt', which leverages machine learning and statistical modeling to adapt to diverse storage configurations. HetOpt integrates a cost-based optimizer with a reinforcement learning module that learns to predict query execution times and adjusts the optimization strategy accordingly. Our experimental results on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate that HetOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to a surge in resource allocation challenges. This paper presents a novel decentralized autonomous agent-based framework for efficient resource allocation in IoT networks. Our approach leverages multi-agent systems to enable devices to negotiate and allocate resources in a distributed manner, minimizing latency and improving overall network performance. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through simulations on a real-world IoT network, showcasing significant improvements in resource utilization and reduced overhead compared to traditional centralized methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coordinating agents to achieve efficient resource allocation is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn decentralized policies for resource allocation. We introduce a hierarchical framework that consists of a high-level coordinator and low-level agents, where the coordinator learns to allocate resources based on the agents' observations and actions. Experimental results on a simulated resource allocation problem demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of resource utilization and allocation efficiency.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Edge Computing
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosive growth in edge-generated data, making real-time analytics a critical component of many applications. However, existing query optimization techniques are inadequate for edge computing environments, where resources are limited and latency is paramount. This paper presents 'ECHO', a novel distributed query optimization framework designed specifically for edge computing. ECHO leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to partition the query graph, enabling efficient query processing and minimizing network latency. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world edge computing platform demonstrates that ECHO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial task in distributed database systems, where the goal is to minimize query execution time and resource utilization. Traditional query optimizers rely on heuristics and rule-based approaches, which may not adapt well to changing workloads and system dynamics. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query plan selection policy. Our approach uses a deep Q-network to estimate the expected execution time of different query plans and selects the optimal plan based on the current system state. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that our approach achieves an average query execution time reduction of 30% compared to traditional query optimizers.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Adaptive Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized coordination of autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments. We propose an adaptive reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn cooperative policies while adapting to changing environmental conditions and agent behaviors. Our approach utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent maintains a local policy and value function, and communicates with its neighbors to leverage shared knowledge. Experimental results in a simulated robotic swarm scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized coordination methods.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of database systems, and traditional methods rely on heuristics and statistical models. This paper presents a novel approach, 'LIX', which leverages learned index structures to accelerate query optimization for main-memory databases. By integrating neural networks into the query optimizer, LIX can accurately predict query execution times and optimize plans more effectively. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that LIX outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time, while maintaining high accuracy and robustness.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction Techniques for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have the potential to improve accessibility for individuals with disabilities. However, existing interaction techniques often rely on manual input, which can be challenging or impossible for users with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework, 'GazeVR', which leverages eye-tracking technology to enable intuitive and hands-free interaction in VR environments. We evaluate the performance of GazeVR in a series of user studies, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction for participants with motor disabilities.

title: Efficient Indexing for Secondary Storage in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and velocity of data in distributed database systems necessitate efficient indexing mechanisms for secondary storage. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, 'SSTree', which leverages a hybrid combination of B-tree and LSM-tree structures to minimize I/O overhead and optimize query performance. Our evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that SSTree outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and storage efficiency. We also provide a detailed analysis of the trade-offs between SSTree and existing indexing methods.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Retrieval of Semi-Structured Data
paper_abstract: With the increasing prevalence of semi-structured data, traditional indexing techniques often struggle to balance query performance and storage efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'FlexIndex', which combines the benefits of inverted indexing and graph-based indexing. FlexIndex adaptively partitions the data into structured and unstructured regions, leveraging the strengths of each indexing method. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of JSON documents demonstrate that FlexIndex achieves a 2-3x speedup in query response time compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while reducing storage overhead by up to 40%.

title: Query Optimization for Scalable RDF Graph Processing in Cloud Storage
paper_abstract: The proliferation of large-scale RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs has led to significant challenges in query optimization for cloud-based storage systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RDF-QO', which leverages graph partitioning, parallel query execution, and adaptive indexing to improve query performance and scalability. We introduce a cost-based optimization model that minimizes data transfer and processing costs, and demonstrate its effectiveness on a real-world RDF dataset. Experimental results show that RDF-QO achieves up to 5x speedup over existing query optimization techniques for large-scale RDF graphs.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Modern search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from massive indexes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages semantic relationships between query terms to improve retrieval accuracy. HQE adaptively selects expansion terms based on their contextual relevance, and organizes them into a hierarchical structure to reduce redundancy and improve query representation. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision at top-10 retrieved documents.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Multimodal Sensor Data using Explainable Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Real-time anomaly detection in multimodal sensor data is crucial for ensuring the reliability and safety of complex systems. This paper proposes a novel approach based on explainable graph attention networks (EGATs) that can efficiently identify anomalies in high-dimensional, heterogeneous sensor data. Our EGAT model leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to learn rich representations of sensor relationships and detect anomalies. We also introduce a novel explanation module that provides interpretable insights into the anomaly detection process. Experimental results on a real-world industrial dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting anomalies with high accuracy and efficiency.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) policies to navigate complex environments. However, these policies are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise safety and reliability. We investigate the susceptibility of DRL policies to targeted attacks, crafting perturbations that manipulate the agent's perception of the environment. Our experiments demonstrate that even small perturbations can induce catastrophic failures in state-of-the-art DRL models. We propose a novel defense mechanism, 'RobustRL', which incorporates adversarial training and uncertainty quantification to improve resilience against attacks. Experimental results show that RobustRL significantly reduces the attack success rate, enhancing the safety of autonomous vehicles in adversarial scenarios.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Deep Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding is a fundamental problem in AI research, with applications in domains such as robotics and video games. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep graph neural networks (GNNs) to efficiently solve this problem. Our method, named GNN-Path, uses a hierarchical graph representation to model agent interactions and incorporates a attention mechanism to focus on critical regions of the environment. Experimental results demonstrate that GNN-Path outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of solution quality and computation time, making it a promising solution for real-world applications.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinated exploration is a critical challenge in multi-agent systems, where agents need to balance individual learning with collective progress. This paper presents a novel graph-based reinforcement learning approach, 'GraphCoExp', that enables agents to share knowledge and adapt to changing environments. By modeling agent interactions as a graph, we develop a decentralized exploration strategy that leverages graph-based clustering and community detection to identify regions of high uncertainty. Experiments on a range of multi-agent environments demonstrate that GraphCoExp outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of exploration efficiency and collective reward.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving optimal performance. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized algorithm, 'RL-TA', which enables agents to learn from their local interactions and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our method leverages a graph neural network to model agent relationships and a deep Q-network to learn optimal task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate that RL-TA outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Conversational Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to support older adults in daily tasks, but existing systems often fail to accommodate their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for developing inclusive voice assistants for older adults. We conducted a series of interviews and usability studies to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Based on our findings, we propose a set of conversational strategies that incorporate explicit guidance, error tolerance, and personalized feedback. A prototype system was developed and evaluated with 20 older adults, demonstrating improved task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Microblog Search
paper_abstract: Microblog search engines face the challenge of retrieving relevant information from a vast, noisy, and dynamic dataset. Recent advances in neural query expansion have shown promise in improving retrieval efficiency. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'NQE-Micro', which leverages a multi-task learning approach to jointly learn query expansion and ranking functions. Our experiments on a large-scale microblog dataset demonstrate that NQE-Micro outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and accuracy, while reducing the computational overhead of traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs has become increasingly important in human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and time segments, enabling the network to capture complex emotional patterns. Experimental results on the RECOLA dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and robustness to noisy inputs.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to decentralized task allocation for autonomous agents using graph-based reinforcement learning. We model the agent environment as a graph, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities and the graph structure. Our approach leverages a decentralized reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Reinforced Query Expansion for Improving Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Conventional query expansion methods often rely on term co-occurrence and relevance feedback, but may produce homogeneous search results. This paper introduces a novel reinforced query expansion approach, 'RQE-Div', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize search result diversity. By framing query expansion as a Markov decision process, RQE-Div adaptively selects expansion terms that maximize a diversity metric, while balancing precision and recall. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that RQE-Div outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of search result diversity, while maintaining competitive precision and recall.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it aims to bridge the gap between the user's query and the relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning-based approach for query expansion, which leverages the capabilities of neural networks to learn semantic relationships between words. Our approach, dubbed 'NeuroQE', uses a combination of word embeddings and recurrent neural networks to generate expanded queries that better capture the user's intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Ranking Models for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it helps to refine the search query and improve the retrieval accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion approach based on deep neural ranking models. Our method leverages the semantic relationships between words in the query and the document collection to generate effective expansion terms. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods. Our results show that the proposed method is particularly effective in retrieving relevant documents for ambiguous queries.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The proliferation of online documents has made efficient document ranking crucial for information retrieval systems. Existing methods rely on handcrafted features or simple graph-based models, which struggle to capture complex relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) for document ranking. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model document relationships at multiple scales, from individual keywords to hierarchical topic structures. Experimental results on the TREC-8 benchmark demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of nDCG@10 and MAP metrics, while reducing computational complexity.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Domain Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems often struggle to generalize across multiple domains and explain their responses. We propose a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) framework that addresses these limitations by modeling complex dialogue flows and incorporating domain-specific knowledge. Our approach leverages a novel attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant domain-specific contexts, enabling the model to generate more accurate and informative responses. We evaluate our approach on a multi-domain dialogue dataset, demonstrating significant improvements in response quality and explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and train a deep reinforcement learning agent to learn an optimal policy for selecting the best execution plan. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Blockchain-based Reputation Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require coordination mechanisms to ensure efficient and fair decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized reputation system based on blockchain technology to facilitate trustful interactions among autonomous agents. Our approach leverages smart contracts to maintain a tamper-proof reputation ledger, enabling agents to evaluate the credibility of their peers and make informed decisions. We evaluate our system through simulations, demonstrating improved coordination outcomes and resistance to malicious behavior compared to traditional centralized reputation systems.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering with Sparse Representations for High-Dimensional Data
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but its scalability is limited by the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel algorithm, 'SparseHClust', which leverages sparse representations to reduce the dimensionality of high-dimensional data. We introduce a hierarchical clustering framework that employes a sparse autoencoder to learn compact representations of the data, which are then clustered using a density-based clustering algorithm. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SparseHClust outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Planning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, planning and decision-making processes often involve complex interactions between agents. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) to facilitate explainable multi-agent planning. HiGAT integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical clustering to model agent relationships and identify key influencers. Our approach enables the discovery of interpretable planning strategies, improving transparency and trust in autonomous systems. Experimental results on a traffic management scenario demonstrate that HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of planning efficiency and explainability.

title: Deep Hierarchical Attention for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to jointly analyze text, image, and audio cues to determine the sentiment of a message. Existing MSA approaches often rely on early fusion or simple concatenation of modalities, neglecting the complex interactions between them. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'MHAtt', which captures intra- and inter-modal relationships through recursive attention mechanisms. We evaluate MHAtt on three MSA benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance and showcasing its robustness to modality imbalance and noisy data.

title: EyeTracking-Based Intelligent Interface for Enhanced User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but user experience can be compromised by cumbersome interfaces. This paper presents an innovative eye-tracking-based intelligent interface, 'EyeGuide', which leverages machine learning to predict user intentions and optimize interaction in VR environments. EyeGuide incorporates a deep neural network that analyzes user gaze patterns to infer semantic meaning, enabling intuitive and gesture-free navigation. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion time, and subjective experience, paving the way for more accessible and immersive VR applications.

title: Eye-Gaze-Based Implicit Authentication for Public Displays
paper_abstract: Public displays are increasingly prevalent, but their security remains a concern. This paper proposes an implicit authentication mechanism that leverages eye-gaze patterns to verify user identity. Our approach, 'GazeAuth', uses a deep learning model to analyze eye movements and detect anomalies indicative of unauthorized access. We evaluate GazeAuth on a dataset of 50 participants, achieving an accuracy of 93.2% and a false acceptance rate of 1.5%. The results demonstrate the feasibility of eye-gaze-based implicit authentication for public displays, offering a convenient and secure alternative to traditional authentication methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Disease Diagnosis
paper_abstract: Accurate disease diagnosis relies on the effective integration of multi-modal data from various sources, including medical images, electronic health records, and genomic data. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) framework that leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between multi-modal data. HiGAT learns to selectively focus on relevant features and interactions, leading to improved diagnostic performance. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate the superiority of HiGAT over state-of-the-art methods, with significant improvements in diagnosis accuracy and interpretability.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed main-memory databases have emerged as a promising solution for high-performance query execution. However, the complexity of query optimization in these systems has become a major bottleneck. This paper presents 'MemOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to efficiently explore the vast space of possible query plans. MemOpt uses a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach to adapt to changing workloads and optimize query performance. Experimental results on a 128-node cluster demonstrate that MemOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Conversational Strategies for Elderly Users
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent, but their usability for elderly users remains a concern. This paper investigates the impact of conversational strategies on the user experience of elderly individuals interacting with voice assistants. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65+, examining the effects of confirmation, clarification, and error recovery strategies on task completion rates, user satisfaction, and cognitive load. Our results show that a combination of these strategies significantly improves the user experience, and we provide design recommendations for developing more inclusive voice assistants.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of modern search engines, as it helps disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper presents a novel context-aware embedding approach, dubbed 'CAE-QE', which leverages both semantic and syntactic information to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method integrates a graph-based neural network with a contextualized language model to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and their surroundings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, especially for ambiguous and OCR-error-prone queries, when compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Scalable Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Imbalanced Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Online learning on imbalanced time-series data is a challenging problem, as it requires adapting to concept drifts and handling class imbalance. This paper proposes a novel online learning algorithm, 'ARISTA', which employs adaptive regularization to dynamically adjust the learning rate and regularization strength. We introduce a novel imbalance measure based on the Hellinger distance, which guides the adaptation of regularization. Experiments on several real-world datasets demonstrate that ARISTA outperforms state-of-the-art online learning methods in terms of accuracy and F1-score, especially in scenarios with severe class imbalance.

title: Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Uncertainty-Aware Reward Shaping
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents to maximize overall performance. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often operate under uncertainty, which can lead to suboptimal task allocation. This paper proposes a novel approach to task allocation that incorporates uncertainty-aware reward shaping. We introduce a probabilistic graphical model to represent the uncertainty in agent capabilities and task requirements, and develop a decentralized optimization algorithm to allocate tasks while maximizing expected reward. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient coalition formation. This paper presents a novel distributed algorithm, 'DCFA', which enables agents to form coalitions and allocate tasks in a decentralized manner. DCFA leverages graph neural networks to learn agent embeddings and a distributed constraint optimization framework to find optimal coalitions. We evaluate DCFA on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and robustness compared to centralized approaches.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Effective Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a promising paradigm for open-domain question answering. However, DPR models often struggle to effectively retrieve relevant passages due to the limited query context. In this paper, we propose a neural query expansion (NQE) approach to enhance the retrieval performance of DPR models. Our NQE framework leverages a combination of semantic and syntactic features to generate expanded queries, which are then used to re-rank the retrieved passages.
