Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the retrieval effectiveness of DPR models, especially for complex and multi-hop questions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, where the goal is to predict the labels of nodes based on their features and connections. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often suffer from computational bottlenecks and over-smoothing issues. To address these limitations, this paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT achieves superior performance and efficiency compared to existing GNN models, especially on large-scale graphs.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition theory to gesture-based interaction in virtual reality (VR). We designed a VR environment that simulates everyday tasks, such as cooking and puzzle-solving, and investigated how users' gestures influence their problem-solving strategies and cognitive load. Our results show that gestures can significantly impact cognitive processing, with users exhibiting improved performance and reduced mental workload when allowed to use gestures. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more intuitive and effective VR interfaces, and highlight the potential of embodied cognition principles to inform future HCI research.

title: Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Autonomous driving has made significant progress, but the lack of transparency in deep reinforcement learning (DRL) models hinders their adoption. This paper presents 'ExplaDrive', a novel framework that generates interpretable explanations for DRL policies in autonomous driving. We employ a generative adversarial network to learn a disentangled representation of driving scenarios, which is then used to generate visual and textual explanations for the agent's actions. Experiments on the CARLA simulator demonstrate that ExplaDrive improves the understanding of DRL models, leading to more trustworthy and safer autonomous driving systems.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has improved significantly in recent years, but user interaction remains a major bottleneck. We propose a novel gaze-based interaction system using deep learning, which enables users to seamlessly interact with virtual objects in AR environments. Our approach leverages a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect and track user gaze, and a recurrent neural network (RNN) to predict user intentions. We evaluate our system using a user study and demonstrate improved interaction accuracy and user experience compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have revolutionized human-computer interaction, but users with motor impairments often struggle to use these systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing inclusive gesture-based interfaces that cater to users with varying motor abilities. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 participants with motor impairments, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed framework, ' GestureAid', incorporates personalized gesture recognition, adaptive feedback, and compensatory strategies to enhance accessibility. Evaluations with 30 participants demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user experience.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated task allocation in multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'CATAR', where each agent learns to select tasks based on its own capabilities, task urgency, and the actions of other agents. Our algorithm incorporates a graph-based encoding of agent-task relationships and a hierarchical reward function that promotes cooperation and efficiency. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that CATAR outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Dynamic Schema Evolution
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing demands efficient indexing mechanisms to support rapid data ingestion and query processing. However, dynamic schema evolution in modern data sources poses significant challenges to traditional indexing approaches. This paper proposes 'DynIx', a novel indexing framework that adapts to schema changes in real-time. DynIx leverages a multi-layered indexing structure and a cost-based optimization algorithm to minimize re-indexing overhead and ensure query performance. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that DynIx outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time and data ingestion throughput.

title: Efficient Online Retrieval of Diverse Documents using Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Online retrieval of diverse documents is crucial in modern search engines, where users expect relevant and varied results. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'DivRank', which combines the strengths of deep learning and traditional IR techniques to efficiently retrieve diverse documents. DivRank utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global patterns in the document collection, and incorporates a diversity-promoting regularization term to minimize redundancy in the retrieved results. Experimental evaluation on several benchmark datasets demonstrates the superiority of DivRank over state-of-the-art methods in terms of both retrieval efficiency and result diversity.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Interaction Patterns
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the speech recognition performance and interaction patterns of older adults with voice assistants. Our results show that existing systems struggle to recognize speech from older adults, particularly those with mild cognitive impairments. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, including personalized speech recognition models, simplified dialogue flows, and multimodal feedback mechanisms. Our findings have implications for the development of more accessible and usable voice assistants for older adults.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Document Clustering using Adaptive Density-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Document clustering is a fundamental task in information retrieval, but existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity or poor scalability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical document clustering approach, 'HDC-AD', which leverages adaptive density-based methods to efficiently identify clusters of varying densities. HDC-AD incorporates a dynamic thresholding strategy that adjusts to the local density of each document, enabling effective clustering of documents with diverse characteristics. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HDC-AD over state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Data Warehouses using Column Store Indexing
paper_abstract: As data warehouses continue to scale, query optimization becomes increasingly crucial for efficient data retrieval. This paper presents a novel query optimization technique, 'CSI-Opt', which leverages column store indexing to reduce query latency in distributed data warehouses. We propose a cost-based optimization model that considers both data locality and storage efficiency, resulting in improved query performance and reduced storage costs. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that CSI-Opt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection for Multimodal Interfaces Using Convolutional Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Error detection in multimodal interfaces is crucial for improving user experience. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GazeErrorNet', which leverages convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to detect errors based on users' gaze patterns. We collect a dataset of gaze and user input data from a multimodal interface and train a CNN to classify errors. Our results show that GazeErrorNet achieves an accuracy of 92.5% in detecting errors, outperforming traditional rule-based approaches. We also explore the impact of gaze-based error detection on user satisfaction and interface usability.

title: Efficient Indexing of RDF Triples using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF (Resource Description Framework) in various domains has led to a surge in the volume of RDF triples, making efficient querying and indexing a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, HBFilter, which leverages hierarchical Bloom filters to accelerate triple pattern matching in RDF databases. Our approach exploits the hierarchical structure of RDF data to reduce the number of filter checks, resulting in improved query performance. Experimental evaluations on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that HBFilter outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinated exploration in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the exponential growth of the joint action space. This paper proposes a novel deep graph reinforcement learning (DGRL) framework that leverages graph neural networks to model the interactions between agents and their environment. Our approach, called CoEx, learns a distributed policy that maximizes the cumulative reward while encouraging agents to explore diverse regions of the state space. We evaluate CoEx on several benchmarks, including a robot navigation task, and demonstrate significant improvements in exploration efficiency and coordination compared to existing methods.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses a significant threat. This paper presents a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in DRL environments using graph-based anomaly detection. We model the agent's interactions with the environment as a graph and leverage graph convolutional networks to identify anomalous patterns indicative of attacks. Our approach is evaluated on several DRL benchmarks and demonstrates superior detection performance compared to existing methods. The proposed technique has far-reaching implications for improving the robustness of DRL systems in safety-critical applications.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various domains, including education, entertainment, and healthcare. However, user engagement remains a significant challenge in VR systems. This paper investigates the impact of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR. We designed and implemented a VR platform that generates avatars tailored to individual users' preferences and personality traits. Our user study involving 120 participants reveals that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, improved task performance, and enhanced overall VR experience. We also identify key factors influencing avatar personalization, including user demographics, personality, and cognitive styles.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning for Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) models have achieved impressive performance, but their decision-making processes remain opaque. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based framework, 'HARE', which leverages explainable reasoning to improve VQA performance and transparency. HARE employs a multi-scale attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant regions of the image and question, generating attention weights that provide insights into the model's decision-making process. Our experiments on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that HARE outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing interpretable explanations for its predictions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent cooperation is a crucial aspect of many real-world applications, such as autonomous vehicles and robotics. However, explaining the decision-making process of black-box models remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework, which leverages graph attention mechanisms and hierarchical reasoning to facilitate explainable cooperation among agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in various multi-agent scenarios, showcasing improved cooperation outcomes and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Graph Neural Networks using Graph Autoencoders
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable performance in various graph-based applications. However, they are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that manipulate the graph structure or node features to mislead the model. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks using Graph Autoencoders (GAEs). We design a GAE-based anomaly detector that learns to reconstruct the graph and identify perturbations introduced by adversarial attacks. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting attacks with high accuracy and F1-score, outperforming existing methods.

title: Adversarial Video Generation using Spatio-Temporal GANs with Attention Mechanism
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to adversarial video generation using spatio-temporal Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with an attention mechanism. Our proposed model, called STAGAN, incorporates a spatial attention module to focus on salient regions in the input frames and a temporal attention module to capture long-range dependencies. We evaluate STAGAN on multiple benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to generate realistic and diverse videos that can deceive state-of-the-art video classification models. Experimental results show that STAGAN outperforms existing video generation models in terms of visual quality and adversarial effectiveness.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Coordination for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time resource allocation in distributed systems is a challenging problem, particularly in scenarios where multiple agents with competing goals need to coordinate their actions. This paper presents a novel decentralized coordination framework that leverages machine learning and game theory to optimize resource allocation in real-time. Our approach, called 'MACRO', uses a hierarchical structure of agents that can adapt to changing system dynamics and negotiate resource allocation through a distributed auction mechanism. Experimental results on a simulated cloud computing platform demonstrate that MACRO achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and response time compared to existing approaches.

title: Neural Query Expansion with Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the quality of search results. This paper proposes a neural query expansion model that leverages context-aware embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to model the interactions between query terms, document keywords, and their surrounding contexts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our model outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly in scenarios with ambiguous or incomplete queries.

title: Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality through Eye-Tracking Based Interface Adaptation
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often suffer from user discomfort and fatigue due to inadequate interface design. This paper presents 'EyeGuide', a novel framework that leverages eye-tracking data to adapt VR interfaces in real-time. Our approach utilizes machine learning models to analyze user gaze patterns, identifying areas of visual attention and adjusting interface elements accordingly. We evaluate EyeGuide through a user study, demonstrating significant reductions in user fatigue and improvements in overall VR experience. The results suggest that eye-tracking-based interface adaptation can become a crucial component of next-generation VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex interactions between agents. While deep reinforcement learning has shown promise in this domain, interpretability remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces HAN-MAD, a hierarchical attention network that learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions, leading to more explainable decision-making. We evaluate HAN-MAD on a suite of cooperative and competitive multi-agent tasks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems in complex environments remains a challenging problem. This paper introduces a novel distributed reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph attention to facilitate cooperation among agents. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphCoop', enables agents to learn coordinated policies by attending to relevant neighbors in a graph-structured state space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphCoop in a variety of simulated environments, including traffic control and robotic swarm navigation, and show that it outperforms existing decentralized learning methods in terms of convergence speed and policy quality.

title: Designing Emotional Intelligence in Voice Assistants: A Study on User Experience
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their lack of emotional intelligence often leads to frustration and disappointment. This study explores the design of emotionally intelligent voice assistants that can recognize and respond to users' affective states. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving user interviews, surveys, and usability testing to identify key design factors that influence user experience. Our findings suggest that incorporating emotional intelligence in voice assistants can significantly improve user satisfaction and trust. We propose a set of design guidelines and a taxonomy of emotional intelligence in voice assistants, which can inform the development of more empathetic and human-centered AI systems.

title: Designing Tactile Feedback for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on visual and auditory cues, neglecting the importance of tactile feedback in creating an immersive experience. This paper presents a novel haptic feedback system, TactiVR, designed to enhance user engagement and realism in VR environments. We propose a taxonomy of haptic effects and develop a machine learning-based model to predict user preferences for tactile feedback in various VR scenarios. Our user study demonstrates a significant improvement in user satisfaction and presence in VR applications incorporating TactiVR, highlighting the potential for haptic feedback to revolutionize VR interaction.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents must coordinate to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework for cooperative task allocation, called CTARL. CTARL leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and interactions with its neighbors. We demonstrate the scalability and adaptability of CTARL in various simulated multi-agent scenarios, including search-and-rescue and package delivery tasks. Experimental results show that CTARL outperforms traditional task allocation algorithms, such as auctions and graph-based methods, in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized multi-agent planning framework that addresses the challenges of incomplete information and partial observability in complex systems. Our approach leverages hierarchical graph attention to reason about the relationships between agents and their local observations. We develop a distributed planning algorithm that iteratively refines the joint plan by propagating and aggregating information across the agent network. Experimental results on a set of benchmark problems demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving near-optimal solutions while reducing communication overhead.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Data using Hierarchical Semantic Indexing
paper_abstract: The proliferation of multi-modal data has necessitated the development of efficient retrieval methods. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Semantic Indexing (HSI), which leverages the semantic relationships between modalities to facilitate fast and accurate retrieval. HSI constructs a hierarchical index structure that captures the correlations between visual, textual, and audio features, enabling efficient pruning of the search space. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate that HSI outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and query latency.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient coordination to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-CAR', which enables autonomous vehicles to learn cooperative policies in a distributed manner. We introduce a novel communication protocol that facilitates the exchange of local observations and intentions among agents, thereby improving coordination and reducing collisions. Experimental results on a simulated traffic scenario demonstrate that MARL-CAR outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of throughput and safety.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) systems leverage audio, video, and text cues to analyze human emotions. However, existing approaches often rely on complex fusion strategies or ignore the hierarchical structure of emotions. We propose HAN-MER, a hierarchical attention network that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and emotional categories. Our model incorporates a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights modality-specific features based on their contribution to emotion recognition. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that HAN-MER outperforms state-of-the-art MER systems while reducing computational costs.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Drone Exploration
paper_abstract: Autonomous drone exploration is a challenging problem in AI research, particularly in complex and dynamic environments. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'DroneExplorer', which leverages a novel decomposition of the exploration task into sub-tasks to improve efficiency and adaptability. Our approach combines a high-level task planner with a low-level motion controller, allowing the drone to adapt to changing environmental conditions and customize its exploration strategy. Experimental results demonstrate that DroneExplorer outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various simulated scenarios, showcasing its potential for real-world applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Task Decomposition and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Effective coordination of multi-agent systems (MAS) is crucial in various applications, including robotics, smart grids, and traffic management. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating MAS through hierarchical task decomposition and reinforcement learning. We introduce a hierarchical framework that decomposes complex tasks into simpler sub-tasks, which are then allocated to agents using a reinforcement learning-based mechanism. Our approach enables agents to learn from experience, adapt to changing environments, and coordinate with each other to achieve global objectives. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in a simulated traffic management scenario, showcasing improved coordination and reduced congestion.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing using Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for various applications, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', specifically designed for column-store databases. ColOpt utilizes a combination of machine learning-based predicate selectivity estimation and a novel cost model that takes into account the column-store layout. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average query speedup of 3.2x. Furthermore, we show that ColOpt can effectively handle high-dimensional data and large-scale datasets.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Improving Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Conventional query expansion techniques often rely on heuristic-based methods, which may not effectively capture the nuances of user intent. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for query expansion, which learn to balance the trade-off between relevance and diversity in search results. Our approach, dubbed 'DIVERSE', utilizes a hierarchical DRL model to iteratively generate expansion terms that maximize a reward function combining relevance, novelty, and coverage metrics. Experimental results on a large-scale web search dataset demonstrate that DIVERSE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of search result diversity while maintaining comparable relevance scores.

title: Emotional Intelligence in Human-Computer Interaction: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Approach
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multimodal emotion recognition approach, integrating computer vision, speech processing, and physiological signals to detect users' emotional states in human-computer interaction. Our system, called EmoSense, leverages a deep learning framework to fuse features from facial expressions, speech tone, and electrodermal activity. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, demonstrating that EmoSense outperforms existing unimodal approaches in recognizing emotions, with an average accuracy of 85.2%. Our findings have implications for designing more empathetic and personalized human-computer interfaces.

title: Coordinated Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Temporal and Spatial Constraints
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenging problem of multi-agent task allocation in dynamic environments with temporal and spatial constraints. We propose a novel distributed algorithm, 'CoMA', which leverages a combination of graph-based methods and constraint satisfaction techniques to efficiently allocate tasks to agents. CoMA takes into account the agents' capabilities, task dependencies, and time-sensitive constraints to optimize the overall system performance. Experimental results on a set of benchmark problems demonstrate that CoMA outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches in terms of solution quality, computational efficiency, and scalability.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized approach to coalition formation for autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments. We introduce a distributed algorithm that enables agents to form coalitions in response to changing environmental conditions, such as task availability or resource scarcity. Our approach leverages a combination of machine learning and game-theoretic techniques to facilitate coalition formation, and we demonstrate its effectiveness in a series of simulations involving robotic agents performing complex tasks. Experimental results show that our approach leads to improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized coalition formation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Attention-based Keyword extraction
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity in recent years, but their performance is often hindered by the quality of the query. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using attention-based keyword extraction. Our method, called AttentiveQE, selectively incorporates keywords from the top-ranked documents to reformulate the query. We employ a neural network to learn the attention weights, which enables the model to focus on the most relevant keywords. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that AttentiveQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Bayesian Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic control is a challenging problem that requires efficient coordination of multiple agents. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages Bayesian reinforcement learning to coordinate multi-agent systems for optimized traffic signal control. Our approach, called 'BayesTraffic', models the uncertainty of traffic flow and incorporates domain knowledge to improve exploration-exploitation trade-offs. We evaluate BayesTraffic on a realistic traffic simulator and demonstrate significant improvements in reducing congestion and travel times compared to state-of-the-art approaches. Our results show that BayesTraffic can be applied to large-scale traffic networks, making it a promising solution for smart city infrastructure.

title: Efficient Incremental View Maintenance for Materialized Aggregates in Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Materialized aggregates are crucial for accelerating query performance in column-store databases. However, maintaining these views incrementally in the presence of continuous data updates poses significant challenges. This paper presents a novel approach, 'IVM-C', which leverages the column-store layout to minimize the overhead of incremental view maintenance. IVM-C employs a hybrid strategy that combines batch processing with micro-batching to achieve efficient and adaptive maintenance of materialized aggregates. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that IVM-C outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods by up to 3x in terms of maintenance time and 2x in terms of query performance.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Hierarchical Relations
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have revolutionized various AI applications, but existing methods struggle to capture hierarchical relations between entities. This paper introduces 'HREmbed', a novel framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn entity and relation representations. HREmbed incorporates a hierarchical relation encoder, which models the semantic dependencies between relations at different levels of abstraction. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HREmbed outperforms state-of-the-art methods in link prediction, entity classification, and question answering tasks.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and velocity of time-series data pose significant challenges to traditional indexing techniques in distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'TS-Index', designed to efficiently support real-time querying and analytics workloads. TS-Index leverages a hierarchical, partitioned indexing structure that adapts to the underlying data distribution and query patterns. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that TS-Index achieves up to 5x faster query response times and reduces storage overhead by 30% compared to existing indexing solutions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-Driven Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI-driven recommendation systems has raised concerns about their transparency and accountability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework that enables explainable recommendations. HGAT leverages graph neural networks to model user-item relationships and attention mechanisms to identify influential nodes. We introduce a novel explanation module that generates interpretable feature importance scores, enabling users to understand the reasoning behind recommended items. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in improving recommendation accuracy while providing meaningful explanations.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Hearing Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their usability for older adults with hearing impairments is limited. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant that caters to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and audiologists to identify key design requirements. Our proposed system, 'HearMe', incorporates multimodal input, personalized audio augmentation, and visual feedback to enhance speech recognition accuracy and user experience. A pilot study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Decision Support Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has gained significant attention in recent years, particularly in decision support systems (DSS) where model interpretability is crucial. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that integrates XAI principles into DSS. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between variables and hierarchically aggregates features to provide transparent and contextual explanations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in a real-world healthcare DSS, achieving improved model performance and enhanced explainability compared to state-of-the-art XAI methods.

title: Distributed Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel distributed multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for autonomous traffic signal control. Our method, referred to as 'Distributed Traffic Agent' (DTA), utilizes a decentralized architecture to enable real-time communication and coordination among agents controlling individual traffic signals. DTA incorporates a hybrid of deep Q-networks and graph neural networks to learn optimal traffic signal control policies, taking into account real-time traffic patterns, road network topology, and neighboring agents' actions. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate significant reductions in congestion and travel times compared to traditional, centralized traffic signal control strategies.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but often struggle with vocabulary mismatch between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion, incorporating knowledge graph embeddings to capture semantic relationships between entities and terms. Our method, called 'KEQE', learns to generate contextualized embeddings for query terms, which are then used to expand the query with related terms. Experimental results on a large-scale IR benchmark dataset show that KEQE significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural models, outperforming traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely on query expansion to retrieve relevant products. Traditional methods employ hand-crafted rules or statistical models, which can be limited by their simplicity. This paper proposes a deep neural network-based approach, 'DeepQE', which learns to expand queries by capturing semantic relationships between words and product attributes. Our experiments on a large e-commerce dataset show that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision and recall, while reducing computational overhead. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepQE in handling out-of-vocabulary queries and cold-start products.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Transfer Learning Approach
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in processing graph-structured data. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel transfer learning approach to generate targeted attacks on GNNs, leveraging the similarity in graph structures across different datasets. We introduce a graph attention mechanism to identify critical nodes and edges, and develop a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the attack strategy. Experimental results on multiple graph datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing the performance of state-of-the-art GNN models, highlighting the need for robustness mechanisms in graph-based ML applications.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems via Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems are critical for efficient search and retrieval in large-scale datasets. However, the query processing time in DIR systems can be significantly high due to the overhead of communication among nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach to reduce the query processing time in DIR systems. Our approach leverages the inherent structure of the data to create a hierarchical index, which enables efficient query routing and reduces the number of nodes involved in query processing. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves an average query processing time reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art DIR systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems (MTDS) have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, but optimizing query performance for multiple tenants remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans based on runtime statistics and tenant-specific workloads. Our experiments on a real-world MTDS dataset demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization, while adapting to changing workload patterns.

title: Coordinated Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is crucial for efficient collaboration. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignment and coordination among agents. We propose a hierarchical framework, CMATA, which learns to allocate tasks based on agent capabilities, task dependencies, and environmental constraints. Our experiments demonstrate that CMATA outperforms traditional methods in scenarios with varying agent availability and task complexity, showcasing its potential for real-world applications such as disaster response and robotic search and rescue.

title: Context-Aware Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document ranking methods rely on hand-crafted features and simplistic scoring functions, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel context-aware document ranking framework, 'DeepRank', which leverages deep neural networks to model complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant contextual information, enabling more accurate ranking of relevant documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate a significant improvement in mean average precision compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Lane Change Maneuvers
paper_abstract: Lane change maneuvers are a crucial aspect of autonomous vehicle navigation. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'LaneChanger', which utilizes a hierarchical architecture to learn lane change policies from raw sensor data. Our approach incorporates a high-level intention network to predict the driver's intent and a low-level control network to execute the lane change. We evaluate LaneChanger on a realistic simulation environment and demonstrate improved safety and efficiency compared to traditional rule-based approaches.

title: Efficient Indexing for Approximate Query Processing in NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: NoSQL databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale, heterogeneous data. However, efficient query processing remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'ApxIndex', that enables fast approximate query processing in NoSQL databases. ApxIndex leverages a probabilistic data structure to store summaries of data distributions, allowing for efficient estimation of query results. We demonstrate that ApxIndex achieves significant performance gains over traditional indexing methods while maintaining high accuracy. Experimental results on real-world datasets show that ApxIndex outperforms state-of-the-art solutions for range queries and aggregation operations.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Adaptive Trust Modeling for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, the presence of untrustworthy agents can compromise system performance. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that incorporates adaptive trust modeling to mitigate the impact of unreliable agents. Our approach leverages probabilistic graph theory to model agent trust and updates these models in real-time based on observed behavior. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our framework achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and reduces the influence of malicious agents compared to existing methods.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Document Retrieval: A Study on Query Expansion and Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have shown significant improvements in document retrieval tasks, but their performance can be limited by the quality of query representations and document embeddings. This paper explores the effectiveness of query expansion techniques in conjunction with neural ranking models and proposes a novel document embedding method, 'Doc2Vec+', which incorporates both local and global contextual information. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that our approach can lead to significant improvements in ranking accuracy, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for real-time traffic management using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'TRAFFIC-RL', where autonomous agents learn to optimize traffic signal control policies in a distributed manner. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model traffic network topology and incorporates real-time traffic data to adapt to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulation platform demonstrate that TRAFFIC-RL outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing congestion and travel times by up to 25%.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Context-Aware Embeddings for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems struggle to capture the nuances of complex medical queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel query expansion approach, 'MedEmb', which leverages context-aware embeddings to enrich the semantic representation of medical queries. MedEmb incorporates domain-specific knowledge graphs to contextualize medical entities and concepts, enabling more effective query expansion. Our experiments on the TREC Medical Retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art MIR systems.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Heterogeneous Preferences
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial task that enables agents to achieve common goals. However, existing approaches often assume homogeneous preferences among agents, which is unrealistic in many real-world scenarios. This paper presents a novel distributed coalition formation algorithm that accommodates heterogeneous preferences among agents. Our approach leverages a graph-based representation of agent relationships and preferences, and employs a decentralized optimization method to form coalitions that maximize the overall system utility. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world domains demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in forming high-quality coalitions that respect agent preferences.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but older adults often struggle to use them due to limitations in speech recognition, dialogue flow, and cognitive demands. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create inclusive voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted co-design workshops with 15 older adults and 5 caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and concise language, simple navigation, and personalized support. We propose a set of design guidelines and a prototype voice assistant, 'ElderAssist', which incorporates these insights. Our evaluation with 20 older adults shows significant improvements in usability, satisfaction, and perceived accessibility.

title: Scalable Incremental View Maintenance for Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Data warehouses rely on materialized views to accelerate query performance, but maintaining these views in the presence of frequent data updates is a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to incremental view maintenance, dubbed 'IVM-Scale', which exploits the properties of hierarchical data structures to minimize the overhead of view updates. We introduce a caching mechanism that selectively materializes intermediate results, reducing the number of necessary recomputations. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that IVM-Scale achieves an average speedup of 3.2x over traditional incremental view maintenance techniques, while scaling to large datasets.

title: Re-ranking with Query-Specific Dense Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus and generating answers. This paper proposes a novel re-ranking approach that leverages query-specific dense passage retrieval (QSDPR) to improve the accuracy of ODQA systems. We introduce a neural re-ranker that takes into account the semantic similarity between the query and passage representations, as well as the relevance of the passage to the query. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that our approach outperforms existing state-of-the-art ODQA models, achieving a 3.5% absolute improvement in exact match accuracy.

title: Deep Hierarchical Clustering for Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series (MTS) is crucial for various applications, including IoT and finance. This paper introduces 'HierAno', a deep hierarchical clustering framework that leverages the strengths of both autoencoders and density-based clustering. HierAno learns a hierarchical representation of MTS data, enabling the detection of anomalies at multiple scales and resolutions. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HierAno outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to noisy data.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for autonomous agents using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our proposed framework, TARL, enables agents to learn cooperative behaviors and allocate tasks efficiently in dynamic environments. We introduce a decentralized Q-network architecture that incorporates a novel attention mechanism, allowing agents to focus on relevant tasks and communicate effectively. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate that TARL outperforms traditional task allocation methods, achieving faster task completion rates and improved overall system efficiency.

title: Meta-Learning for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel meta-learning framework for multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model complex agent interactions. Our approach, called Meta-MARL-GNN, uses a meta-learning algorithm to adapt to new tasks and environments by learning a shared policy across multiple agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Meta-MARL-GNN in several MARL benchmarks, including traffic control and robot soccer, and show that it outperforms existing MARL methods in terms of learning speed and adaptability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Retrieval for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel neural retrieval approach for query expansion, which learns to generate relevant expansion terms from a dense vector space. Our model, called NeuralQE, leverages a dual-encoder architecture to jointly optimize query and document embeddings, and is trained using a contrastive loss function. Experimental results on several standard Benchmarks demonstrate that NeuralQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Attention-based Keyword Extraction for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search engines rely on effective document ranking to provide relevant results to users. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages neural attention-based keyword extraction to improve ranking accuracy. Our method, 'AttendRank', uses a transformer-based architecture to identify salient keywords in queries and documents, and incorporates these into a learning-to-rank framework. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that AttendRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models, achieving a 12% increase in mean average precision and a 9% increase in normalised discounted cumulative gain.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of many information retrieval systems, but it can be computationally expensive and prone to suboptimal results. This paper introduces a novel query-driven document expansion approach, which selectively incorporates relevant terms from the top-retrieved documents to augment the original query. Our approach leverages a neural ranking model to predict the relevance of each document and identify the most informative terms. Experimental results on the MS MARCO dataset demonstrate that our method significantly improves the retrieval efficiency while maintaining the accuracy of the top-ranked passages.

title: Optimizing Query Execution Plans for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution plans remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of distributed query optimization. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for distributed database systems. Our approach, called 'RL-QEP', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query execution plan based on the database system's workload and performance metrics. Experimental results show that RL-QEP outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on explicit user input, such as button presses or gesture recognition, which can be cumbersome and limiting. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction technique for VR using deep reinforcement learning. Our approach, 'GazeRL', leverages a neural network to predict user intentions from eye-tracking data and generates corresponding actions in the virtual environment. We evaluate GazeRL in a series of user studies, demonstrating improved interaction efficiency and reduced cognitive load compared to traditional input methods. Our results have implications for enhancing VR usability and accessibility in various domains, including gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking Models with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional term-based ranking models in information retrieval (IR) often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'DeepRankXE', which integrates query expansion techniques with a transformer-based architecture. Our approach leverages pre-trained language models to generate expanded query representations, which are then used to compute relevance scores between queries and documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepRankXE outperforms state-of-the-art IR models, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Accelerating Query Execution on Distributed Database Systems using GPU-Aware Query Optimization
paper_abstract: The proliferation of big data and the increasing complexity of queries have made query optimization a critical component of distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GPU-Opt', that leverages the parallel processing capabilities of Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) to accelerate query execution. We propose a GPU-aware cost model that estimates the execution time of queries on both CPU and GPU architectures, enabling the optimizer to make informed decisions about query execution. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GPU-Opt achieves an average speedup of 3.2x compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gesture recognition that adapts to the abilities of users with motor impairments. Our system, called AdaptiveGesture, uses a machine learning model to identify the user's motor capabilities and adjusts the gesture recognition algorithm accordingly. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with varying levels of motor impairment and found that AdaptiveGesture significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional systems. Our results have implications for the design of more inclusive and accessible human-computer interfaces.

title: Robustifying Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies against Adversarial Attacks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. In this paper, we propose a novel approach, 'AdvRLShield', which leverages adversarial training to robustify DRL policies against targeted attacks. We introduce a multi-objective optimization framework that balances policy performance and attack resilience. Experimental results on popular DRL benchmarks demonstrate that AdvRLShield significantly improves the robustness of DRL policies against various types of adversarial attacks, including observation and action perturbations.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding human-robot collaboration in these environments is crucial. This study explores the role of embodiment in VR on human trust and performance in collaborative tasks with robots. We designed an experiment where participants, immersed in VR, collaborated with a robotic arm to complete a puzzle. Our results show that participants who embodied the robot's movements exhibited higher trust and completed tasks more efficiently than those who did not. Furthermore, we found that embodiment increased the perceived sense of agency and social presence. These findings have implications for the design of VR-based human-robot collaboration systems, highlighting the importance of considering embodiment in these interactions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Robust Time Series Forecasting with Missing Values
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a fundamental problem in many applications, but it is often complicated by missing values. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that effectively handles missing values and improves forecasting accuracy. Our approach leverages a hierarchical structure to capture complex patterns at multiple scales, while incorporating a attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most relevant inputs. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean absolute error and mean squared error.

title: Exploring Semantic Query Expansion using Graph Attention Networks for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to semantic query expansion using graph attention networks (GATs). By modeling the query and document graphs as heterogeneous networks, our approach leverages attention mechanisms to identify salient entities and relationships, thereby enhancing the retrieval process. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for queries with ambiguous or complex semantics.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating the actions of multiple agents, such as traffic lights and autonomous vehicles. This paper proposes a novel framework that leverages reinforcement learning to train a decentralized multi-agent system for urban traffic management. Our approach, called 'TrafficMAgent', uses a graph-based representation of the traffic network and incorporates domain-specific knowledge to guide the learning process. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that TrafficMAgent outperforms traditional optimization methods in reducing congestion and travel times, while adapting to changing traffic conditions.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Heterogeneous Capabilities
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient allocation of tasks to agents with heterogeneous capabilities. This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework, 'HeteroAssign', which leverages graph neural networks to learn agent capabilities and task affinities. We develop a distributed optimization algorithm that minimizes task latency and maximizes system utility, while respecting agent capacity constraints. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HeteroAssign outperforms state-of-the-art centralized and decentralized approaches, achieving up to 30% reduction in task latency and 25% improvement in system utility.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Data Warehousing on Modern Storage Devices
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media platforms has led to an exponential growth in data volumes, necessitating efficient data warehousing solutions. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'FlashIndex', optimized for modern storage devices such as flash drives and solid-state drives. FlashIndex leverages the characteristics of these devices to reduce query latency and improve overall system performance. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that FlashIndex outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 30% in terms of query response time and up to 25% in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Databases using Adaptive Sampling
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large amounts of data and scale horizontally. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in such systems. This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize query performance by adaptively sampling the data distribution. Our method, called 'AdaSample', dynamically adjusts the sample size based on the query's selectivity and the underlying data distribution. We demonstrate that AdaSample outperforms existing sampling-based query optimization techniques in terms of query latency and accuracy, while also reducing the overhead of data transfer and processing.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph queries and the need to minimize communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using learned index structures, which can efficiently prune the search space and reduce query latency. We introduce a reinforcement learning-based framework that learns to optimize queries based on graph structural properties and query patterns. Experimental results on several real-world graph datasets demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel graph-based reinforcement learning framework, 'GraphCoord', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies in decentralized settings. We model the agent interactions as a graph and use graph neural networks to learn a shared policy that optimizes the global reward. Experimental results in simulated robotic soccer and autonomous driving scenarios demonstrate that GraphCoord outperforms existing decentralized reinforcement learning methods in terms of coordination efficiency and overall performance.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic signal control is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-TSC', that leverages decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (DEC-POMDPs) to model the traffic network. MARL-TSC employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant agents and states, reducing the computational complexity and improving the scalability of the approach. Experimental results on a real-world traffic dataset demonstrate that MARL-TSC outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reducing traffic congestion and travel times.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face significant challenges in efficiently retrieving relevant documents from large-scale, geographically dispersed repositories. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages semantic relationships between query terms to improve retrieval effectiveness. Our HQE method integrates a graph-based term clustering algorithm with a distributed indexing framework, enabling efficient query processing and document ranking. Experimental results on a large-scale DIR testbed demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall, while reducing query response times by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural-Based Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel neural-based approach, 'ContextEmb', which leverages contextualized embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and their surroundings. By integrating ContextEmb into a state-of-the-art retrieval framework, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets, particularly in scenarios where the original query is ambiguous or contains out-of-vocabulary terms.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gesture-based Authentication in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including gaming, education, and healthcare. However, the security of user authentication in VR environments remains a significant concern. This paper investigates the effectiveness of gesture-based authentication in VR, focusing on the trade-off between security and usability. We designed and implemented a gesture-based authentication system, 'VR-GestureAuth', and evaluated its performance with 30 participants. Our results show that VR-GestureAuth achieves a high authentication accuracy of 95.6% while maintaining a relatively low false rejection rate of 12.5%. Furthermore, our user study reveals that participants prefer gesture-based authentication over traditional password-based methods in VR environments.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploratory Study on Accented Speech Recognition
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their performance on accented speech remains a significant concern. This paper presents an empirical study investigating the recognition accuracy of three popular voice assistants on speech samples from non-native English speakers. We recruited 30 participants from diverse linguistic backgrounds and recorded their interactions with the voice assistants. Our results show that the current systems struggle to recognize accented speech, especially for less represented accents. We propose a set of design guidelines for developing more inclusive voice assistants, including the use of accent-agnostic training data and personalized adaptation mechanisms.

title: Designing Augmented Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize assistive technologies for users with visual impairments. However, designing accessible AR interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel framework for creating inclusive AR experiences, focusing on auditory and haptic feedback. We conducted user studies with visually impaired participants to inform the design of an AR-based navigation system, which was then evaluated in a controlled experiment. Results show significant improvements in navigation accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing assistive technologies. Our framework provides a foundation for future research on accessible AR interface design.

title: Enabling Real-Time Query Optimization with Learned Index Structures in Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Traditional query optimization techniques in relational databases rely on manual indexing and rule-based optimization, leading to suboptimal performance and high maintenance costs. This paper proposes 'QLearn', a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to enable real-time query optimization. QLearn uses a neural network to predict optimal index structures based on query patterns and database statistics, achieving up to 3x query performance improvement and 2x indexing space reduction compared to state-of-the-art techniques. We evaluate QLearn on various real-world datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in adaptively optimizing query performance under changing workloads.

title: Designing Emotional Feedback Mechanisms for Virtual Reality-based Social Skills Training
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in social skills training for individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and other conditions. However, inadequate emotional feedback can hinder the effectiveness of these interventions. This paper presents an exploratory study on designing emotional feedback mechanisms for VR-based social skills training. We propose a novel affective computing framework that incorporates machine learning-based emotion recognition and adaptive feedback generation. Our user study with 20 participants with ASD demonstrates that our approach leads to improved emotional regulation and social skills performance compared to traditional VR training. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more empathetic and effective VR-based interventions.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must dynamically allocate tasks to optimize system performance. This paper presents a novel approach using autonomous agents that learn to allocate tasks through reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'AgentRL', which enables agents to adapt to changing task demands and environmental conditions. Our approach leverages a hybrid reward function that balances task completion, agent utilization, and communication overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentRL outperforms traditional task allocation algorithms in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria: An Exploratory Study on Speech Recognition and Adaptive Feedback
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and intelligibility, often face difficulties when interacting with voice-based interfaces. This paper presents an exploratory study on the design of adaptive speech recognition systems and personalized feedback mechanisms to enhance the usability and accessibility of voice-based interfaces for users with dysarthria. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants with dysarthria, exploring the effects of speech recognition accuracy, feedback types, and user preferences on interaction experiences. Our results highlight the importance of user-centered design and the need for more inclusive and adaptive speech recognition systems.

title: Gaze-Aware Adaptive Interfaces for Augmented Reality Systems
paper_abstract: As Augmented Reality (AR) systems become increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for interfaces that can adapt to user behavior and preferences. This paper presents a novel gaze-aware adaptive interface framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to dynamically adjust AR content and layout based on user gaze patterns. Our approach incorporates a probabilistic model of user attention to predict gaze fixations and saccades, enabling the system to proactively optimize content rendering and reduce visual clutter. User studies demonstrate significant improvements in user engagement, task completion time, and overall AR experience.

title: QR-Tree: A Novel Indexing Structure for Efficient Query Processing in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have become increasingly popular in recent years, but existing indexing structures are often optimized for disk-based storage, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes QR-Tree, a novel indexing structure designed specifically for main-memory databases. QR-Tree leverages the properties of modern CPU architectures to minimize memory access patterns and reduce query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a range of real-world workloads demonstrates that QR-Tree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing structures by up to 3x in terms of query throughput and response time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Disease Diagnosis
paper_abstract: Accurate disease diagnosis is often hindered by the complexity of integrating multiple data modalities. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to integrate multi-modal data from electronic health records, medical imaging, and genomic data. HGAT learns to focus on relevant features and relationships across modalities, enabling accurate diagnosis and identification of disease subtypes. Experiments on a large-scale cancer diagnosis dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12% improvement in diagnosis accuracy.

title: Scalable Concurrency Control for Real-Time Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time database systems (RTDBS) require predictable and efficient concurrency control mechanisms to ensure timely access to shared data. This paper presents a novel scalable concurrency control algorithm, 'RT-CC', which leverages a hybrid approach combining optimistic and pessimistic concurrency control techniques. RT-CC dynamically adjusts its strategy based on system workload and data contention, resulting in improved throughput and reduced latency compared to traditional locking-based approaches. Experimental evaluation on a real-world RTDBS benchmark demonstrates the effectiveness of RT-CC in supporting high-performance and low-latency transactions.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing in IoT Environments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of time-series data, demanding real-time data warehousing solutions that can efficiently support complex queries. This paper introduces 'RT-IOTA', a novel indexing framework that leverages a hybrid approach combining column-store indexing and in-memory caching. We propose an adaptive partitioning strategy that dynamically adjusts to changing data velocities and query patterns, ensuring consistent query performance and minimizing storage overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate RT-IOTA's ability to support real-time analytics while achieving significant performance gains over state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant challenges in terms of data retrieval efficiency, particularly in scenarios involving large-scale datasets and high query volumes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'Distributed Hierarchical Indexing' (DHI), which leverages a combination of local and global indexing mechanisms to improve query performance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DHI through extensive experiments on a real-world dataset, showcasing improvements in query response time and system scalability compared to traditional indexing techniques.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Learning-based Query Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
