paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to refine the original query to better capture user intent. While traditional QE methods rely on hand-crafted rules or statistical models, we propose a deep learning-based approach that learns query embeddings to effectively expand queries. Our model, dubbed QE-Embed, leverages a neural network to project queries into a dense vector space, where semantic relationships between terms are preserved. The learned embeddings are then used to select expansion terms, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc track demonstrate that QE-Embed outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, showcasing the effectiveness of deep learning in IR applications.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to real-time traffic management using coordinating autonomous agents. Our method, called Hierarchical Autonomous Traffic Management (HATM), leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning to enable agents to adapt to changing traffic conditions and coordinate with each other to optimize traffic flow. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HATM in simulations of a real-world traffic network, showing significant reductions in travel time and congestion. Our approach has the potential to revolutionize traffic management systems, enabling them to respond dynamically to changing traffic conditions and improve overall traffic efficiency.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Learning-based Eye-Tracking
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems require intuitive and natural interaction methods. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework for VR, leveraging deep learning-based eye-tracking to accurately estimate user intent. Our approach utilizes a convolutional neural network (CNN) to analyze eye movement patterns and classify gaze targets in real-time. We evaluate our system using a VR-based puzzle game and demonstrate significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user experience compared to traditional controller-based methods.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a given question. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which leverages both coarse-grained document-level and fine-grained passage-level ranking to improve retrieval efficiency. We introduce a dual-encoder architecture that jointly optimizes document and passage representations, enabling the model to capture both global and local context. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Multimodal Approach
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel, multimodal approach to designing conversational interfaces that are accessible and engaging for older adults. We propose a framework that integrates speech, gesture, and facial expression recognition to facilitate more natural and intuitive interactions. Our user study with 30 older adults (ages 65-85) shows that the proposed interface significantly improves task completion rates, reduces errors, and enhances user satisfaction compared to traditional text-based interfaces. We also provide design guidelines and recommendations for incorporating accessibility features in conversational systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach for efficient query optimization in multi-tenant environments. Our method, called GraphOpt, leverages the structural properties of query graphs to identify optimal index configurations. We evaluate GraphOpt on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to traditional indexing techniques, with up to 3x reduction in query latency and 2x reduction in storage overhead.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has made significant strides in recent years, but the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We designed a custom VR platform with varying levels of haptic feedback and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user engagement, reduces motion sickness, and enhances overall user satisfaction. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including stimulus type and intensity. Our findings have important implications for the design of future VR systems.

title: Scalable Agent-Based Adaptive Resource Allocation for Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel agent-based framework for adaptive resource allocation in distributed systems. Our approach leverages autonomous agents to dynamically allocate resources based on real-time system monitoring and prediction. We propose a novel decentralized coordination mechanism that enables agents to adapt to changing system conditions, ensuring efficient resource utilization and improved system performance. Experimental results demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of our approach in various distributed system scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become increasingly prevalent in online platforms, yet their opacity often raises concerns about bias and fairness. This paper introduces 'HierGAT', a hierarchical graph attention network that incorporates both item and user relationships to provide interpretable recommendations. We demonstrate that HierGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models on three benchmark datasets, while offering visual explanations for its suggestions through attention weights. Our approach enables users to understand the reasoning behind recommendations, fostering trust and transparency in AI-driven systems.

title: Gaze-Based Emotional Intelligence for Virtual Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotional intelligence is crucial in human-human interaction, but its significance has been overlooked in virtual human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based framework, 'EmoGaze', which enables virtual agents to recognize and respond to users' emotions in real-time. We develop a deep learning model that leverages eye-tracking data to infer users' emotional states and generates empathetic responses. Our user study demonstrates that EmoGaze significantly improves user engagement and satisfaction in virtual interactions, paving the way for more human-like HCI.

title: Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel real-time object detection framework for autonomous vehicles, leveraging hierarchical attention networks to improve detection accuracy and efficiency. Our approach incorporates a multi-scale feature fusion mechanism, which adaptively weights features from different scales and levels of abstraction. We also propose a spatio-temporal attention module that selectively focuses on relevant regions and frames, reducing computational overhead. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that our framework achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of precision, recall, and speed, making it suitable for real-world autonomous driving applications.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness in Short-Text Search
paper_abstract: Short-text search is a challenging problem in information retrieval, where the brevity of queries often leads to poor retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our model, dubbed 'DeepQE', uses a combination of word embeddings and convolutional neural networks to generate expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short queries, when compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems in complex environments remains a challenging problem. We propose a novel approach that integrates reinforcement learning with graph attention mechanisms to enable effective collaboration among agents. Our framework, 'MA-GAT', learns to represent the agent interactions as a graph, which is then used to compute attention weights for each agent. These weights facilitate the selection of optimal actions that balance individual and collective goals. Experimental results on a simulated traffic management scenario demonstrate that MA-GAT outperforms existing methods in terms of overall system efficiency and adaptability to changing conditions.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in various applications, but their accessibility for users with visual impairments remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an accessible conversational interface, 'TalkEase', which leverages natural language processing and audio-based feedback to facilitate intuitive interaction. We conducted a series of usability studies with visually impaired participants, resulting in a set of design guidelines that improve the overall user experience. Our evaluation demonstrates that TalkEase significantly reduces errors and increases user satisfaction compared to traditional screen reader-based interfaces.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Feedback for Enhanced User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to provide effective user feedback, leading to user frustration and disorientation. We present 'GazeGuide', a gaze-based adaptive feedback framework that leverages eye-tracking data to dynamically adjust feedback strategies in real-time. Our approach incorporates machine learning models to predict user attention and intent, and generates personalized feedback cues that adapt to individual user behavior. A comprehensive user study demonstrates that GazeGuide significantly improves user performance, reduces cognitive load, and enhances overall user experience in VR environments.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex systems is challenging due to the exponential growth of possible interactions. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model agent interactions at multiple scales. HGAT enables efficient coordination of agents by learning hierarchical representations of their relationships and adapting to changing environmental conditions. Our experiments on a simulated urban traffic control scenario demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of coordination efficiency and adaptability.

title: Co-Designing Augmented Reality Interfaces for People with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize assistive technology for people with visual impairments. However, current AR interfaces are often inaccessible or unusable for this population. This paper presents a co-design approach to developing AR interfaces that are tailored to the needs and preferences of visually impaired users. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with visually impaired individuals, resulting in the development of a novel AR-based navigation system that leverages audio and haptic feedback. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in navigation efficiency and user satisfaction compared to existing AR systems.

title: Real-time Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Improving Search Engine Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in search engines, as it significantly impacts the retrieval performance. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and rule-based approaches, which often fail to capture the complexities of natural language queries. We propose a novel framework, 'DeepQE', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query expansion policy. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical neural network to model the query-document interaction and learns to select the most informative expansion terms in real-time. Experiments on a large-scale Web search dataset demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin, achieving a 12.5% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Real-time Decision-Making in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles (AVs) become increasingly prevalent, ensuring their decision-making processes are transparent and explainable is crucial for safety and trust. This paper presents a novel model-agnostic explainability framework, 'AVEX', designed for real-time decision-making in AVs. AVEX leverages a combination of attention-based feature importance and counterfactual analysis to provide interpretable explanations for the vehicle's actions. Our experiments on a large-scale AV dataset demonstrate that AVEX can provide accurate explanations within milliseconds, making it suitable for real-time deployment. We also show that AVEX can improve driver trust and understanding of AV decision-making through user studies.

title: Optimizing Query Performance through Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant performance challenges due to data partitioning and replication. This paper presents an adaptive indexing technique, 'DynIndex', that dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distributions. DynIndex utilizes a cost-benefit analysis to select the most effective indexing strategy for each query, minimizing overhead while maximizing query performance. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database demonstrate that DynIndex achieves up to 3x improvement in query response time compared to traditional static indexing approaches.

title: Multi-Version Concurrency Control for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component in various industries, but it poses significant challenges in maintaining data consistency and concurrency control. This paper presents a novel multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) protocol, 'RT-MVCC', designed specifically for real-time data warehousing. RT-MVCC leverages a combination of timestamp-based and serialization-based approaches to ensure high concurrency, low latency, and strong consistency guarantees. We evaluate RT-MVCC using a comprehensive simulation framework and demonstrate its superiority over existing MVCC protocols in terms of throughput, latency, and data freshness.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness Enhancement in Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. This paper presents a novel adversarial training framework, 'AdvRL', which leverages a min-max optimization strategy to enhance the robustness of DRL policies. We demonstrate that AdvRL can effectively defend against both white-box and black-box attacks, while maintaining competitive performance on standard benchmarks. Our extensive experiments on Atari games and robotic control tasks show that AdvRL can significantly improve the robustness of DRL agents, highlighting its potential for real-world applications.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles operating in uncertain environments face significant challenges in adapting to changing conditions. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'DRVN', which leverages uncertainty-aware exploration and robustification techniques to improve control policies. We incorporate a probabilistic model of the environment, allowing the agent to reason about uncertainty and adjust its exploration strategy accordingly. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving platform demonstrate that DRVN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both safety and efficiency in uncertain scenarios.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are widely used in modern applications, but query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes an adaptive replication strategy, 'AdaRep', that dynamically adjusts data replication based on query patterns and system workloads. We develop a cost model that incorporates query frequency, data access patterns, and network latency to determine optimal replication configurations. Experimental results on a real-world DDS deployment show that AdaRep improves query response times by up to 35% and reduces average query latency by 20% compared to traditional static replication schemes.

title: Designing Accessible Voice-Based Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria often face significant barriers when interacting with voice-based interfaces due to speech recognition errors. This paper presents 'AssistVoice', a novel framework that leverages speech therapy principles to adapt voice interfaces for users with dysarthria. We propose a set of acoustic and prosody-based features to detect and accommodate user-specific speech patterns, and develop a personalized error correction mechanism. Our user study with 20 participants with dysarthria shows that AssistVoice significantly improves speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework, which integrates graph neural networks with hierarchical attention mechanisms. HAGNN learns to represent users and items as graphs, capturing complex relationships and dependencies. The hierarchical attention mechanism enables the model to focus on relevant features and nodes, providing interpretable explanations for the recommended items. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in improving recommendation accuracy and providing meaningful explanations.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Cognitive Load on User Performance in Gesture-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular in recent years, but their impact on user performance and cognitive load remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the effects of cognitive load on user performance in gesture-based interfaces. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built gesture recognition system and a cognitive load manipulation task. Our results show that high cognitive load significantly impairs user performance, leading to increased error rates and decreased gesture recognition accuracy. We also found that users' cognitive load levels can be accurately predicted using machine learning models trained on physiological and behavioral data. Our findings have important implications for the design of gesture-based interfaces and highlight the need for cognitive load-aware interaction techniques.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for optimal resource utilization and system performance. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'DMARL-TA', which enables autonomous agents to learn dynamic task allocation policies in real-time. We introduce a novel agent communication protocol that facilitates information sharing and coordination among agents, while respecting system constraints and resource limitations. Experimental results on a simulated distributed system demonstrate that DMARL-TA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and system throughput.

title: Exploring Gesture-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize industrial workflows, but effective human-computer interaction remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a gesture-based interaction framework for AR in industrial settings, which leverages machine learning algorithms to recognize and interpret worker gestures. We conducted a user study with 20 participants from a manufacturing background, demonstrating improved task efficiency and reduced errors compared to traditional controller-based interaction methods. Our approach enables workers to focus on the task at hand, freeing them from the constraints of traditional input devices.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications. However, query optimization for DDS remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of distributed query plans and the need to balance performance and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We design a DRL framework that learns to optimize query plans for DDS by interacting with a simulated environment. Our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques in terms of query latency and resource utilization on a real-world dataset.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to cooperative task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities must collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. Our method leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn a task allocation policy that optimizes global performance while respecting individual agent constraints. We introduce a hierarchical graph representation that captures both inter-agent dependencies and task requirements, enabling the GCN to learn effective task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rate and overall system efficiency compared to existing allocation strategies.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for multi-agent coordination. Our approach combines a high-level, graph-based policy for task assignment with low-level, deep Q-networks for individual agent control. We evaluate our method in a simulated warehouse management scenario, demonstrating improved coordination and task completion rates compared to traditional decentralized DRL approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalized Acoustic Models for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their effectiveness is often hindered by acoustic variability among users, particularly older adults. This paper presents a novel approach to designing inclusive voice assistants by creating personalized acoustic models tailored to individual users. We collect a large dataset of speech samples from older adults and propose a transfer learning framework that adapts a pre-trained acoustic model to each user's vocal characteristics. Our evaluation shows that personalized models significantly improve speech recognition accuracy and reduce error rates, enhancing the overall user experience for older adults.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-time Semantic Search in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs have become a crucial component of many AI applications, but their scale and complexity pose significant challenges for real-time semantic search. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'KG-Index', which leverages graph neural networks to learn compact, semantic representations of entities and relations. We propose a hierarchical indexing scheme that efficiently supports complex queries with multiple predicates and variables. Experimental results on large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that KG-Index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in query response time while achieving comparable accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, but existing approaches struggle to effectively integrate and process multi-modal data. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages graph-based representations to model complex relationships between facial expressions, speech features, and textual inputs. Our approach hierarchically aggregates attention weights across modalities, enabling the model to selectively focus on salient features for improved emotion recognition. Experimental results on the recently released Multi-Modal Emotion Dataset (MMED) demonstrate the superiority of HAGNN over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5% across six emotions.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Conversational Search using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to retrieve relevant information through multi-turn dialogues. However, processing complex and context-dependent user queries remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel deep query reformulation approach, 'HierQR', which leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to model query semantics and contextual relationships. HierQR learns to identify key entities, intent, and semantic roles in the query and generates a refined, context-aware representation that improves retrieval performance. Experiments on a large conversational search dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HierQR in reducing query ambiguity and enhancing search accuracy.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. Our approach enables agents to learn an optimal task assignment policy in a distributed manner, without requiring a centralized controller or explicit communication between agents. We introduce a hierarchical deep reinforcement learning architecture that incorporates both local and global reward functions, allowing agents to adapt to changing task demands and system dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated multi-robot system demonstrate significant improvements in task completion efficiency and system robustness compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Robustness of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks via Input Preprocessing
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. This paper proposes a novel input preprocessing technique, 'DefendNet', that enhances the robustness of DNNs against such attacks. DefendNet applies a hierarchical transformation to the input data, which detects and suppresses perturbations introduced by adversarial attacks. We evaluate the efficacy of DefendNet on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superior performance compared to existing defense mechanisms. Our approach achieves a significant improvement in model accuracy under attack, while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Effective traffic signal control is crucial for reducing congestion and improving urban mobility. This paper presents a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HMAC', for autonomous traffic signal control. HMAC consists of two levels: a high-level policy that coordinates the traffic signals at adjacent intersections and a low-level policy that optimizes the signal timing at each individual intersection. We evaluate HMAC using a realistic traffic simulator and demonstrate significant improvements in traffic flow and reduced congestion compared to traditional fixed-time and adaptive signal control strategies.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Real-time Data Warehousing using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern data analytics. However, traditional indexing techniques often struggle to meet the performance demands of real-time query processing. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to optimize query performance. We introduce a new indexing technique, 'QuickIndex', which uses machine learning models to predict the optimal indexing strategy for a given query workload. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale real-time data warehousing system demonstrates that QuickIndex outperforms traditional indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency, while also reducing index maintenance costs by up to 50%

title: Deep Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques struggle with heterogeneous document collections, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant terms from the collection into the query representation. We show that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall. Furthermore, we demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepQE in handling out-of-vocabulary queries and documents with varying semantic complexity.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding using Graph Neural Networks and Hierarchical Planning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding is a complex problem in AI, particularly in scenarios with large numbers of agents and dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel approach that combines graph neural networks (GNNs) with hierarchical planning to efficiently solve MAPF problems. Our method, called GNN-HP, uses GNNs to learn agent representations and graph embeddings, which are then used to guide a hierarchical planner to find near-optimal solutions. Experimental results on various benchmark scenarios demonstrate that GNN-HP outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of solution quality and computation time, making it a promising approach for real-world applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval using Deep Semantic Representation
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval remains a challenging task in modern search engines, mainly due to the lack of contextual information. This paper proposes a novel approach for query expansion using deep semantic representation. Our method, dubbed 'SemExpan', leverages a pre-trained language model to generate a set of semantically similar keywords for a given query. We then incorporate these keywords into a probabilistic retrieval framework, allowing the model to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and document content. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries on these databases remains a challenging problem due to the inherent complexity of graph data and the distributed nature of the system. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning. We present a framework that learns to optimize queries by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution time. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world graph dataset shows that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Networks with Query-Document Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'QRank', that leverages query-document interaction to improve the accuracy and efficiency of document ranking in information retrieval. QRank employs a deep neural network to learn a dense representation of queries and documents, and incorporates a novel attention mechanism to capture their interaction. We conduct experiments on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate that QRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision and mean reciprocal rank. We also analyze the computational efficiency of QRank and show that it can be effectively deployed in real-world search engines.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Effective Document Retrieval in Hierarchical Collections
paper_abstract: Hierarchical collections, such as file systems or digital libraries, pose significant challenges for traditional IR systems. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, HiRank, which leverages the hierarchical structure to improve document retrieval. HiRank incorporates a graph attention mechanism to capture semantic relationships between documents and their hierarchical contexts. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HiRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models on hierarchical collections, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Efficient Retrieval in Neural Search Engines
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity for their ability to capture semantic relationships in queries and documents. However, they often struggle with complex or ambiguous queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a deep query reformulation approach, 'NeuQR', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to generate a set of semantically diverse query variants. These variants are then used to retrieve a diverse set of candidate documents, which are subsequently re-ranked using a neural scoring model. Experiments on the TREC Deep Learning track demonstrate that NeuQR significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, particularly for difficult queries, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval using Hierarchical Cluster-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: The proliferation of large-scale distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems has necessitated the development of efficient indexing techniques to facilitate fast query processing. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical cluster-based indexing approach, HCI+, which leverages the inherent structural properties of distributed datasets to reduce query latency. HCI+ employs a multi-level clustering strategy that adaptively partitions the index into hierarchical clusters, enabling efficient query routing and pruning. Experimental evaluations on real-world web datasets demonstrate that HCI+ outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 35% reduction in query response time while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency with Adaptive Index Skipping in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: In large-scale distributed information retrieval (IR) systems, efficient query processing is crucial for providing timely results to users. This paper presents an adaptive index skipping technique, called 'AISkip', which dynamically adjusts the number of index segments to skip during query execution. AISkip leverages statistical analysis of query patterns and index structures to minimize unnecessary disk I/O and reduce query latency. Our experiments on a real-world web corpus demonstrate that AISkip achieves up to 30% improvement in query response time compared to traditional static index skipping approaches, while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy.

title: Real-time Human Pose Estimation using Graph Neural Networks and Skeletal Constraints
paper_abstract: Human pose estimation is a fundamental task in computer vision, with applications in fields like healthcare, robotics, and entertainment. This paper introduces 'PoseGraph', a real-time pose estimation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model the intricate relationships between body joints. By incorporating skeletal constraints and a novel bone-length regularization term, PoseGraph achieves state-of-the-art performance on popular benchmarks like Human3.6M and MPI-INF-3DHP. Our approach enables accurate and efficient pose estimation, even in challenging scenarios with occlusions or limited sensor data.

title: Designing Adaptive Assistive Interfaces for Individuals with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Individuals with dyslexia often face challenges when interacting with digital interfaces. This paper presents an adaptive assistive interface framework, 'DyslexiaAid', which leverages machine learning-based text analysis and user modeling to provide personalized support for users with dyslexia. Our approach incorporates real-time text simplification, font and color adjustments, and dynamic hinting to enhance readability and comprehension. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in reading speed and accuracy, as well as increased user satisfaction, when using DyslexiaAid compared to standard interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant text segments containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages both syntactic and semantic relationships between query terms to generate an expanded query representation. Our HQE method combines phrase-level expansion with entity-based expansion, enabling more effective passage ranking and reducing the number of retrieved passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% improvement in top-1 accuracy while reducing the average number of retrieved passages by 30%.

title: Efficient Explainability Methods for Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but the lack of transparency in learned policies hinders trust and understanding. This paper presents a novel explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which generates model-agnostic, interpretable explanations for DRL policies. We propose a combination of feature importance and attention-based techniques to identify key states, actions, and temporal dependencies driving policy decisions. Experimental results on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Explain in providing insightful explanations, improving policy understanding, and facilitating debugging.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Task-Oriented Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We propose a novel framework for coordinating heterogeneous task-oriented agents using hierarchical reinforcement learning. Our approach, called Hierarchical Task Assignment and Coordination (HTAC), employs a two-level hierarchy of agents: high-level task managers and low-level skill executors. Task managers learn to assign tasks to skill executors based on their capabilities and the current environment, while skill executors learn to execute tasks using reinforcement learning. We evaluate HTAC in a simulated robotics domain and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced coordination overhead compared to flat, non-hierarchical approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Column Store Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and complexity of big data has led to a growing need for efficient query optimization techniques. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using column store indexing, which leverages the benefits of columnar storage to reduce query execution times. We propose a cost-based optimization framework that incorporates a probabilistic model to estimate query selectivity and a machine learning-based indexing strategy to adapt to changing data distributions. Experimental results on a large-scale analytics workload demonstrate a significant reduction in query execution times and improved resource utilization compared to traditional row store indexing.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become increasingly complex, with large user-item graphs and cold start problems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that efficiently captures long-range dependencies and node relationships. We introduce a hierarchical pooling mechanism that aggregates node features at multiple scales, enabling accurate and scalable recommendation generation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in recall and precision over state-of-the-art graph-based methods, with reduced computational overhead.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Contextualized Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to refine user queries to better capture their information needs. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages deep contextualized embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms. Our approach, dubbed 'ConEx', combines BERT-based embeddings with a graph-based modeling technique to identify salient expansion terms. Experimental results on several TREC benchmarks demonstrate that ConEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, yielding significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Evaluation of Robustness Measures
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks, but their robustness against adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of existing robustness measures for GNNs, including graph pruning, adversarial training, and input preprocessing. We propose a novel attack method, 'Graph-FGSM', which leverages the fast gradient sign method to perturb graph structures and node features. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that Graph-FGSM outperforms existing attacks in terms of attack success rate and transferability across different GNN architectures.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are crucial for supporting large-scale applications, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query execution plans in DDS. We design a DRL agent that learns to select the optimal plan based on query characteristics, system workload, and resource availability. Our experiments on a real-world DDS dataset demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques, achieving up to 30% improvement in query response time and 25% reduction in resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained increasing attention in recent years, as users seek transparency in personalized suggestions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention graph convolutional network (HAGCN) model that leverages both node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to generate interpretable recommendations. Our approach learns to identify influential users and items in the graph, and their relationships, to provide personalized explanations for top-N recommendations. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGCN in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional neural ranking models for document retrieval often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HiRank', which leverages a tree-based architecture to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. HiRank combines a coarse-grained relevance scorer with a fine-grained ranking module, allowing for a significant reduction in computational overhead while maintaining retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HiRank over state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of retrieval accuracy and query processing time.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents for urban traffic control using deep reinforcement learning. Our framework, 'TrafficCtrl', utilizes a decentralized multi-agent system where each agent learns to optimize traffic signal control in real-time. We introduce a graph neural network-based architecture that integrates traffic flow, road network, and agent interactions to improve traffic efficiency and reduce congestion. Experimental results in a simulated urban environment demonstrate that TrafficCtrl outperforms traditional rule-based systems and state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods, achieving a 23% reduction in average travel time and a 15% decrease in traffic congestion.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education by providing immersive and interactive learning experiences. However, the role of embodiment in VR-based learning environments remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the effects of embodiment on user experience and learning outcomes in a VR-based educational platform. We designed and implemented a VR system that allowed users to manipulate virtual objects using gestures and body movements. Our results show that embodiment significantly enhances user engagement, spatial awareness, and cognitive load reduction. We also identify key design recommendations for VR-based learning systems that incorporate embodiment.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interfaces for Cognitive Load Reduction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but high cognitive loads can hinder user experience. This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in VR, where gestural interfaces can reduce cognitive load by leveraging the brain's motor-sensory integration. We design and evaluate a novel gestural interface, 'CogniGest', which utilizes proprioceptive feedback to facilitate intuitive object manipulation in VR. Our user study shows that CogniGest significantly reduces cognitive load and improves task performance compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. The findings have implications for the design of more immersive and accessible VR experiences.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular in modern data analytics, but query optimization remains a significant performance bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to changing workload patterns and data distributions. Our method, 'RL-QO', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan policy from a set of candidate plans. We evaluate RL-QO on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional rule-based optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents with Dynamic Constraints
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments require efficient task allocation strategies to ensure effective collaboration. This paper presents a decentralized approach, 'DynCAT', which leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and adapt to changing constraints. Our approach incorporates a novel constraint propagation mechanism, enabling agents to negotiate task assignments in real-time while respecting feasibility constraints. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of DynCAT in reducing task completion time and improving overall system resilience compared to centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Graph Attention for AI-powered Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have increasingly relied on knowledge graph embedding (KGE) to incorporate semantic information. However, existing KGE methods suffer from scalability issues and fail to capture hierarchical relationships. This paper proposes a novel approach, HierGraph, which leverages hierarchical graph attention to efficiently embed knowledge graphs. By aggregating node representations at multiple scales, HierGraph improves recommendation accuracy and outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets. We also demonstrate the applicability of HierGraph in real-world AI-powered recommender systems.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval due to the limited context and ambiguity of query terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of query terms and documents. Specifically, we employ a multi-task learning approach that combines query term embeddings with a relevance-based ranking model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving improvements in both precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Task Decomposition for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Planning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often involve complex task allocation and planning. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task decomposition framework, 'GraphPlan', which leverages graph-based planning to efficiently allocate tasks among agents. GraphPlan represents task dependencies as a graph and employs a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify subtasks that can be executed in parallel. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphPlan in a simulated disaster response scenario, showing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized planning approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification in Large-Scale Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in large-scale graphs is a fundamental problem in graph-based machine learning. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges. We introduce a hierarchical aggregation strategy that iteratively applies attention at multiple granularity levels, enabling efficient feature extraction and propagation. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT achieves state-of-the-art node classification performance while reducing computational overhead by up to 75% compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Planning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, planning and coordination are crucial for achieving complex tasks. However, the lack of transparency in agent decision-making hinders trust and understanding among agents and humans. This paper presents HTN-X, a novel hierarchical task network framework that incorporates explainability mechanisms into multi-agent planning. HTN-X leverages model-based reasoning to generate hierarchical plans, and then applies model-agnostic explanations to provide insights into agent decision-making. Experimental results on a variety of multi-agent scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of HTN-X in improving plan explainability and agent coordination.

title: Efficient Optimization of Neural Network Architectures using Graph-based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The design of neural network architectures is a time-consuming process that requires significant expertise. We propose a novel graph-based reinforcement learning approach, 'NeuroGraph', to efficiently search for optimal architectures. NeuroGraph represents neural networks as graphs and employs a reinforcement learning agent to iteratively modify the graph structure to improve the network's performance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of NeuroGraph on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing the search time by an order of magnitude compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Hearing Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible voice-based interfaces that cater to older adults with hearing impairments. This paper presents an exploratory study on the design of inclusive voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted a series of user interviews and usability testing sessions to identify key challenges and preferences. Our results highlight the importance of speech rate adjustment, visual feedback, and personalized acoustic models. We propose a novel multimodal interface that incorporates these features, achieving a 30% improvement in task completion rate and 25% reduction in user frustration.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various industries, but its adoption is hindered by user experience issues. Personalization has been proposed as a key factor in improving user experience, but its impact on VR remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effects of personalization on user experience in VR, examining factors such as user engagement, cognitive load, and emotional response. Our results show that personalized VR experiences lead to increased user engagement and reduced cognitive load, but also introduce biases in emotional response. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and provide recommendations for incorporating personalization in VR applications.

title: EyeGaze+: Enhancing Gaze-Based Interaction with Deep Learning-based Fixation Detection
paper_abstract: Gaze-based interfaces have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but accurate fixation detection remains a significant challenge. This paper presents EyeGaze+, a novel approach that leverages deep learning to improve fixation detection in gaze-based interaction. We propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) that learns to identify fixations from raw eye-tracking data, achieving an average accuracy of 95.2% on a benchmark dataset. We demonstrate the effectiveness of EyeGaze+ in a gaze-based typing application, resulting in a 23.4% reduction in error rate compared to traditional fixation detection methods.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often fail to adapt to the complexities of heterogeneous document collections, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes AQE-HT, a novel adaptive query expansion framework that leverages both local and global contextual information to identify relevant terms. AQE-HT incorporates a reinforcement learning module that dynamically adjusts the expansion strategy based on user feedback and document characteristics. Experimental results on a diverse collection of web documents demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Real-time IoT Streams
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices generates vast streams of data, making real-time anomaly detection a pressing challenge. We propose a novel deep learning framework, 'IoT-AD', that leverages a hybrid attention-based autoencoder and a one-class SVM to identify anomalies in IoT streams. Our approach achieves fast inference times by exploiting GPU parallelization and pruning redundant neurons. Experimental results on several IoT benchmarks demonstrate that IoT-AD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and speed, while being robust to concept drift and noisy data.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process of recommendation models. This paper proposes a novel heterogeneous graph attention network (HGAT) for ERS, which integrates user, item, and knowledge graph data to generate personalized explanations. We design a graph attention mechanism that captures complex relationships between users, items, and knowledge entities, and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of both recommendation performance and explanation quality.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Workload-Aware Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant challenges in balancing query performance and data consistency. This paper presents an adaptive replication strategy, 'AWARE', that dynamically adjusts data replication based on workload patterns and query distributions. AWARE leverages machine learning models to predict query hotspots and proactively replicates data to reduce latency and improve throughput. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system demonstrates that AWARE achieves up to 35% improvement in query performance and 25% reduction in replication overhead compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-Scale Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: The exponential growth of digital documents has necessitated the development of efficient hierarchical clustering algorithms for document retrieval. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HierDoc', which leverages the properties of graph theory to cluster documents in a hierarchical manner. By representing documents as nodes in a graph and edges as similarity measures, we develop a divisive clustering algorithm that recursively partitions the graph into densely connected subgraphs, enabling efficient retrieval of relevant documents. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HierDoc outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and retrieval efficiency.

title: Adaptive Document Re-ranking using BERT-based Query Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity of patent documents and the ambiguity of user queries. This paper proposes an adaptive document re-ranking approach that leverages BERT-based query embeddings to better capture query intent. Our method, called AQE-Rerank, fine-tunes a pre-trained BERT model on a large patent dataset to generate dense query embeddings. These embeddings are then used to compute a weighted similarity score between the query and patent documents, which are re-ranked accordingly. Experimental results on the CLEF-IP 2019 dataset demonstrate that AQE-Rerank outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Indexing for Time-Series Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Time-series data is increasingly prevalent in various domains, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, querying and indexing such data in distributed database systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'TS-tree', which leverages a combination of spatial and temporal locality to optimize query performance. TS-tree adapts to varying data distributions and query workloads, achieving up to 3x query speedup and 2x storage savings compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods. We evaluate TS-tree on a large-scale IoT dataset and demonstrate its efficacy in supporting real-time analytics and decision-making.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Fleets
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle fleets require efficient task allocation to optimize resource utilization and minimize latency. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'MARLA', which leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to coordinate task assignments among agents. MARLA incorporates a decentralized MDP framework, enabling agents to learn from local observations and adapt to dynamic environment changes. Experimental results demonstrate that MARLA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and fleet-wide efficiency, while maintaining robustness to agent failures and communication disruptions.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Ad-hoc Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval in large-scale document collections is a fundamental task in information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, dubbed 'NQE', which leverages a pre-trained language model to generate semantically relevant expansion terms. NQE is designed to reduce the computational overhead associated with traditional query expansion methods, making it suitable for real-time search applications. Experimental results on the TREC news dataset demonstrate that NQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of mean average precision and retrieval efficiency.

title: Efficient Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Adaptive Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Meta-learning has emerged as a promising approach to few-shot learning, where a model is trained to adapt to new tasks with limited data. However, existing methods often rely on complex architectures or require extensive hyperparameter tuning. This paper proposes a simple yet effective meta-learning framework, 'AdaTask', which leverages adaptive task embeddings to condition the model's parameters. We introduce a novel task embedding scheme that captures task similarities and dissimilarities, enabling the model to focus on the most informative samples. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaTask achieves state-of-the-art performance on few-shot image classification tasks, while requiring significantly fewer hyperparameter searches.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Relational Link Prediction
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has emerged as a crucial technique for link prediction in multi-relational graphs. However, existing KGE methods often neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in many real-world graphs. This paper introduces 'HATT-KGE', a novel framework that leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between entities and their attributes. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATT-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in multi-relational link prediction tasks, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval of Short Text Documents
paper_abstract: Short text documents, such as tweets and product reviews, pose significant challenges for information retrieval systems due to their brevity and lack of context. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HyQE', which leverages both local and global semantic relationships to enrich the query representation. HyQE first identifies relevant keywords from the query and expands them using a graph-based method, and then hierarchically refines the expanded query by incorporating topic models and word embeddings. Experimental results on several short text datasets demonstrate that HyQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Warehouse Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous warehouse management requires efficient task planning and execution to optimize productivity and reduce costs. This paper presents a Hierarchical Task Network (HTN) planning framework that leverages Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) to coordinate robots and warehouse workers. Our approach, called HTN-MARL, decomposes complex tasks into sub-tasks and allocates them to agents based on their capabilities and availability. We evaluate HTN-MARL in a simulated warehouse environment and show that it outperforms traditional HTN planning methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which learns to generate context-aware expansion terms from large-scale clickthrough data. Our proposed model, 'DeepQE', leverages a combination of recurrent and convolutional neural networks to capture both sequential and semantic relationships between query terms. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods and state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Distributed Negotiation for Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to resource allocation in smart grids by coordinating autonomous agents through distributed negotiation. We develop a multi-agent system where agents representing different stakeholders (e.g., households, utilities, and renewable energy sources) negotiate over resource allocation to optimize energy efficiency and reduce costs. Our approach leverages semantic reasoning and machine learning to enable agents to learn from their interactions and adapt to changing grid conditions. Experimental results demonstrate improved resource allocation and reduced energy waste compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Explainable AI
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has gained significant attention in recent years, but most XAI methods rely on complex and computationally expensive neural networks. This paper presents a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, dubbed 'ExplainNAS', which targets the discovery of efficient XAI models. Our approach leverages a Differentiable Search Algorithm to optimize the neural architecture, taking into account both model accuracy and interpretability. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ExplainNAS on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in explainability metrics while reducing computational overhead by up to 50%.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data is becoming increasingly common in various applications, including computer vision, natural language processing, and scientific simulations. However, indexing such data in distributed database systems poses significant challenges. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'HDIX', which leverages the inherent correlations between dimensions to reduce the indexing overhead. We demonstrate that HDIX outperforms existing indexing methods, such as R-trees and ball-trees, in terms of query performance and storage efficiency. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that HDIX achieves up to 3x speedup in query response time and 2x reduction in storage requirements.

title: Enhancing Retrieval Efficiency with Hierarchical Query Expansion for Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: The proliferation of large-scale document collections has exacerbated the challenge of efficient information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, HiQE, which leverages semantic relationships between query terms to improve retrieval efficiency. HiQE incorporates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify relevant term clusters, which are then used to generate expanded queries. Our experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HiQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency, with an average reduction of 37% in query latency, while maintaining comparable retrieval effectiveness to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Query-Driven Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of modern question answering systems. However, existing methods often rely on dense vector representations of documents, leading to high computational costs and memory requirements. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document representation scheme, 'QDDR', which selectively encodes only the most relevant passages in a document based on the query context. Our approach leverages a combination of sparse attention mechanisms and hierarchical document encoding to reduce the dimensionality of the representation space. Experimental results on the TREC CAR dataset demonstrate that QDDR achieves significant improvements in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Image Captioning
paper_abstract: Image captioning models often struggle to provide interpretable results, limiting their applicability in real-world scenarios. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that generates captions while providing explicit attention weights for visual and linguistic components. We propose a multi-task learning objective that jointly optimizes caption generation and attention weights, enabling the model to focus on salient image regions and relevant contextual information. Experimental results on the COCO dataset demonstrate that our HAN model achieves state-of-the-art performance while offering improved explainability and interpretability.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, 'CloudOptimizer', which learns to adaptively allocate resources based on real-time workload patterns. We design a novel reward function that incorporates both performance and energy efficiency metrics, and demonstrate that CloudOptimizer outperforms traditional rule-based allocation methods in terms of response time and resource utilization. Our experiments on a real-world cloud dataset show that CloudOptimizer achieves up to 30% reduction in energy consumption and 25% improvement in response time compared to baseline methods.

title: Gaze-Based Intelligent Wheelchair Navigation for Individuals with Severe Mobility Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with severe mobility impairments often rely on caregivers or specialized devices for navigation. This paper presents a novel gaze-based intelligent wheelchair navigation system, 'GazeNav', which leverages eye-tracking technology and machine learning algorithms to enable independent mobility. GazeNav uses a convolutional neural network to classify user gaze patterns and predict intended navigation commands. We evaluated GazeNav with 15 participants and achieved an average accuracy of 92.5% in navigating through simulated obstacle courses. Our system demonstrates promising potential for enhancing the autonomy and quality of life of individuals with severe mobility impairments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often rely on computationally expensive fusion methods or neglect modalities with limited data. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that adaptively weighs and integrates features from text, image, and audio modalities. Our HAN model employs a two-stage attention mechanism, where modality-specific attention is first applied to extract relevant features, followed by a higher-level attention that selectively combines modalities based on their predictive power. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods while requiring significantly fewer computational resources.

title: Exploiting Graph Attention Networks for Effective Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) is a crucial task in artificial intelligence, aiming to represent entities and relationships in a low-dimensional vector space. This paper proposes a novel KGE approach, dubbed GraphAttentionKE, which leverages graph attention networks to model complex relationships between entities. By adaptively assigning attention weights to different neighbors, our model captures nuanced semantic patterns and improves entity representation. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphAttentionKE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods, achieving significant gains in link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph attention networks (GATs) to learn the task allocation policy. Our method, called GAT-ALLOC, leverages the graph structure of the agent communication network to learn attention weights that capture the importance of each agent's local information. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GAT-ALLOC in a simulated disaster response scenario, where it outperforms traditional decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and communication overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to analyze sentiment from various modalities, such as text, images, and audio. Despite recent advances, existing MSA models lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the decision-making process. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates explainable multimodal fusion. Our HAN model employs a novel attention mechanism that assigns importance scores to each modality, enabling the identification of sentiment-bearing regions. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art MSA models while providing insightful visualizations of sentiment-driven modality interactions.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Hierarchical Indexing for Distributed Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (IR) systems face significant scalability challenges as the volume of indexed data grows. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HIRI', that leverages a combination of tree-based and hash-based indexing techniques to accelerate query processing. HIRI adaptively partitions the index into hierarchical layers, enabling more efficient query routing and reducing the number of nodes involved in query processing. Experimental results on a large-scale IR benchmark demonstrate that HIRI achieves up to 3x improvement in query throughput and 2x reduction in average query latency compared to existing indexing methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Streams using Deep Reinforcement Learning
