paper_abstract: Real-time data stream processing has become a critical component of modern data infrastructure, but optimizing query execution plans for dynamic data streams remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for real-time data streams. Our method, called 'StreamOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan based on the current query workload, data distribution, and system resources. We evaluate StreamOpt on a range of real-world datasets and demonstrate significant performance improvements over traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multimodal Information Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MMIR) has gained significant attention in recent years, but the challenge of effectively representing and querying heterogeneous data remains. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which leverages the strengths of both visual and textual features. We introduce a multimodal autoencoder that learns to project query and document representations into a shared latent space, enabling efficient and effective query expansion. Experimental results on a large-scale MMIR dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and efficiency compared to traditional methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Hash Tables
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework, 'DHAT-MA', which leverages distributed hash tables (DHTs) to enable agents to autonomously allocate tasks. We propose a hierarchical DHT structure that allows agents to discover and allocate tasks in a self-organized manner, while ensuring load balancing and minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of DHAT-MA in achieving higher task completion rates and lower response times compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Gestural Interfaces for Elderly Users: A Study on Gesture Recognition and Feedback
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible interfaces for elderly users becomes increasingly important. This paper presents a study on gestural interfaces, focusing on gesture recognition and feedback mechanisms tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65-85, evaluating the effectiveness of three gesture recognition algorithms and four feedback modalities (visual, auditory, tactile, and haptic). Our results show that a machine learning-based approach outperforms traditional rule-based methods, while multimodal feedback significantly improves user performance and satisfaction. The findings inform the design of gestural interfaces that cater to the unique needs of elderly users.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Voice-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of voice-based interfaces, personalization has become a crucial aspect of enhancing user experience. This study explores the effects of personalization on user satisfaction, engagement, and efficiency in voice-based interactions. We designed a controlled experiment involving 120 participants, where we manipulated the level of personalization in a smart speaker system. Our results show that personalized voice responses improve user satisfaction and engagement, but may compromise efficiency due to increased response time. We also identify individual differences in user preferences and discuss implications for designing personalized voice-based interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Negotiation-Based Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents need to coordinate to achieve global objectives. This paper proposes a novel negotiation-based distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) framework for task allocation. Our approach leverages local negotiation protocols and constraint propagation to efficiently allocate tasks to agents, while ensuring global constraints are satisfied. We evaluate our approach on a realistic robotics scenario, demonstrating improved scalability and solution quality compared to centralized optimization methods.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities must work together to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a deep reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn effective task allocation strategies through interactions with their environment and other agents. Our approach, called 'CooperA', leverages graph neural networks to represent agent interactions and a decentralized actor-critic architecture to enable efficient learning. Experimental results demonstrate that CooperA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods and existing learning-based approaches in various task allocation scenarios, showcasing its potential for real-world applications such as search and rescue operations.

title: Hybrid Task-Oriented Dialogue Management using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid task-oriented dialogue management framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning to improve dialogue efficiency and coherence. Our approach combines a high-level task manager with a low-level language generator, allowing the agent to adapt to changing user goals and preferences. We evaluate our approach using a large-scale dialogue dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in task success rate, dialogue length, and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Models
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for efficient query optimization in distributed databases. Our method models the database as a graph and leverages graph neural networks to learn the optimal query execution plan. We evaluate our approach on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and scalability compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems Using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective task assignment strategies. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphAgent', represents the agent-task graph as a dynamic neural network, enabling agents to learn from local observations and adapt to changing task requirements. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphAgent in simulated robotics and sensor network scenarios, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic control is a complex problem that requires coordination among multiple agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to train a multi-agent system to coordinate traffic signals in real-time. Our approach, called 'TrafficMA', uses a decentralized architecture where each agent learns to adjust its signal timing based on local observations and communicates with neighboring agents to achieve global optimality. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that TrafficMA outperforms traditional methods in reducing travel times and increasing network throughput.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics, but optimizing queries in such systems remains a challenging task. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, dubbed 'Distributed Graph Index' (DGI), which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to efficiently optimize queries. DGI exploits the sparsity of query graphs to reduce the search space and employs a hierarchical indexing scheme to facilitate fast query execution. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that DGI outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to support older adults with cognitive impairments, but their design often neglects the unique needs of this population. This paper presents a human-centered design approach to creating accessible conversational agents for this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our findings inform the development of a novel conversation framework that incorporates simplification, redundancy, and error tolerance to support users with cognitive impairments. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach in improving interaction experiences and reducing frustration.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Preferences
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial problem that involves forming teams of agents to achieve a common goal. However, real-world scenarios often involve uncertain preferences among agents, leading to suboptimal coalitions. This paper proposes a novel distributed coalition formation algorithm, 'Uncertainty-Aware Coalition Formation' (UACF), which leverages probabilistic graphical models to capture uncertain preferences. UACF incorporates a novel uncertainty-aware reward function and a distributed optimization framework to facilitate the formation of robust coalitions. Experimental results on a simulated multi-robot scenario demonstrate that UACF outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of coalition quality and adaptability to uncertain preferences.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that affects overall system performance. This paper proposes a novel autonomous task allocation framework using reinforcement learning. Our approach, 'MA-RL', leverages a decentralized, multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to learn optimal task assignments in dynamic environments. We evaluate MA-RL on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and system efficiency compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods. The proposed framework has potential applications in various domains, including search and rescue, logistics, and smart cities.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Scalable RDF Query Processing
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF as a data representation standard has led to a growing need for efficient querying mechanisms. In this paper, we propose a novel indexing framework, 'RDFlex', designed to accelerate RDF query processing on large-scale datasets. RDFlex combines a graph-based indexing approach with a hierarchical clustering technique, enabling fast query optimization and efficient join processing. We evaluate RDFlex on several real-world RDF datasets, demonstrating significant performance improvements over existing state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Coordinated Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for coordinated traffic signal control. We model each traffic signal as an autonomous agent that learns to optimize its signal timing policy based on real-time traffic conditions and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach, called 'TrafficAgent', employs a novel graph neural network architecture to represent the complex traffic network topology and facilitates efficient information sharing among agents. Experimental results using real-world traffic data demonstrate that TrafficAgent reduces congestion and travel times by up to 25% compared to traditional, centrally controlled signal timing strategies.

title: Designing Auditory Cues for Enhanced Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on visual cues to communicate feedback to users, but this can lead to cognitive overload and decreased immersion. This paper explores the use of auditory cues to enhance gesture recognition in VR. We propose a novel approach that leverages psychoacoustic modeling to design informative and non-distracting sound effects. In a user study, we demonstrate that our approach improves gesture recognition accuracy by 22% compared to a baseline visual-only system, while also reducing cognitive workload. Our findings have implications for the design of more accessible and engaging VR experiences.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Agent Cooperative Navigation
paper_abstract: Cooperative navigation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the complexity of agent interactions and the need for adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-CoNav', which enables agents to learn both low-level motion control and high-level cooperative strategies. Our approach leverages a novel hierarchical State-Action-Critic (SAC) architecture to handle the Curse of Dimensionality and improve learning efficiency. Experimental results on a variety of simulation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of HRL-CoNav in achieving efficient and collision-free navigation in dense environments.

title: Optimizing Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems using Query Rewriting and Path Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for managing large-scale data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in such systems. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines query rewriting and path indexing to optimize data retrieval in distributed database systems. We introduce a query rewriting algorithm that transforms complex queries into optimized subqueries, and a path indexing technique that accelerates query execution by reducing the number of nodes to be traversed. Experimental results on a real-world distributed dataset show that our approach outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time and 25% in terms of data transfer cost.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly enter industrial workplaces, effective human-robot collaboration (HRC) is crucial for productivity and safety. This paper explores the role of embodiment in HRC, examining how a robot's physical presence and gestures influence human trust, communication, and task performance. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, using a robotic arm with varying levels of embodiment. Results show that a more embodied robot leads to higher trust and better task outcomes, but also increases perceived workload. Our findings have implications for the design of HRC systems and highlight the need for careful consideration of embodiment in industrial robot design.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of dynamically allocating resources to meet fluctuating user demand. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARLA', which enables autonomous agents to learn and adapt to changing resource requirements. MARLA employs a decentralized, auction-based mechanism to allocate resources, and incorporates a novel reward function that balances resource utilization with latency and cost considerations. Experimental results demonstrate that MARLA outperforms traditional static allocation methods in terms of resource efficiency, response time, and cost savings.

title: Optimizing Query Execution Plans for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy is becoming increasingly prevalent in cloud-based database systems, where multiple tenants share the same physical infrastructure. However, this leads to complex query optimization challenges. This paper presents a novel approach to optimizing query execution plans for multi-tenant database systems. We propose a hierarchical planning framework that leverages tenant-level statistics and resource utilization to generate efficient query plans. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate significant performance improvements over traditional query optimization techniques, with an average reduction of 35% in query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in autonomous driving, where reinforcement learning (RL) agents make critical decisions. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to provide insights into the decision-making process. Our HAN model consists of a hierarchical feature extractor, attention-based state representation, and a policy network. Experimental results on a simulated driving environment show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art RL methods in terms of task performance while providing interpretable explanations for the agent's actions.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Large-Scale Graph Databases Using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between entities. However, optimizing queries on large-scale graph databases remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to predict optimal query plans. Our technique, called 'GraphPlan', uses a combination of graph embeddings and reinforcement learning to learn a policy for selecting efficient query execution plans. Experimental results on several real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphPlan outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, reducing query execution times by up to 50%.

title: Efficient Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Imbalanced Classification
paper_abstract: Imbalanced classification problems, where one class has a significantly larger number of instances than the others, are prevalent in many real-world applications. Online learning algorithms are often employed to handle streaming data, but they can struggle with class imbalance. This paper proposes a novel online learning framework, 'AdReg', which incorporates adaptive regularization to tackle class imbalance. AdReg dynamically adjusts the regularization strength based on the class distribution and the model's performance, leading to improved accuracy and robustness. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AdReg in handling imbalanced classification tasks.

title: Investigating the Effect of Personalization on User Engagement in Voice-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: The proliferation of voice-based interfaces has led to a growing need to understand how personalization affects user engagement. This paper presents a mixed-methods study that explores the impact of personalization on user experience in voice-based interfaces. We designed and developed a voice-based assistant that incorporates user preferences and adapts to their behavior over time. Our results show that personalized responses lead to increased user satisfaction and engagement, but also raise concerns about bias and transparency. We provide design recommendations for voice-based interface designers and discuss the implications for future research in this area.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel reinforcement learning (RL) approach to QE, which learns to select the most effective expansion terms by interacting with a simulated search environment. Our method, dubbed 'RL-QE', leverages a deep Q-network to estimate the expected retrieval performance of different expansion strategies, and adaptively adjusts the exploration-exploitation trade-off during training. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Effective Entity Retrieval
paper_abstract: Entity retrieval is a critical task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve entities that match a given query. However, the limited query context often leads to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-ER', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to generate contextualized query expansions. We utilize a novel entity-aware training objective that incorporates both relevance and entity-relatedness signals. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that NQE-ER significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% relative improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of document retrieval systems, as it helps to capture the nuances of user queries and improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'NeuroExp', which leverages neural embeddings to model the semantic relationships between query terms and document vocabulary. NeuroExp employs aEncoder-Decoder architecture to generate expanded queries that better capture the context and intent behind user queries. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroExp outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the semantic gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages neural networks to learn semantic representations of query terms and expand them with relevant synonyms and related concepts. Our experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, leading to improved retrieval performance and robustness to noisy queries.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning-based Index Selection
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, query optimization in DDS remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of data distribution and indexing. This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize query performance in DDS using machine learning-based index selection. We develop a framework that leverages query workload patterns and data distribution characteristics to predict the most effective index configurations. Our experimental results on a real-world DDS dataset demonstrate significant improvements in query response time and resource utilization compared to traditional indexing techniques.

title: Deep Hierarchical Representation Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has garnered significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to effectively fuse and represent heterogeneous data from different modalities. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical representation learning framework, termed 'MHRL', which leverages a multimodal graph neural network to learn hierarchical representations from text, image, and speech inputs. We demonstrate that MHRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods on three benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in sentiment classification accuracy and correlation with human annotations. Our approach has promising implications for real-world applications, such as sentiment analysis in social media and customer service platforms.

title: Scalable Graph Query Optimization with Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Graph query optimization is crucial for various applications, including social network analysis and recommendation systems. Traditional query optimization techniques rely on heuristics, which often lead to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to optimize graph queries. We introduce 'GraphLix', a framework that learns to predict the most efficient query execution plan based on historical query patterns and graph topology. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphLix outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving up to 3x speedup and 2x reduction in memory usage.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic design on User Trust in Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their success hinges on establishing user trust. This study investigates the effect of anthropomorphic design elements on user trust in conversational agents. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment, where 120 participants interacted with either an anthropomorphized or non-anthropomorphized chatbot. Results show that anthropomorphic design positively influences user trust, particularly among users with lower levels of technological expertise. However, we also identify potential pitfalls, such as over-reliance on anthropomorphism, which can lead to reduced trust when expectations are not met. Our findings have implications for the design of conversational interfaces that aim to establish long-term, trustworthy relationships with users.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities must be assigned to tasks to optimize system performance. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized architecture where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on its local observations and interactions with other agents. Our algorithm, 'DeepTASK', leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and deep Q-networks to learn task allocation policies. We evaluate DeepTASK on a simulated multi-agent system and demonstrate significant improvements in system efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional optimization-based approaches.

title: Integrating Entity Disambiguation with BERT-based Ranking for Multi-Task Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel architecture for multi-task information retrieval, integrating entity disambiguation with BERT-based ranking models. Our approach leverages the strengths of both tasks to improve the overall retrieval performance. We propose a hierarchical neural network that jointly learns to disambiguate entities and rank documents, exploiting the semantic relationships between entities and their contextualized representations. Experimental results on a large-scale benchmark dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and entity disambiguation F1-score compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Symbolic Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can manipulate the input data to mislead the model. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural symbolic learning (BNSL) framework to robustify DNNs against such attacks. BNSL integrates symbolic reasoning with Bayesian neural networks to learn a probabilistic representation of the input data. We demonstrate that BNSL can effectively detect and correct adversarial attacks, leading to improved model robustness. Experimental results on the CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets show that BNSL outperforms state-of-the-art defense methods in terms of accuracy and robustness.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires coordinating agents to achieve common goals. This paper presents a novel distributed constraint optimization approach for task allocation, which leverages the strengths of both constraint programming and distributed problem-solving. Our proposed algorithm, called DCA-TA, enables agents to autonomously assign tasks while respecting global constraints and minimizing conflicts. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DCA-TA outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding via Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial component in various AI applications. However, existing KGE methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) based KGE framework, dubbed 'KG-HAN', which leverages the hierarchical structure of knowledge graphs to reduce the computational overhead. KG-HAN adaptively focuses on relevant entities and relations, leading to improved embedding quality and inference efficiency. Our extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of KG-HAN compared to state-of-the-art KGE methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely heavily on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph (NQG) approach for efficient query expansion. NQGs learn to represent queries as graph structures, capturing semantic relationships between query terms and their contextual dependencies. Our method uses a graph-based attention mechanism to identify the most informative expansion terms, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of NQGs in terms of precision, recall, and efficiency, outperforming traditional query expansion methods.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Notification Filtering for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Notification overload is a pervasive problem in modern computing, leading to distraction, fatigue, and decreased productivity. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive notification filtering using gaze-based attention tracking. Our system, 'GazeFilter', leverages machine learning models trained on user gaze patterns to predict notification relevance and prioritize timely, context-aware interventions. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating significant reductions in notification dismissals and improved task performance compared to traditional filtering methods. The results have implications for HCI designs that support more harmonious human-computer interaction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often suffer from limitations in capturing nuanced context and semantics. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CAE-QE', which leverages context-aware embeddings to improve query expansion. Our method incorporates attention-based neural networks to model the relationships between query terms, documents, and their contextual information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for People with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but people with dyslexia often struggle to interact with them effectively. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create more inclusive conversational interfaces for individuals with dyslexia. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving surveys, interviews, and usability testing to identify the challenges and needs of this population. Our findings informed the development of a set of design guidelines and a prototype system that incorporates multimodal input, visual aids, and personalized support. Evaluation results show significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for participants with dyslexia, demonstrating the potential of our approach to promote digital inclusion.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability in critical applications. Detecting these attacks is essential, but existing methods are often limited by their specificity to particular models or datasets. This paper proposes a meta-learning approach, 'MetaGuard', which learns to detect adversarial attacks across different models and datasets. By leveraging a few-shot learning paradigm, MetaGuard can adapt to new attack patterns and generalize to unseen models. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaGuard in detecting various types of attacks, including those crafted using state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, which aims to reformulate the original query to retrieve more relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, 'DRL-QE', learns to select the most informative terms from the top-retrieved documents and incorporates them into the original query. We formulate the query expansion process as a Markov decision process and utilize a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DRL-QE achieves significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Natural Language Search
paper_abstract: Natural language search has become increasingly popular, but its efficiency is hindered by the need to process complex queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages semantic relationships between words to reduce the dimensionality of the search space. HQE uses a probabilistic graph model to capture term dependencies and identifies the most informative query terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency while maintaining comparable accuracy to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle with indexing and querying large document collections, leading to slow response times. We propose a novel hierarchical document representation, HDRep, which leverages a combination of semantic and syntactic features to capture document structure and content. HDRep enables efficient indexing and querying by facilitating the pruning of irrelevant documents at multiple levels of granularity. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate that HDRep achieves a 30% reduction in query latency while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and intelligibility, often struggle to interact with voice assistants. This paper presents 'DysaVA', a novel framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that accommodate users with dysarthria. We propose a multi-modal input system combining acoustic, linguistic, and visual features to improve speech recognition accuracy. Our user study with 20 participants with dysarthria demonstrates that DysaVA significantly enhances interaction experience, reducing errors by 35% and increasing user satisfaction by 42%. We discuss implications for accessible HCI design and future directions for personalized assistive technologies.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Deep Semantic Hashing for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer user queries. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepHash', which leverages deep semantic hashing to efficiently retrieve top-k passages. We propose a neural network-based hash function that projects passages into a compact binary space, enabling fast lookup and ranking. Experimental results on popular ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that DeepHash outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods in terms of both retrieval efficiency and answer accuracy.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for big data analytics, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents 'Columbo', a novel query optimization framework that leverages statistical models and machine learning techniques to improve query performance. Columbo introduces a scalable, distributed architecture for query optimization, which can handle large query workloads and adapt to changing data distributions. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that Columbo achieves an average query speedup of 3.2x compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Consensus-Based auctions
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the task allocation problem in decentralized multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and preferences need to allocate tasks to maximize overall system performance. We propose a consensus-based auction mechanism that enables agents to negotiate and agree on task assignments in a distributed manner. Our approach leverages a novel combination of distributed constraint optimization and auction theory to ensure efficient and fair task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of system utility and fairness.

title: Context-Aware Knowledge Graph Embedding for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained popularity, but existing methods struggle to capture complex relationships between users, items, and contextual factors. We propose a novel context-aware knowledge graph embedding (CAKGE) approach that integrates multi-relational knowledge graphs with contextual information. CAKGE learns entity and relation embeddings that incorporate contextual dependencies, enabling the generation of interpretable explanations for recommendations. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that CAKGE outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval due to the limited context available. Query expansion techniques can improve retrieval performance, but often rely on term co-occurrence statistics or manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CAQE', which leverages context-aware embeddings to model the semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Our method incorporates a graph-based attention mechanism to adaptively weight the importance of contextual information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly for short queries.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Patent Retrieval using Neural Embeddings
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity of patent documents and the ambiguity of query terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'Patent2Vec', which leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method uses a combination of word and patent embeddings to generate expanded queries that better match the intent of the user. Experimental results on a large patent dataset show that Patent2Vec significantly improves retrieval performance, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on simple keyword matching, which often fails to capture the semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture for document ranking, which learns to represent queries and documents as dense vectors in a shared semantic space. Our approach leverages both local and global context information to improve the relevance and diversity of retrieved documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HNN-based ranking model outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in terms of NDCG and MAP metrics.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, often relying on simplistic term weighting schemes. We propose a novel graph-based approach to query expansion, which leverages semantic embeddings to capture latent relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'GraphEx', constructs a knowledge graph from a large corpus and learns to embed query terms in a dense vector space. Experimentation on several benchmark datasets demonstrates that GraphEx significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving an average improvement of 15% in mean average precision.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: We present a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for autonomous traffic signal control. Our method, called 'SmartSignal', leverages real-time traffic data to optimize signal timings and minimize congestion. Each agent, representing a signalized intersection, learns to adapt its control policy based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We evaluate SmartSignal on a large-scale simulation of the Pittsburgh traffic network, demonstrating significant reductions in travel time and emissions compared to traditional fixed-time and actuated control strategies.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their scalability and fault-tolerance. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for query optimization, which models the query plan as a graph and leverages graph neural networks to predict the optimal plan. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Deep Ensemble Learning for Uncertainty Estimation in Medical Image Segmentation
paper_abstract: Medical image segmentation is a crucial task in disease diagnosis, but the uncertainty associated with model predictions can lead to incorrect diagnoses. This paper proposes a deep ensemble learning framework, 'MedSegEnsemble', which leverages multiple diverse models to estimate uncertainty in medical image segmentation tasks. We introduce a novel Bayesian neural network architecture that incorporates Monte Carlo dropout and batch normalization to estimate epistemic uncertainty. Experimental results on the BraTS dataset demonstrate that MedSegEnsemble outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and uncertainty estimation, while providing interpretable uncertainty maps for radiologists.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Agents for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to improve the lives of older adults, but their design often neglects the needs and preferences of this demographic. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive conversational agents for older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key design requirements, including simplicity, clarity, and emotional support. We developed a prototype agent that incorporates these requirements and evaluated its usability and acceptability with 30 older adults. Results show significant improvements in user experience and engagement compared to existing agents. Our findings have implications for the design of accessible and supportive conversational agents in healthcare and beyond.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Relation extraction (RE) from unstructured text is a fundamental task in natural language processing. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that learns to extract relevant relations by modeling entity interactions at multiple scales. HGAN incorporates a graph attention mechanism to selectively focus on informative entity pairs and a hierarchical aggregation strategy to capture complex relationships. Experimental results on the TACRED dataset demonstrate that HGAN outperforms existing RE models while providing transparent and explainable relation extraction.

title: Optimizing Query Performance through Adaptive Indexing for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents AIDA, an adaptive indexing framework that dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. AIDA leverages a hybrid indexing approach that combines traditional B-tree indexing with a novel, compact indexing scheme tailored for distributed environments. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that AIDA achieves up to 3x improvement in query performance compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while maintaining a low storage overhead.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Representation Learning for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of many natural language processing applications, but its efficiency is often hindered by the high dimensionality of document representations. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document representation learning (QADRL) framework that learns to adaptively compress and refine document embeddings based on the query context. Our approach leverages a dual-encoder architecture with a query-aware attention mechanism, enabling efficient passage retrieval while maintaining retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of QADRL in reducing retrieval latency while improving recall and MRR scores.

title: Neural Re-ranking Models for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The proliferation of online documents has rendered traditional search engines inefficient, necessitating novel document retrieval techniques. This paper presents a neural re-ranking model, 'DocRanker', that leverages BERT-based encoding and graph attention mechanisms to capture semantic relationships between query and document representations. By pruning irrelevant documents using a hierarchical clustering approach, DocRanker reduces the computational overhead of traditional ranking models while maintaining superior retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on a large-scale web dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving a 25% reduction in latency compared to state-of-the-art re-ranking models.

title: Hierarchical Structured Pruning for Efficient Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performances in various AI applications, but their increasing complexity and computational requirements hinder their deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical structured pruning (HSP) method that reduces the computational cost and memory footprint of DNNs while preserving their accuracy. HSP leverages a nested pruning strategy, where redundant filters and channels are eliminated at multiple scales, resulting in a more efficient and compact network architecture. Experimental results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that HSP outperforms existing pruning methods, achieving up to 5.2x reduction in FLOPS and 3.5x reduction in model size with minimal accuracy loss.

title: Efficient Query Processing for RDF Databases using Graph-based Indexing
paper_abstract: Resource Description Framework (RDF) databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, query processing efficiency remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of RDF data models and the lack of effective indexing strategies. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, RDF-GIN, which leverages the structural properties of RDF graphs to accelerate query processing. We demonstrate that RDF-GIN outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 30% in terms of query response time and reduces memory consumption by up to 25% on real-world RDF datasets.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Reformulation on Diversified Search Results
paper_abstract: Diversified search systems aim to provide users with a variety of relevant results, rather than a list of similar documents. Query reformulation is a common technique used to improve the diversification of search results. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the impact of query reformulation on diversified search results. We propose a novel framework that incorporates multiple query reformulation strategies and evaluates their effects on search result diversification. Our experiments on a large-scale web corpus show that our approach significantly improves the diversity of search results, while also enhancing the overall relevance of the retrieved documents.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Multi-Robot Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for efficient multi-robot task allocation in dynamic environments. We propose a two-level hierarchy, where a high-level policy learns to allocate tasks to robots based on their capabilities and the environment, and a low-level policy controls the robot's actions to execute the assigned tasks. Our approach leverages a Graph Attention Network to model the interactions between robots and tasks, and a Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient algorithm to learn the policies. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate that our HRL framework achieves significant improvements in task completion time and robot utilization compared to traditional methods.

title: Partial Observable Markov Decision Process-based Agent Collaboration for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management systems require efficient agent collaboration to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper proposes a novel Partial Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP)-based framework for agent collaboration in autonomous traffic management. We model the traffic environment as a POMDP, where each agent observes a partial state of the environment and makes decisions based on its local observation. We develop a decentralized POMDP algorithm that enables agents to collaborate and share information to improve overall system performance. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized approaches and achieves near-optimal performance in terms of average travel time and traffic congestion.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Graph-based Temporal Abstraction
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents often struggle to provide insights into their decision-making processes, hindering their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to explainable RL, 'GraphX', which leverages graph-based temporal abstraction to identify and visualize key state transitions and their relationships. By learning a hierarchical graph representation of the environment, GraphX enables agents to justify their actions by tracing them back to underlying causal factors. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphX in a range of Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing its potential to increase trust and understanding in RL systems.

title: Adaptive Document Ranking with Hierarchical Convolutional Neural Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on hand-crafted features and shallow models, leading to suboptimal performance and inefficient querying. This paper introduces a novel approach, Hierarchical Convolutional Neural Networks for Document Ranking (HCNN-DR), which learns rich representations of documents and queries through hierarchical convolutional and pooling operations. Our model adaptively weights and combines multiple ranking signals, enabling efficient and effective retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and query latency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Query Graph Generation
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on manually crafted query models, which often fail to capture complex relationships between query terms. We propose a novel neural approach, 'QueryGraph', which generates a query graph from a natural language query and leverages graph neural networks for document ranking. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QueryGraph outperforms state-of-the-art models, such as BERT-based rankers, in terms of precision, recall, and NDCG. We also show that QueryGraph can be effectively used for query expansion and reformulation, leading to further improvements in retrieval performance.

title: Scalable Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Decentralized Edge Computing
paper_abstract: Decentralized edge computing (DEC) enables efficient resource allocation and reduced latency in IoT applications. This paper proposes a novel agent-based framework, 'AURA', which leverages multi-agent systems to optimize resource allocation in DEC environments. AURA employs a distributed, auction-based mechanism that allows edge devices to autonomously bid for resources, ensuring efficient allocation and minimizing latency. We demonstrate AURA's scalability and performance through extensive simulations and real-world experiments, showcasing its potential for large-scale DEC deployments.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Autonomous Multi-Agent Systems Using Blockchain
paper_abstract: Autonomous multi-agent systems (AMAS) rely on trust among agents to achieve collaborative goals. However, trust management in decentralized AMAS is challenging due to the lack of a centralized authority. This paper proposes a blockchain-based decentralized trust management framework, 'TrustChain', which enables agents to establish and update trust relationships in a secure and transparent manner. We design a novel consensus protocol that integrates reputation systems and game-theoretic incentives to ensure trust consistency across the network. Experimental results demonstrate that TrustChain outperforms traditional centralized trust management approaches in terms of robustness and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous networks is a challenging task due to the varying node degrees, types, and relationships. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that addresses these challenges. HAGNN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture node-level, subgraph-level, and graph-level features, enabling effective node classification. We evaluate HAGNN on several real-world heterogeneous networks and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art graph neural network models, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in F1-score.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Partitioning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics workloads. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel adaptive partitioning scheme, 'APart', which dynamically adjusts data placement and replication based on query patterns and workload characteristics. APart integrates a machine learning-based predictor to anticipate query access patterns and optimize data distribution accordingly. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate up to 3x improvement in query response times and 2x reduction in communication overhead compared to existing static partitioning schemes.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time-Series Anomaly Detection in IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of sensor-generated data, making it increasingly challenging to identify anomalous patterns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for time-series anomaly detection in IoT sensor data. Our approach leverages a multi-scale attention mechanism to capture complex dependencies across different time granularities, allowing for more accurate detection of anomalies. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that our HAN approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of F1-score and detection latency.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interaction and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but its cognitive implications are not yet fully understood. This study explores the relationship between gestural interaction, cognitive load, and embodied cognition in VR. We designed an experiment where participants performed a series of tasks in a VR environment, using either gestures or controllers. Our results show that gestural interaction reduces cognitive load and enhances embodied cognition, leading to improved task performance and user experience. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR systems and their potential applications in fields such as education and therapy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-Driven Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting has numerous applications in finance, healthcare, and climate science. While AI-driven models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates explainability mechanisms into time series forecasting. Our HAN model adaptively focuses on relevant segments of the input sequence, providing insights into the underlying dynamics. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on four benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in forecasting accuracy and providing meaningful explanations of the predicted outcomes.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient passage retrieval from a large corpus to answer a given question. Existing approaches often rely on keyword-based matching or dense retrievers, which can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Document Representation (HDR) model that leverages a novel document encoding scheme to capture both local and global contextual information. Our experiments on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that HDR achieves state-of-the-art passage retrieval accuracy while reducing the computational cost by up to 30% compared to existing dense retrieval methods.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Real-World Robotics
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in robotics, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders trust and adoption. This paper proposes a novel explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which integrates model-agnostic explanations with feature importance metrics to provide insights into DRL policies. We develop an efficient optimization approach that leverages proxy tasks and transfer learning to reduce the computational overhead of explainability. Experimental results on robotic manipulation tasks demonstrate that RL-Explain improves policy understanding and debugging, while maintaining performance competitiveness with state-of-the-art DRL methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with motor impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive gesture-based interfaces for this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving co-design workshops and usability testing with 20 older adults with motor impairments. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptability, feedback, and customization in gesture-based interfaces. We propose a set of design guidelines and a novel gesture recognition algorithm that can accommodate varying levels of motor ability. Our approach shows promise in enhancing the accessibility and usability of gesture-based interfaces for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis on multimodal data, such as images and text, is a challenging task due to the complexity of modeling interactions between modalities. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based neural network, 'HMN', which learns to selectively focus on relevant regions of the input data. HMN consists of two stages: (1) modality-specific attention modules that extract features from each modality, and (2) a hierarchical fusion module that adaptively combines features across modalities. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HMN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multimodal sentiment analysis, achieving an average improvement of 3.2% in accuracy.

title: Reinforced Query Expansion for Efficient Ad-hoc Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval in heterogeneous document collections poses significant challenges due to the diverse nature of documents and user queries. This paper proposes a novel reinforced query expansion approach, 'RQE-HDC', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query expansion for efficient retrieval. RQE-HDC incorporates a document similarity graph to capture complex relationships between documents and a query-dependent reward function to guide the expansion process. Experimental results on a large-scale heterogeneous dataset demonstrate a significant improvement in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning with Attention for Autonomous Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous urban traffic control aims to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that incorporates attention mechanisms to handle complex urban traffic dynamics. Our approach, called HART, consists of a high-level policy that selects traffic signal control strategies and a low-level policy that adjusts signal timings. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HART on a realistic simulation platform, showcasing improved traffic efficiency and reduced congestion compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex environments, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders trust and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical explainability framework for DRL, enabling the dissection of complex policies into comprehensible, modular components. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that highlights critical state features and action influences, facilitating the identification of causal relationships. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic manipulation tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving policy understanding and facilitating error analysis.

title: Unsupervised Discovery of Hierarchical Task Representations for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, the ability to learn hierarchical task representations is crucial for efficient coordination and planning. This paper presents a novel unsupervised learning approach, called HTR-MA, which discovers hierarchical task representations from raw agent observations. Our method leverages a hierarchical variational autoencoder to learn a disentangled representation of tasks, and a graph-based clustering algorithm to identify meaningful task clusters. Experimental results on a range of multi-agent environments demonstrate that HTR-MA significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and agent coordination.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Term Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) that aims to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach for query expansion, which leverages semantic term embeddings to capture the nuanced relationships between terms. Our approach, dubbed 'TermEmb', uses a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to learn dense vector representations of terms that are aware of their context and semantic meaning. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TermEmb significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision (MAP) and normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG).

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control with Uncertainty Quantification
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require robust control systems that can handle uncertain and dynamic environments. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that integrates uncertainty quantification (UQ) to improve the safety and efficiency of autonomous vehicle control. We introduce a novel UQ module that estimates the uncertainty of the vehicle's state and action spaces, which is then used to adapt the HRL policy. Our approach is evaluated on a realistic simulation platform, demonstrating improved control performance and reduced uncertainty compared to traditional HRL methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval often suffers from the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query terms fail to match the relevant documents. Query expansion is a popular technique to address this issue, but existing methods rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a deep neural ranking model, 'NeuralQE', which learns to expand queries by ranking candidate terms based on their semantic relevance. We experiment with various neural architectures and find that a combination of BERT-based encoding and graph attention yields significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets.

title: Efficient Indexing for Subgraph Matching in Dynamic Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Subgraph matching is a fundamental operation in graph databases, but existing indexing techniques struggle with dynamic graphs that undergo frequent updates. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'DynSub', which leverages a combination of graph summarization and incremental indexing to efficiently support subgraph matching queries in dynamic graph databases. We propose a novel graph summarization algorithm that adaptively selects a subset of graph nodes to represent the entire graph, and develop an incremental indexing scheme that efficiently updates the index structure in response to graph updates. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that DynSub outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query performance and 5x in index maintenance efficiency.

title: Scalable Real-time Object Detection using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Object detection is a fundamental task in computer vision, but real-time inference remains a significant challenge, particularly for high-resolution images. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant regions and scales. Our approach enables efficient feature extraction, reducing computational complexity while maintaining accuracy. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on various benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance on COCO and VOC datasets while operating at 30 FPS on 1080p images.

title: Heterogeneous Agent-Based Systems for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: Real-time resource allocation in smart grids is a complex problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel heterogeneous agent-based system, called 'GridAgent', which integrates multiple agents with different expertise and coordination mechanisms to optimize resource allocation. We propose a decentralized Markov decision process (MDP) framework that enables agents to learn and adapt to changing grid conditions, while ensuring scalability and robustness. Experimental results on a realistic testbed demonstrate that GridAgent outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods in terms of response time, energy efficiency, and fault tolerance.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning for Open-Set Domain Adaptation
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has made significant progress in recent years, but most existing methods are limited to closed-set domain adaptation, where the target domain is known during training. In this paper, we propose a hierarchical few-shot learning framework, 'HierFA', that tackles the more challenging open-set domain adaptation problem, where the target domain is unseen during training. HierFA utilizes a hierarchical meta-learning strategy to learn domain-invariant representations and adapt to new domains with few labeled examples. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HierFA in adapting to novel domains and improving the robustness of few-shot learning models.

title: Efficient Out-of-Distribution Detection for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but they often fail to recognize out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, leading to unreliable predictions. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian uncertainty estimation approach, 'BayesOOD', which leverages the epistemic uncertainty of neural networks to detect OOD samples. We develop a theoretically grounded framework that integrates Bayesian neural networks with a probabilistic OOD detection mechanism. Experiments on various image classification datasets demonstrate that BayesOOD outperforms existing OOD detection methods, achieving higher detection accuracy and robustness to adversarial attacks.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration for Complex Queries using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The join order problem is a fundamental challenge in query optimization, particularly for complex queries involving multiple tables and joins. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics or exhaustive enumeration, which can lead to suboptimal plans and poor performance. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to optimize join order enumeration. We formulate the problem as a Markov decision process and train a deep Q-network to learn the optimal join order for a given query pattern. Experiments on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of execution time and 2x in terms of memory usage.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed resource allocation is a complex problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must learn to coordinate their actions to optimize global rewards. This paper presents a novel framework for scalable multi-agent reinforcement learning, called 'MA-RL-DA', which leverages decentralized actor-critic methods and communication protocols to facilitate cooperation among agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MA-RL-DA in simulated and real-world scenarios, showcasing improved resource allocation efficiency and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-based Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent due to the ambiguity of query terms. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach that leverages graph-based word embeddings to model semantic relationships between words. Our method, GraphExpan, constructs a weighted graph of co-occurring terms in the query and then applies a random walk-based algorithm to generate expanded queries. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms traditional methods, such as Rocchio's algorithm, in terms of mean average precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) tasks require models to integrate information from both visual and linguistic inputs. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that efficiently fuses multimodal features for improved VQA performance. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical structure to model complex relationships between visual regions and question tokens, and introduces a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weighs the importance of each modality. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 benchmark demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art models, particularly in scenarios with limited training data.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient and Effective Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it enhances the retrieval of relevant documents by incorporating related terms into the original query. However, existing query expansion methods suffer from high computational complexity and suboptimal performance in large-scale document collections. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion approach, termed 'HQE', which leverages a multi-level indexing structure to efficiently identify relevant terms and expand the query. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Agents for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their design often overlooks the needs of people with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for creating inclusive conversational agents that accommodate diverse abilities. We conducted a large-scale user study with participants from various disability groups, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed framework incorporates multimodal interaction, personalized adaptation, and accessible feedback mechanisms. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through a prototype chatbot, 'Empathy', which significantly improves user engagement and satisfaction for users with disabilities.

title: Autonomous Conflict Resolution in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often encounter conflicts that hinder their collective performance.
