This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous conflict resolution using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized conflict resolution framework, 'ACR-DRL', where agents learn to negotiate and resolve conflicts through a combination of deep Q-networks and graph neural networks. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated traffic management scenario, where ACR-DRL achieves a 35% reduction in conflict frequency compared to traditional rule-based methods. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence properties of our algorithm.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Self-Supervised Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task in machine learning, particularly when limited labeled data is available. This paper presents a novel meta-learning approach, 'ProtoMeta', which leverages self-supervised prototypical networks to learn robust representations from unlabeled data. We introduce a new metric-based loss function that encourages the learning of prototype representations that are closer to the true class means. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ProtoMeta significantly outperforms existing few-shot classification methods, achieving state-of-the-art results on Mini-ImageNet and CIFAR-FS.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatar Customization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of personalized avatar customization on user experience in VR environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR system that allowed them to customize their avatars based on their personality traits. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly increased user engagement, sense of presence, and overall satisfaction. We also found that users with high levels of extraversion and openness to experience benefited more from personalized avatars. These findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to enhance user experience and encourage long-term engagement.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their usability for older adults is often limited due to cognitive, sensory, and motor impairments. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework that integrates voice, gesture, and visual cues to enhance accessibility for older adults. Our approach leverages machine learning-based gesture recognition and adaptive feedback mechanisms to facilitate intuitive interaction. A user study with 30 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (NIR) models have shown promising results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks. However, they often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal performance. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion framework that leverages the strengths of both traditional keyword extraction and neural language modeling. Our approach, called 'NeuroXPand', combines the semantic spaces of BERT and Word2Vec to generate high-quality expansion terms, which are then weighted using a neural ranking model. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that NeuroXPand significantly improves the retrieval effectiveness of state-of-the-art NIR models, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Guided Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing gesture recognition systems often fail to accommodate users with disabilities. This paper presents ' GestureGuide', a novel framework that leverages machine learning to recognize and adapt to diverse gestures, including those made by individuals with motor impairments. Our approach integrates a wearable sensor suite and a probabilistic gesture model to provide real-time feedback and personalized guidance. A user study with participants with and without disabilities demonstrates that GestureGuide significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user experience in VR environments.

title: Designing Accessible Augmented Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to enhance the daily lives of older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing AR interfaces are often inaccessible to this population due to their complex design and high cognitive demands. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create accessible AR interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to inform the design of our AR system, which incorporates simple and intuitive interactions, audio cues, and personalized assistance. Our evaluation results show that our system significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional AR interfaces.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Data Analytics on IoT Sensor Streams
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in sensor data, posing significant challenges for real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'RT-Index', which leverages a combination of in-memory caching, prefix-compression, and probabilistic indexing to achieve efficient query processing on high-volume sensor streams. Our approach reduces query latency by up to 75% compared to existing indexing techniques, while maintaining a low memory footprint. We evaluate RT-Index on a large-scale industrial IoT dataset, demonstrating its applicability in real-world scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, query optimization in these systems is a complex task due to the distributed nature of the data. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize queries by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on the query execution time. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the independence and quality of life of older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). However, existing systems often fail to account for the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an inclusive voice assistant, 'EasySpeak', which incorporates cognitive support features and personalized adaptation to facilitate successful interactions. Our user study with 20 older adults with MCI demonstrates that EasySpeak significantly reduces error rates and improves user satisfaction compared to a commercial voice assistant. The findings inform the development of more accessible and supportive voice interfaces for this growing demographic.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging hierarchical reinforcement learning to optimize task assignment and execution. Our approach, called HRL-TA, consists of two layers: a high-level task allocation layer that uses a deep Q-network to select tasks, and a low-level execution layer that employs a policy gradient method to optimize task execution. We evaluate HRL-TA in a simulated environment with multiple agents and tasks, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized task allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Language Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods rely on manual intervention or simplistic statistical models. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'NeuroQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to capture semantic relationships between query terms. We introduce a ranking-based approach that incorporates both local and global context to generate high-quality expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while requiring minimal human intervention.

title: Designing Emotive Avatars for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize social interactions, but existing avatars often lack emotional expressiveness, limiting user engagement and inclusivity. This paper presents a novel framework for designing emotive avatars that can convey nuanced emotions and personalities. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, using a combination of facial recognition, gesture analysis, and emotional intelligence metrics to evaluate the effectiveness of our approach. Results show that our emotive avatars significantly increase user feelings of empathy, presence, and social connection in VR environments. We discuss implications for accessible VR experiences and future research directions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) is a fundamental task in search engines, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion (QE) is a widely used technique to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel QE approach based on deep neural ranking models (NRM), which leverages the semantic relationships between words to generate effective expansion terms. Our method, called NRM-QE, uses a siamese neural network to learn a similarity function between the query and candidate expansion terms. Experimental results on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that NRM-QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural search models have shown promising results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but often struggle with vocabulary mismatch between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, NPREF, which leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to adaptively generate expansion terms. NPREF uses a neural reranker to estimate the relevance of top-ranked documents and then applies a modified Rocchio algorithm to extract expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that NPREF significantly improves the performance of a state-of-the-art neural search model, outperforming traditional query expansion methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the lives of older adults with motor impairments, but existing systems often fail to accommodate their unique needs. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to developing an inclusive gesture recognition system, tailored to the abilities and preferences of older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and usability studies to identify key design requirements, including adaptable gesture sets, personalized feedback mechanisms, and accessible system interfaces. Our results show that our system achieves high recognition accuracy and user satisfaction, even for users with severe motor impairments.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction Design
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) interaction design. We conducted a user study to investigate the effects of gesture-based interaction on cognitive load, user experience, and task performance in a VR environment. Our results show that incorporating embodied cognition principles into VR interaction design can significantly reduce cognitive load and improve user experience. We also identify key design recommendations for VR interface designers and provide implications for future research in this area.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve a common goal is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) with graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn efficient coordination strategies. Our method, called HRL-GNN, uses GNNs to model the graph structure of the agents' interactions and HRL to learn high-level policies that coordinate the agents' actions. We evaluate HRL-GNN in a variety of multi-agent scenarios, including traffic management and resource allocation, and demonstrate significant improvements in coordination efficiency and overall system performance.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to be assigned to tasks to maximize overall system efficiency. We propose a decentralized auction-based mechanism, called 'TaskAuction', which allows agents to bid on tasks based on their private valuations. TaskAuction incorporates a novel pricing scheme that incentivizes agents to reveal their true valuations, and a task allocation algorithm that maximizes social welfare. Experimental results on a simulated multi-agent system demonstrate that TaskAuction outperforms existing centralized allocation methods in terms of system efficiency and fairness.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Query Expansion in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but existing methods often rely on simplistic term-weighting schemes and ignore the hierarchical structure of documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation framework, 'HiDER', which captures both local and global context information. By leveraging a graph-based neural network to encode document hierarchies, HiDER enables more effective query expansion and improves retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HiDER over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Explainable Reasoning for Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MQA) requires models to perform complex reasoning over multiple sentences. While state-of-the-art models have achieved impressive results, their black-box nature hinders interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based explainable reasoning framework, 'HERO', which disentangles reasoning steps and provides transparent attention weights. We introduce a multi-task objective that jointly optimizes answer accuracy and explainability, enabling the model to generate faithful explanations for its predictions. Experimental results on three MQA benchmarks demonstrate that HERO improves both answer accuracy and explanation quality compared to existing explainable models.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient decision-making to maximize overall performance. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MATRL', which leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and learn optimal task assignments. We introduce a hierarchical action space decomposition method that reduces the complexity of the task allocation problem, enabling MATRL to scale to large numbers of agents and tasks. Experimental results on a simulated robotic warehouse scenario demonstrate that MATRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in Information Retrieval (IR) systems to improve the retrieval performance. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion method using deep reinforcement learning. Our approach, called QERL, formulates query expansion as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) and utilizes a deep Q-network to learn the optimal expansion strategy. The agent learns to select the most informative terms to add to the original query by interacting with the IR system and receiving rewards based on the retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QERL outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, including RM3 and Relevance Models.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition is a challenging task that involves fusing information from multiple sources such as speech, text, and vision. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features for emotion recognition. Our HAN model consists of two stages: modality attention and feature attention. The modality attention module learns to weight the importance of each modality, while the feature attention module focuses on the most informative features within each modality. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods, achieving an average F1-score of 0.83.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on hand-crafted features and weighting schemes, which often fail to capture complex document relationships. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network architecture, 'DocRank', which leverages self-attention mechanisms and contextualized embeddings to learn effective document representations. We demonstrate that DocRank outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models on several benchmark datasets, including TREC and ClueWeb. Our approach also enables efficient querying and indexing, making it suitable for large-scale web search applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Conversational Interaction
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their effectiveness for older adults is hindered by limited accessibility and usability. This study explores the design of inclusive voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, using a conversational interaction framework to analyze their voice assistant interactions. Our findings highlight the importance of explicit error handling, personalized dialogue management, and multimodal feedback. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating age-friendly voice assistants, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Retrieval Diversity in Search Engines
paper_abstract: Current search engines often return redundant or similar results, leading to a lack of retrieval diversity. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach to address this issue. Our method leverages contextualized embeddings to identify semantically related terms and expand the original query. We then incorporate a diversification module that re-ranks the expanded document set to prioritize novelty and relevance. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval diversity and user satisfaction, particularly for ambiguous and open-domain queries.

title: Designing Intelligent Virtual Assistants for People with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have become ubiquitous, but people with visual impairments (PWVI) often struggle to interact with them. This paper presents an HCI-driven approach to designing intelligent VAs that cater to PWVI. We conducted a user study with 20 participants to identify key challenges and preferences. Our proposed system, 'AccessibleVA', incorporates AI-driven speech recognition, natural language processing, and personalized feedback mechanisms. A usability evaluation with 15 PWVI participants showed significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing VA systems.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel approach to cooperative task allocation using distributed reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, called 'MARA', enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing environmental conditions. By leveraging a decentralized actor-critic framework, MARA improves task allocation efficiency and reduces communication overhead compared to traditional centralized optimization methods. We evaluate MARA in a simulated warehouse management scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in increasing overall system performance and robustness.

title: Efficient Bayesian Neural Network Pruning via Knowledge Distillation
paper_abstract: Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) offer a promising approach to uncertainty estimation in deep learning, but their high computational requirements hinder deployment in resource-constrained environments. We propose a novel pruning method, 'BayesDistil', which leverages knowledge distillation to reduce the complexity of BNNs while preserving their uncertainty estimation capabilities. Our approach involves training a compact, deterministic student network to mimic the predictive distribution of the original BNN, resulting in significant reductions in model size and inference time. Experiments on various image classification benchmarks demonstrate the efficacy of BayesDistil in maintaining accuracy and uncertainty calibration while achieving substantial speedups.

title: Multimodal Emotion Recognition using Deep Learning and Vibrotactile Feedback for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition systems have been increasingly employed in various human-computer interaction applications. However, existing approaches often rely on visual or auditory cues, overlooking the potential of haptic feedback. This paper proposes a novel multimodal emotion recognition framework that leverages deep learning techniques to integrate facial expressions, speech patterns, and vibrotactile feedback. Our system, 'EmoTouch', uses a wearable device to provide subtle vibrations that enhance user experience and improve emotion recognition accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that EmoTouch outperforms state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal approaches, achieving an F1-score of 0.92 in a real-world affective computing dataset.

title: Efficient Indexing for Range Queries in Main-Memory Column Stores
paper_abstract: Main-memory column stores have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics, but efficient indexing for range queries remains a significant challenge. Existing solutions often rely on traditional B-tree indexes, which can lead to poor performance due to the high storage overhead and limited cache efficiency. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'Ridge', which leverages the columnar storage layout to create a compact, cache-friendly index. Ridge uses a combination of bit-vector compression andSIMD instructions to accelerate range query processing. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that Ridge outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 5x in query performance while reducing memory usage by 30%.

title: Designing Augmented Reality-based Feedback Mechanisms for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but users often struggle to navigate virtual environments due to limited feedback. This paper presents a novel augmented reality (AR)-based feedback mechanism, 'VR-Feedback+', which utilizes visual, auditory, and haptic cues to enhance user experience in VR. We conducted a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of VR-Feedback+ and found significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion time, and spatial awareness compared to traditional VR feedback methods. Our results provide insights into the design of effective feedback mechanisms for VR applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, optimizing query performance becomes crucial for real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'Raptor', designed specifically for distributed column-store databases. Raptor leverages statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to predict query execution times and identify optimal query plans. We propose a cost-based optimization approach that considers both data distribution and computational resources. Experimental results on a large-scale analytics workload demonstrate that Raptor reduces query latency by up to 75% compared to state-of-the-art optimizers, while maintaining high accuracy and scalability.

title: Hypergraph-based Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but its computational complexity can be prohibitive for large document collections. This paper proposes a novel hypergraph-based approach to query expansion, which leverages the structural properties of hypergraphs to efficiently identify relevant terms and documents. Our methodology, 'HyperQE', represents queries and documents as hyperedges and nodes, respectively, and applies a probabilistic inference framework to estimate the relevance of expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HyperQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and computational efficiency.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but individuals with disabilities often face barriers to adopting these systems. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interface that enables users with mobility impairments to interact with VR environments more easily. Our approach leverages convolutional neural networks to accurately detect and classify gaze patterns, and integrates them with a VR system to provide intuitive control. We evaluate our method through a user study with participants with and without disabilities, demonstrating improved accessibility and usability in VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-robot interaction (HRI), enabling robots to respond empathetically to users. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates multi-modal sensory inputs from speech, facial expressions, and physiological signals. Our HAN model learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and temporal segments, improving emotion recognition accuracy in HRI scenarios. Experiments on the RECOLA dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an F1-score of 0.842 in recognizing six emotions. We discuss the implications of our work for developing more empathetic and socially aware robots.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a reinforcement learning framework that learns to optimize query plans based on the database's workload and hardware configuration. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks via Hierarchical Input Transformations
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be crafted by applying small, imperceptible perturbations to the input data. This paper proposes a novel defense mechanism, dubbed 'Hierarchical Input Transformation' (HIT), which leverages a hierarchical representation of the input data to increase the robustness of DNNs against such attacks. Our approach involves applying a series of transformations to the input data at multiple scales, effectively 'denoising' the input and making it more difficult for an adversary to craft effective attacks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HIT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in terms of robustness to adversarial attacks.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gestural Feedback in Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance the lives of individuals with motor impairments, but existing VR interfaces often rely on precise hand or finger movements that can be challenging for this population. This study investigates the efficacy of gestural feedback in VR interfaces designed for users with motor impairments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, comparing traditional visual and auditory feedback to a novel gestural feedback system that utilizes haptic and proprioceptive cues. Results show significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction with the gestural feedback system, highlighting its potential for increasing accessibility in VR applications.

title: Query-Driven Document Ranking with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel document ranking approach that leverages hierarchical graph attention networks (HGAT) to model complex query-document relationships. Our method, dubbed QR-HGAT, represents queries and documents as graph-structured data and applies attention mechanisms at multiple granularity levels to capture both local and global semantic patterns. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QR-HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of ranking accuracy and robustness to query variations.

title: Distributed Agent-Based Decision Support System for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic management poses significant challenges due to the complexity and dynamics of urban transportation networks. This paper proposes a novel distributed agent-based decision support system (D-ABDSS) that leverages multi-agent systems and distributed computing to optimize traffic signal control and routing. The D-ABDSS framework consists of autonomous agents that cooperate to minimize travel times, reduce congestion, and improve traffic safety. We evaluate the system using real-world traffic data from San Francisco, demonstrating significant improvements in traffic flow and reductions in travel times compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often struggle to capture the nuances of heterogeneous document collections, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which incorporates semantic and syntactic features from the document collection to generate context-specific expansion terms. CAQE leverages a graph-based attention mechanism to weight the contribution of each feature, enabling the model to adapt to diverse document collections. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving up to 25% improvement in retrieval precision.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Keyword Extraction
paper_abstract: Traditional keyword extraction techniques for document retrieval often rely on manual annotation or shallow linguistics. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages hierarchical neural networks to automatically extract relevant keywords from documents. Our model, Hier KE, incorporates a document-level encoder to capture global context and a sentence-level decoder to identify local keyword patterns. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that Hier KE outperforms state-of-the-art keyword extraction methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on cumbersome controllers or voice commands, limiting immersion and accessibility. We present a novel approach to gaze-based interaction in VR using deep learning. Our method, 'GazeNet', employs a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect and classify gaze patterns in real-time, enabling users to interact with virtual objects through gaze alone. We evaluate GazeNet in a VR environment and demonstrate its accuracy and robustness in various scenarios, including object selection, navigation, and manipulation. The results show promising implications for enhancing user experience and accessibility in VR applications.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Enhancing Dense Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has revolutionized open-domain question answering by leveraging neural networks to encode queries and passages. However, DPR often struggles with lexical mismatch and limited context. This paper proposes a neural query expansion (NQE) approach that generates semantically rich and diverse query representations. Our NQE model is trained using a combination of contrastive learning and semantic similarity metrics, allowing it to effectively capture latent query intents. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that NQE-enhanced DPR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a 13.5% relative improvement in top-1 accuracy.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Query Optimization
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of database systems, and join order enumeration is a key step in this process. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, which can lead to suboptimal plans. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize join order enumeration. Our method, called 'JoinRL', uses a neural network to learn a policy that guides the search for optimal join orders. We evaluate JoinRL on a range of benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time compared to state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Autonomous Vehicles in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles operating in dynamic environments require efficient task planning to adapt to changing circumstances. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network planning framework, 'HTNP-AV', which integrates symbolic and geometric planning to generate feasible and optimal plans. HTNP-AV utilizes a layered architecture to reason about tasks, motions, and trajectories, allowing it to handle complex scenarios with multiple goals and constraints. Experimental results in a simulated urban environment demonstrate the effectiveness of HTNP-AV in reducing planning time and improving vehicle safety compared to traditional planning approaches.

title: Query-Driven Indexing for Efficient Retrieval in Hierarchical Document Collections
paper_abstract: The growing complexity of hierarchical document collections necessitates efficient indexing techniques for fast query processing. This paper presents a novel query-driven indexing approach, 'HIER-index', which adaptively constructs and refines indexes based on query patterns and document structures. By leveraging the hierarchical organization of documents, HIER-index reduces the indexing overhead and accelerates query evaluation. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that HIER-index outperforms existing indexing methods, achieving up to 3x faster query response times and 2x better storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Recent advances in autonomous driving have focused on deep reinforcement learning (RL) methods, but these often suffer from high sample complexity and limited scalability. We propose a novel hierarchical RL framework, 'HRL-AD', which leverages a multi-level abstraction of driving tasks to improve efficiency and adaptability. By decomposing the driving policy into high-level goals and low-level control primitives, HRL-AD reduces the exploration space and achieves faster convergence. We evaluate HRL-AD on a realistic simulation platform, demonstrating improved driving performance and robustness to diverse scenarios and weather conditions.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents via Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating autonomous agents in dynamic environments. Our approach, called Hierarchical-Actor-Critic (HAC), leverages a hierarchical policy representation to decompose complex tasks into simpler sub-tasks, enabling more efficient exploration and learning. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAC in a simulated robotic soccer domain, where teams of agents must adapt to changing opponents and environmental conditions. Experimental results show that HAC outperforms state-of-the-art flat reinforcement learning methods in terms of task completion rate and overall team performance.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Large-Scale Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Large-scale multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve global objectives. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-TA', which leverages hierarchical task decomposition and distributed reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in a decentralized manner. We demonstrate that HRL-TA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and system scalability, while also exhibiting improved robustness to agent failures. Experimental results on a simulation platform with 1000+ agents validate the effectiveness of our approach in real-world scenarios.

title: Scalable Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely on query expansion to retrieve relevant products, but traditional methods are limited by their reliance on handcrafted rules and shallow semantic analysis. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages neural networks to learn semantic relationships between queries and products. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights term importance based on query context and product attributes. Experiments on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that DeepQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 23% increase in retrieval accuracy and a 15% decrease in latency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Embedding-based Term Selection for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in improving the effectiveness of ad-hoc retrieval systems. This paper presents a novel neural embedding-based approach to term selection, which leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. Our model, called NeuroTE, learns to represent query terms and documents as dense vectors, enabling the identification of informative expansion terms that are semantically close to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroTE consistently outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial step in database systems, but traditional cost-based optimization techniques often struggle to accurately estimate query execution times. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to accelerate query optimization. We develop a neural network-based model that learns to predict query execution times from a dataset of historical query plans. Our experiments on a real-world database workload show that our approach can reduce query optimization time by up to 75% while maintaining competitive plan quality. We also explore the integration of learned index structures with traditional optimization techniques to further improve performance.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Navigation for Augmented Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) interfaces often rely on manual input methods, which can be cumbersome and limiting. This paper presents a novel gaze-based adaptive navigation system, 'GazeNav', that leverages eye-tracking technology to enable more intuitive and efficient user interaction. We introduce a machine learning model that predicts user intent from gaze patterns and adapts the navigation scheme accordingly. Our user study demonstrates that GazeNav significantly reduces task completion time and improves user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods. The system's flexibility and adaptability make it suitable for a wide range of AR applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query formulations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the selection of expansion terms. Our approach, dubbed 'RL-QE', learns to balance the trade-off between query specificity and coverage by interacting with a simulated search environment. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, improving mean average precision by up to 15%.

title: Multi-Task Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require complex control policies that can handle diverse scenarios and tasks. This paper presents a multi-task deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MT-DRL', that learns to control autonomous vehicles in various environments and scenarios. Our approach uses a shared policy network that learns to perform multiple tasks simultaneously, such as lane following, obstacle avoidance, and traffic signal recognition. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MT-DRL on a realistic simulation platform, achieving improved performance and adaptability compared to single-task learning methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Blockchain-based Reputation Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and trustworthy decision-making. This paper presents a novel decentralized approach that leverages blockchain technology to establish a reputation system for autonomous agents. Our framework, 'AgentRep', enables agents to evaluate each other's performance and reliability in real-time, ensuring that tasks are allocated to the most suitable agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentRep through simulations of search-and-rescue scenarios, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Exploiting Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems often require agents to learn from each other's experiences to achieve common goals. However, existing approaches struggle to scale to large agent populations and complex graph-structured environments. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) architecture, 'CoopGAT', which enables efficient and flexible knowledge sharing among agents. By incorporating attention mechanisms, CoopGAT adaptively weights the importance of neighboring agents' experiences, leading to improved cooperation and faster convergence. Experiments on a range of multi-agent tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of CoopGAT in promoting cooperative behavior and achieving superior performance over baseline methods.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Graph Neural Networks and Hierarchical Planning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent pathfinding, which combines graph neural networks (GNNs) with hierarchical planning. Our method, called Hierarchical Graph Planner (HGP), leverages the strengths of GNNs in learning node representations and the efficiency of hierarchical planning in reducing the search space. We demonstrate that HGP outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of solution quality, computation time, and scalability on various benchmark scenarios. Moreover, we provide a thorough analysis of the impact of GNN architecture and hierarchical planning parameters on the performance of HGP.

title: Gaze-based Intention Recognition for Proactive Assistive Systems
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often rely on assistive devices that respond to explicit commands. However, these systems can be slow and laborious to use. We propose a novel approach to proactive assistive systems, which leverages gaze-based intention recognition to anticipate users' goals. Our method, 'GazeIntention', combines convolutional neural networks with graph-based models to analyze eye movement patterns and infer the user's intended action. Experimental results with 20 participants demonstrate that GazeIntention achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by 15.2%. We discuss the implications of our work for enhancing the quality of life for individuals with motor impairments.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to make critical decisions, but the lack of transparency in these models hinders trust and accountability. This paper proposes XRL, a novel framework that integrates explainability into RL for autonomous vehicle decision-making. XRL employs a model-agnostic explanation technique to provide real-time insights into the decision-making process, thereby improving safety and interpretability. Experimental results on a simulated driving environment demonstrate that XRL achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art RL methods while providing meaningful explanations for its decisions.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks through Hierarchical Adversarial Training
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be catastrophic in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical adversarial training framework, 'HAT', which leverages the idea of curriculum learning to improve the robustness of deep models. HAT iteratively generates adversarial examples at multiple scales, from local to global, and incorporates them into the training process. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAT-trained models achieve state-of-the-art robustness against various types of attacks, including white-box and black-box attacks, while maintaining competitive performance on clean data.

title: Efficient skyline query processing using hierarchical indexing on distributed databases
paper_abstract: Skyline queries are essential in many applications, such as multi-criteria decision-making and data analysis. However, processing skyline queries efficiently on large-scale distributed databases remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'HierSky', which leverages a hierarchical structure to prune the search space and reduce communication overhead. Our empirical evaluation on real-world datasets demonstrates that HierSky outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 50% in terms of query response time and scales well with increasing data sizes.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Older Adults: A Wizard-of-Oz Study
paper_abstract: This paper presents a Wizard-of-Oz study examining the design of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) for older adults. We investigated the impact of agent embodiment, dialogue style, and feedback mechanisms on user experience and perceived trust. Our results show that older adults prefer agents with human-like embodiment and empathetic dialogue, and that explicit feedback mechanisms can improve user engagement. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of ECAs in healthcare and social isolation interventions, highlighting the need for user-centered approaches that accommodate the unique needs and preferences of older adults.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph queries and the distributed nature of the data. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework for distributed graph databases, which leverages graph partitioning and query rewriting techniques to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. We evaluate our approach on a real-world graph dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to existing query optimization techniques.

title: Neural Query Graph Generation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to open-domain question answering (ODQA) by generating neural query graphs (NQGs) to efficiently retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus. Our method, dubbed 'GraphQA', models the query-passage relationships using a graph neural network, which learns to encode the query semantics and passage relevance in a unified graph representation. We demonstrate significant improvements in passage retrieval efficiency and question answering accuracy compared to traditional keyword-based and BERT-based methods on several benchmark datasets.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Embodiment on User Trust in Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) are increasingly integrated into daily life, but their lack of embodiment can lead to user distrust. This study investigates the effect of anthropomorphic embodiment on user trust in VAs. We designed an experiment with 120 participants, where they interacted with a VA either with a humanoid avatar or without. Results show that participants who interacted with the embodied VA reported higher trust and perceived the VA as more intelligent and relatable. We also found that users' personality traits, such as agreeableness and conscientiousness, influenced their trust in the VA. Our findings have implications for the design of future VAs, suggesting that embodiment can be a crucial factor in establishing user trust.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Dense Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient passage retrieval to reduce the search space for answer generation. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Neural Dense Passage Retrieval (HN-DPR) model that leverages a hierarchical architecture to prune irrelevant passages. Our approach combines a coarse-grained retrieval module with a fine-grained re-ranking module, achieving a 30% increase in retrieval accuracy and a 2x speedup compared to state-of-the-art DPR models. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HN-DPR in improving ODQA performance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media has severe consequences for individuals and society. Despite advances in deep learning-based fake news detection, interpretability remains a major concern. This paper proposes a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages the structural properties of social networks to identify suspicious patterns. Our approach incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to focus on critical nodes and edges, enabling the identification of key propagators and topics contributing to fake news dissemination. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HGAT in improving detection accuracy while providing insights into the underlying diffusion mechanisms.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems (DDS) increasingly employ heterogeneous storage configurations, query optimization becomes a critical challenge. This paper presents 'HeteroOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to adapt to varying storage characteristics. HeteroOpt integrates a storage-aware cost model, a query plan enumerator, and a reinforcement learning-based plan selector to minimize query latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world DDS testbed demonstrate that HeteroOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 35% in terms of query response time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Real-Time Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time database systems require efficient indexing mechanisms to support high-performance query processing. Existing indexing techniques often compromise between query latency and update throughput. This paper presents 'Raijin', a novel, adaptive indexing framework that dynamically adjusts the index structure based on workload patterns and system resource utilization. Raijin leverages machine learning-based prediction models to anticipate query patterns and optimize index maintenance, ensuring low query latency and high update throughput. Experimental evaluations on a real-world financial database demonstrate that Raijin outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query latency and 2x in update throughput.

title: Deep Adaptive Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of dynamically allocating resources to meet varying workloads and optimize performance. This paper proposes a novel deep adaptive reinforcement learning framework, 'DARLA', which leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning and adaptive exploration to optimize resource allocation in cloud computing environments. We demonstrate that DARLA achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Furthermore, we show that DARLA can adapt to changing workloads and scales well to large-scale cloud deployments.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Patent Search using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Patent search is a crucial task in intellectual property management, but the complexity and variability of patent documents make it challenging. We propose a hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to capture the semantic relationships between patent concepts. Our method, called HQE-GNN, first constructs a graph of query terms and their synonyms, then applies GNNs to learn a dense representation of the query. Experimental results on a large patent dataset demonstrate that HQE-GNN outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision and recall, while reducing the computational cost.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Deep Learning on Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a given mention. Existing approaches suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large-scale knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel graph-based deep learning approach, GraphED, which leverages the structural properties of knowledge graphs to disambiguate entities. GraphED uses a graph attention mechanism to capture contextual information and a hierarchical clustering strategy to reduce the search space. Experimental results on popular benchmarks demonstrate that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin, achieving an F1-score of 95.2% on the YAGO dataset.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Indexing Techniques for Scalable RDF Query Processing
paper_abstract: The growing popularity of Resource Description Framework (RDF) has led to an increased need for efficient query processing techniques. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of various indexing techniques for scalable RDF query processing. We implement and compare four indexing approaches, namely, B-Tree, Hash, Trie, and Bitmapped indexing, using a real-world RDF dataset. Our experimental results show that the choice of indexing technique significantly impacts query performance, with Bitmapped indexing outperforming other approaches by up to 30% in certain scenarios. We also discuss the trade-offs between indexing techniques and provide guidelines for selecting the most suitable approach based on query patterns and dataset characteristics.

title: Designing Emotive Avatars for Enhanced User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has immense potential for immersive experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to designing emotive avatars that simulate human-like emotions, thereby increasing user empathy and participation. We propose an affective computing framework that integrates facial expression recognition, sentiment analysis, and machine learning-based emotional state modeling. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that emotive avatars significantly enhance user engagement, with a 35% increase in self-reported emotional connection and a 25% increase in task completion rates.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Hybrid Relational-NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The rise of big data has led to the increasing adoption of hybrid relational-NoSQL databases, which combine the structured querying capabilities of relational databases with the scalability and flexibility of NoSQL systems. However, query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'HybridOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and a hierarchical query rewriting approach to efficiently optimize queries in hybrid databases. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HybridOpt outperforms existing query optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'EmbedQE', which leverages word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms. We introduce a graph-based method to select the most informative expansion terms, considering both local and global context. Experimental results on several TREC collections demonstrate that EmbedQE outperforms traditional QE methods, achieving significant gains in precision and recall.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Scalable Time-Series Data Management
paper_abstract: Time-series data is increasingly prevalent in various applications, from IoT sensor readings to financial transactions. The sheer volume and velocity of such data pose significant challenges to traditional indexing methods, leading to poor query performance and high storage overhead. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'TSIndex', which leverages a combination of data compression, chunk-based indexing, and query optimization techniques to achieve efficient query processing and reduced storage requirements. Experimental results on real-world time-series datasets demonstrate that TSIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in query response time and 5x in storage efficiency.

title: Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Session-based Search
paper_abstract: Session-based search queries often lack contextual information, leading to ineffective query representations. We propose a novel approach, 'HGAT-Expand', which leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to model complex query relationships and expand the original query. Our method first constructs a hierarchical graph representing the query session, and then applies a graph attention mechanism to learn weighted representations of query terms. Experimental results on the TREC Sessions track dataset demonstrate that HGAT-Expand significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of search ranking performance and relevance metrics.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria: An Exploration of Adaptive Speech Recognition Techniques
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and pronunciation, often face challenges when interacting with voice assistants. This paper presents an investigation into adaptive speech recognition techniques to improve the accessibility of voice assistants for users with dysarthria. We propose a novel framework that incorporates personalized acoustic models, spectral features, and uncertainty-based confidence scoring. Our evaluation with a dataset of dysarthric speech shows significant improvements in speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction, highlighting the potential of our approach to enhance the inclusivity of voice-controlled systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for multi-agent dialogue systems, enabling explainable decision-making in complex conversational scenarios. Our approach integrates task-oriented and social dialogue management, allowing agents to adapt to changing contexts and user preferences. We evaluate our HAN model on a benchmark dataset, demonstrating significant improvements in dialogue coherence, relevance, and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we provide visual analytics tools to facilitate understanding of the attention mechanisms, enhancing transparency and trust in AI-driven dialogue systems.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Decentralized Reinforcement Learning in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple autonomous agents in complex environments is a challenging problem with applications in robotics, smart cities, and IoT. This paper proposes a decentralized reinforcement learning framework, 'Decentralized Action-Value Estimation' (DAVE), which enables agents to learn coordinated policies without relying on a centralized controller. DAVE leverages an actor-critic architecture and a novel attention mechanism to facilitate communication and coordination among agents. We evaluate DAVE in a simulated urban traffic scenario, demonstrating improved coordination and reduced congestion compared to traditional decentralized approaches.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning with Graph-Based Meta-Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) has seen significant progress with the advent of graph neural networks (GNNs). However, most existing approaches rely on manual graph construction or require large amounts of labeled data. This paper proposes a novel graph-based meta-reinforcement learning framework, 'MetaZSL', which learns to adapt to new unseen classes without additional training data. We introduce a reinforcement learning objective that encourages the agent to explore the graph structure and meta-learn effective policies for ZSL tasks. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaZSL in improving ZSL performance and reducing the need for manual graph engineering.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar Customization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various industries, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatar customization on user experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, randomly assigning them to either a personalized or non-personalized avatar condition. Our results show that users with personalized avatars exhibited higher engagement levels, as measured by time spent in the VR environment and self-reported enjoyment. Furthermore, we identified significant correlations between avatar customization features and user personality traits, suggesting that personalized avatars can enhance user experience by catering to individual preferences.

title: Hybrid Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in search engines rely on hand-crafted features, which often fail to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a hybrid neural ranking model, 'NeuRank', that combines the strengths of neural networks and traditional ranking models. NeuRank employs a multi-task learning framework, where a shared neural encoder learns to represent queries and documents in a joint latent space, while task-specific ranking and classification heads optimize for relevance and semantic matching. Experiments on a large-scale web search dataset demonstrate that NeuRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of retrieval efficiency and document ranking quality.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Enhance Accessibility for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have become an integral part of modern life, but their usability is often limited for individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a novel multimodal framework for designing inclusive virtual assistants that can adapt to the diverse needs of users with disabilities. We propose a hybrid approach combining speech, gesture, and eye-tracking inputs to enhance accessibility. Our user study with 30 participants with disabilities demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional text-based interfaces. We also discuss the implications of our findings for future HCI research and the development of more inclusive AI systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Dense Retrieval for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a technique used to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. We propose a neural dense retrieval approach for query expansion, which leverages the semantic similarities between query terms and document representations. Our approach outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as Rocchio and relevance feedback, on several benchmark datasets. We also demonstrate that our approach can be efficiently integrated into a real-world search engine, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) has seen significant progress with the advent of neural retrievers. However, existing methods suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper presents HierGraph, a novel hierarchical graph neural network architecture for efficient passage retrieval in ODQA. HierGraph leverages a graph-based representation of the document collection, enabling the model to capture complex contextual relationships between passages. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HierGraph achieves state-of-the-art results while reducing inference time by up to 70% compared to existing methods.

title: Deep Hierarchical Clustering for Unsupervised Representation Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Unsupervised representation learning has become increasingly important in computer vision, as it allows models to learn features without human annotations. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical clustering framework, 'HierClus', which learns hierarchical representations by iteratively clustering and refining feature embeddings. We introduce a novel loss function that encourages the discovery of discriminative and hierarchical features, and demonstrate the effectiveness of HierClus on several benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet. Experimental results show that HierClus outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised learning methods in terms of clustering quality and downstream task performance.

title: Gaze-based Intention Detection for Hand-free Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology advances, there is a growing need for more natural and intuitive interaction methods. This paper presents a novel approach for detecting user intentions in VR using gaze-based input. Our method leverages a deep learning-based gaze estimation model and a probabilistic intention recognition framework to infer user goals from their gaze patterns. We evaluate our approach in a series of experiments involving object manipulation and navigation tasks, demonstrating improved interaction performance and user experience compared to traditional controller-based methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing systems require efficient resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'CloudAllocator', which allocates resources adaptively based on real-time system state and workload patterns. Our approach uses decentralized, self-organizing agents that learn to cooperate and negotiate resource allocation decisions, resulting in improved system utilization and reduced latency. Experimental results on a large-scale cloud simulation platform demonstrate the effectiveness of CloudAllocator in minimizing resource wastage and enhancing overall system performance.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task-Oriented Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Task-oriented dialogue systems struggle to balance efficiency and accuracy, often relying on handcrafted rules or shallow reinforcement learning. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Dialog', which leverages a novel two-level task decomposition mechanism. The high-level policy focuses on task progression, while the low-level policy handles turn-level dialogue management. We introduce a curriculum-based training approach, where the low-level policy is initially trained on a simulated user dataset and gradually adapted to real user interactions. Experimental results on a banking domain dataset demonstrate that HRL-Dialog achieves improved task completion rates, reduced dialogue turns, and enhanced user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time decision-making to navigate complex scenarios. We propose a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that leverages a two-level abstraction to balance exploration and exploitation. The high-level policy focuses on strategic decision-making, while the low-level policy executes tactical control actions. We introduce a novel experience replay mechanism that adaptively samples transitions based on their relevance to the current state, reducing the need for large-scale exploration. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves superior performance and faster adaptation to changing environments compared to flat reinforcement learning methods.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency with Adaptive Indexing for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The increasing volume of data has led to a surge in information retrieval (IR) queries, posing significant challenges to query efficiency. This paper presents an adaptive indexing approach, QueryScalpel, that dynamically optimizes index structures based on query patterns and data distributions. Our approach leverages a reinforcement learning framework to learn the most effective indexing strategy, achieving up to 3.5x query speedup and 2x storage reduction compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques. Experimental results on a large-scale web dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of QueryScalpel in improving query efficiency and scalability.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but individuals with motor impairments often face barriers in using these systems. This paper presents an investigation into the design of inclusive gesture-based interfaces that cater to diverse motor abilities. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with motor impairments, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the development of a novel gesture recognition framework, 'IncluGesture', which incorporates adaptive thresholding, gesture segmentation, and machine learning-based gesture classification. Evaluation results demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in modern recommendation systems to build trust with users. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Neural Network (HGNN) architecture that incorporates both item and user graph structures to generate personalized recommendations. Our model learns to identify influential items and users, providing interpretable explanations for the recommended items. We conduct extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets, demonstrating the superiority of HGNN over state-of-the-art methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem. We propose a decentralized approach using Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes (POMDPs) to model agent decision-making. Our method, 'Dec-POMDP-Co', enables agents to learn coordination policies in a decentralized manner, without requiring a centralized controller or complete knowledge of the environment. We evaluate Dec-POMDP-Co in a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved coordination and task completion rates compared to traditional, centralized approaches.

title: Indexing Materialized Views in Column-Store Databases for Efficient Query Optimization
paper_abstract: Column-store databases have gained popularity due to their ability to efficiently store and query large amounts of data. However, query optimization remains a challenging task, especially when dealing with complex queries involving multiple joins and aggregations. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique for materialized views in column-store databases, which enables the database to prune unnecessary data and reduce the query processing time. Our approach, called ColMVIndex, leverages the column-store layout to create a hierarchical index structure that efficiently supports query optimization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColMVIndex achieves an average speedup of 3.2x compared to traditional indexing techniques.

title: Decision-Theoretic Planning for Autonomous Agents in Stochastic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in stochastic environments must balance exploration and exploitation to achieve their objectives. This paper presents a novel decision-theoretic planning framework that integrates planning-as-satisficing and model-based reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'StoPAS', leverages a probabilistic model of the environment to compute a satisficing plan that maximizes the expected utility of the agent. We demonstrate the effectiveness of StoPAS in a series of experiments involving a robotic agent navigating a partially observable maze, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art planning and reinforcement learning methods in terms of cumulative reward and planning efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Databases
