paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become ubiquitous in modern data processing, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing approach, 'DynIndex', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distribution. DynIndex combines machine learning-based query prediction with cost-based optimization to minimize query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database shows that DynIndex achieves up to 3x query performance improvement compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while reducing storage overhead by up to 25%

title: Hybrid Ranking Model for Diversified Search Results using Neural Query Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Modern search engines often struggle to provide diversified results, leading to redundant information and poor user experience. This paper proposes a novel hybrid ranking model, 'NeuDiv', which leverages neural query graph embeddings to capture complex relationships between queries and documents. By combining the strengths of both lexical and semantic matching, NeuDiv achieves significant improvements in search result diversification while maintaining relevance. Experimental evaluations on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of NeuDiv in reducing redundancy and enhancing user satisfaction.

title: Adaptive Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Heterogeneous Objectives
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, existing approaches often assume homogeneous objectives among agents, which is unrealistic in many real-world scenarios. This paper proposes an adaptive coalition formation framework that accommodates heterogeneous objectives and dynamic environments. We introduce a novel graph-based algorithm that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize coalition structures and adapt to changing agent objectives. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving overall system performance and robustness.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple autonomous agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn both high-level traffic management strategies and low-level control policies. Our approach leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to optimize its local traffic signal control while coordinating with neighboring agents to achieve global objectives. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate that our approach improves traffic flow by up to 25% compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, query performance remains a significant challenge due to the inherent complexity of distributed indexing. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing approach that dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. We introduce a novel cost model that estimates the query execution time and optimizes the index configuration accordingly. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional static indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search is a fundamental task in information retrieval (IR) where the search system must retrieve relevant documents for a given query. However, the performance of IR systems is often limited by the quality of the query. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of queries and documents. Our approach, called 'NeuroQE', uses a transformer-based architecture to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and generates expanded queries that improve retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant gains in precision and recall.

title: EyeGaze+: A Deep Learning-based Gaze Estimation System for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Gaze estimation is a crucial component in human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling applications like gaze-based interfaces and visual attention analysis. We present EyeGaze+, a deep learning-based gaze estimation system that leverages a novel multi-modal fusion approach combining eye images and 3D head pose information. Our system achieves state-of-the-art performance on the MPIIGaze dataset, with a mean absolute error of 4.21°. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of EyeGaze+ in a real-world HCI scenario, where users interacted with a gaze-based interface to select targets on a screen with high accuracy.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Large-Scale Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but its computational cost can be prohibitive for large-scale document collections. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach that leverages a deep learning-based ranking model to generate context-aware query expansions. Our approach, 'NeuroQE', learns to identify informative query terms and expand them with relevant synonyms, hypernyms, and related entities. We evaluate NeuroQE on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Heterogeneous Capabilities
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents possess heterogeneous capabilities and resources. We propose a decentralized, auction-based approach that utilizes a novel, capability-aware bidding strategy to allocate tasks efficiently. Our approach takes into account not only the agents' processing capacities but also their communication constraints and task precedence relationships. Experimental results on a series of benchmarks demonstrate that our framework achieves significant improvements in task completion times and resource utilization compared to existing centralized and decentralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Range Queries in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: As main-memory databases continue to gain popularity, query optimization techniques must adapt to their unique characteristics. This paper focuses on multidimensional range queries, which are critical in various applications such as spatial databases and data analytics. We propose a novel query optimization algorithm, 'Ranger', that leverages the properties of main-memory storage to reduce query latency. Ranger employs a combination of indexing, caching, and parallel processing to minimize the number of memory accesses and improve query performance. Experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that Ranger outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x for complex range queries.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Re-Ranking with Query-Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models in information retrieval (IR) often rely on complex and computationally expensive architectures. This paper proposes a novel deep neural re-ranking model, 'QRN', which leverages query-document embeddings to efficiently capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. QRN utilizes a dual-encoder architecture that jointly learns query and document representations, and a lightweight re-ranking module that refines the initial ranking list. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that QRN significantly outperforms traditional ranking methods and achieves comparable performance to more complex neural ranking models, while requiring significantly less computational resources.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Multi-Modal Dialog Systems
paper_abstract: Traditional knowledge graph embedding methods struggle to capture complex relationships and contextual dependencies in multi-modal dialog systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based approach, 'HAT-KGE', which learns to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations within the graph. We introduce a multi-level attention mechanism that aggregates entity and relation embeddings across different modalities, enabling more effective and efficient dialog management. Experiments on a large-scale dialog dataset demonstrate significant improvements in response generation quality and dialog coherence compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Query Expansion via Deep Neural Networks for Enhancing Retrieval Effectiveness in Short-Text Documents
paper_abstract: Short-text documents, such as tweets and product reviews, pose significant challenges to information retrieval systems due to their limited context and vocabulary. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, dubbed 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to capture semantic relationships between words and expand query terms. We employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to identify relevant context words and weighted term embeddings to refine query representations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and robustness to query ambiguity.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but existing techniques often struggle with domain-specific terminology and scarce training data. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE', which leverages domain knowledge graphs and word embeddings to generate more informative and context-aware queries. HQE iteratively expands the query by incorporating relevant domain concepts, synonyms, and hypernyms, leading to significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall. Experimental results on a collection of biomedical and legal documents demonstrate the effectiveness of HQE in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 25%.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms require efficient resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudOptimizer', which learns to optimize resource allocation in real-time. Our approach combines a deep Q-network with a graph neural network to capture complex dependencies between resources and workloads. We evaluate CloudOptimizer on a large-scale cloud simulation platform and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to existing heuristics and model-free RL methods.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Haptic Feedback for Enhanced Virtual Reality Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but users often struggle to navigate virtual environments due to limited haptic feedback. This paper presents a novel gaze-based adaptive haptic feedback system, 'GazeHaptics', which leverages eye-tracking data to dynamically adjust tactile feedback in real-time. Our approach utilizes machine learning algorithms to predict user intentions and subtly modulate haptic cues, thereby enhancing user immersion and reducing disorientation. User studies demonstrate significant improvements in task performance and subjective experience, highlighting the potential of GazeHaptics to transform VR interactions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Neural Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to predict sentiment from heterogeneous data sources such as text, images, and videos. Existing approaches often rely on early fusion or late fusion strategies, which may not effectively capture complex interactions between modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention neural network (HANN) for MSA, which recursively applies attention mechanisms to different modalities and fusion levels. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSI and YouTube datasets show that HANN outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 3.2% and 2.5% in terms of accuracy, respectively. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned attention patterns, revealing insights into the importance of modality interactions in MSA.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for multi-agent systems, leveraging hierarchical reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. We formalize the problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) and propose a hierarchical Q-network architecture that learns to allocate tasks based on agent capabilities, task priority, and environmental constraints. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional distributed allocation methods.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks via Bayesian Neural Symbolic Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to improving the adversarial robustness of DNNs by integrating Bayesian neural networks with symbolic learning. Our method, 'BayesSL', first learns a probabilistic neural network to model the uncertainty of the input data, and then uses symbolic reasoning to identify and prune vulnerable neurons. We evaluate BayesSL on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving the robustness of DNNs against various types of adversarial attacks.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant contexts for answer extraction. However, existing methods often struggle to retrieve passages that contain the answer but lack exact keyword matches. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, QDE, which generates synthetic passages by iteratively applying semantic perturbations to the query. We evaluate QDE on several ODQA benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in recall and overall answer accuracy. Our analysis reveals that QDE effectively captures latent semantic relationships between the query and relevant documents, leading to more comprehensive passage retrieval.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task, particularly when faced with limited labeled data. This paper presents a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, 'HiCo', which leverages both local and global feature representations to improve classification accuracy. By hierarchically clustering samples and adapting the contrastive loss function, HiCo learns more discriminative features and reduces the impact of noisy labels. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiCo outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, while requiring fewer computational resources.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval models often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which selectively incorporates relevant contextual information from external knowledge graphs to enrich the document representation. Our experiments on the TREC benchmarks demonstrate that QDE significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, especially for queries with ambiguous or implicit intent. We also analyze the impact of QDE on various query types and provide insights into its applicability in real-world search engines.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Entity Disambiguation in Multilingual Queries
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in multilingual queries remains a challenging task in information retrieval. This paper proposes a hybrid retrieval model, 'HybridED', which integrates semantic embeddings with graph-based entity disambiguation. HybridED leverages pre-trained language models to capture contextualized semantic relationships between entities and queries, while also exploiting graph structure to resolve ambiguity. Experimental results on a large-scale multilingual dataset demonstrate significant improvement in entity disambiguation accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art models by up to 12% in F1-score.

title: Investigating the Effects of Anthropomorphic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become an increasingly popular platform for immersive experiences, but designing effective feedback mechanisms remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of anthropomorphic feedback on user experience in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, randomly assigning them to either an anthropomorphic or non-anthropomorphic feedback condition. Results show that anthropomorphic feedback significantly improves user engagement, reduces cognitive load, and enhances overall user satisfaction. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of future VR systems and provide recommendations for incorporating anthropomorphic feedback into VR experiences.

title: Scalable Multi-Task Learning with Hierarchical Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning has shown promise in improving model performance and efficiency. However, as the number of tasks grows, the complexity of task relationships and interactions increases, leading to scalability issues. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task embedding framework, 'HiTE', which learns to represent tasks as hierarchical clusters of embeddings. We demonstrate that HiTE enables efficient knowledge sharing across tasks, improves overall model performance, and reduces training time. Experiments on a large-scale multi-task dataset show that HiTE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 25% improvement in average task accuracy.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the limited query context. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QueryExpan', which leverages deep learning-based language models to generate contextualized document summaries. By incorporating these summaries into the retrieval process, QueryExpan significantly improves the retrieval performance, especially for short and ambiguous queries. Our experiments on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of QueryExpan in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems are crucial for building trustworthy AI-driven decision-making tools. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture that incorporates node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to model complex user-item interactions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in capturing both local and global dependencies in user behavior, resulting in improved recommendation accuracy and interpretability. Our experiments on real-world datasets show that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art baselines while providing transparent explanations for recommended items.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Sentence Embeddings for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on effective passage retrieval to identify relevant contexts from a massive corpus. This paper presents a novel approach to passage retrieval using hierarchical sentence embeddings, which capture both local and global semantic relationships within a passage. Our method, 'HierSent', represents sentences as hierarchical graphs and learns to embed them in a dense vector space. We demonstrate that HierSent outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods on several ODQA benchmarks, achieving a 12% improvement in top-1 passage accuracy and a 20% reduction in computational cost.

title: Efficient Indexing for Temporal Graph Databases using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly important for analyzing large-scale network data. However, indexing techniques for efficient query processing remain limited. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, TempHierBloom, which leverages hierarchical Bloom filters to accelerate temporal graph queries. By adaptively partitioning the graph into hierarchical clusters and leveraging Bloom filter properties, TempHierBloom achieves significant improvements in query performance and reduces memory overhead. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in supporting various temporal graph queries.

title: Efficient Secondary Indexing for Time-Series Data in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and sensors has led to an explosion in time-series data, necessitating efficient storage and querying mechanisms. This paper presents a novel secondary indexing approach, 'TSIndex', tailored for column-oriented NoSQL databases. TSIndex exploits the inherent properties of time-series data to reduce storage overhead and improve query performance. Our experiments on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that TSIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3.5x in query latency and 2x in storage efficiency, while maintaining data freshness guarantees.

title: Gaze-Based Gesture Recognition for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing control mechanisms can be limiting for users with disabilities. This paper presents 'GazeGest', a novel gaze-based gesture recognition system that enables intuitive interaction with VR environments. Our approach leverages machine learning models to classify gaze patterns and identify corresponding gestures, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% in user studies. We also introduce a novel gaze-based gesture vocabulary, designed in collaboration with accessibility experts, to facilitate seamless interaction with VR applications.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Expansion on Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Deep neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks. However, their effectiveness is often dependent on the quality of the input queries. Query expansion techniques have been shown to improve retrieval performance, but their impact on neural ranking models remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of query expansion on several popular neural ranking models, including BERT and transformer-based architectures. We explore various expansion methods, including pseudo-relevance feedback and word embeddings-based techniques, and evaluate their impact on retrieval performance using standard benchmarks. Our results demonstrate that careful selection of query expansion methods can significantly improve the performance of neural ranking models, and provide insights into the optimal combination of expansion techniques and model architectures.

title: Deep Neural Retrieval for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Sparse Query Representations
paper_abstract: Traditional ad-hoc retrieval models rely on dense vector representations of queries, which can lead to suboptimal performance when dealing with sparse or incomplete queries. This paper proposes a novel deep neural retrieval approach, 'SparseQL', that leverages sparse query representations to improve retrieval effectiveness. Our model adapts a graph neural network to learn query-dependent document representations, and incorporates a query-aware sparse attention mechanism to focus on relevant query terms. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness over state-of-the-art models.

title: Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed resource allocation problems are ubiquitous in modern complex systems, such as smart grids, communication networks, and traffic management. This paper proposes a novel heterogeneous multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HMaRL', which enables agents with different capabilities and objectives to learn cooperative policies for efficient resource allocation. We introduce a decentralized, graph-based actor-critic architecture that leverages local observations and communication to adapt to changing system dynamics. Experimental results on a realistic smart grid simulation demonstrate that HMaRL achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and latency reduction compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems through Decentralized Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We propose a novel decentralized reinforcement learning framework for coordinating heterogeneous multi-agent systems. Our approach, dubbed 'HetMAS', leverages a graph neural network to learn a shared representation of the agents' dynamics and objectives. By incorporating a decentralized actor-critic architecture, HetMAS enables agents to learn cooperative policies in a self-organizing manner, without relying on a centralized controller or explicit communication. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HetMAS in a simulated robotic swarm scenario, where agents learn to adapt to changing environmental conditions and achieve improved task performance.

title: Efficient Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks often require large amounts of labeled data to achieve good performance. Online learning methods can mitigate this issue by adapting to new data streams, but they may suffer from catastrophic forgetting. This paper proposes an efficient online learning framework for deep neural networks, which incorporates adaptive regularization to balance stability and plasticity. Our approach dynamically adjusts the regularization strength based on the gradient norm of the model, allowing it to adapt to changing data distributions. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves competitive performance to offline training while reducing computational costs.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent Networks for Real-Time Traffic Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel decentralized autonomous agent network (DAAN) framework for real-time traffic optimization. Our approach leverages multi-agent systems to model and simulate complex urban traffic dynamics, enabling real-time optimization of traffic signal control and route planning. We propose a distributed reinforcement learning algorithm that allows agents to adapt to changing traffic conditions and learn from each other's experiences. Experimental results using real-world traffic data from the city of San Francisco demonstrate significant reductions in travel times and congestion compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: As the volume of digital data continues to grow, distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems have become essential for efficient querying. However, the communication overhead and data redundancy in these systems can lead to significant latency and resource waste. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'DirClust', which organizes peer nodes into a hierarchical structure based on their data similarity and query patterns. Our experiments on a large-scale DIR system show that DirClust reduces the average query response time by 35% and improves the system's scalability by 28% compared to traditional flooding-based query routing strategies.

title: Self-Supervised Representation Learning for Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various applications, but it often suffers from limited labelled data. This paper proposes a self-supervised representation learning approach, 'TSRL-AD', that leverages the inherent structures of time series data to learn effective representations. We design a contrastive learning framework that jointly learns a feature extractor and an anomaly detector, without requiring labelled anomalies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TSRL-AD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness, while requiring significantly fewer labelled samples.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (NIR) models have recently shown promise in improving search engine rankings. However, they often struggle with query-document mismatch, where the query terms do not appear in the relevant documents. We propose a novel query-adaptive document expansion (QADE) approach, which generates synthetic documents that incorporate latent semantic knowledge from the query. Our method leverages a transformer-based architecture to dynamically generate expansion terms, conditioned on the query context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness, especially for queries with limited term overlap.

title: EyeTracking-Based Adaptive Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to provide an optimal user experience due to the complexity of user interactions. This paper presents an innovative eye-tracking-based adaptive interface, 'EyeAdapt', which dynamically adjusts the VR environment to individual users' needs. By analyzing users' gaze patterns and pupillary responses, EyeAdapt identifies areas of interest and adjusts the visual layout, reducing cognitive load and improving task performance. We conduct a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion times compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Coordinating autonomous agents in complex multi-agent systems is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HierAgent', which enables agents to learn coordinated policies in a decentralized manner. HierAgent employs a novel hierarchical structure, where high-level agents learn to coordinate low-level agents, facilitating the emergence of complex behaviors. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierAgent in a series of experiments, showcasing its ability to coordinate agents in tasks such as resource allocation and predator-prey scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using BERT-based Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but often struggle with query representation and expansion. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using BERT-based document embeddings. We first fine-tune a BERT model on a large corpus of documents to generate dense vector representations. Then, we develop an efficient algorithm to expand the query by identifying the most relevant terms from the document embeddings. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Document-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: As document-oriented databases become increasingly popular, optimizing query performance is crucial for scalable data processing. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'DocOQ', designed specifically for distributed document-oriented databases. DocOQ leverages a combination of statistical analysis and machine learning techniques to identify optimal query plans, minimizing latency and resource utilization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DocOQ through extensive experiments on a real-world dataset, achieving up to 3x speedup compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: We present a novel graph attention network (GAT) framework, HeteroGAT, designed to tackle the complex task allocation problem in multi-agent systems. By explicitly modeling heterogeneous agent and task relationships, HeteroGAT learns to allocate tasks efficiently and adapt to dynamic environmental changes. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global dependencies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in simulated and real-world robotic scenarios.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation is a crucial mechanism for agents to reach mutually beneficial agreements. However, when agents have incomplete information about each other's preferences and utilities, negotiation becomes a challenging problem. This paper proposes a decentralized negotiation strategy, 'InfoNeg', which leverages probabilistic modeling and Bayesian inference to reason about other agents' private information. We demonstrate the effectiveness of InfoNeg in various negotiation scenarios, showing improved agreements and faster convergence compared to existing decentralized negotiation protocols. Our approach has applications in autonomous vehicles, smart grids, and e-commerce platforms.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems via Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used to handle large-scale data workloads, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents an adaptive indexing technique, 'AdapIndex', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distributions. Our approach leverages machine learning models to predict query access patterns and optimize index configuration accordingly. Experimental results on a real-world DDS deployment show that AdapIndex reduces query latency by up to 40% and improves throughput by up to 25% compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Coalition Formation
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents form coalitions to execute complex tasks. We introduce a distributed coalition formation algorithm that leverages graph theory and social welfare optimization to ensure efficient task allocation. Our approach is robust to changes in agent capabilities and task requirements, and can adapt to dynamic environments. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and agent utility compared to existing decentralized allocation methods.

title: Deep Ensemble Learning for Robust Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Data Streams
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional data streams is a crucial task in various applications, including cybersecurity, finance, and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel deep ensemble learning framework, 'DeepENS', which combines the strengths of multiple deep learning models to detect anomalies in real-time data streams. Our approach leverages the concept of ensemble diversity to improve robustness and adaptability to concept drift. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepENS outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and speed.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Networks with Query Embeddings
paper_abstract: Current document ranking models in Information Retrieval (IR) often rely on handcrafted features and shallow learning architectures. We propose a novel neural ranking model, 'Query2Rank', which leverages deep neural networks to learn query embeddings and document representations simultaneously. Our approach uses a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize ranking and relevance classification tasks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that Query2Rank outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Task Networks for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents for efficient resource allocation in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce a hierarchical task network (HTN) framework that enables agents to decompose high-level tasks into smaller, more manageable subtasks, and allocate resources accordingly. Our approach leverages a combination of task planning, constraint satisfaction, and decision-theoretic reasoning to optimize resource allocation and minimize conflicts between agents. Experimental results in a simulated manufacturing scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving resource utilization and reducing task completion times.

title: Accelerating Query Processing with Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Modern main-memory databases require efficient query processing to support real-time analytics. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'LIX', which leverages learned index structures to accelerate query execution. We introduce a hybrid indexing scheme that combines traditional B-tree indexing with machine learning-based indexing, exploiting the statistical properties of the data. Experimental results on a popular benchmark dataset demonstrate that LIX achieves an average query performance improvement of 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while maintaining similar storage overhead.

title: Transaction-Aware Concurrency Control for Modern Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Modern main-memory database systems (MMDBs) rely on concurrency control mechanisms to ensure transactional consistency. However, traditional approaches incur significant performance overhead due to logging, locking, and latching. This paper proposes a novel transaction-aware concurrency control scheme, 'TACCM', which leverages the inherent parallelism of MMDBs. TACCM dynamically adjusts concurrency levels based on transaction conflict rates, reducing overhead while maintaining correctness. Experimental evaluations on a real-world workload demonstrate that TACCM achieves up to 3.5x throughput improvement over state-of-the-art solutions.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex interactions between agents. This paper presents a novel attention mechanism, 'Explainable Attention for Agents' (EAA), which enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent environments. EAA leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and incorporate domain knowledge. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmarks, outperforming existing attention-based methods in terms of both decision quality and interpretability. We demonstrate EAA's effectiveness in a real-world autonomous vehicle scenario, providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks for Explainable AI-driven Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI is crucial in recommendation systems to gain user trust. We propose a novel Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network (HGNN) framework, 'ExplainRec', which integrates graph attention and meta-learning to generate personalized explanations for AI-driven recommendations. Our approach leverages multi-modal user data and item relationships to learn explainable representations. Experiments on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate that ExplainRec outperforms state-of-the-art recommendation models while providing interpretable explanations for recommended items.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems are increasingly popular in human-computer interaction, but their performance often degrades for individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel adaptive gesture recognition framework, 'AdapGesture', which leverages machine learning and sensor fusion to accommodate varying levels of motor ability. AdapGesture utilizes a personalized calibration phase to learn user-specific gesture patterns and adaptively adjusts its recognition thresholds based on user performance. Our user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing gesture recognition systems.

title: EmotionAware: A Multimodal Affective Computing Framework for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Affective computing has revolutionized human-computer interaction (HCI) by enabling machines to recognize and respond to human emotions. However, existing approaches rely on a single modality, such as facial expressions or speech, and fail to capture the complexity of human emotions. This paper presents EmotionAware, a novel multimodal affective computing framework that integrates computer vision, natural language processing, and physiological signal processing to recognize and classify emotions. Our approach leverages a graph-based neural network to fuse features from multiple modalities, achieving a 25% improvement in emotion recognition accuracy compared to state-of-the-art unimodal approaches. We demonstrate EmotionAware's potential in enhancing user experience in HCI applications, such as personalized recommendations and emotional support systems.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly prevalent in modern data-intensive applications. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a challenging problem due to the complex interplay between data distribution, network latency, and query patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query performance in DDS. We design a deep Q-network (DQN) that learns to adaptively adjust query execution plans based on real-time system conditions. Experimental results on a simulated DDS environment demonstrate that our RL-based approach achieves significant improvements in query response time and throughput compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of modern recommendation systems, as it can increase user trust and provide valuable insights for system improvement. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attentional Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework for explainable recommendation. HAGNN leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex user-item relationships and incorporates a hierarchical explanatory module to generate personalized, interpretable explanations for each recommendation. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in improving both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control with Uncertainty-Aware Exploration
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient and safe control strategies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that integrates uncertainty-aware exploration with a probabilistic motion forecasting module. Our approach, 'HRL-UAE', leverages a high-level policy to select optimal goal-directed actions while a low-level controller adapts to uncertain environment dynamics. We demonstrate the efficacy of HRL-UAE in simulated urban driving scenarios, showcasing improved navigation performance and reduced uncertainty compared to state-of-the-art model-free RL methods.

title: Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Traditional indexing techniques fail to scale with the exponential growth of big data, resulting in inefficient query execution times. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using learned index structures, which leverage machine learning models to predict the optimal index configuration for a given query workload. We develop a reinforcement learning framework that learns to optimize index structures based on query patterns and data distributions, and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and storage efficiency on real-world datasets.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is a crucial task in affective computing. We propose a novel attention mechanism, 'ModalGaze', which selectively focuses on the most informative modalities and time-steps to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our approach leverages a hierarchical graph neural network to model cross-modal relationships and incorporates a uncertainty-based attention module to weigh the contributions of each modality. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that ModalGaze outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Index Pruning for Neural Ranking Models in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have become increasingly popular in e-commerce search due to their ability to capture complex query-document relationships. However, their computational requirements and memory footprint can be prohibitive for large-scale deployments. This paper proposes a novel index pruning technique, 'NP-Prune', that reduces the computational cost of neural ranking models by eliminating redundant and irrelevant index terms. We introduce a reinforcement learning-based approach to learn pruning policies that maximize search quality while minimizing computational overhead. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that NP-Prune achieves significant speedups and memory savings while preserving search accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for timely business decision-making. However, optimizing queries for column-store databases remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'RTOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and a genetic algorithm for efficient query plan generation. Our experiments on a large-scale column-store database demonstrate that RTOpt achieves an average query speedup of 3.5x compared to traditional query optimizers, while also reducing memory usage by 25%. We also discuss the applicability of RTOpt to various data warehousing use cases.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: As big data analytics continues to grow, query optimization has become a critical bottleneck. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics and statistical models, which often fail to capture complex data distributions. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach, 'ML-Optimizer', which leverages query execution patterns and data characteristics to predict optimal query plans. We formulate the optimization problem as a Markov Decision Process and employ deep reinforcement learning to learn an optimal policy. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ML-Optimizer outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Augmented Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gesture recognition in augmented reality (AR) interfaces, focusing on adapting to individual users' motor patterns and preferences. We propose a machine learning-based framework that incorporates both kinematic and kinetic features from hand and finger tracking data. Our system, AR Gesture Adapt, employs a reinforcement learning algorithm to optimize gesture recognition accuracy and user experience in real-time. Experimental results with 30 participants demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Cooperative Exploration of Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative exploration in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized, asynchronous framework that enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing environments. Our algorithm, 'CoEx', integrates Graph Attention Networks with Deep Q-Networks to facilitate efficient communication and coordination among agents. Experimental results on a series of multi-agent exploration tasks demonstrate that CoEx outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of exploration efficiency, coordination, and task completion rate.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Users with Speech Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but individuals with speech disabilities face significant barriers in using these systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive voice-based interfaces, focusing on users with dysarthria. We propose a participatory design approach, involving users with dysarthria in the design process to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our framework incorporates a range of techniques, including speech recognition adaptation, personalized acoustic modeling, and multimodal feedback. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction, highlighting the potential of our approach to promote greater accessibility and inclusion.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration for Distributed Query Processing
paper_abstract: Distributed query processing is crucial for scalability in modern data systems, but optimizing join order enumeration remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'JoinEagle', which leverages graph neural networks to model the query plan space and efficiently explore promising join orders. We introduce a hierarchical representation of query plans, enabling our model to capture complex interactions between joins and effectively prune the search space. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that JoinEagle outperforms state-of-the-art techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time, while also reducing the number of enumerations by an order of magnitude.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for elderly individuals with cognitive impairments, but current interfaces often exacerbate existing accessibility barriers. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating inclusive VR interfaces tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 elderly participants with cognitive impairments, revealing key design recommendations for simplifying navigation, enhancing visual cues, and incorporating assistive features. Our prototype, 'ElderVR', demonstrates significant improvements in user engagement and task completion rates compared to commercial VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, enabling more empathetic and personalized systems. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HIER', for multi-modal emotion recognition. HIER leverages both visual and auditory cues from facial expressions and speech, incorporating attention mechanisms to selectively focus on salient features. Our experiments on the RECOLA dataset demonstrate that HIER outperforms state-of-the-art approaches, achieving an average F1-score of 0.83 across six emotions. We further analyze the learned attention patterns, revealing insights into the complex relationships between modalities and emotions.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Task Learning for Efficient Human-Robot Collaboration
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, efficient human-robot collaboration (HRC) is crucial. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical multi-task learning (HMTL) framework that enables robots to learn multiple HRC tasks simultaneously, while adapting to changing human behavior. By leveraging a hierarchical structure, our approach reduces the complexity of the learning problem, allowing for faster adaptation and improved task performance. Experimental results on a real-world HRC dataset demonstrate that our HMTL framework outperforms existing single-task learning methods in terms of task success rate and human satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models typically rely on complex neural network architectures to integrate visual and linguistic information. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that efficiently fuses multi-modal inputs to improve VQA performance. Our approach leverages a stack of attention modules to selectively focus on relevant image regions and question words, enabling more accurate and interpretable question answering. We evaluate our HAN model on the VQA 2.0 dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in accuracy and inference speed compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for various applications, including healthcare, finance, and cybersecurity. Despite advances in deep learning, existing methods often lack interpretability, making it challenging to identify the root cause of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) for time-series anomaly detection. HGAN leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between variables and hierarchical representations to capture multi-scale patterns. We evaluate HGAN on several benchmarks and demonstrate its superior performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Semantic Hashing and Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Conventional information retrieval systems rely on exact keyword matching, neglecting semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepHash-QE', which integrates deep semantic hashing and query expansion to improve document retrieval efficiency. Our method learns compact binary representations of documents and queries, enabling fast similarity search and reducing the need for exact matching. Experimental results on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that DeepHash-QE outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while requiring significantly fewer computational resources.

title: Eye-Gaze Based Authentication for Virtual Reality Head-Mounted Displays
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) head-mounted displays (HMDs) have become increasingly popular, but their security remains a concern. This paper presents a novel eye-gaze based authentication system for VR HMDs, which leverages the unique characteristics of eye movements to verify user identities. Our approach uses a combination of machine learning algorithms and computer vision techniques to analyze the user's gaze patterns, achieving an accuracy of 95.6% in a user study with 30 participants. We also discuss the trade-offs between security, user experience, and system complexity, providing guidelines for the design of secure and usable VR authentication systems.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model with Semantic Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Conventional information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to balance retrieval effectiveness with query response time. This paper proposes a hybrid retrieval model that combines the strengths of lexical and semantic matching techniques. Our approach leverages pre-trained language models to generate dense semantic embeddings, which are then incorporated into a probabilistic retrieval framework. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency, particularly for complex queries. We also explore the impact of embedding dimensionality and query rewriting strategies on model performance.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Hybrid Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Hybrid memory database systems (HMDBs) have gained popularity due to their performance benefits in modern data-intensive applications. However, optimizing query performance in HMDBs remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'HybOpt', which leverages both CPU and GPU processing units to accelerate query execution. We develop a cost model that takes into account the memory hierarchy, query patterns, and data distribution to effectively allocate queries to either CPU or GPU. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HybOpt achieves significant performance improvements compared to traditional query optimization techniques, with speedups of up to 3.5x for complex analytical queries.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient decision-making strategies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework that integrates high-level goal-directed planning with low-level motion control. Our approach employs a hierarchical policy architecture, where a high-level planning module selects goals, and a low-level control module executes actions to achieve those goals. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DHRL in a simulated urban driving environment, showing improved decision-making performance and reduced computational overhead compared to flat reinforcement learning baselines.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Disentanglement for Enhanced Search Result Diversification
paper_abstract: Current search engines often struggle to capture the nuances of user intent, leading to homogeneous search results. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised approach to disentangle query intent, enabling more diverse and relevant search results. Our method, 'IntentFuse', leverages a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query similarity, intent clustering, and result diversification. We evaluate IntentFuse on a large-scale query log dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in search result diversity and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and system scalability. This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning to query optimization, leveraging the strengths of both query optimization techniques and reinforcement learning. We propose a novel framework, 'DQN-QO', which utilizes a deep Q-network to learn query optimization strategies from a large dataset of query plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that DQN-QO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, achieving up to 30% improvement in query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Attention-based Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must coordinate to accomplish tasks without a central authority. This paper proposes a novel approach using attention-based graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We model the agent-task graph and design a GNN architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agent-task interactions. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario show that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized methods, achieving higher task completion rates and improved system efficiency.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenging problem of distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn optimal task assignment policies. Our method, called 'DeepAlloc', utilizes a decentralized actor-critic framework, where each agent learns to select tasks based on its local observations and received rewards. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepAlloc through extensive simulations, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing algorithms.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval in Microblogging Platforms
paper_abstract: Microblogging platforms generate vast amounts of short-form text data, posing significant challenges for information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages both semantic and syntactic features of short-text queries to improve retrieval effectiveness. CAQE incorporates a graph-based method to model the relationships between entities, topics, and keywords, and applies a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the query expansion process. Experimental results on a large-scale Twitter dataset demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Query-Driven Indexing for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) models have achieved state-of-the-art results in open-domain question answering tasks. However, their computational cost and memory requirements increase quadratically with the number of passages in the index. This paper proposes a query-driven indexing approach that selectively indexes passages based on their relevance to the query. Our approach leverages a learned passage representation model to identify relevant passages and constructs a sparse index that reduces memory usage by up to 90% while maintaining retrieval performance. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing computational cost and improving query latency.

title: Attention-based Explainable Recommendation with Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Explainability in recommender systems has gained significant attention in recent years. This paper proposes a novel attention-based framework that incorporates knowledge graph embeddings to provide interpretable recommendations. Our approach, 'Att-KGE', learns to attend to relevant entities in the knowledge graph and generates personalized explanations for each recommendation. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that Att-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gesture-based interfaces that can accommodate a wide range of motor abilities. We propose a machine learning-based framework that leverages real-time gesture recognition and adaptation to dynamically adjust interface parameters, such as gesture speed and accuracy thresholds. Our user study with 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates improved interface accessibility and usability, with participants exhibiting a 35% increase in successful gesture recognition and a 25% decrease in interaction time.

title: Adaptive Agent Negotiation Strategies for Dynamic Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of renewable energy sources in smart grids necessitates adaptive resource allocation strategies to ensure efficient and reliable power distribution. This paper proposes a novel approach to agent negotiation for dynamic resource allocation, incorporating machine learning and game theory. Our approach, 'AANA', employs a decentralized architecture where agents representing different stakeholders in the grid negotiate resource allocation based on real-time supply and demand data. AANA adapts to changing grid conditions through reinforcement learning and minimizes energy waste and costs. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid environment demonstrate the effectiveness of AANA in reducing energy losses and improving grid stability.

title: Designing Emotion-Aware Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User Study on Trust and Perceived Empathy
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in older adults' daily lives, but their lack of emotional intelligence can lead to user frustration and mistrust. This study investigates the impact of emotion-aware voice assistants on trust and perceived empathy in older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, aged 65-85, who interacted with either an emotion-aware or a standard voice assistant. Results show that the emotion-aware assistant significantly improved user trust and perceived empathy, particularly among participants with higher levels of anxiety and depression. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more empathetic and supportive voice assistants for older adults.

title: Hyperbolic Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art recommendation systems rely on Euclidean geometry-based graph neural networks, which struggle to model complex relationships in large-scale graphs. This paper introduces HyperGAT, a novel graph attention network that leverages hyperbolic geometry to capture hierarchical and scale-free properties of user-item interactions. By incorporating hyperbolic attention mechanisms, HyperGAT achieves significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and scalability on several benchmark datasets, while reducing computational complexity. We provide theoretical insights into the expressiveness of hyperbolic graph representations and demonstrate the efficacy of HyperGAT in real-world recommender systems.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Agent Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multiple autonomous vehicles in complex urban scenarios. We leverage a two-level hierarchy, where a high-level policy learns to allocate tasks and resources to individual vehicles, while low-level policies control the vehicles' trajectories. Our approach incorporates domain knowledge and safety constraints, ensuring efficient and safe coordination. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in a simulated environment, achieving improved throughput and reduced congestion compared to existing decentralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: In multi-agent dialogue systems, understanding the decision-making process of agents is crucial for transparency and trust. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework for explainable multi-agent dialogue management. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant context and agent interactions, generating interpretable dialogue responses. We evaluate our HAN model on a real-world dialogue dataset and demonstrate improved response accuracy and explainability compared to state-of-the-art baseline models. Furthermore, our framework provides insights into agent decision-making, facilitating more effective human-agent collaboration.

title: Designing Gamified Interfaces for Enhancing User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper presents a systematic approach to designing gamified interfaces for enhancing user engagement in virtual reality (VR) environments. We introduce a novel framework, 'VR-GAME', which integrates game design elements, such as rewards, challenges, and social sharing, with VR-specific features like spatial awareness and gesture recognition. Our user study with 30 participants shows that VR-GAME significantly increases user engagement, retention, and overall experience satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. We also provide design recommendations for developers to create more immersive and engaging VR experiences.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and learning outcomes in VR-based learning environments. We designed a user study with 120 participants, randomly assigned to either a personalized avatar or a generic avatar condition. Our results show that users with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of presence, motivation, and overall satisfaction, leading to improved learning outcomes. We also identified key design factors influencing avatar personalization and provide guidelines for educational VR system designers.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Real-time Traffic Management using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for real-time traffic management. Our approach, called 'TrafficMA', leverages autonomous agents to optimize traffic signal control and routing in complex urban networks. We introduce a novel coordination mechanism, 'Async-QL', which enables agents to learn from each other's experiences and adapt to changing traffic patterns. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that TrafficMA outperforms traditional traffic management systems, reducing congestion and travel times by up to 25%.

title: Incentive Mechanism Design for Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperative task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. However, designing incentive mechanisms to encourage agents to participate and contribute to the collective goal remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel, decentralized mechanism that leverages game-theoretic principles to incentivize agents to cooperate. Our approach, called 'CoopIncent', combines a reputation system with a novel scoring function that rewards agents for their contributions to the collective goal. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate that CoopIncent outperforms existing mechanisms in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing is becoming increasingly important in today's fast-paced business environments. However, optimizing queries for real-time analytics remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization technique that leverages column store indexing to improve query performance. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that takes into account the unique characteristics of column store indexes and real-time data warehousing workloads. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves significant performance gains over traditional query optimization techniques, with an average query speedup of 3.2x.

title: Coordinating Human-Agent Teams through Reinforcement Learning-based Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Human-agent teams have shown great potential in various applications, but effective task allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to coordinating human-agent teams using reinforcement learning (RL). Our method, called HARTA, learns to allocate tasks to humans and agents based on their strengths and weaknesses. HARTA incorporates a dynamic uncertainty model to adapt to changing task requirements and team member availability. We evaluate HARTA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved team performance and reduced task completion time compared to traditional task allocation methods.

title: ElasticRank: A Scalable and Adaptive Ranking Framework for Dynamic Search Engines
paper_abstract: Modern search engines face the challenge of efficiently indexing and ranking a vast, constantly evolving corpus of documents. This paper introduces ElasticRank, a novel ranking framework that adapts to changing query patterns and document updates in real-time. By leveraging a hierarchical indexing structure and a probabilistic query modeling approach, ElasticRank achieves a 30% improvement in query throughput and a 25% reduction in indexing latency compared to state-of-the-art methods. We evaluate ElasticRank on a large-scale web crawl dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in handling sudden changes in query popularity.

title: Designing Inclusive and Adaptive Voice Assistants for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in smart home devices, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive and adaptive voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted a series of interviews and usability studies to identify key challenges and preferences of older adults when interacting with voice assistants. Our proposed system, 'ElderVoice', incorporates a multimodal interface, personalized dialogue management, and adaptive speech recognition to accommodate age-related cognitive and sensory decline. A pilot study with 30 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion rates, and perceived ease of use.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task, particularly when dealing with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning framework, Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), which leverages hierarchical representations to adapt to new classes. HPN learns to generate class prototypes at multiple scales, enabling more effective knowledge transfer and improved performance on unseen classes. We conduct extensive experiments on popular benchmarks, demonstrating that HPN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot image classification tasks.

title: Proximity-Aware Document Representation for Efficient Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Existing document representation techniques in information retrieval (IR) often neglect the spatial relationships between query terms, leading to suboptimal ranking performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks. This paper proposes a novel proximity-aware document representation framework, 'ProxRep', which incorporates term co-occurrence patterns and proximity features into a dense vector space. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ProxRep significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain, while requiring fewer computational resources.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Aggregation Queries on IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of sensor data, making real-time aggregation queries a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'RTAgg', which leverages the temporal and spatial correlations inherent in IoT data to accelerate query processing. RTAgg utilizes a hierarchical indexing structure that adaptively partitions the data into hot and cold regions, enabling efficient aggregation and filtering. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrates that RTAgg outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query response time and storage efficiency.

title: Decentralized Consensus Protocol for Multi-Agent Systems with Byzantine Fault Tolerance
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, achieving consensus in the presence of Byzantine faults is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel decentralized consensus protocol, 'Byzantine-Resilient Consensus' (BRC), which guarantees consensus even when up to one-third of agents are Byzantine faulty.
