BRC leverages a combination of digital signatures, voting mechanisms, and a reputation system to detect and isolate faulty agents. We prove the correctness and fault tolerance of BRC through formal verification and evaluate its performance on a simulated multi-agent system, demonstrating improved resilience and efficiency compared to existing Byzantine fault-tolerant consensus protocols.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Efficient Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed systems, efficient resource allocation is crucial for optimal system performance. This paper proposes an autonomous agent-based framework, 'AgentCoord', to coordinate resource allocation among agents in a decentralized manner. AgentCoord utilizes a multi-agent reinforcement learning approach, where agents learn to negotiate and allocate resources based on local observations and feedback. We introduce a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share knowledge and adapt to changing system dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated distributed system demonstrate that AgentCoord outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of resource utilization and system throughput.

title: Enhanced Document Representation with Hierarchical Graph Attention for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document representation techniques in information retrieval (IR) rely on bag-of-words or shallow neural networks, neglecting the rich structural information present in document graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention model, 'GraphIR', which learns to represent documents as a hierarchical composition of node and graph-level features. Experimental results on several benchmark IR datasets demonstrate that GraphIR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, particularly for documents with complex structures and relationships.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Traffic Flow Optimization using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize traffic flow using autonomous agents and graph convolutional networks (GCNs). We model the traffic network as a graph, where each node represents an intersection, and agents learn to optimize traffic signal control policies using a decentralized, multi-agent reinforcement learning framework. Our GCN-based model learns to capture complex traffic patterns and dependencies, outperforming traditional optimization methods in simulations. We demonstrate the feasibility of our approach in a real-world case study, achieving a 23% reduction in travel time and a 15% decrease in fuel consumption.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Improving Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component in many information retrieval systems. However, the effectiveness of traditional query expansion methods is limited by their reliance on term frequency and co-occurrence statistics. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and passage contents. Our proposed method, 'EmbedExpan', uses a transformer-based architecture to learn dense representations of query terms and passages, and then performs query expansion by identifying the most similar terms in the embedding space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbedExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column Stores
paper_abstract: Distributed column stores have emerged as a popular choice for real-time analytics, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'RapidFire', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and dynamically reorders query plans to minimize latency. We propose a cost model that captures the intricacies of column-store storage and demonstrate RapidFire's efficacy on a range of real-world workloads, achieving up to 3x speedups over state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Scalable and Secure Data Sharing using Multi-Party Computation in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems often require secure data sharing among multiple parties. Existing solutions rely on trusted third-party mediators or encrypted data transfer, which compromise on performance or scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'SecureShare', that leverages multi-party computation (MPC) to enable secure data sharing in distributed database systems. SecureShare uses a combination of homomorphic encryption and secure function evaluation to enable queries on shared data without revealing individual party's data. Our experiments on a real-world healthcare dataset demonstrate that SecureShare achieves a 3x performance improvement over existing solutions while maintaining strong security guarantees.

title: Hypergraph-based Document Representation for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document representation methods in information retrieval (IR) often rely on bag-of-words or vector space models, which fail to capture complex relationships between entities and concepts. This paper introduces a novel hypergraph-based document representation, 'HyperDoc', which leverages high-order dependencies between words and entities to improve retrieval efficiency. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HyperDoc on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in recall and precision compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we show that HyperDoc can be seamlessly integrated with existing IR systems, making it a practical solution for real-world applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media has severe consequences for individuals and society. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Neural Network (HGNN) framework for explainable fake news detection. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between news articles, users, and their engagement patterns. We incorporate multi-hop attention to identify influential nodes and iteratively refine the attention weights. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that our HGNN model outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of accuracy, F1-score, and interpretability, providing actionable insights for mitigating the spread of fake news.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Enhanced User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, the need for intuitive and efficient interfaces grows. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface framework, 'AdaptiGest', which leverages machine learning to adapt to individual users' gesture patterns and preferences in real-time. Our approach incorporates a hybrid sensor fusion model that combines data from hand tracking sensors, eye-tracking, and EEG to enable more accurate gesture recognition. We evaluate AdaptiGest through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience, reduced cognitive load, and enhanced overall system usability.

title: Investigating the Effect of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-robot collaboration, but the impact of embodiment on collaboration outcomes is not well understood. This study examines how embodiment – the sense of ownership and agency over a virtual body – influences human trust, communication, and task performance in VR-based human-robot collaboration. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform and a robot avatar. Our results show that high embodiment is associated with increased trust, more effective communication, and improved task performance. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR-based human-robot collaboration systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular, but their adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility features for users with motor disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive gesture-based interfaces that accommodate users with varying levels of motor abilities. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key challenges and opportunities, and developed a set of design principles and guidelines for creating accessible gestures. Our evaluation of a prototype system demonstrates significant improvements in usability and user experience for participants with motor disabilities.

title: EyeGazeLens: A Gaze-Based Interface for Augmented Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) interfaces often rely on manual input, which can be cumbersome and limiting. This paper presents EyeGazeLens, a novel gaze-based interface for AR that leverages deep learning to accurately infer user intent. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to analyze eye movement patterns and identify fixation points, enabling users to interact with virtual objects in 3D space. We evaluate EyeGazeLens using a custom-built AR platform and demonstrate improved interaction time and accuracy compared to traditional input methods. The implications of this work are significant, enabling more natural and intuitive human-computer interaction in AR environments.

title: Optimizing Query Execution Plans for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans in distributed relational databases. Our approach, called 'RL-QEP', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query execution plan based on the database's performance metrics. We evaluate RL-QEP using the TPC-DS benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data Using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Optimizing query performance is crucial for efficient data retrieval in modern databases. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach for multi-dimensional data, dubbed 'HiDIM'. By partitioning the data space into a hierarchical structure of smaller, correlated subspaces, HiDIM enables fast and accurate query processing. We develop an efficient indexing algorithm that minimizes storage overhead and query latency. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HiDIM outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems to improve search results. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'DeepRank', which leverages deep neural networks to learn contextualized representations of documents and queries. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset show that DeepRank outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of mean average precision and NDCG@10.

title: Efficient Data Pruning for Column-Oriented In-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: In-memory databases have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics, but their memory-bound nature makes data pruning crucial for performance. This paper presents a novel pruning approach, 'ColPrune', specifically designed for column-oriented in-memory databases. ColPrune leverages statistical correlation analysis to identify and eliminate redundant data columns, reducing memory footprint while preserving query accuracy. We evaluate ColPrune on a suite of real-world benchmarks, demonstrating up to 40% memory savings and 20% query performance improvement compared to state-of-the-art pruning techniques.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning via Hierarchical Policy Distillation
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex tasks, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical policy distillation framework, 'Hierarchical Robust Policy Distillation' (HRPD), to improve the robustness of DRL policies against adversarial perturbations. HRPD leverages a teacher-student architecture, where a robust teacher policy guides the learning of a student policy through a hierarchical distillation process. Experimental results on multiple Atari games demonstrate that HRPD significantly enhances the robustness of DRL policies against various types of adversarial attacks.

title: Efficient Real-time Object Detection using Hierarchical Attention Networks for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems, requiring high accuracy and low latency. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for real-time object detection. Our approach leverages a pyramid of attention modules to selectively focus on relevant regions of the input image, reducing computational complexity and improving detection performance. We evaluate our method on the KITTI object detection benchmark, achieving state-of-the-art performance with a 30% reduction in inference time compared to existing CNN-based detectors.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing queries in such systems remains a challenging task, particularly in the presence of dynamic workloads and heterogeneous hardware configurations. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, which learns to adapt to changing database conditions and optimizes query execution plans accordingly. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach using a real-world dataset and show significant improvements in query performance and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Turn Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have seen significant advances with the advent of deep learning, but their opacity hinders widespread adoption. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for multi-turn dialogue systems, which provides inherent explainability through attention weights. Our HAN framework consists of two stages: (1) utterance-level attention to identify relevant context, and (2) dialogue-level attention to model conversation flow. We evaluate our approach on four benchmark datasets, demonstrating improved response accuracy and fluency while providing insights into the decision-making process through visualized attention patterns.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have become increasingly prevalent in human-computer interaction, but their design often overlooks the needs of users with motor impairments. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive gesture recognition systems, focusing on users with cerebral palsy and Parkinson's disease. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops and usability studies to inform the development of a novel gesture recognition framework that incorporates adaptive machine learning algorithms and personalized gesture sets. Our results show significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture recognition systems.

title: Eliminating Semantic Gap in Image Retrieval Systems using Deep Learning-based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Image retrieval systems often suffer from the semantic gap, where low-level visual features fail to capture high-level semantic concepts. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'Semantics-in-Embeddings' (SiE), which leverages deep learning-based embeddings to bridge this gap. SiE learns to represent images as dense vectors that encode both visual and semantic information, enabling more accurate and semantically meaningful image retrieval. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, with SiE outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data analysis, where the goal is to predict the labels of unseen nodes. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages the hierarchical structure of graphs to improve node classification performance. Our model employs attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant nodes and neighborhoods, and adaptively combines features from different hierarchical levels. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in achieving state-of-the-art performance, especially on graphs with complex hierarchical structures.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multimodal fusion in Visual Question Answering (VQA) remains a challenging task due to the complexity of aligning and integrating visual and textual features. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant regions of the image and words in the question, enabling more accurate and interpretable answers. Our approach leverages a hierarchical structure to model the relationships between modalities, and incorporates a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each modality. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Drone Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous drone navigation in dynamic environments is a challenging problem due to the need to adapt to changing obstacles, weather conditions, and mission objectives. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HierDrone', which integrates a high-level mission planner with a low-level motion controller. The mission planner uses a graph-based representation to optimize the drone's trajectory, while the motion controller employs a deep Q-network to adapt to local environment changes. We evaluate HierDrone in a simulated urban environment and demonstrate improved navigation efficiency and robustness compared to flat reinforcement learning baselines.

title: Gaze-based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information, but current interaction methods often rely on manual input devices. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction as a more natural and intuitive approach. We conducted a user study to analyze eye movement patterns in VR and developed a machine learning model to predict user intent based on gaze behavior. Our results show that the proposed model achieves high accuracy in intent recognition, outperforming traditional interaction methods. This work has implications for the development of more immersive and accessible VR experiences.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of multi-modal data has created challenges for traditional indexing techniques. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach that combines the strengths of inverted indexing and hierarchical clustering. Our method, called 'HybridIndex', leverages the efficiency of inverted indexing for textual data and the effectiveness of hierarchical clustering for non-textual data. We demonstrate the efficacy of HybridIndex through extensive experiments on a large-scale dataset, showcasing significant improvements in retrieval time and accuracy compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, as agents with varying capabilities and constraints need to work together efficiently. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective task allocation strategies. Our GNN model, 'AgentGNN', leverages the structural properties of the agent-task graph to learn a representation of agent capabilities and task requirements. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentGNN in simulated scenarios, showing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional heuristic-based approaches.

title: Hybrid Negotiation Strategies for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments face the challenge of adapting to changing circumstances while negotiating with other agents to achieve their goals. This paper proposes a hybrid negotiation strategy that combines machine learning-based opponent modeling with game-theoretic analysis. Our approach enables agents to reason about the uncertainty of their opponents' behaviors and adjust their negotiation tactics accordingly. Experimental results demonstrate that our hybrid strategy outperforms existing approaches in achieving efficient and fair agreements in a variety of scenarios.

title: EyeGazePath: A Novel Gaze-Based Navigation System for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information. However, navigation in VR environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents EyeGazePath, a novel gaze-based navigation system that utilizes eye-tracking technology to enable users to navigate through virtual spaces more efficiently. Our system leverages machine learning algorithms to predict user intent and provide personalized navigation paths. We conducted a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of EyeGazePath and found significant improvements in navigation time, accuracy, and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based navigation methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Complex SQL Queries using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing complex SQL queries is a crucial task in database management systems. Traditional optimization techniques often rely on heuristics or rule-based approaches, which can lead to suboptimal query plans. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'RL-Optimizer', which learns to optimize queries by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution time. We introduce a novel state representation that captures the structural and semantic properties of SQL queries, enabling the RL agent to generalize to unseen queries. Experiments on a variety of benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-Optimizer outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers, achieving up to 30% reduction in query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction is a challenging task that requires models to generalize well to unseen relations with limited training data. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages the graph structure of entity-relation graphs to learn more effective representations. Our approach employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant entities and relations at different levels of abstraction. Experiments on two benchmark datasets show that HGAT significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot relation extraction, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5%.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Data Warehousing using GPU-Accelerated Join Algorithms
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, necessitating efficient query processing to support timely decision-making. This paper explores the potential of harnessing GPU acceleration to optimize join algorithms, a critical bottleneck in query processing. We propose a novel GPU-accelerated join framework, 'GPUJoin', which leverages parallel processing and memory coalescing to significantly reduce query execution times. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that GPUJoin outperforms state-of-the-art CPU-based join algorithms, achieving speedups of up to 10x for complex queries.

title: Scalable Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant performance challenges due to complex query optimization. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, 'RL-QO'. By modeling query optimization as a Markov decision process, RL-QO learns to adapt to dynamic query workloads and optimize query execution plans. We evaluate RL-QO on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate significant improvements in query throughput and latency compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers. Our results show that RL-QO can effectively scale to large distributed systems and provide robust performance under varying workloads.

title: Improved Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (IR) is a challenging task due to the complexity and nuance of medical terminology. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, specifically designed for medical IR. Our model, MedExp, leverages a combination of word embeddings and convolutional neural networks to identify relevant expansion terms from a large corpus of medical texts. Experimental results on a standard medical IR dataset show that MedExp significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a mean average precision improvement of 15.2%. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of MedExp in improving retrieval performance on a real-world medical IR system.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Complex Database Schemas using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of database management systems, but existing methods struggle with complex database schemas. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn query optimization strategies. We represent database schemas as graphs and utilize GNNs to capture their structural and semantic properties. Our approach, dubbed 'GQO', outperforms traditional query optimization techniques on a range of benchmarks, achieving an average improvement of 23% in query execution time. We also demonstrate the scalability of GQO on large-scale databases with thousands of tables.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multi-Modal Search using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: With the increasing demand for multi-modal search, query expansion techniques have become crucial for improving retrieval efficiency. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'MMQE', which leverages the strengths of both language models and visual feature extractors to expand queries. MMQE uses a multi-task learning framework to jointly learn query semantics and visual representations, enabling effective expansion of queries for text-image searches. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that MMQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Adaptive Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification tasks require models to adapt quickly to new classes with limited data. This paper proposes a novel deep meta-learning approach, 'AdaTask', which learns to generate task embeddings that adapt to the specific classification task at hand. Our method leverages a hierarchical neural network to learn a task-agnostic representation and then fine-tunes the embeddings for each new task. We demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet, and show that AdaTask outperforms existing methods in both accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Attention
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when faced with novel tasks. This paper introduces a novel meta-learning approach, 'TaskAware', which leverages task-aware attention mechanisms to adapt to new tasks with limited labeled data. Our method learns to selectively focus on relevant task-specific features and adapt the attention weights based on the task distribution. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TaskAware on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on few-shot image classification tasks while reducing computational overhead.

title: Gaze-Based Emotion Recognition using Deep Learning for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling systems to respond empathetically to users. This paper presents a novel gaze-based emotion recognition approach using deep learning. We propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) that extracts features from eye movement data and classify emotions into seven categories. Our approach leverages a large-scale dataset of gaze patterns annotated with emotional labels. Experimental results show that our model outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an accuracy of 92.1% and an F1-score of 91.5%. We also demonstrate the applicability of our approach in a real-world HCI scenario, where it enables a virtual assistant to respond empathetically to users' emotional states.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Subgraph Homomorphism
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query optimization remains a challenging task due to the complexity of graph patterns and the need to minimize communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel query optimization technique that leverages subgraph homomorphism to efficiently identify and prune unnecessary subqueries. We introduce a hierarchical query decomposition framework that exploits the structural properties of graph patterns, reducing the search space and improving query performance. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but the lack of embodied cognition in VR interfaces hinders user experience. This paper investigates the role of gesture-based interaction in enhancing cognitive engagement and immersion in VR. We designed a VR system that incorporates gesture recognition and haptic feedback, and conducted a user study to evaluate its effectiveness. Results show that our approach significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces cognitive load, and increases presence in VR environments. Our findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and engaging VR interfaces.

title: Deep Variational Autoencoders for Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel approach based on deep variational autoencoders (DVAEs), which learn a probabilistic representation of normal data patterns. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that incorporates temporal and spatial attention mechanisms, enabling the model to capture complex dependencies and Identify anomalies at multiple scales. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to noise and concept drift.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: We propose a novel neural query expansion approach that leverages deep learning to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of document retrieval in modern search engines. Our method, dubbed 'NQE', utilizes a transformer-based architecture to learn query-document relationships and generate expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval accuracy and query latency, making it a promising solution for large-scale search applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Q-Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, utilizing multi-agent Q-networks to learn cooperative policies. We extend the traditional Q-learning framework to accommodate multiple agents, enabling them to learn from their individual experiences and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated logistics scenario, demonstrating improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to centralized optimization methods. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of our algorithm, ensuring the emergence of cooperative behavior among agents.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: As document collections continue to grow in size, the efficiency of query expansion techniques becomes paramount for effective information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, HQE, which leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and documents to identify the most informative expansion terms. HQE uses a probabilistic topic modeling approach to generate a hierarchical representation of the document collection, enabling more accurate and efficient query expansion. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: This study examines the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) to alleviate cognitive load in older adults during human-computer interactions. We designed an ECA-based interface that utilizes gestures, facial expressions, and vocal cues to facilitate comprehension and engagement. Our user study involved 30 older adults completing a series of cognitively demanding tasks with and without the ECA interface. Results show significant reductions in cognitive load, measured through eye-tracking and self-reported surveys, when the ECA interface was used. Our findings have implications for the design of accessible and inclusive interfaces for older adults.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require advanced control strategies to navigate complex, dynamic environments. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for autonomous vehicle control, comprising a high-level policy for scenario recognition and a low-level policy for trajectory planning. We introduce a novel temporal attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant sensory inputs and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results in simulated and real-world scenarios demonstrate improved control stability and adaptability compared to flat, non-hierarchical reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning for Novel Class Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on accurate object detection to ensure safe navigation. However, detecting novel classes not seen during training is a significant challenge. This paper introduces 'AV-ZSL', a zero-shot learning framework that leverages semantic embeddings and graph neural networks to recognize novel classes. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the popular KITTI dataset, with an average precision of 84.2% on novel classes. We also propose a novel metric, 'Novelty-Aware mAP', to evaluate the performance of zero-shot learning methods in autonomous driving scenarios.

title: Guiding Hand Gestures for Enhanced Virtual Reality Interaction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on controllers or tracking devices to detect user input, limiting the naturalness and expressiveness of interactions. This paper presents 'HandGuide', a novel system that leverages computer vision and machine learning to recognize and interpret hand gestures in VR environments. By analyzing a dataset of annotated hand movements, we develop a gesture recognition model that can accurately classify and predict user intentions. We also propose a set of design guidelines for creating intuitive and immersive VR experiences that incorporate hand gestures, validated through a user study.

title: Robust Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach to task allocation using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the agent-task interactions as a graph and leverage GNNs to learn a robust task allocation strategy that is resilient to agent failures and dynamic changes in the environment. Experimental results on a set of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate and adaptability to changing conditions.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Document Embeddings for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering requires efficiently retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus. This paper introduces Hierarchical Document Embeddings (HiDE), a novel neural retrieval model that learns to represent documents in a hierarchical fashion, capturing both local and global semantic structures. HiDE outperforms state-of-the-art dense retrieval models on several benchmark datasets, achieving a 15% improvement in retrieval accuracy while reducing computational cost by 30%. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HiDE in an end-to-end question answering pipeline, showcasing its potential for real-world applications.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using a Graph-based Approach
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for anomaly detection using deep learning techniques. We represent time series data as graphs, where each node corresponds to a time step, and edges capture temporal dependencies. We then employ a graph convolutional network (GCN) to learn a robust representation of normal patterns and identify anomalies. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults Using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, it is essential to design interfaces that are accessible and usable for older adults. This paper presents a machine learning-based approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults. We propose a novel gesture recognition framework that leverages transfer learning and domain adaptation to improve recognition accuracy for older adults. Our user study with 30 older adults shows that our approach significantly reduces error rates and improves user satisfaction compared to existing gesture recognition systems. We also provide design guidelines for creating inclusive gesture-based interfaces that can be used in various applications, such as smart homes and healthcare systems.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in such systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and use deep Q-networks to learn an optimal query execution plan. Our approach takes into account various factors such as data distribution, network latency, and node availability. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems with heterogeneous storage architectures have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data and improve query performance. However, optimizing queries in such systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel cost-based query optimization framework that takes into account the storage characteristics of different nodes in the system. We introduce a new storage-aware cost model that estimates the execution time of queries based on the data distribution and storage capacity of each node. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Ranking-based Document Retrieval using Context-Aware Query Embeddings
paper_abstract: Modern search engines rely on query embeddings to capture the semantic meaning of user queries. However, existing methods often neglect the contextual information surrounding the query, leading to suboptimal document retrieval. This paper proposes a novel ranking-based approach, 'CAQE', that incorporates contextual features into query embeddings. By leveraging a graph-based attention mechanism, CAQE learns to weigh the importance of contextual terms and phrases, resulting in more accurate document retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems face scalability challenges as the number of users and items grows. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex user-item relationships. HGAT hierarchically aggregates node representations, enabling efficient processing of large graphs. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several real-world datasets, achieving significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and scalability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in Smart Cities
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for dynamic task allocation in smart cities. We consider a scenario where multiple agents, representing urban service providers, need to allocate tasks to optimize overall city performance. Our approach, called Dec-MARL, utilizes a novel communication mechanism that enables agents to share experiences and learn from each other in a decentralized manner. We evaluate Dec-MARL on a realistic simulation platform and demonstrate its ability to adapt to changing city dynamics, outperforming traditional centralized task allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Word Embeddings for Retrieval in Short-Text Collections
paper_abstract: Short-text collections, such as Twitter or product reviews, pose unique challenges for information retrieval systems. Query expansion techniques can improve retrieval effectiveness, but existing methods often rely on term co-occurrence statistics or manually curated resources. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'EmbedQE', uses a graph-based algorithm to select expansion terms that are most similar to the original query in the vector space. Experiments on several short-text datasets demonstrate that EmbedQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for queries with low term frequency.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Human-Robot Collaboration
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in shared workspaces, there is a growing need for efficient human-robot collaboration (HRC) strategies. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that enables robots to adapt to changing human preferences and tasks in real-time. Our approach combines a high-level policy that selects tasks based on human feedback with a low-level policy that executes the selected task. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our HRL framework in a simulated HRC environment, achieving significant improvements in task completion efficiency and human satisfaction compared to traditional flat reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems via Adaptive Graph-Based Planning
paper_abstract: Coordinated exploration is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to efficiently explore an environment while avoiding redundant actions. This paper proposes a novel graph-based planning approach, 'AdaptGraph', which adaptively constructs a graph representation of the environment and allocates agents to explore different regions. We introduce a probabilistic model that updates the graph structure based on the agents' observations, enabling them to adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate that AdaptGraph outperforms existing methods in terms of exploration efficiency and communication overhead.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Document Structures
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial step in many information retrieval applications, but existing neural ranking models often fail to effectively utilize the hierarchical structure of documents. We propose a novel neural ranking model, Hierarchical Passage Ranker (HPR), which incorporates document structure through a hierarchical attention mechanism. HPR first learns a document-level representation by aggregating passage-level features, and then uses this representation to compute a final ranking score. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HPR outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, particularly for documents with complex hierarchical structures.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Efficient task allocation is crucial for autonomous vehicles operating in complex environments. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARTA', which enables distributed task allocation among autonomous vehicles. MARTA leverages graph neural networks to represent the spatial relationships between vehicles and tasks, and employs a decentralized Q-learning approach to optimize task assignments. We evaluate MARTA on a realistic simulation platform, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Deep Recursive Neural Networks for Graph-Based Dependency Parsing
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel deep learning architecture for graph-based dependency parsing, leveraging recursive neural networks to model hierarchical graph structures. Our approach, dubbed 'RecDep', recursively applies a graph convolutional network to capture complex dependencies between nodes, enabling the parser to accurately predict subtree structures. Experimental results on the English Penn Treebank dataset demonstrate that RecDep achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming existing graph-based parsers by a significant margin.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Conventional information retrieval systems rely on shallow ranking models, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking framework, 'HiRank', which leverages document hierarchies to improve retrieval efficiency. HiRank employs a document-level neural network to extract semantic representations, followed by a hierarchical aggregation mechanism to capture contextual relationships. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HiRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Learning-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases are increasingly used in modern applications, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel learning-based indexing approach, 'GraphLIX', which leverages machine learning models to predict query patterns and optimize index creation. We develop a graph neural network (GNN) that learns to identify frequent query subgraphs and generates adaptive indexing strategies. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphLIX reduces query latency by up to 3x and improves index creation time by 2x compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, autonomous negotiation is crucial for achieving efficient and fair outcomes. This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous negotiation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a hierarchical framework that integrates a deep Q-network with a negotiation protocol, enabling agents to adapt to changing environments and opponent strategies. Experimental results on a variety of negotiation scenarios demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of negotiation outcomes, convergence speed, and robustness to opponent types.

title: Distributed Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In real-world scenarios, multi-agent systems often face incomplete information about their environment, leading to suboptimal planning. This paper presents a novel distributed planning framework, 'InfoGap', that enables agents to reason about uncertainty and adapt to new information. We introduce a probabilistic graphical model to represent agents' beliefs and develop a decentralized planning algorithm that leverages local observations to reduce uncertainty. Experimental results on a rescue robotics domain demonstrate that InfoGap outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and robustness to incomplete information.

title: EyeGazeType: A Machine Learning-based Keyboard System for Efficient Text Entry
paper_abstract: This paper presents EyeGazeType, a novel keyboard system that leverages machine learning and eye-gaze tracking to improve text entry efficiency. By analyzing users' eye movements, our system predicts the intended character and auto-completes words, reducing the need for manual typing. We evaluate EyeGazeType using a large-scale user study, demonstrating a significant reduction in typing time and error rate compared to traditional keyboard systems. Furthermore, we explore the use of transfer learning to adapt our model to individual users, resulting in improved performance and personalization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning aims to learn from limited data, but existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and poor generalization. This paper proposes Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical feature representations and attention mechanisms to improve few-shot learning efficiency. HANs adaptively select relevant feature subsets and aggregate them using a hierarchical attention mechanism, reducing the requirement for large-scale labeled data. We evaluate HANs on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating superior performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Dementia
paper_abstract: This paper presents the design and evaluation of ' GestureEase', a gesture-based interface tailored to support older adults with dementia. Our approach incorporates a multimodal fusion of computer vision, machine learning, and user-centered design to recognize and adapt to individual differences in gesture patterns. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction compared to traditional touchscreen interfaces. Our findings inform the development of more inclusive and accessible interfaces for older adults with dementia, highlighting the potential for HCI to promote healthy aging and social participation.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has become a crucial aspect of building trustworthy recommendation systems. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that integrates graph-based feature extraction with attention mechanisms to generate personalized recommendations. HGAT learns to attend to relevant user and item features, as well as their hierarchical relationships, to provide transparent and interpretable recommendations. We evaluate HGAT on three real-world datasets and demonstrate improved performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art recommendation models. Our approach has significant implications for deploying XAI-driven recommendation systems in high-stakes applications.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when dealing with novel classes. This paper introduces a hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'TaskAware', which leverages task-aware embeddings to adapt to new classes with limited labeled data. Our approach combines a task encoder with a novel meta-learner that generates class-specific weights for the embedding space. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that TaskAware outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved accuracy and robustness in the face of class imbalance and noisy data.

title: Query Expansion via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when users submit poorly formulated queries. This paper introduces a novel query expansion approach, QERL, which leverages deep reinforcement learning to iteratively refine queries based on user feedback. Our method employs a hierarchical policy network to select relevant terms from a candidate set, simulating user interactions to optimize the retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that QERL outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% relative increase in mean average precision.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Vibrotactile Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on visual and auditory cues to provide users with a sense of immersion. However, the lack of haptic feedback can lead to a disconnect between the user's actions and the virtual environment. This paper investigates the impact of vibrotactile feedback on user experience in VR. We designed a study to compare user performance and satisfaction in a VR task with and without vibrotactile feedback. Our results show that vibrotactile feedback significantly improves user performance and reduces user frustration, particularly in tasks requiring fine motor control. We also present a novel framework for integrating vibrotactile feedback into VR systems, which can be adapted to various applications.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness Enhancement in Deep Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Deep learning-based recommender systems have shown remarkable success in personalized recommendation tasks. However, they are often vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can drastically degrade their performance. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training approach, 'AdvRec', specifically designed for deep recommender systems. AdvRec leverages a generative adversarial network (GAN) to craft realistic and diverse adversarial examples, which are then used to augment the training data. Our extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdvRec significantly improves the robustness of deep recommender systems against various types of attacks, including data poisoning and model inversion attacks.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Adaptive Haptic Feedback in Virtual Reality for Individuals with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve access to information and experiences for individuals with visual impairments. However, the lack of tactile feedback in VR environments can hinder user engagement and navigation. This paper presents a novel adaptive haptic feedback system, 'HapticGuide', designed to provide personalized tactile cues to users with visual impairments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, comparing HapticGuide to traditional audio-based feedback. Results show significant improvements in navigation efficiency, user satisfaction, and reduced cognitive load with HapticGuide. Our findings have implications for the development of inclusive VR experiences.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering via Hierarchical Dense Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient passage retrieval from a massive corpus to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Dense Passage Retrieval (HDPR), which leverages hierarchical dense representations to capture complex semantic relationships between questions and passages. Our method first encodes questions and passages into dense vectors using a neural retriever, and then applies a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group similar passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDPR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods in terms of both retrieval efficiency and downstream QA performance.

title: Gaze-Based Typing Error Correction for People with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with computers, resulting in high error rates and frustration. This paper presents a novel gaze-based typing error correction system, 'GazeCorrect', designed for users with motor impairments. GazeCorrect utilizes a machine learning-based approach to predict the intended key press based on the user's gaze patterns, correcting errors in real-time. Our evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated a significant reduction in error rates (45.6%) and increased typing speed (23.4%) compared to traditional gaze-based typing systems.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Cloud-Native Databases
paper_abstract: Cloud-native databases have become increasingly popular for large-scale data storage and processing. However, efficient indexing techniques for multi-dimensional range queries remain a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel indexing scheme, 'SkyPiler', which leverages the concept of skyline points to prune the search space and reduce query latency. We propose a cost-based optimization framework that adaptively adjusts the index structure based on query patterns and data distribution. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that SkyPiler outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query performance and 2x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Assistants: A Multimodal Approach for Aging Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have the potential to improve the daily lives of aging adults with cognitive impairments. However, current VA designs often neglect the unique needs of this population. This paper presents a multimodal VA framework that incorporates visual, auditory, and tactile feedback to facilitate task completion. We conducted a user study with 20 aging adults with cognitive impairments and found that our approach significantly improved task accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional VA designs. Our framework also includes a novel cognitive load assessment module that adaptively adjusts the VA's communication style to the user's cognitive state.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to enrich the original query to better capture user intent. Traditional methods rely on term frequency and co-occurrence analysis, but often struggle to capture semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a neural embedding-based approach, 'NeuroXpand', which learns dense vector representations of query terms and their contextual relationships. By incorporating these embeddings into a novel query expansion framework, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets, including TREC and ClueWeb. Our approach also exhibits robustness to query ambiguity and outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Search Engines using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data queries. However, query efficiency remains a significant challenge, particularly in scenarios where data is scattered across multiple machines. This paper presents a novel approach to indexing and querying in distributed search engines. We propose a hierarchical indexing scheme that exploits the inherent structure of the data to reduce the number of machines involved in query processing. Our experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate significant improvements in query latency and throughput compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval of Biomedical Literature
paper_abstract: The exponential growth of biomedical literature has necessitated the development of efficient and effective information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'BioHQE', which leverages domain-specific ontologies and semantic embeddings to disambiguate query terms and expand the search space. Our experiments on the PubMed dataset demonstrate that BioHQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 25% increase in mean average precision and a 30% reduction in query response time.

title: Reinforcing Document Representation with Entity-Aware Graph Attention for Knowledge Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional knowledge retrieval systems rely on bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture complex relationships between entities in documents. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'EntityGraph', which incorporates entity-aware graph attention mechanisms to learn contextualized document representations. By jointly modeling entity interactions and semantic relationships, EntityGraph significantly improves the retrieval performance on benchmark datasets. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in retrieving relevant documents for entity-centric queries, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Designing Inclusive Multimodal Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Older adults with cognitive impairments face significant barriers when interacting with modern digital systems. This paper presents a novel multimodal interface framework, 'EasyAccess', that integrates speech, gesture, and gaze-based inputs to facilitate intuitive and accessible interactions. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults with cognitive impairments, demonstrating that EasyAccess significantly improved task completion rates and reduced frustration compared to traditional keyboard-and-mouse interfaces. Our findings highlight the importance of considering cognitive and sensory abilities in HCI design, and provide insights for developing more inclusive and supportive technologies.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to the exponential growth of possible assignments. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to efficiently allocate tasks to agents. Our method, called GraphMA, represents the agent-task graph as a learnable structure, enabling the GNN to capture subtle dependencies between agents and tasks. We evaluate GraphMA on several benchmarks, demonstrating a significant reduction in computational complexity and improved solution quality compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we show that GraphMA can be easily extended to accommodate dynamic task arrivals and agent failures.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans is crucial in distributed relational databases. Recent advances in graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promise in learning complex patterns in graph-structured data. We propose a novel approach, 'GNN-Opt', that leverages GNNs to learn a query optimization model from a database's query logs and schema. Our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques, such as dynamic programming and rule-based optimization, in terms of query latency and resource utilization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GNN-Opt on a real-world distributed database, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x over existing optimization methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to capture complex semantic relationships between query terms. Our method, called NeuroQE, uses a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query representation and expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving an average increase of 15% in mean average precision.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has shown promising results in open-domain question answering. However, its computational requirements and memory footprint limit its applicability to large-scale retrieval tasks. This paper introduces a novel query-adaptive document embedding (QADE) method that learns to adaptively adjust document representations based on the query context. QADE leverages a lightweight transformer architecture to generate query-dependent document embeddings, resulting in significant speedup and reduced memory usage while maintaining retrieval performance. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of QADE in improving the efficiency of DPR-based systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and capturing complex relationships. We propose HAGCN, a hierarchical attention graph convolutional network that leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant neighboring nodes. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art results on multiple benchmark datasets, including ogbn-arxiv and ogbn-products, while reducing computational complexity by up to 50% compared to existing GNN-based methods. Experiments demonstrate the efficacy of HAGCN in real-world applications, such as user profiling and recommender systems.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a pervasive problem that affects many cities worldwide. This paper explores the use of autonomous agents, coordinated through reinforcement learning, to optimize traffic signal control in real-time. We propose a decentralized framework, 'Traffic Harmony', where agents learn to adjust signal timings based on local traffic conditions and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach incorporates domain knowledge from traffic engineering and leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to adapt to changing traffic patterns. Experimental results using real-world traffic data demonstrate significant reductions in congestion and travel times compared to traditional fixed-time signal control strategies.

title: An Adaptive Trust Model for Multi-Agent Systems with Heterogeneous Sources of Evidence
paper_abstract: Trust models are crucial for effective collaboration in multi-agent systems, but existing approaches often rely on a single source of evidence or assume homogeneous agent interactions. This paper presents a novel adaptive trust model, 'HeteroTrust', that integrates heterogeneous sources of evidence, including direct interactions, indirect reputation, and contextual information. We propose a probabilistic framework that learns to weigh the importance of each evidence source based on the specific scenario and agent behavior. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response domain demonstrate that HeteroTrust outperforms state-of-the-art trust models in terms of accuracy and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide transparency into the decision-making process. This paper introduces a novel attention-based graph neural network (AGNN) model that incorporates both user-item interactions and item attributes to generate personalized explanations for recommendations. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to identify influential items and highlight relevant features, enabling users to understand the reasoning behind the recommended items. Empirical results on three real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AGNN in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient resource allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach that combines deep reinforcement learning with graph neural networks to coordinate agents in adaptive resource allocation tasks. Our method, 'DRL-GNN', learns to optimize resource allocation policies by modeling the complex interactions between agents and their environment. Experimental results in simulated smart grid scenarios demonstrate that DRL-GNN outperforms traditional optimization methods in terms of resource utilization and adaptability to changing environment conditions.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Individuals with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive conversational systems that cater to diverse abilities. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with disabilities, revealing key barriers and preferences in conversational interactions. Our framework, 'InConverse', integrates multimodal input mechanisms, adaptive dialogue management, and personalized accessibility features. We evaluate InConverse through a prototype implementation, demonstrating improved user satisfaction and task completion rates for individuals with visual, hearing, and motor impairments.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) models often rely on complex reasoning and contextual understanding, but their decision-making processes remain opaque. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical reasoning to enhance explainability in MHQA. HGAT learns to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges in the knowledge graph, allowing for interpretable visualizations of the reasoning process. Experimental results on the HotPotQA benchmark demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing more transparent and faithful explanations.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models have made significant progress, but their lack of interpretability hinders their adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages multi-scale graph attention to selectively focus on relevant regions of the image and question. Our approach enables the generation of interpretable attention maps, providing insights into the decision-making process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on the VQA 2.0 dataset, achieving state-of-the-art performance while offering unprecedented interpretability.

title: EyeTrackingLens: A Gaze-Based Interaction Framework for Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: Augmented Reality (AR) interfaces often rely on manual input methods, which can be cumbersome and limiting. This paper presents EyeTrackingLens, a novel framework that leverages gaze-based interaction to enable more natural and efficient user experiences in AR. We develop a machine learning model that accurately predicts user intent from eye movement patterns, and integrate it with a real-time gaze tracking system. Our user study demonstrates that EyeTrackingLens significantly reduces interaction time and improves user satisfaction in AR-based tasks. We also discuss the implications of our approach for users with disabilities and its potential applications in various domains.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Query-Dependent Neural Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Existing neural ranking models for ad-hoc retrieval often rely on static document embeddings, neglecting the nuanced relationships between queries and documents. We propose a novel query-dependent neural embedding approach, 'QDNE', which generates dynamic document representations conditioned on the query context. Our approach leverages a multi-head attention mechanism to capture fine-grained semantic interactions between query terms and document entities. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that QDNE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of NDCG@10 and ERR, while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Exploiting Contextualized Query Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval models typically rely on exact term matching, neglecting the rich contextual information inherent in queries. This paper introduces a novel neural ranking model, 'CtxQER', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate contextualized query embeddings. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weighs the importance of query terms based on their semantic roles. Experiments on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that CtxQER significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models, particularly for complex, multi-entity queries. Our analysis reveals that the proposed approach effectively captures nuanced query semantics, leading to improved retrieval effectiveness.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document indexing methods in information retrieval (IR) rely on fixed, dense vector representations, which can be computationally expensive and may not capture the nuances of user queries. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document embedding (QADE) approach, which dynamically generates compact, sparse representations of documents based on the context and semantics of the input query. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADE improves retrieval efficiency by up to 30% while maintaining state-of-the-art retrieval effectiveness.

title: Unsupervised Query Suggestion via Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely on query suggestion to improve user experience.
