Existing methods often rely on supervised learning, which requires expensive annotation and may not generalize well to unseen queries. This paper proposes 'HRL-QS', a novel unsupervised query suggestion framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning. HRL-QS learns to identify relevant query suggestions by maximizing a reward function that balances search result relevance and diversity. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HRL-QS outperforms state-of-the-art supervised and unsupervised baselines, while reducing annotation costs.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced Learning Outcomes
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to improve learning outcomes. We design and evaluate a gesture-based interaction system that leverages the cognitive benefits of bodily engagement in learning. Our user study with 60 participants shows that the embodied interaction paradigm leads to significant improvements in knowledge retention and recall compared to traditional keyboard-and-mouse interfaces. We also identify key gestures and movement patterns that are correlated with successful learning outcomes, shedding light on the cognitive underpinnings of embodied cognition in VR.

title: Graph-Based Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for managing large-scale data. However, query processing remains a significant bottleneck due to the complexities of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GraphIX', which leverages graph theory to efficiently prune irrelevant data partitions and minimize communication costs. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphIX reduces query response time by up to 40% compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while maintaining comparable query accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, real-time analytics has become a critical component of modern data-driven applications. However, optimizing queries for distributed databases remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'OptiStream', which leverages machine learning and graph-based techniques to minimize query latency and resource utilization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of OptiStream through extensive experiments on a real-world IoT dataset, showcasing improvements of up to 3x in query response time and 2x in resource efficiency compared to state-of-the-art optimization methods.

title: Efficient Document Representation for Neural Information Retrieval using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (NeuIR) models have shown promising results in various retrieval tasks. However, learning effective document representations remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel contrastive learning approach, 'CLR-DR', for learning document representations. CLR-DR leverages large-scale unlabeled text data to learn robust document embeddings that capture semantic relationships between documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CLR-DR outperforms existing state-of-the-art NeuIR models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems rely on bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between documents. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Semantic Embeddings (HSE), which learns a hierarchical graph neural network to encode documents as dense vectors. HSE leverages both local and global contextual information to capture semantic hierarchies, enabling more accurate and efficient document retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods, achieving up to 25% relative increase in retrieval precision.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems often rely on handcrafted features and ranking models, which may not capture the nuances of complex queries. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking approach that incorporates query expansion to improve document retrieval efficiency. Our model, dubbed 'DeepQE', leverages a hierarchical neural network to learn semantic representations of queries and documents, and then applies a reinforcement learning-based ranking strategy to optimize the retrieval process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models in terms of precision and recall, while reducing query latency by up to 30%.

title: Real-time Human Pose Estimation using Graph Attention Networks for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Human pose estimation is a crucial component in autonomous systems, such as self-driving cars and robots, for understanding human behavior and intentions. This paper presents a novel real-time human pose estimation framework, 'PoseGAN', which leverages graph attention networks to model the complex relationships between body joints. PoseGAN achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, outperforming traditional CNN-based methods in terms of accuracy and speed. We demonstrate the effectiveness of PoseGAN in a real-world autonomous driving scenario, enabling the system to accurately detect and respond to pedestrian movements.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant answers. However, the lexical gap between questions and passages often hinders accurate retrieval. This paper introduces DPRF, a novel deep query reformulation framework that learns to paraphrase questions into more effective search queries. DPRF leverages a hierarchical encoder to capture contextual relationships between question words and incorporates a reinforcement learning objective to optimize retrieval performance. Experimental results on theNatural Questions benchmark demonstrate that DPRF improves passage retrieval accuracy by 12.3% and reduces the number of required passages by 30.5%, leading to significant speedups in ODQA systems.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding via Hierarchical Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial technique for various artificial intelligence applications. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and neglect the hierarchical structure of relations in knowledge graphs. To address these limitations, we propose a novel KGE framework, 'HIERA', which leverages hierarchical relation attention to selectively focus on relevant relational patterns. Our approach reduces the number of parameters and computations required while improving the quality of embeddings. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HIERA over state-of-the-art methods in link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering via Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a user's question. This paper presents a novel hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) approach that efficiently retrieves top-k passages by jointly optimizing passage and document-level representations. Our method leverages a multi-level attention mechanism to capture both local and global context, resulting in improved retrieval accuracy and reduced computational cost. Experimental results on popular ODQA benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of HDR, achieving state-of-the-art results in terms of top-k accuracy and retrieval efficiency.

title: Real-Time Data Integration for IoT Streams using Adaptive Query Optimization
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in streaming data, posing significant challenges for real-time data integration and querying. This paper presents 'AQOS', an adaptive query optimization system that dynamically adjusts query plans based on IoT stream characteristics and workload patterns. AQOS leverages machine learning models to predict query performance and optimize query execution, resulting in improved response times and reduced resource utilization. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate AQOS's ability to achieve up to 3x faster query response times and 40% reduced CPU utilization compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for coordinating autonomous vehicles in complex scenarios. Our approach, called 'MAV-CAD', utilizes a graph neural network to model the interactions between vehicles and a decentralized actor-critic algorithm to learn cooperative policies. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MAV-CAD in reducing congestion and improving safety in simulations of real-world traffic scenarios. The results show that MAV-CAD outperforms traditional rule-based approaches and centralized optimization methods in terms of both efficiency and adaptability.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Cold Start Problem in Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: The cold start problem in recommendation systems hinders personalized suggestions for new users or items. This paper proposes a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'HyRec', that combines the strengths of collaborative filtering (CF) and natural language processing (NLP) techniques. HyRec leverages item embeddings from a pre-trained language model to augment user-item interactions, thus enabling effective retrieval for cold start items. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that HyRec outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of precision, recall, and A/B testing metrics.

title: Optimizing query performance using a Hybrid Indexing Scheme for NoSQL databases
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of big data has led to the widespread adoption of NoSQL databases, which often compromise on query performance to achieve high scalability. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing scheme, termed HIndex, which combines the strengths of log-structured merge-trees and B+ trees to optimize query performance in NoSQL databases. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that HIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing schemes by up to 30% in terms of query latency, while maintaining comparable storage efficiency.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the gap between the user's query and the relevant documents. While traditional methods rely on hand-crafted rules and heuristics, this paper explores the application of deep neural networks to learn query expansion strategies. We propose a novel architecture, 'QNLP', which leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent layers to capture both local and global patterns in the query and document representations. Experimental results on the TREC benchmark demonstrate that QNLP outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that learns to represent agents' interactions and cooperatively reason about their goals. HGAT combines graph attention with hierarchical reinforcement learning to enable agents to adapt to changing environments and communicate effectively. Experimental results on a simulated robotic soccer domain show that HGAT outperforms existing approaches in terms of team performance and adaptability, while reducing communication overhead.

title: Deep Transfer Learning for Few-Shot Object Detection in Aerial Imagery
paper_abstract: Object detection in aerial imagery is a challenging task, especially when annotated data is scarce. This paper proposes a novel deep transfer learning approach that leverages pre-trained models and fine-tunes them on a few labeled examples. We introduce a residual feature fusion module that adaptively combines features from different layers, enabling the model to capture rich contextual information. Experimental results on the popular Inria Aerial Image Dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on few-shot object detection tasks, outperforming existing methods by a significant margin.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for urban traffic management using hierarchical reinforcement learning. We propose a two-level framework, where high-level agents learn to optimize traffic signal control policies and low-level agents adapt to local traffic conditions. Our method leverages graph neural networks to represent complex traffic networks and incorporates real-time traffic data to improve policy learning. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing congestion and travel times by up to 25%.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Data Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes an adaptive data replication strategy that dynamically adjusts data placement based on query patterns and system workload. Our approach leverages machine learning-based query prediction and a cost-benefit analysis to determine the optimal data replication scheme. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves up to 35% improvement in query response time and 25% reduction in network traffic compared to existing static replication strategies.

title: Scalable Query Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of database systems, but traditional methods often struggle to adapt to dynamic workloads and large-scale distributed environments. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query plans in distributed database systems. We design a DRL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database environment and receiving rewards based on query execution time and resource utilization. Our experimental results on a simulated distributed database system show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized coordination framework for autonomous agents using reinforcement learning. Our approach, dubbed 'Decentralized-CoRL', enables agents to learn coordination strategies in complex, dynamic environments without relying on a centralized controller. We introduce a multi-agent Q-network that incorporates communication and observation graphs to facilitate cooperation and conflict resolution. Experimental results in a realistic simulated environment demonstrate the efficacy of Decentralized-CoRL in achieving efficient task allocation and resource utilization compared to traditional, non-learning based approaches.

title: Cooperative Path Planning for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative path planning for multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MAPPER', which enables agents to learn cooperative behaviors and adapt to changing environmental conditions. MAPPER uses a hybrid architecture combining graph neural networks and deep Q-networks to represent agent interactions and optimize path planning. Experimental results on a simulated urban transportation scenario demonstrate that MAPPER outperforms traditional model-based planning methods in terms of task completion time and agent safety.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: Fake news detection remains a critical challenge in natural language processing. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) framework that leverages graph-based representation learning and attention mechanisms to identify fake news articles. We introduce a hierarchical graph structure that captures both local and global contextual relationships between news articles and their corresponding user engagements. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in fake news detection, while providing interpretable explanations for its predictions.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In large-scale multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph-based reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. We model the agents' communication network as a graph and employ a novel graph neural network architecture to learn a policy that maximizes the system's overall performance. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead compared to traditional centralized methods.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning for Multimedia Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multimedia knowledge graphs have become increasingly popular for integrating heterogeneous data from various sources. However, existing embedding models require large amounts of labeled data, which is often scarce and expensive to obtain. This paper proposes a novel zero-shot learning approach, 'MultimediaZSL', which leverages the graph structure and multimodal features to learn robust embeddings without any labeled data. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different modalities and relations, resulting in improved embedding quality and better performance on downstream tasks. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of MultimediaZSL in facilitating knowledge graph completion and entity disambiguation.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies: A Taxonomy and Defense Strategies
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, including robotics, finance, and healthcare. However, recent studies have shown that DRL policies are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and safety. This paper presents a comprehensive taxonomy of adversarial attacks on DRL policies, including poisoning, evasion, and exploration attacks. We also propose a set of defense strategies, including input preprocessing, reward shaping, and policy regularization, to mitigate the effects of these attacks. Our experiments on several benchmark environments demonstrate the effectiveness of our defense strategies in improving the robustness of DRL policies.

title: Scalable Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various applications, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, existing methods struggle to scale with the increasing volume and complexity of data. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS-ADNet', which leverages a hierarchical encoder-decoder architecture to learn robust representations of time series data. Our method can efficiently handle long-term dependencies and identify anomalies through a reconstruction-based method. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TS-ADNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic control is a complex problem that requires coordinating the actions of multiple agents. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph attention to learn effective communication strategies among agents. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphMAC', represents the traffic network as a graph and uses attention mechanisms to focus on the most relevant neighboring agents. We demonstrate the efficacy of GraphMAC in a realistic simulation environment, showcasing improved traffic flow and reduced congestion compared to traditional decentralized methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents learn to allocate tasks autonomously using distributed reinforcement learning. We propose a actor-critic architecture that enables agents to learn from their local observations and communicate with neighboring agents to coordinate task assignments. Our approach outperforms traditional centralized task allocation methods in terms of adaptability, scalability, and robustness to agent failures. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and preferences need to be assigned to tasks to optimize system performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model agent-task interactions. Our approach represents the agents and tasks as nodes in a graph, and uses GCNs to learn a hierarchical representation of the task allocation problem. Experimental results on a simulated robot swarm scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and system efficiency.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Multi-Modal Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines often struggle to effectively retrieve relevant results when users query with multi-modal inputs, such as images and text. This paper introduces a novel neural ranking model, 'MMR-NRM', which jointly learns to represent and rank multi-modal queries and documents. Our approach leverages a transformer-based architecture to capture complex relationships between modalities and incorporates a listwise ranking loss function to optimize retrieval performance. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that MMR-NRM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recall and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control with Real-time Sensor Fusion
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient and robust control systems to navigate complex environments. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework that integrates real-time sensor data from cameras, lidars, and GPS to optimize vehicle control. Our method, 'SensorFusionRL', uses a multi-modal fusion approach to combine sensor inputs and improve the agent's decision-making process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SensorFusionRL in simulations and real-world experiments, showcasing improved stability, adaptability, and safety compared to traditional model-based control methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation in uncertain environments, where agents must adapt to changing task priorities and resource availability. We propose a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'AdaptMAL', which leverages decentralized exploration and communication to optimize task allocation. Our approach integrates a probabilistic task model with a deep reinforcement learning algorithm, enabling agents to learn effective allocation strategies in real-time. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that AdaptMAL outperforms traditional optimization methods, achieving higher task completion rates and reduced latency in the face of uncertainty.

title: Designing Adaptive UI Components for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but its adoption is hindered by limited accessibility features for users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive UI components in VR, which dynamically adjust to individual users' needs and abilities. We propose a multi-modal interaction model that incorporates machine learning-based user profiling, gesture recognition, and real-time feedback mechanisms. Our user study with participants with varying abilities demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Deep Neural Ranking Models for Semantic Search
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on lexical matching and tf-idf based ranking, which often fail to capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'SemRank', that leverages pre-trained language models to learn semantic representations of queries and documents. We introduce a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes ranking, classification, and clustering objectives to improve retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SemRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and relevance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query formulations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which leverages context-aware neural embeddings to enrich query representations. By incorporating both semantic and syntactic features, CAQE generates more informative and diverse query expansions, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 benchmark demonstrate the effectiveness of CAQE, particularly in scenarios with ambiguous or under-specified queries.

title: Designing Inclusive Augmented Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current AR interfaces often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel, inclusive AR framework that leverages haptic feedback, audio cues, and object recognition to provide an immersive experience for visually impaired users. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that our framework improved task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional AR interfaces. Our work contributes to the development of more accessible and inclusive AR systems that can benefit a broader range of users.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with BERT-based Query Expansion and Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) and pseudo-relevance feedback (PRF) are two widely used techniques for improving document retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach that integrates BERT-based QE with PRF to leverage the strengths of both methods. Our approach, termed BERT-QEPRF, uses BERT to generate context-aware query expansions, which are then utilized to select pseudo-relevant documents for feedback. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and TREC-2004 datasets demonstrate that BERT-QEPRF achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art QE and PRF methods, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem, particularly when agents have diverse capabilities and tasks have varying requirements. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for distributed task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. Our approach leverages a high-level task allocator that assigns tasks to agent groups, and a low-level allocator that distributes tasks within each group. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through simulations in a disaster response scenario, where agents with different capabilities work together to rescue people and deliver aid.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Cloud-based Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have become increasingly popular due to their scalability, flexibility, and cost-effectiveness. However, optimizing queries for multi-tenant DBaaS platforms poses significant challenges. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'QTune', which leverages machine learning-based workload characterization and dynamic resource allocation to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Our experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform show that QTune outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query performance and 2.2x in terms of system utilization.

title: ElasticRank: Scalable and Adaptive Learning to Rank for Dynamic Search Environments
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of modern search systems demands more efficient and adaptive learning-to-rank (LTR) models. This paper proposes ElasticRank, a novel LTR framework that leverages online learning and transfer learning to adapt to dynamic search environments. ElasticRank utilizes a hierarchical neural network architecture to model complex query-document relationships and incorporates a meta-learning component to rapidly adapt to changing user behavior and query distributions. Experimental results on a large-scale search engine dataset demonstrate that ElasticRank significantly outperforms state-of-the-art LTR methods in terms of ranking quality, computational efficiency, and adaptability to environmental changes.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often face the challenge of efficient task allocation, which is critical in real-world applications like warehouse management and autonomous delivery. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Contrastive Learning (HCL) framework that learns to represent tasks and agents in a shared latent space, enabling effective task allocation and transfer learning across agents. Our approach leverages a hierarchical architecture to capture both local and global relationships between tasks and agents, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in simulation experiments. We demonstrate the applicability of HCL in a real-world warehouse scenario, achieving a 25% reduction in task allocation time.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Reinforcement Learning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and system scalability. While traditional query optimizers rely on heuristics and rule-based approaches, we propose a novel reinforcement learning-based framework, 'RL-QOpt', that learns to optimize query plans in a distributed setting. RL-QOpt utilizes a deep Q-network to estimate the expected execution cost of query plans and adaptively searches for optimal plans. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system demonstrates that RL-QOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving up to 3x speedup on complex queries.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Enhanced Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using neural embeddings, which significantly improves the retrieval performance of search engines. Our method, called NeuroQE, leverages pre-trained language models to generate semantically rich query representations. These representations are then used to expand the original query, incorporating relevant terms and concepts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision and a 20% increase in recall.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatar Representation on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of human life, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatar representation on user involvement and experience in VR environments. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment involving 120 participants, who interacted with either a personalized or a generic avatar in a VR game. Our results show that users with personalized avatars reported higher levels of presence, enjoyment, and emotional arousal, and demonstrated improved performance in the game. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and potential applications in education, entertainment, and therapy.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines via Contrastive Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promise in improving search results, but often rely on cumbersome query expansion techniques. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'ConQE', which leverages contrastive representation learning to generate informative query expansions. By training a neural network to predict similar queries, we learn a dense representation space that captures semantic relationships between queries and documents. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that ConQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 12.5% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Query Document Matching in Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to efficiently match queries with relevant documents, particularly in large-scale collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document embedding (HDE) approach that captures multi-level semantic relationships between documents. Our method leverages a graph-based neural network to learn dense vector representations of documents, which are then organized into a hierarchical index for fast query-document matching. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Gov2 datasets demonstrate that HDE outperforms state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and query latency.

title: Heterogeneous Agent Coalition Formation for Disaster Response Management
paper_abstract: Effective disaster response management requires the coordination of multiple agents with diverse capabilities. This paper presents a novel approach to heterogeneous agent coalition formation, which enables the dynamic creation of task-oriented teams. Our method, called HACF, leverages a combination of machine learning and constraint-based optimization to identify optimal coalition structures. We evaluate HACF using simulations of wildfire response scenarios, demonstrating improved response times and resource allocation compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Adaptive Trust and Reputation Models
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust and reputation models play a crucial role in facilitating cooperation and preventing malicious behavior. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'AdaptTrust', which integrates adaptive trust and reputation models to improve the coordination of autonomous agents. Our approach leverages probabilistic graphical models to capture the uncertainty of agent interactions and adaptively updates trust values based on observed behavior. Experimental results demonstrate that AdaptTrust outperforms traditional trust models in dynamic environments, achieving higher cooperation rates and improved system resilience.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it helps to bridge the vocabulary gap between the user's query and the relevant documents. However, existing methods rely on manual feature engineering and often suffer from over-expansion. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'RL-QE', which learns to select the most informative expansion terms by interacting with a simulated environment. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Unsupervised Query Expansion using Hierarchical Document Representation for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel unsupervised query expansion approach that leverages hierarchical document representation to better model query-document relationships. Our method, called HiQE, represents documents as hierarchical graphs, which enables the capture of nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that HiQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving an average improvement of 15% in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Stores using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed column-stores have become increasingly popular for big data analytics, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'RL-QO', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for distributed column-stores. RL-QO uses a deep Q-network to learn a query optimization policy that adapts to the underlying data distribution and system configuration. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RL-QO outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Co-Designing Accessible Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant barriers when interacting with gesture-recognition systems. This paper presents a co-design approach to developing accessible gesture recognition systems, involving users with motor impairments throughout the design process. We propose a novel gesture recognition framework that leverages a combination of machine learning and computer vision techniques to adapt to the unique abilities and needs of each individual. Our user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments shows that our system achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming existing systems by 25%. We also provide design guidelines for inclusive gesture recognition systems, highlighting the importance of user-centered design in HCI.

title: DRAGON: A Distributed RDF Graph Query Optimization Framework for Scalable Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs have become a crucial component in various applications, including artificial intelligence, natural language processing, and data integration. However, querying large-scale knowledge graphs remains a significant challenge due to their massive size and complexity. This paper presents DRAGON, a distributed RDF graph query optimization framework that leverages a novel combination of graph partitioning, query rewriting, and parallel processing techniques. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that DRAGON achieves significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimization approaches, making it a promising solution for scalable knowledge graph querying.

title: Deep Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-based learning, where the goal is to predict the labels of nodes in a graph. Recently, graph attention networks (GATs) have shown promising results in this domain. However, existing GAT models suffer from two major limitations: they are shallow and lack hierarchical representations. In this paper, we propose a novel deep hierarchical graph attention network (DHGAT) that addresses these limitations. Our model uses a hierarchical architecture to capture node representations at multiple scales, and employs a novel attention mechanism that adapts to the graph structure. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DHGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification tasks.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems, leveraging hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to optimize task assignments and improve overall system efficiency. Our proposed method, dubbed 'HierAgent', employs a two-level hierarchy of agents, where high-level agents learn to allocate tasks to low-level agents based on their capabilities and availability. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierAgent through simulations of a disaster response scenario, showing significant improvements in task completion rates and resource utilization compared to baseline methods.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Edge Computing
paper_abstract: In edge computing, efficient resource allocation is crucial for reducing latency and improving quality of service. This paper proposes a decentralized agent-based framework, 'EdgeAgent', which leverages autonomous agents to dynamically allocate resources in edge networks. Our approach utilizes a novel reward function that incorporates both local and global optimization objectives, enabling agents to adapt to changing network conditions and user demands. Simulation results demonstrate that EdgeAgent outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of resource utilization and application performance.

title: Multi-Task Learning for Joint Intent Detection and Slot Filling in Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Conversational AI systems rely on accurate intent detection and slot filling to understand user requests. Existing approaches typically treat these tasks separately, leading to suboptimal performance. We propose a novel multi-task learning framework, ' JointIDSF', which jointly learns intent detection and slot filling using a shared encoder and task-specific decoders. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to model complex relationships between intent and slot labels. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets, ATIS and SNIPS, demonstrate that JointIDSF outperforms state-of-the-art models on both tasks, achieving a 5.2% absolute improvement in intent detection accuracy and a 3.5% increase in slot filling F1-score.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing techniques often rely on simplistic term weighting and language modeling. This paper proposes a neural approach, 'NDE-QE', which leverages document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms and documents. We employ a transformer-based architecture to generate contextualized embeddings, which are then used to expand the query with relevant terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that NDE-QE achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of MAP and NDCG@20.

title: Hierarchical Task Networks for Autonomous Agent Coordination in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments require efficient coordination mechanisms to achieve complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task network (HTN) framework for agent coordination, which integrates planning, execution, and monitoring capabilities. Our approach leverages a layered architecture, where high-level tasks are decomposed into lower-level subtasks, enabling agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our HTN framework in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional decentralized approaches.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Gesture Recognition on Cognitive Load in Virtual reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education, but the cognitive load imposed by VR interfaces can negatively impact learning outcomes. This study investigates the effect of gesture recognition on cognitive load in VR-based learning environments. We designed an experiment involving 30 participants who interacted with a VR-based educational simulation using either gesture recognition or traditional input methods. Our results show that gesture recognition significantly reduces cognitive load, improving user experience and learning retention. We also identify key design implications for VR-based educational systems.

title: Gaze-Based Intelligent Tutoring Systems for Enhanced Learning Experience
paper_abstract: Intelligent tutoring systems (ITSs) have shown promise in personalized education, but often neglect the role of human gaze in learning. This paper presents 'EyeGuide', a novel ITS that leverages gaze-tracking technology to infer students' cognitive states and adapt instructional content accordingly. Our system uses machine learning-based gaze pattern analysis to detect instances of confusion, boredom, or engagement, and responds with targeted interventions to improve learning outcomes. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates significant improvements in student understanding and satisfaction when using EyeGuide compared to traditional ITSs.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Co-Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory co-design approach to create an inclusive voice assistant tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with 15 older adults, resulting in 25 design recommendations that prioritize simplicity, flexibility, and multimodal interaction. We implemented these recommendations in a prototype voice assistant and evaluated its usability with 20 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion and user satisfaction. Our findings contribute to the development of more accessible and user-centered voice assistants for older adults.

title: Sparse Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies heavily on efficient passage retrieval from a large corpus. This paper proposes a novel sparse document representation method, 'SparsePass', which reduces the dimensionality of document embeddings while preserving their semantic meaning. We leverage a hierarchical clustering-based approach to identify and prune redundant dimensions, resulting in a 30% reduction in storage and a 25% speedup in passage retrieval time. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that SparsePass achieves comparable or better performance than state-of-the-art dense representations while significantly reducing computational resources.

title: Improving Explainability of Deep Neural Networks using Multimodal Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various computer vision tasks, but their lack of interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel multimodal attention mechanism that leverages visual and textual features to provide explainable predictions. Our approach, dubbed 'MMA-X', incorporates a hierarchical attention framework that selectively focuses on relevant input regions and attributes importance scores to input features. We evaluate MMA-X on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in model interpretability, while maintaining competitive performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning for Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) requires models to reason over multiple sentences and identify relevant information. While recent advances in transformer-based architectures have improved MHQA performance, they often lack transparency and interpretability. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based model, HARE, which incorporates explicit reasoning modules to generate explanations for its predictions. HARE uses a top-down attention mechanism to identify relevant sentences and a bottom-up attention mechanism to identify relevant entities, enabling the model to generate faithful explanations. Experimental results on the HotPotQA dataset demonstrate that HARE achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful explanations for its predictions.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordination among multiple agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HiMAT', which enables autonomous vehicles to learn decentralized policies for traffic signal control. HiMAT consists of two layers: a high-level layer that learns to allocate green light times to intersections, and a low-level layer that learns to control individual traffic signals. We evaluate HiMAT in a realistic simulation environment and show that it outperforms traditional signal control methods in terms of reducing congestion and travel time.

title: Exploring Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a crucial task in natural language processing, but it remains challenging when dealing with multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, and videos). This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture to efficiently integrate information from multiple modalities. Our approach leverages a weighted attention mechanism to adaptively focus on relevant modalities and features, reducing the computational overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hybrid Semantic Indexing for Efficient Retrieval of Short-Text Documents
paper_abstract: The proliferation of short-text documents on social media and online forums poses significant challenges for information retrieval systems. This paper presents a novel hybrid semantic indexing approach that combines the benefits of traditional keyword-based indexing with semantic embeddings. Our method leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to group semantically similar documents, allowing for efficient filtering and ranking of search results. Experimental evaluations on a large short-text dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and query processing time compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but current VR interfaces often fail to accommodate users with disabilities. This paper presents ' GestureFit', a novel adaptive gesture recognition system that enables individuals with motor impairments to interact with VR environments more effectively. We propose a machine learning-based approach that leverages multimodal sensor data and user feedback to dynamically adjust the gesture recognition model, ensuring a more inclusive and personalized VR experience. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for managing large-scale data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution and node heterogeneity. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DistroOpt', which leverages machine learning and graph theory to optimize query plans for DDS. We introduce a hierarchical clustering approach to group nodes based on their data distribution and a reinforcement learning-based query planning algorithm to minimize query latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DistroOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification on graph-structured data is a fundamental task in various domains. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown promising results, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand their decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to capture node representations. We demonstrate that HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while providing visualizable attention weights that reveal insightful patterns in the graph structure. Experimental results and ablation studies validate the effectiveness of HGAT for interpretable node classification.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents increasingly rely on sentiment analysis to provide personalized responses. However, existing approaches struggle to effectively process multimodal input (e.g., text, speech, and vision) and capture nuanced sentiment shifts. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates modality-specific attention mechanisms to learn joint representations of multimodal input. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the CMU-MOSI benchmark, outperforming previous multimodal fusion techniques by 12.5% in F1-score. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in real-world conversational agent applications, such as customer service chatbots.

title: Investigating the Effects of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, but the impact of haptic feedback on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive study examining the effects of haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We designed and conducted a user study with 40 participants, who performed a series of tasks in a VR environment with and without haptic feedback. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly enhances user engagement, reduces motion sickness, and improves task performance. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including the type of haptic device and the complexity of the task. The findings of this study have implications for the design of VR systems and applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Ranking for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short and ambiguous queries. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuQE', that leverages deep neural ranking models to estimate the relevance of expansion terms. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes the ranking loss and a regularization term encouraging diversity in the expanded query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Robust04 benchmarks demonstrate that NeuQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% relative improvement in mean average precision.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Orthogonal Gradient Alignment
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which pose significant security threats in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to analyze the robustness of DNNs against adversarial attacks using orthogonal gradient alignment. We develop a theoretical framework to quantify the alignment between the gradient of the loss function and the gradient of the adversarial perturbation, and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting and mitigating adversarial attacks. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art defense methods in terms of robustness and efficiency.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Recognition for Intelligent Wheelchair Navigation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gaze-based intention recognition approach for intelligent wheelchair navigation. Our system utilizes a deep learning-based gaze estimation model to infer the user's intended direction of travel. We introduce a adaptive calibration method that accommodates individual differences in gaze patterns and wheelchair control styles. Experimental results with 20 participants demonstrate that our approach achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5% and reduces navigation errors by 35% compared to traditional joystick-based control. The proposed system has the potential to enhance the mobility and independence of individuals with severe motor impairments.

title: Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) have emerged as a powerful tool for graph-structured data analysis. However, designing efficient GCN architectures remains a manual and time-consuming process. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) algorithm, GraphNAS, which leverages reinforcement learning to search for optimal GCN architectures. GraphNAS incorporates a novel graph-aware reward function and a dynamic pruning mechanism to reduce search space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphNAS discovers GCN architectures with improved computational efficiency and comparable accuracy to state-of-the-art manual designs.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Contextualized Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion, leveraging contextualized word embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms. Our model, CQE, integrates BERT-based embeddings with a graph-based ranking algorithm to select the most informative expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that CQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of MAP, P@10, and nDCG, while reducing the computational overhead associated with traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of distributed column-stores for real-time analytics, query optimization has become a critical bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'Columbo', that leverages machine learning-based cost modeling and adaptive indexing. Columbo dynamically adjusts the query plan based on column statistics, data distribution, and system workload, resulting in significant performance gains. We evaluate Columbo on a real-world financial dataset and demonstrate an average query speedup of 3.2x compared to state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents from a large corpus. We propose a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HNR, which leverages both semantic and syntactic features to rank passages. HNR consists of a sentence encoder, a passage encoder, and a hierarchical ranking module that jointly learns to optimize the ranking of passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that HNR outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% improvement in top-1 accuracy while reducing computation time by 30%

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization for column-store databases, which leverages a combination of data partitioning, index selection, and join ordering to minimize query latency. Our proposed algorithm, 'ColOpt', is shown to reduce query execution time by up to 50% compared to state-of-the-art optimizers in a real-world benchmark. We further demonstrate the applicability of ColOpt in a large-scale data warehousing environment, highlighting its potential for real-time analytics and decision-making.

title: Heterogeneous Agent-Based Simulation for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel heterogeneous agent-based simulation framework for urban traffic management. We propose a multi-agent system that integrates different types of agents, including autonomous vehicles, human-driven vehicles, and pedestrians, to simulate real-world traffic scenarios. Our framework incorporates advanced traffic signal control, lane changing, and route planning strategies to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. Experimental results on a realistic urban traffic network demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing travel time, increasing traffic throughput, and improving overall traffic safety.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Decentralized Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in resource allocation tasks. We propose a novel algorithm, 'MARL-RA', that enables agents to learn decentralized policies through self-organization and adaptation. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and resource dependencies, allowing agents to make autonomous decisions that maximize global utility. Experimental results on a realistic resource allocation scenario demonstrate that MARL-RA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of scalability, adaptability, and overall system efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Workloads using Reinforcement Learning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale datasets, but optimizing query workloads remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query scheduling in DDS. Our method, dubbed 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query scheduling policy based on runtime metrics, such as query latency and resource utilization. We evaluate RL-Optimizer on a realistic benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in query throughput and latency compared to traditional rule-based scheduling algorithms.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Elderly Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for adaptive gesture recognition systems tailored to elderly users with motor impairments. Our approach leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to recognize gestures from RGB-D sensor data. We introduce a personalized calibration phase that adaptively adjusts the recognition model to individual users' abilities, taking into account their motor limitations and gesture variability. Experimental results show that our system achieves higher recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that can significantly impact the overall system's performance. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'Dec-TAR', that leverages reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn effective task assignment strategies. Dec-TAR uses a graph neural network to model the agent's local environment and a multi-agent Q-network to learn the optimal task allocation policy. Experimental results on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that Dec-TAR outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods, achieving an average improvement of 25% in task completion rate and 30% in system utility.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Query Expansion for Improving Retrieval Efficiency in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search engines often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to incomplete or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based approach to query expansion, which adaptively selects expansion terms based on their predicted relevance to the original query. Our method, dubbed 'RL-QE', leverages a deep Q-network to learn the optimal expansion strategy for a given query, taking into account the trade-off between retrieval efficiency and precision. Experiments on the TREC 2004 Robust Track dataset demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision and retrieval time.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach for Efficient Document Ranking in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval (IR) often rely on hand-crafted features and heuristics, which may not generalize well to diverse query types and document collections. This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for document ranking, which learns to optimize ranking policies based on user interactions and relevance feedback. Our approach, 'DRL-Rank', utilizes a hierarchical neural network to model document representations and a policy gradient method to learn ranking strategies. Experimental results on benchmark IR datasets demonstrate that DRL-Rank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of precision and recall, while adapting to changing user preferences and query distributions.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to distributed task allocation using multi-agent reinforcement learning with graph attention. Our method, called GARL-TA, leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to efficiently allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. We evaluate GARL-TA on a set of benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion times and overall system efficiency compared to traditional methods. We also analyze the scalability of our approach and provide insights into the learned attention patterns.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments requires effective communication and cooperation strategies. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information and coordinate their actions. Our approach incorporates a multi-level attention mechanism that captures both local and global context, allowing agents to adapt to changing environments and optimize their joint performance. Experimental results in a simulated robotic soccer domain demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in improving team performance and providing insights into agent decision-making processes.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification in Large-Scale Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data analysis, but existing methods often struggle with scaling to large networks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) that leverages both local and global structural features to improve node classification accuracy. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights node representations at different scales, enabling the model to capture complex relationships between nodes. Experimental results on several large-scale benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art graph neural network models, achieving a significant improvement in node classification accuracy.

title: Query Performance Optimization for Distributed Indexing in Peer-to-Peer Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Peer-to-peer (P2P) information retrieval (IR) systems have gained popularity due to their scalability and fault tolerance. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel distributed indexing framework, 'PeerIndex', which leverages a hierarchical indexing strategy to minimize query latency. We introduce a load balancing mechanism that dynamically reassigns indexing tasks based on node availability and query workload. Experimental results on a large-scale P2P IR system demonstrate that PeerIndex reduces query response time by up to 40% compared to existing indexing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Road Traffic Prediction
paper_abstract: Road traffic prediction is a complex task that involves capturing intricate patterns in spatial and temporal data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that leverages both node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to model traffic dynamics. HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods on three benchmark datasets, achieving a 12.5% improvement in mean absolute error. Furthermore, we demonstrate the interpretability of HGAT through visualizations of attention weights, providing insights into the most influential roads and time intervals for traffic prediction.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Multi-Modal Fusion in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenging problem of multi-modal fusion in computer vision tasks, where the optimal combination of modalities and neural architectures is critical. We propose a novel neural architecture search (NAS) method, 'MMF-NAS', which leverages a hierarchical search space and a differentiable neural predictor to efficiently search for the best fusion strategy. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that MMF-NAS outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, while also providing interpretable insights into the importance of different modalities.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Learning-based Recommendation Systems: A Taxonomy and Defense Strategies
paper_abstract: Deep learning-based recommendation systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but they are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can manipulate user preferences and recommendations. This paper presents a comprehensive taxonomy of adversarial attacks on deep learning-based recommendation systems, including data poisoning, model poisoning, and query-based attacks. We also propose defense strategies based on anomaly detection, robust optimization, and transfer learning to mitigate these attacks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed defense strategies in improving the robustness of recommendation systems against adversarial attacks.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Enhancing Retrieval Performance in Healthcare Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Healthcare information retrieval (HIR) systems struggle to capture the nuances of medical queries, leading to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion (CAQE) framework that incorporates domain knowledge and user intent to improve retrieval accuracy. CAQE leverages a hybrid approach combining ontological and lexical semantic analysis to generate context-dependent query expansions. Experimental results on a large-scale medical dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving an average precision gain of 23.1% and a mean reciprocal rank improvement of 18.5%.

title: Scalable Data Partitioning for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems require efficient data partitioning to minimize data transfer and improve query performance. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach for scalable data partitioning, exploiting the underlying structure of the data. We introduce a hierarchical graph partitioning algorithm that adapts to the database schema and query patterns, achieving significant improvements in data locality and query response times. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing data transfer and improving system scalability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-based Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI has become a crucial aspect of recommender systems, as they need to provide transparent and trustworthy suggestions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) framework that leverages item relationships and user preferences to generate personalized explanations for recommendations. HGAN consists of a hierarchical graph encoder and a multi-hop attention mechanism, which allows the model to capture complex item relationships and identify influential items. Experimental results on four benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art explainable recommendation models in terms of accuracy, diversity, and explanation quality.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Trust in Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: As virtual assistants become increasingly pervasive, it is essential to understand the factors influencing user trust. This study investigates the role of embodiment in shaping trust in virtual assistants. We conducted a controlled experiment with 120 participants, comparing a humanoid robot, achatbot, and a voice-only assistant. Results show that users perceive the humanoid robot as more trustworthy and likable, while the chatbot is seen as more efficient. However, we found no significant difference in task performance across conditions. Our findings have implications for the design of virtual assistants and highlight the need for a more nuanced understanding of embodiment in HCI.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: With the rapid growth of big data, query optimization has become a critical component of data analytics pipelines. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics and rules-based approaches, which can be suboptimal and inflexible. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RL-QOpt', that leverages reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query plan from past query executions. We design a reward function that balances query performance, resource utilization, and data freshness, and demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques on a range of big data benchmarks.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the complexity of agent interactions and the need for adaptability to dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We introduce a hierarchical framework that combines a high-level task allocation module with low-level agent controllers, enabling agents to learn effective task assignments and execution strategies. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in achieving improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Column-Oriented In-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: In-memory column-oriented databases have gained popularity for their high performance in analytical workloads. However, query optimization remains a crucial challenge, particularly for complex queries involving joins and aggregations.
