This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages probabilistic modeling and machine learning to predict optimal query plans. ColOpt integrates a cost-based optimizer with a learned index structure, enabling efficient exploration of the query plan space. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 3.2x on complex queries.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve accessibility for individuals with disabilities, but existing gesture recognition systems often struggle to accommodate diverse abilities. This paper presents a novel, adaptive gesture recognition framework that leverages machine learning and user modeling to personalize recognition accuracy for individual users. Our approach incorporates a real-time feedback mechanism, enabling users to correct and refine system performance over time. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction for participants with varying abilities.

title: Efficient Explainability Methods for Deep Reinforcement Learning in High-Dimensional State Spaces
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but the lack of interpretability hinders trust and adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper introduces 'DeepLens', a novel model-agnostic explanation framework for DRL in high-dimensional state spaces. DeepLens leverages attention mechanisms and conditional mutual information to identify influential state features and quantify their contributions to policy decisions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepLens on multiple Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing improved transparency and performance in model-based exploration strategies.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Deep Semantic Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships in heterogeneous document collections. We propose a novel approach, 'DeepExp', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate context-aware query expansions. By incorporating a semantic relevance scorer and a hierarchical clustering algorithm, DeepExp significantly improves retrieval accuracy and reduces computational overhead. Experiments on a large-scale, multi-domain corpus demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in retrieving relevant documents with diverse semantic relationships.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the complexity of interactions between agents and the environment. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn coordination policies for task allocation. We introduce a hierarchical framework, 'MACTA', that uses a centralized critic to evaluate the global performance of the system and decentralized actors to learn task allocation policies. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm dataset demonstrate that MACTA outperforms traditional decentralized approaches and achieves near-optimal task allocation in complex scenarios.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'DMA', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to adapt to dynamic environments. We design a novel multi-agent Q-network that incorporates graph attention mechanisms to model agent interactions and task dependencies. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate that DMA outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Attention-based State Abstraction
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved impressive success in complex decision-making tasks, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes an attention-based state abstraction framework, 'AttnAbs', that provides explainability in RL by identifying relevant state features and their relationships. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that learns to focus on salient state variables and abstract away irrelevant ones, resulting in more transparent and efficient policy learning. Experimental results on a range of Atari games demonstrate that AttnAbs improves policy interpretability without sacrificing performance.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Human-Robot Collaboration in Manufacturing
paper_abstract: As manufacturing systems increasingly incorporate robots and human workers, real-time collaboration becomes essential. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Collab', that enables robots to adapt to dynamic human behaviors and optimize collaborative task execution. Our approach leverages a two-level hierarchy: a high-level policy selects collaboration strategies, while a low-level policy controls robot actions. We evaluate HRL-Collab in a simulated manufacturing environment and demonstrate improved task efficiency and worker satisfaction compared to traditional scripted robot control.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Dynamic Database Schemas
paper_abstract: Traditional query optimizers rely on static database schema assumptions, which can lead to suboptimal performance in modern dynamic databases. We propose an adaptive query optimization framework, 'DynaOpt', which leverages machine learning to predict schema changes and adjust query plans accordingly. DynaOpt integrates a schema change detector, a query plan reoptimizer, and a cost-based optimizer to minimize query latency and resource utilization. Experimental evaluation on a real-world dynamic database benchmark demonstrates that DynaOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and 2x in terms of resource efficiency.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents in complex environments often face challenges in task allocation due to incomplete information and uncertainty. This paper proposes a distributed task allocation framework, 'POMDP-TA', that leverages partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) to reason about agent beliefs and preferences. We develop a scalable algorithm that integrates POMDP planning with distributed constraint optimization to allocate tasks efficiently. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate that POMDP-TA outperforms existing decentralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and agent satisfaction.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve complex tasks is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper introduces a novel framework based on hierarchical task networks (HTNs) to coordinate agents in dynamic environments. Our approach represents tasks as hierarchical graphs, enabling agents to reason about task dependencies and allocate resources efficiently. We develop a distributed planning algorithm that leverages HTNs to generate coordinated plans, and demonstrate its effectiveness in a simulated disaster response scenario. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: A Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: While neural ranking models have significantly improved the accuracy of document retrieval systems, their computational complexity remains a major bottleneck. This paper proposes a hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HiRank', which leverages a novel tree-based architecture to reduce the number of document comparisons required during retrieval. Our experiments on several large-scale datasets demonstrate that HiRank achieves comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art models while reducing inference time by up to 60%. Furthermore, we show that HiRank can be easily integrated into existing retrieval systems, making it a practical solution for real-world applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have revolutionized human-computer interaction, but their design often neglects the needs of elderly users with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants that cater to this demographic. We conducted a series of interviews and usability studies to identify key challenges and preferences of elderly users. Our findings informed the development of 'ElderVoice', a novel voice assistant that incorporates adaptive dialogue management, personalized feedback, and multimodal interaction. Evaluation results show that ElderVoice significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction for elderly users with cognitive impairments.

title: Reinforced Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Heterogeneous information networks (HINs) have become increasingly prevalent in modern information retrieval systems. However, the complexity of HINs poses significant challenges for effective document retrieval. This paper introduces a novel reinforced query expansion approach, RQE-HIN, which leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select expansion terms based on the heterogeneous relationships between entities in the network. Experimental results on a large-scale HIN dataset demonstrate that RQE-HIN outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular in modern data-intensive applications. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning (ML) to optimize query execution plans in DDS. We develop a ML-based query optimizer, 'QOpt', which learns from historical query patterns and adapts to changing workload characteristics. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that QOpt outperforms traditional rule-based optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical attention networks for Explainable AI in Medical Imaging
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved remarkable success in medical image analysis, but their black-box nature limits their adoption in clinical settings. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that provides explainable AI capabilities for medical imaging tasks. HAN adaptively selects relevant regions of interest and highlights critical features, enabling clinicians to understand the decision-making process. We evaluate HAN on a large-scale dataset of MRI scans and demonstrate improved performance, interpretability, and robustness compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Designing Accessible Touchless Gestures for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible interfaces for older adults with motor impairments is crucial. This paper presents a novel approach to touchless gesture recognition, tailored to the needs of older adults with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning-based framework that leverages depth sensors and computer vision to detect and recognize gestures, eliminating the need for precise finger movements. Our user study with 20 older adults with motor impairments shows that our approach achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming existing touch-based interfaces. We also provide design guidelines for creating accessible touchless gestures, highlighting the importance of speed, amplitude, and movement trajectory.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Specialized Search Engines
paper_abstract: Specialized search engines, such as those for scholarly articles or e-commerce products, require efficient retrieval mechanisms to handle complex queries. This paper presents a novel deep learning approach, 'DQE', which leverages query expansion techniques to improve retrieval precision. DQE employs a transformer-based architecture to learn semantic relationships between query terms and expand the query with relevant keywords. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of academic papers demonstrate that DQE outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models in terms of mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Term Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) that aims to refine the original query to better capture user intent. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to term embeddings, dubbed 'TermGraph', which leverages the semantic relationships between terms to improve query expansion. We represent the vocabulary as a graph, where terms are nodes and edges capture co-occurrence, synonymy, and hyponymy relationships. During query expansion, we perform a random walk on this graph to generate a set of expanded terms that are semantically related to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TermGraph outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, leading to significant improvements in retrieval accuracy.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Individuals with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of individuals with dyslexia. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing accessible conversational interfaces tailored to individuals with dyslexia. We conducted a mixed-methods study, involving interviews, surveys, and usability testing with 25 participants, to identify key challenges and preferences. Our findings inform the development of a set of guidelines and a prototype system that incorporates adaptive text-to-speech, phonetic-based error correction, and personalized feedback mechanisms. Results show significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Designing Intelligent Assistive Systems for Users with Dyslexia: A Multimodal Approach
paper_abstract: Individuals with dyslexia often face challenges in reading and writing, which can negatively impact their daily lives. This paper presents a novel multimodal assistive system, 'DysRead', that leverages computer vision, natural language processing, and machine learning to provide personalized support for users with dyslexia. DysRead incorporates a real-time text recognition module, a grammar and spell checker, and a reading assistant that adapts to the user's reading speed and accuracy. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that DysRead significantly improved their reading comprehension and writing accuracy compared to traditional assistive tools.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This study explores the role of embodiment in virtual reality (VR) on users' sense of social presence. We conducted a within-subjects experiment, where participants interacted with a virtual avatar in a collaborative task, either with a fully tracked body or a simplified, non-tracked representation. Our results show that full-body tracking significantly enhances social presence, particularly in terms of perceived co-presence and mutual understanding. Furthermore, we found that the effects of embodiment on social presence are mediated by the user's sense of agency and self-presence in the virtual environment. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to facilitate social interaction and collaboration.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Entity-Disambiguated Search Queries
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a critical step in search query understanding, as it resolves ambiguity in user queries and improves retrieval effectiveness. This paper presents a hybrid retrieval model, 'Hydra', that integrates entity disambiguation into the retrieval process. Hydra combines a knowledge graph-based entity disambiguator with a neural ranking model, enabling the model to capture both semantic and contextual relationships between entities. Experimental results on a large-scale search query dataset demonstrate that Hydra outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a 12.5% improvement in NDCG@10 and a 9.2% improvement in ERR@10.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Interaction for Improving Accessibility in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current interactions often rely on manual inputs, which can be limiting for users with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel gaze-based adaptive interaction system, 'GAZE+', that leverages eye-tracking data to enable more intuitive and accessible interactions in VR environments. Our approach incorporates machine learning-based gaze prediction and adaptive difficulty adjustment, allowing users to seamlessly navigate and interact with virtual objects. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional manual input methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) models have achieved state-of-the-art performance on various benchmarks, but their interpretability remains a major challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for MHQA, which recursively applies attention mechanisms to capture complex reasoning patterns. Our approach leverages a graph-based reasoning framework to identify relevant entities and relationships, and incorporates an explainability module to generate faithful explanations for the predicted answers. Experimental results on the HotPotQA and WikiHop datasets demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms existing MHQA models while providing insightful explanations for its predictions.

title: Efficient Context-Aware Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which leverages both semantic and syntactic features to disambiguate user queries. We develop a graph-based attention mechanism that captures the relationships between query terms, entities, and context words, allowing the model to selectively expand the query with relevant terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural search engines, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on IoT Sensor Data Streams
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosive growth in sensor data, posing significant challenges for real-time analytics. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'SIFT', which leverages a combination of in-memory caching, hierarchical clustering, and probabilistic filtering to enable fast and efficient querying of IoT sensor data streams. We demonstrate SIFT's scalability and performance through experiments on a large-scale industrial IoT dataset, achieving query response times of under 10ms for complex aggregations and joins.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using auctions and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities must coordinate to accomplish tasks efficiently. This paper presents a novel approach that combines auctions and reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in a decentralized manner. Our method, called Auction-RL, uses a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auction mechanism to allocate tasks to agents based on their bids, and employs reinforcement learning to adapt the bidding strategy to the dynamic environment. We evaluate Auction-RL in a simulated robotics scenario and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving task completion rates and reducing coordination overhead compared to existing decentralized task allocation methods.

title: Efficient Document Re-ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial task in information retrieval (IR), which involves retrieving relevant passages from a large document collection given a query. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'PassRank', for document re-ranking in passage retrieval. PassRank leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to model the interactions between query, passage, and document contexts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that PassRank outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, particularly when dealing with long documents and complex queries.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective coordination is crucial for achieving complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework for learning coordination strategies in decentralized environments. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model agent interactions and hierarchical structures to capture long-range dependencies. We evaluate HGAT on a range of benchmarks, including traffic signal control and robotic swarm navigation, and demonstrate significant improvements in coordination efficiency and task performance compared to existing methods.

title: Attention-Based Explainable Reasoning for Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) models have achieved impressive performance, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. We propose a novel attention-based framework, 'ExplainVQA', which generates explanations for its reasoning process. Our approach leverages a multi-modal attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant image regions and question words, enabling the model to provide interpretable answers. Experimental results on VQA 2.0 demonstrate that ExplainVQA achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful explanations for its predictions.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Contrastive Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved impressive successes in complex tasks, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'GraphXRL', which integrates contrastive graph embeddings with RL to provide explainable decision-making. By learning a graph representation of the state-action space, our approach can identify influential factors and relationships that contribute to the RL agent's policy. We demonstrate GraphXRL's effectiveness on a variety of Atari games and a real-world autonomous driving scenario, showcasing improved transparency and trustworthiness of the RL system.

title: Deep Neural Models for Efficient Query Expansion in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it aims to capture the underlying user intent behind a query. Traditional query expansion methods rely on hand-crafted rules or term co-occurrence analysis, which can be limited by their simplicity and lack of adaptability. This paper proposes a novel deep neural model, 'QNLP', which leverages the power of semantic embeddings and contextualized language representations to learn effective query expansion strategies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QNLP consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly for ambiguous and multi-faceted queries.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Hierarchical Graph Decomposition
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding is a fundamental problem in various domains, including robotics, video games, and autonomous vehicles. Existing solutions often suffer from high computational complexity, making them impractical for large-scale scenarios. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph decomposition approach, 'HGD-MA', which enables efficient and scalable multi-agent pathfinding. By recursively decomposing the graph into smaller subgraphs, HGD-MA reduces the problem size and exploits the structure of the graph to minimize conflicts between agents. Experimental results on various benchmarks demonstrate that HGD-MA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of computation time and solution quality.

title: EyeTribe: A Gaze-Based Interface for Enhancing Children's Reading Comprehension
paper_abstract: This paper presents EyeTribe, a novel gaze-based interface designed to improve reading comprehension in children. Our approach leverages eye-tracking technology to identify areas of difficulty in real-time, providing personalized feedback and guidance to young readers. We conducted a user study with 30 children aged 8-10 and found that EyeTribe significantly enhances reading comprehension scores compared to traditional reading methods. Furthermore, our interface was rated highly in terms of user experience and engagement. We discuss the implications of our findings for the development of assistive technologies in education.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Learning Models using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their hyperparameters require careful tuning for optimal results. Bayesian optimization has emerged as a promising approach for hyperparameter tuning, but its computational cost can be prohibitive for large models and datasets. This paper presents a novel Bayesian optimization algorithm, 'HyperBO', which leverages a combination of Gaussian processes and random forest surrogates to efficiently explore the hyperparameter space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HyperBO on several benchmarks, achieving significant speedups over existing methods while maintaining competitive model performance.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Models
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for scalable query optimization, which leverages the structural properties of query plans to identify optimal execution strategies. We introduce a graph neural network-based model that learns to predict query execution costs and generates optimized plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and improves system throughput by up to 2x.

title: Emotion-aware Adaptive Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information, but existing interfaces often fail to account for users' emotional states. This paper presents 'EmoVR', an emotion-aware adaptive interface that leverages real-time physiological signals and machine learning to personalize the VR experience. Our approach incorporates a novel affective modeling framework that detects and responds to users' emotional shifts, dynamically adjusting the interface to optimize engagement, comfort, and overall user satisfaction. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in user experience and emotional well-being using EmoVR compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic control systems rely on reinforcement learning (RL) agents to optimize traffic flow. However, the lack of transparency in RL decision-making hinders widespread adoption. We propose 'MARL-Explain', a novel multi-agent RL framework that incorporates explainability techniques to provide insights into agent decision-making. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms and saliency maps to visualize the contribution of each agent to the global reward function. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate improved interpretability and a 15% reduction in travel time compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous navigation in dynamic environments requires agents to adapt to changing circumstances while making decisions in real-time. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-NAV', which leverages a novel decomposition of the navigation task into high-level planning and low-level control. The high-level planner utilizes a graph-based representation to reason about the environment, while the low-level controller employs a deep Q-network to execute actions. We evaluate HRL-NAV on a simulated driving scenario and demonstrate improved navigation performance and adaptability compared to flat reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Coordination for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent system for real-time resource allocation in smart grids. Our approach, called 'MA-RA', uses a decentralized coordination mechanism to optimize energy distribution and reduce power losses. MA-RA leverages a hierarchical architecture, where local agents negotiate with neighboring agents to allocate resources, and a global agent facilitates system-wide optimization. We demonstrate the scalability and efficacy of MA-RA through simulations on a large-scale smart grid testbed, showcasing significant improvements in response time and energy efficiency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Data Poisoning Attacks in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to data poisoning attacks, where an adversary manipulates the training data to compromise the model's performance. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'PoisonGuard', which proactively defends against data poisoning attacks by perturbing the training data in a way that simulates potential attacks. We demonstrate that PoisonGuard improves the robustness of deep neural networks against various data poisoning scenarios, including label flipping and backdoor attacks. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets show that PoisonGuard achieves state-of-the-art performance in detecting and mitigating data poisoning attacks, while maintaining the model's accuracy on clean data.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Virtual Reality Head-Mounted Displays
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) head-mounted displays (HMDs) have become increasingly popular, but their security remains a major concern. This paper presents a novel gaze-based authentication system, 'GazeSecure', designed specifically for VR HMDs. GazeSecure leverages the high-resolution eye-tracking capabilities of modern VR HMDs to authenticate users based on their unique gaze patterns. Our approach uses a combination of machine learning algorithms and computer vision techniques to analyze the user's gaze behavior and verify their identity. Experimental results show that GazeSecure achieves an accuracy of 97.5% and a false acceptance rate of 0.5%, outperforming existing authentication methods for VR HMDs.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize therapy, education, and entertainment for individuals with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR interfaces often exacerbate cognitive load, leading to user frustration and abandonment. This paper presents 'CogVR', a novel VR interface design framework that incorporates evidence-based cognitive support strategies, such as simplified navigation, error forgiveness, and visual cueing. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with cognitive impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates, user satisfaction, and cognitive workload reduction. Our findings inform the development of more inclusive and accessible VR experiences.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents via Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, dynamic task allocation is crucial for efficient resource utilization and adaptability to changing environments. We propose a reinforcement learning framework, 'HARA', that enables heterogeneous agents to coordinate and optimize task allocation in real-time. HARA leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to balance exploration and exploitation of tasks based on its capabilities and environmental feedback. We evaluate HARA on a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced coordination overhead compared to traditional planning-based approaches.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the factors that influence user engagement is crucial. This study investigates the effect of haptic feedback on user experience in VR interfaces. We designed a controlled experiment wherein participants performed a series of tasks with and without haptic feedback. Our results show that the inclusion of haptic feedback significantly enhances user engagement, as measured by both subjective self-reporting and objective metrics such as task completion time and accuracy. We also explore the role of individual differences in haptic perception and discuss implications for the design of VR systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Learned Indexes
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in DDS due to the complexity of data distribution and partitioning. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using learned indexes, which leverages machine learning models to predict the optimal query execution plan. We introduce a hybrid indexing scheme that combines traditional B-tree indexes with learned indexes, allowing for efficient query optimization in DDS. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Context-Aware Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) to enhance the retrieval performance. Existing methods, however, often rely on simplistic word representations, neglecting the contextual nuances of query terms. We propose a novel approach, 'ContextEmb', which leverages context-aware word embeddings to better capture the semantic relationships between query words. By incorporating contextualized embeddings into a probabilistic retrieval framework, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness on several benchmark datasets. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, especially in scenarios with ambiguous or polysemous query terms.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, coordinating individual agents to achieve global optimality is a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize resource allocation in decentralized systems. We introduce a hierarchical architecture consisting of a global coordinator and local agents, where each agent learns to adapt its behavior based on the coordinator's guidance. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach significantly improves resource utilization and reduces overall system cost, outperforming traditional heuristic-based methods in various scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Skeleton-based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained popularity due to its applications in human-computer interaction and healthcare. However, existing methods struggle to capture complex relationships between body joints. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which leverages multi-scale graph attention mechanisms to model joint dependencies at different levels of abstraction. Our experiments on the NTU-RGB+D and Kinetics datasets demonstrate that HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming existing graph-based and CNN-based methods. We further analyze the attention weights to provide insights into the importance of different body joints for action recognition.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time Series Anomaly Detection in IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT sensors has generated vast amounts of time series data, making anomaly detection a critical task. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for identifying anomalies in IoT sensor data. Our approach leverages multi-scale temporal dependencies and feature importance via a hierarchical attention mechanism. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and F1-score, while reducing computational overhead. We also provide insights into the interpretability of HAN's attention weights, enabling the identification of anomalous patterns and features.

title: Gaze-Based Typing Errors Correction using Deep Learning for Assistive Technologies
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often rely on gaze-based typing systems, which can be prone to errors. This paper presents a novel deep learning approach, 'GazeCorrect', to correct typing errors in real-time using gaze data. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly predicts the intended character and the error type. Our model leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to capture the spatial and temporal patterns in gaze data. Experiments on a large-scale gaze dataset demonstrate that GazeCorrect outperforms state-of-the-art correction methods, reducing error rates by up to 30% and improving overall typing efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Conversational Repair Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in many households, but their effectiveness is often hindered by communication breakdowns, particularly for older adults. This paper investigates the role of conversational repair strategies in improving the usability and accessibility of voice assistants for this demographic. Through a mixed-methods approach, we identify common error scenarios and develop a taxonomy of repair strategies. Our findings inform the design of a novel voice assistant interface that incorporates proactive and reactive repair mechanisms, reducing errors and improving user satisfaction in a pilot study with older adults.

title: Graph-Based Indexing for Efficient Query Optimization in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As distributed databases continue to grow in scale and complexity, query optimization becomes an increasingly important challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GIDX', which leverages graph theory to efficiently identify optimal query plans. By modeling the database as a graph and applying graph-based algorithms, GIDX reduces the search space for query optimization, resulting in significant performance improvements. Experiments on a real-world distributed database show that GIDX outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Heterogeneous information networks (HINs) often contain complex relationships between nodes of different types. Node classification in HINs is a challenging task due to the varying importance of different node types and relationships. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant nodes and relationships when classifying target nodes. HGAT consists of multiple attention layers that capture node- and relation-level attention, enabling the model to adapt to the heterogeneous structure of the network. Experiments on several benchmark HIN datasets demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods for node classification tasks.

title: Eye-Gaze Driven Adaptive Interaction for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with disabilities. However, current VR systems often rely on manual input methods, which can be challenging or impossible for users with mobility impairments. This paper presents 'EyeQuest', an eye-gaze driven adaptive interaction framework for VR. EyeQuest utilizes machine learning-based gaze estimation and adaptive difficulty adjustment to enable seamless interaction with virtual objects. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has led to a surge in demand for efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for adaptive resource allocation in IoT networks. Our approach leverages a novel graph neural network architecture to learn a distributed policy that allocates resources based on real-time network conditions. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through extensive simulations, showing significant improvements in network throughput and latency compared to centralized optimization methods.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Autonomous Agents in Multi-Stakeholder Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for autonomous agents to negotiate with multiple stakeholders in complex, dynamic environments. Our approach, called Adaptive Negotiation Strategy (ANS), leverages machine learning to adapt the negotiation strategy based on the stakeholder's preferences, power dynamics, and environmental factors. We evaluate ANS in a simulated supply chain management scenario, demonstrating improved negotiation outcomes and increased robustness to changes in stakeholder behavior compared to traditional, rule-based negotiation approaches.

title: Optimizing Query Workloads using Deep Reinforcement Learning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDBS) are crucial for large-scale data processing, but optimizing query workloads remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query execution plans in DDBS. We design a DRL agent that learns to select the optimal query plan based on the database state, query workload, and system resources. Our experiments on a real-world DDBS show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Proximal Hashing with Neural Codes for Efficient Image Retrieval
paper_abstract: Image retrieval has become a fundamental task in computer vision, but existing methods suffer from high computational costs and memory requirements. This paper introduces a novel approach, Proximal Hashing with Neural Codes (PHNC), which leverages the strengths of hashing and neural networks to achieve efficient and accurate image retrieval. PHNC uses a proximal optimization algorithm to learn compact binary codes that preserve semantic information, and a neural network to refine the hashing process. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that PHNC outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and query speed.

title: Efficient Dialogue State Tracking with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a critical component of conversational AI systems, requiring accurate identification of user goals and preferences. We propose a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that leverages the graphical structure of dialogue flows to improve DST performance. HGAT employs a novel hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant dialogue context and entities, reducing computational complexity and improving robustness to noisy user inputs. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ benchmark demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art DST models in terms of joint goal accuracy and scalability.

title: Investigating Embodiment and Gesture-Based Interaction in Virtual Reality for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but designing intuitive and immersive interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the role of embodiment and gesture-based interaction in VR, examining how users' sense of bodily presence and agency affects their experience. We present a study comparing three VR interaction modalities: controller-based, gesture-based, and hybrid. Our results show that gesture-based interaction enhances user engagement, reduces cognitive load, and increases feelings of presence, but also introduces challenges related to gesture recognition and feedback. We discuss implications for VR interface design and future research directions.

title: Adaptive Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents with varying capabilities. This paper proposes a novel approach to adaptive task allocation using reinforcement learning. Our method, called MARL-TA, leverages the strengths of deep Q-networks to learn an optimal task allocation policy that adapts to changing agent capabilities and task requirements. We evaluate MARL-TA on a simulated logistics scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in overall system performance and robustness compared to existing heuristics. Furthermore, we provide insights into the learned policy and discuss its applicability to real-world scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search engines rely on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. However, traditional methods often suffer from high computational overhead and limited semantic understanding. This paper proposes 'NeuroXpand', a novel query expansion framework that leverages neural embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and documents. Our approach combines a neural encoder with a graph-based clustering algorithm to generate a compact set of expansion terms, reducing the dimensionality of the query space. Experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and query throughput compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Enhancing Query Suggestion with Session-based Temporal Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query suggestion is a crucial component of modern search engines, as it helps users formulate effective queries. Traditional approaches rely on static query logs, ignoring the temporal dynamics of user behavior. We propose a novel framework, TemporalGraphSuggest, which leverages session-based temporal graph embeddings to model the evolving query intent. Our approach captures short-term and long-term dependencies in user search sessions, enabling more accurate and personalized query suggestions. Experimental results on a large-scale query log dataset demonstrate significant improvements in suggestion quality and user engagement over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Investigation of Cognitive Load and User Experience
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of users with cognitive or motor impairments. This study explores the impact of cognitive load on user experience with voice assistants, particularly for individuals with disabilities. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, using a custom-built voice assistant platform. Our results show that users with higher cognitive load exhibit decreased accuracy and increased frustration when interacting with voice assistants. We propose a set of design guidelines and recommendations for developing more inclusive voice assistants, incorporating features such as adaptive prompt timing and personalized feedback.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Human-Computer Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding how users interact with virtual environments is crucial. This study explores the role of embodied cognition in shaping human-computer interaction (HCI) in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform to investigate how bodily experiences influence spatial awareness, object manipulation, and cognitive load. Our results show that embodied cognition significantly affects HCI in VR, with users exhibiting improved performance and reduced cognitive load when their virtual body is congruent with their physical body. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and future research directions.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control with Uncertainty Awareness
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to navigate complex scenarios. However, existing RL methods often neglect uncertainty in sensor readings and environment dynamics, leading to suboptimal or unsafe decisions. This paper presents Hierarchical Uncertainty-Aware Reinforcement Learning (HUAL), which integrates probabilistic modeling and hierarchical RL to address uncertainty in autonomous vehicle control. We demonstrate HUAL's efficacy in simulated urban driving scenarios, showcasing improved safety and adaptability in the face of sensor noise and uncertain environment dynamics.

title: EmoTract: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Framework for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents EmoTract, a novel multimodal framework that leverages computer vision, speech recognition, and electroencephalography (EEG) to recognize emotions in real-time. EmoTract integrates a deep learning-based facial expression recognition module, a convolutional neural network (CNN) for speech emotion classification, and an EEG-based affective state detection module. Our experiments on a diverse dataset of 100 participants demonstrate that EmoTract outperforms state-of-the-art unimodal approaches, achieving an average emotion recognition accuracy of 87.5%. We envision EmoTract as a key component in developing more empathetic and responsive HCI systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Molecular Property Prediction
paper_abstract: Accurate prediction of molecular properties is crucial in chemical compound design and discovery. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have emerged as a powerful tool for molecular representation learning. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, 'HierGAT', which leverages both local and global structural information in molecules. By incorporating attention mechanisms at multiple scales, HierGAT effectively captures complex molecular interactions and significantly improves property prediction performance. Experiments on a benchmark dataset demonstrate the superiority of HierGAT over existing state-of-the-art models in predicting molecular solubility, logP, and toxicity.

title: Context-Aware Document Expansion for Improved Retrieval in Sparse Domains
paper_abstract: Document expansion techniques have been shown to improve retrieval performance in sparse domains. However, most approaches rely on generic term weighting schemes, neglecting the semantic context in which queries are issued. This paper proposes a novel context-aware document expansion framework, 'CADE', which leverages entity disambiguation and semantic role labeling to incorporate contextual information into the expansion process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CADE outperforms state-of-the-art document expansion methods, especially in scenarios where query context is crucial for disambiguating ambiguous keywords.

title: Autonomous Agent Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created a need for efficient resource allocation mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel autonomous agent-based negotiation framework for multi-resource allocation in IoT networks. We design a decentralized, multi-issue negotiation protocol that enables agents to negotiate over multiple resources simultaneously, while considering the dynamic constraints and preferences of each agent. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of allocation efficiency, fairness, and robustness to changes in the network.

title: Designing Emotional Intelligence in Conversational Agents for Healthcare
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have emerged as a promising tool in healthcare, but their lack of emotional intelligence can lead to patient dissatisfaction and decreased trust. This paper presents a novel framework for designing emotionally intelligent conversational agents that can recognize and respond to users' emotions in a healthcare context. We propose a multimodal approach that combines natural language processing, computer vision, and affective computing to detect emotional cues. A user study with 100 participants demonstrates that our approach significantly improves user experience and perceived empathy in healthcare conversations.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-Scale Time-Series Data using Neural Embeddings
paper_abstract: Time-series data clustering is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, traditional clustering algorithms struggle with large-scale datasets and correlated time-series features. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering framework, 'NeuroClust', which leverages neural embeddings to capture complex patterns in time-series data. We introduce a multi-resolution clustering approach that iteratively refines cluster assignments using learned representations from a self-supervised neural network. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroClust outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, using a mixed-methods approach to analyze both quantitative and qualitative data. Our results show that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, improved sense of presence, and reduced cybersickness. We also identify key factors influencing avatar personalization, including facial similarity, body shape, and clothing style.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Large-Scale Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between massive amounts of data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge, particularly in distributed environments. This paper presents 'GraphOpt', a novel distributed query optimization framework designed for large-scale graph databases. GraphOpt leverages graph partitioning, parallel query execution, and adaptive join ordering to minimize query latency and reduce resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Scalable Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, this problem becomes increasingly complex when dealing with heterogeneous agents having varying capabilities and constraints. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'AgentDRL', which learns to allocate tasks optimally in such systems. By incorporating graph neural networks to model agent relationships and a hierarchical DRL architecture to handle task dependencies, AgentDRL achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and reduces overall system latency. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm scenario demonstrate the scalability and adaptability of our approach in dynamic environments.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms require efficient resource allocation to minimize costs and ensure quality of service. This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach to optimize resource allocation in real-time, considering dynamic workload patterns and available resources. Our proposed framework, 'CloudOpt', utilizes a novel combination of deep Q-networks and actor-critic methods to learn a policy that adapts to changing system conditions. Experimental results on a large-scale cloud simulation platform demonstrate that CloudOpt outperforms state-of-the-art heuristic-based approaches, achieving up to 25% reduction in resource wastage and 15% improvement in response time.

title: Efficient Data Partitioning for Distributed Query Optimization in Cloud-Based Database Systems
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of cloud-based database systems, distributed query optimization has become a critical challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to data partitioning, 'PartiQL', which leverages machine learning-based clustering techniques to identify optimal data splits. PartiQL is designed to minimize data transfer and reduce query latency in distributed query execution. We evaluate PartiQL on a real-world cloud-based database system and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to existing partitioning schemes.

title: Efective Visualization of Multimodal Interaction Data for Enhanced Collaborative Analysis
paper_abstract: As multimodal interaction data becomes increasingly prevalent, effective visualization techniques are crucial for facilitating collaborative analysis. This paper presents 'MIVIS', a novel visualization framework designed to integrate and represent multiple modalities of interaction data, including speech, gesture, and gaze. MIVIS employs a hybrid approach, combining both summary-based and detail-on-demand visualization techniques to support diverse analytical tasks. We evaluate MIVIS through a user study, demonstrating its ability to enhance collaborative analysis and decision-making in multimodal interaction data.

title: Reinforcing Query Expansion with Deep Learning for E-commerce Product Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce product search often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval accuracy. However, existing methods typically employ rule-based or probabilistic approaches, which may not capture complex semantic relationships between queries and products. This paper proposes a deep learning-based query expansion framework, 'DeepQE', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn query and product embeddings. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that selectively incorporates relevant product attributes into the expansion process. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that DeepQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision.

title: Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Retrieval-based Question Answering
paper_abstract: Retrieval-based question answering systems rely on effective query representation to retrieve relevant passages. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method using hierarchical graph attention networks (HGAT). Our approach models the query as a graph, where nodes represent terms and edges capture semantic relationships. HGAT learns to attend to relevant terms and their relationships, generating a expanded query that better captures the question's intent. Experiments on the SQuAD and HotPotQA datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval recall and end-to-end question answering accuracy.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion through Neural Entity Disambiguation for Semantic Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of semantic search systems, but existing methods often struggle with ambiguity in natural language queries. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages neural entity disambiguation to selectively expand query terms. We introduce a graph-based neural model that jointly learns entity representations and disambiguation, and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show significant gains over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for queries with ambiguous terms.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems require effective decision-making strategies that balance individual goals with collective outcomes. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (H-GAT) architecture for explainable multi-agent decision-making. H-GAT combines graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical clustering to identify influential agents and their interactions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of H-GAT in a variety of cooperative and competitive scenarios, showcasing improved decision-making outcomes while providing interpretable insights into agent interactions. Our approach has implications for real-world applications such as autonomous vehicle coordination, smart grids, and disaster response.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in education, but its effectiveness can be hindered by a one-size-fits-all approach. This study explores the role of personalization in VR learning environments, focusing on user engagement and learning outcomes. We designed a VR-based educational platform that incorporates user modeling, adaptive difficulty adjustment, and real-time feedback. Our user study with 120 participants reveals that personalized VR experiences lead to significant increases in engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to non-personalized counterparts. We discuss implications for VR-based education and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Graph Neural Network Training
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based applications. However, their training process is often computationally expensive and memory-intensive, limiting their scalability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) framework that accelerates GNN training by selectively aggregating node features at multiple scales. Our approach reduces the computational complexity of GNN training while maintaining its expressive power. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN achieves significant speedups over traditional GNN training methods, making it a promising solution for large-scale graph learning tasks.

title: A Hierarchical Query Expansion Approach for Improving Retrieval Efficiency in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: With the increasing scale of distributed search engines, query expansion techniques play a crucial role in improving retrieval efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HiQE', which leverages both semantic and syntactic features to generate informative and diversified expansion terms. HiQE employs a two-stage framework, where the first stage uses word embeddings to identify semantically similar terms, and the second stage utilizes a syntax-based ranking model to prioritize expansion terms that are more likely to occur in relevant documents. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed search engine dataset demonstrate that HiQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and precision.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) systems require intuitive and efficient user interfaces. We propose a novel gaze-based interaction method that leverages deep reinforcement learning to predict user intent from eye movement data. Our approach employs a hierarchical policy framework, combining a high-level goal-directed policy with a low-level motor control policy. The system is trained using a large-scale dataset of human gaze patterns and AR interactions. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional manual input methods, paving the way for more immersive and accessible AR experiences.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-time Aggregations in Column Stores
paper_abstract: Column stores have become increasingly popular for analytical workloads due to their ability to efficiently store and query large amounts of data. However, real-time aggregation queries still pose a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'CAI', which leverages the characteristics of column stores to accelerate aggregation queries. CAI uses a combination of Bloom filters and bit-vector indexing to reduce the number of rows that need to be accessed during aggregation, resulting in significant performance improvements. Our experiments on a popular column store DBMS demonstrate that CAI outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x for real-time aggregation workloads.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficacious Retrieval in Multimodal Information Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal information systems have become increasingly prevalent, but their inherent complexity hinders effective retrieval. This paper introduces a novel context-aware query expansion (CAQE) framework that leverages multimodal features to facilitate more accurate and relevant search results. By incorporating user preferences, query context, and semantic relationships between query terms, CAQE generates an optimized set of expansion terms that bridge the semantic gap between the user's information need and the multimodal data. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate a significant improvement in retrieval performance, particularly for multimedia-rich queries.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Discovery using Deep Clustering for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Existing information retrieval systems rely on predefined query intent categorizations, which can be limiting and inflexible. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised approach to discover query intent patterns using deep clustering on ad-hoc retrieval datasets. Our method, dubbed 'IntentCluster', leverages a combination of word embeddings and clustering algorithms to automatically identify underlying query intent categories. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that IntentCluster outperforms state-of-the-art intent detection methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural word embeddings to better represent query semantics. We develop a dense passage retrieval model that jointly learns to embed queries and documents in a shared vector space, enabling effective expansion of query terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for short and ambiguous queries. Our approach provides a simple yet effective way to enhance the accuracy of ad-hoc retrieval systems without requiring extensive manual tuning or domain-specific knowledge.

title: Efficient Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of distributed query plans. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DistroOpt', which leverages machine learning and graph-based techniques to efficiently explore the query optimization search space. We introduce a distributed cost estimation model that accurately predicts query execution times, and a genetic algorithm-based search strategy that adaptively prunes the search space. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark show that DistroOpt outperforms existing query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems using auction-based mechanisms. We propose a novel auction protocol that considers the agents' diverse capabilities, preferences, and communication constraints. Our approach enables efficient task allocation while promoting fairness and robustness in the system. Experimental results on a simulated urban search and rescue scenario demonstrate that our framework outperforms existing centralized and distributed task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Intelligent Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Edge Computing Environments
paper_abstract: Edge computing has gained significant attention in recent years due to its ability to reduce latency and improve real-time processing. However, efficient resource allocation in edge computing environments remains a major challenge. This paper proposes a novel intelligent agent-based framework that leverages decentralized decision-making to allocate resources dynamically. Our approach utilizes a multi-agent system, where each agent is capable of learning and adapting to changing workload patterns. We evaluate our framework using a real-world edge computing dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and overall system efficiency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Deep Learning-based Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Deep learning-based retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often rely on sparse and incomplete query representations, which can limit their effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages contextualized word embeddings and graph-based keyword extraction. Our method, 'DeepQE', is designed to generate a set of relevant expansion terms that capture the semantic nuances of the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE significantly improves the retrieval performance of popular neural ranking models, outperforming traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for real-time autonomous vehicle control. Our approach, dubbed 'SafeDrive', leverages a hybrid architecture combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to learn robust policies for navigating complex urban environments. SafeDrive incorporates a safety shield module that enforces constraints on velocity, acceleration, and steering to ensure safe and smooth control. We evaluate our approach using a high-fidelity simulator and demonstrate significant improvements in terms of safety, efficiency, and adaptability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a crucial task in human-computer interaction. While deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal features and provides explainable emotion recognition. Our HAN model uses attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, enabling the identification of important contributors to emotion detection. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of recognition accuracy and provides meaningful insights into the decision-making process.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Conversational Strategies for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational interfaces often exclude older adults with hearing or cognitive impairments. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the effects of personalized conversational strategies on the usability and accessibility of voice assistants for older adults. We designed and evaluated three novel strategies: slow-and-clear speech, semantic repetition, and turn-based dialogues. Our results show significant improvements in task completion rates, user satisfaction, and cognitive load reduction using these strategies. We also provide guidelines for designing inclusive voice assistants that cater to diverse older adult populations.

title: Deep Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Multi-Modal Retrieval in Large-Scale Information Systems
paper_abstract: As information systems continue to grow in scale and complexity, efficient retrieval of relevant information from diverse modalities (e.g., text, images, videos) becomes increasingly challenging. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'MMR-NET', which leverages multi-modal fusion and hierarchical attention mechanisms to improve retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that MMR-NET outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of precision, recall, and latency, making it a promising solution for real-world information retrieval applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants and chatbots, have become increasingly prevalent in our daily lives. However, people with disabilities often face significant barriers in using these systems due to limitations in current design practices. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive conversational interfaces that cater to the needs of individuals with disabilities. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving user interviews, surveys, and usability testing to identify key accessibility challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed framework incorporates adaptive dialogue management, multimodal output, and personalized feedback mechanisms to enhance the user experience for people with disabilities.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained popularity in recent years due to the availability of large-scale datasets and advancements in 3D skeleton estimation. However, existing methods struggle to effectively capture complex spatio-temporal relationships between joints. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages both node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant joints and skeletal structures. We demonstrate the efficacy of HAGNN on three benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of accuracy and F1-score.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Latent Semantic Analysis with Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional latent semantic analysis (LSA) techniques for document retrieval suffer from the curse of dimensionality and ignore semantic relationships between words.
