This paper proposes a novel approach, 'LSA-WE', which integrates word embeddings into the LSA framework to capture nuanced word semantics. We demonstrate that LSA-WE significantly improves document retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, achieving a 25% increase in precision and a 30% reduction in retrieval time compared to traditional LSA methods. Experiments on a large-scale news article dataset validate the efficacy of our approach.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-scale Time Series Data using Deep Embeddings
paper_abstract: Time series clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but existing methods struggle with large-scale datasets. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Embedding Clustering (HEC), which leverages deep learning to efficiently cluster time series data. HEC first learns a hierarchical representation of the data using a deep embedding network, and then applies a traditional clustering algorithm to the learned representation. Our experiments on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HEC outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency, making it suitable for large-scale time series analysis.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective allocation strategies. Our approach represents the agent-task graph as a dynamic neural network, allowing agents to learn from their local observations and make autonomous decisions. We evaluate our framework in a simulated urban search and rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (NIR) models have shown promising results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but often struggle with document representation and query-document matching. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which leverages sentence embeddings and attention mechanisms to selectively expand documents with relevant context. We experiment with various query types and show that QDE significantly improves retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets, including Robust04 and ClueWeb09. Our analysis reveals that QDE is particularly effective in capturing nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Traffic signal control is a challenging problem in urban planning, requiring real-time adaptation to dynamic traffic patterns. We propose a multi-agent system that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize traffic signal timing. Our approach, called MARL-TSC, consists of multiple agents, each controlling a traffic signal, which learn to coordinate their actions to minimize travel time and reduce congestion. We evaluate MARL-TSC using a realistic traffic simulator and demonstrate significant improvements over traditional fixed-time and adaptive signal control methods. Our results show that MARL-TSC can reduce travel time by up to 23% and decrease congestion by 18% during peak hours.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems often struggle to balance multiple tasks, such as intent recognition, sentiment analysis, and response generation. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant context, intent, and sentiment features across tasks. Our HAN model is designed to be explainable, providing visualizations of attention weights to facilitate understanding of the decision-making process. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-task dialogue dataset demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art models, highlighting the potential of HAN for real-world applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-based machine learning, but it often suffers from scalability issues and inadequate feature representation. We propose a novel hierarchical attention graph convolutional network (HAGCN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and features. Our approach integrates graph convolutional layers with hierarchical attention to capture complex node relationships and improve classification accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Adaptive Context-Aware Term Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to improve retrieval effectiveness by incorporating relevant terms into the original query. This paper presents a novel QE approach, termed ACTE (Adaptive Context-aware Term Embeddings), which leverages the power of deep learning and contextualized term representations. ACTE adaptively updates term embeddings based on the query context, effectively capturing nuanced semantic relationships between terms. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ACTE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, particularly in scenarios with ambiguous or polysemous queries.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Limited Domain Knowledge
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively incorporate domain-specific knowledge, particularly when limited training data is available. This paper presents a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-Lite', which leverages a compact, learnable knowledge graph to augment query representations. By incorporating a lightweight attention mechanism, NQE-Lite can adapt to diverse query types and domains, outperforming traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets. We demonstrate the effectiveness of NQE-Lite in improving retrieval performance, especially for tail queries, and discuss its potential applications in specialized search engines and recommender systems.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent Framework for Real-time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized autonomous agent framework for real-time traffic management, which leverages multi-agent systems to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. Our framework, 'TrafficAgent', utilizes a novel distributed decision-making approach that enables agents to adapt to changing traffic conditions and communicate with each other in real-time. We evaluate TrafficAgent using a large-scale simulation of a metropolitan area and demonstrate significant reductions in travel time and traffic congestion compared to traditional centralized traffic management systems.

title: Designing Gesture-Based Authentication for Smart Home Devices
paper_abstract: As smart home devices become increasingly pervasive, secure authentication mechanisms are essential to prevent unauthorized access. This paper presents a novel gesture-based authentication system, 'SmartGest', designed for smart home devices. Our approach leverages machine learning algorithms to recognize and verify user-specific hand gestures captured by device-embedded cameras. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, demonstrating a false acceptance rate of 2.1% and a false rejection rate of 1.5%. Our system is robust against various attack scenarios and provides an intuitive, touchless authentication experience for users.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph Embeddings and Attention-based Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches struggle with scalability and accuracy. We propose a novel method, 'GraphAttentiveED', which leverages graph embeddings and attention-based neural networks to disambiguate entities in large-scale knowledge graphs. Our approach learns to represent entities as dense vectors, capturing their context and relationships, and employs an attention mechanism to focus on relevant information during disambiguation. Experimental results on the Wikidata5M dataset demonstrate that GraphAttentiveED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while reducing computational time by an order of magnitude.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become a cornerstone of modern data management, but optimizing query execution plans remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to scalable query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, 'QOptRL', leverages a hierarchical DRL framework to learn query optimization policies that adapt to diverse workload patterns and database configurations. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database testbed demonstrate that QOptRL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average query response time reduction of 35% and improved resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Multi-modal time series forecasting is a crucial task in various applications, including healthcare and finance. However, existing methods often struggle to capture complex dependencies between different modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework, which leverages graph attention mechanisms to model both intra- and inter-modality relationships. HGAT consists of a hierarchical graph encoder, which learns to represent each modality as a graph, and a forecasting module, which aggregates the graph representations to predict future values. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of forecasting accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Graph Attention for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Recent advancements in knowledge graph embedding have shown promise in question answering tasks. However, existing methods often disregard the hierarchical structure inherent in knowledge graphs, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention mechanism, 'HGA-QA', which learns to focus on relevant entities and relations at different levels of abstraction. We evaluate HGA-QA on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in question answering accuracy and reduced computational overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Mitigating Cognitive Biases
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in daily life, but their interactions can inadvertently perpetuate cognitive biases, exacerbating social inequalities. This paper presents a novel, inclusive design framework for voice assistants that incorporates multimodal interfaces and adaptive feedback mechanisms to detect and mitigate biases. Our approach leverages machine learning-driven sentiment analysis and user modeling to recognize bias-prone interactions, and responds with contextually appropriate, bias-reducing interventions. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates that our framework significantly increases user awareness of biases and promotes more equitable interactions.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for RDF Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: RDF graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large amounts of semantic data. However, query optimization remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of RDF data models and the vast number of possible query plans. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select optimal query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query performance. Our experiments on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and memory usage compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Disambiguation for E-commerce Search Engines
paper_abstract: Effective search intent disambiguation is crucial for e-commerce search engines to provide relevant results. Existing approaches rely on labor-intensive manual annotation or supervised learning, which can be time-consuming and costly. This paper proposes an unsupervised query intent disambiguation framework, 'IntentMine', that leverages graph-based clustering and semantic role labeling to identify underlying intent behind ambiguous queries. Our experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset show that IntentMine outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while eliminating the need for manual annotation.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering for Deep Generative Models
paper_abstract: Deep generative models have shown remarkable success in various applications, but their clustering capabilities are often limited by the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering algorithm, 'DeepHier', which leverages the representational power of deep neural networks to learn a hierarchical structure of clusters. We introduce a scalable, online learning framework that adaptively updates the clustering tree as new data points arrive, enabling efficient processing of large datasets. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepHier achieves state-of-the-art clustering performance while reducing computational complexity.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Information Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of large-scale information systems has led to an exponential increase in document collections, making efficient retrieval a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to document retrieval, leveraging hierarchical document embeddings to reduce the dimensionality of the search space. We introduce a neural network-based model that learns to project documents into a hierarchical space, enabling the pruning of irrelevant documents at early stages of the retrieval process. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency while maintaining state-of-the-art accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of hierarchical task network planning for multi-agent systems in partially observable environments. We propose a novel planning framework that integrates belief space planning with hierarchical task decomposition. Our approach enables agents to reason about incomplete information and adapt to changing environmental conditions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through experiments in a simulated search and rescue scenario, where our system outperforms existing planning methods in terms of mission success rate and robustness to uncertainty.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to balance retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, particularly when dealing with large document collections. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QueryAware', which learns query-adaptive document embeddings to facilitate efficient retrieval. By incorporating query semantics into the embedding space, QueryAware reduces the search space and enables fast filtering of irrelevant documents. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a growing concern, and traditional traffic signal control systems often struggle to optimize traffic flow in real-time. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for autonomous traffic signal control, which leverages both high-level traffic pattern recognition and low-level signal timing optimization. Our approach integrates a graph neural network (GNN) with a deep Q-network (DQN) to learn a hierarchical policy that adapts to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulator demonstrate that our HRL approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reducing congestion, decreasing travel times, and improving overall traffic network efficiency.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic signal control has the potential to significantly reduce congestion and emissions in urban areas. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for coordinating traffic signals in real-time. Our approach leverages a decentralized, communication-efficient architecture where each agent learns to optimize its own signal timing based on local observations and sparse rewards. We demonstrate the scalability of our method through large-scale simulations, showing improved traffic flow and reduced waiting times compared to traditional, fixed-timing strategies.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of conversational AI systems, requiring the accurate identification of user intents and slots across multiple modalities. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for efficient multi-modal DST. Our approach leverages a hierarchical structure to model the relationships between utterances, modalities, and slots, while incorporating attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant context. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset demonstrate that our HAN-based model outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of joint goal accuracy and computational efficiency, making it suitable for real-world deployment.

title: Task-Oriented Dialogue Management using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Agents
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents require effective dialogue management to achieve task-oriented goals in human-agent interactions. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, HierRL, which integrates a high-level task manager with a low-level dialogue generator. The task manager learns to select relevant tasks and subtasks, while the dialogue generator uses a deep reinforcement learning model to generate context-dependent responses. We evaluate HierRL in a simulated environment and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task success rate and dialogue coherence. Our approach has implications for the development of more sophisticated autonomous agents in real-world applications.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Semantic Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of complex queries, leading to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion, 'SemExpan', which leverages semantic embeddings to better capture the context and intent behind user queries. By incorporating pre-trained language models and domain-specific knowledge graphs, SemExpan generates more informative and relevant expansion terms, resulting in improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on a large patent corpus demonstrate significant gains in precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches struggle to scale to large datasets. This paper presents a novel method that combines knowledge graph embeddings with graph attention mechanisms to efficiently disambiguate entities. Our approach, called GraphED, learns to represent entities as dense vectors in a low-dimensional space, and then uses graph attention to selectively focus on relevant neighboring entities and contextual information during disambiguation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and efficiency, making it a promising solution for large-scale knowledge graph construction.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Objective Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for autonomous agents, focusing on scenarios where agents have diverse capabilities and preferences. We propose a multi-objective optimization framework that balances task completion efficiency, agent workload, and resource utilization. Our algorithm leverages a decentralized, auction-based mechanism to assign tasks to agents, while incorporating constraints on agent capacity, spatial proximity, and temporal dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated drone-based surveillance system demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced resource waste compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Topic Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on effective query representation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages hierarchical topic modeling (HTM) to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. Our method, HTM-QE, recursively applies HTM to generate a hierarchical representation of the query, enabling the incorporation of contextualized term weights and phrase-level dependencies. Experiments on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that HTM-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, with significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal dialogue systems have become increasingly popular, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates visual, acoustic, and textual features to generate more accurate and explainable responses. Our approach uses a novel multimodal fusion mechanism to capture cross-modal relationships and a hierarchical attention module to selectively focus on relevant input features. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in response accuracy and generating more interpretable explanations.

title: Augmenting Accessibility: A Study on Personalized Gesture Recognition for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with technology. This paper presents a novel approach to personalized gesture recognition, leveraging machine learning and computer vision techniques to improve the accuracy and usability of gesture-based interfaces. We propose a framework that adaptively learns to recognize gestures from a user's unique motor patterns, accommodating variations in ability and movement. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates a significant improvement in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction, paving the way for more inclusive and accessible human-computer interaction.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents via Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: We propose a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) techniques. Our approach, called AgentTA, enables agents to dynamically allocate tasks while respecting constraints on resource availability, communication range, and agent capabilities. We develop a gossip-based protocol that allows agents to iteratively refine their task assignments, leading to improved system-wide efficiency and scalability. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate that AgentTA outperforms existing centralized and distributed task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and resource utilization.

title: Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Attention-based YOLO
paper_abstract: Object detection is a critical component in autonomous vehicle systems. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based YOLO framework, HA-YOLO, which achieves state-of-the-art performance in real-time object detection. HA-YOLO leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions of interest, reducing computational complexity while improving detection accuracy. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that HA-YOLO outperforms existing YOLO variants in terms of accuracy, speed, and robustness to varying lighting conditions.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query processing in DDS remains a significant challenge due to the high latency and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach that leverages both vertical and horizontal partitioning to optimize query performance. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query workload and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach reduces query response time by up to 40% compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Conversational Systems
paper_abstract: Conversational systems increasingly rely on multimodal input, such as text, speech, and facial expressions, to understand user sentiment. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that jointly models these modalities to improve sentiment analysis. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant input features, and a hierarchical fusion strategy to integrate modality-specific representations. Experimental results on a large conversational dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods, achieving a 12% improvement in sentiment classification accuracy.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
paper_abstract: The proliferation of edge devices has created a pressing need for efficient deep learning models that can operate within stringent resource constraints. This paper presents 'EcoNAS', a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework that leverages a surrogate-based optimization strategy to identify compact, high-performance models for edge deployment. Our approach incorporates a device-aware fitness function that considers both accuracy and resource utilization, enabling the discovery of models that achieve state-of-the-art performance on edge benchmarks while reducing memory footprint and energy consumption by up to 50%. We demonstrate EcoNAS's efficacy on various edge computing tasks, including image classification and object detection.

title: Exploring Gestural Input for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current input methods can be exclusionary for users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel gestural input framework, 'GestVR', which leverages machine learning and computer vision to enable users to interact with VR environments using a range of natural, full-body gestures. We conducted a user study with participants with and without disabilities, demonstrating significant improvements in usability, accessibility, and overall user experience. Our approach opens up new possibilities for inclusive VR interactions, enabling a broader range of users to engage with immersive technologies.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various node classification tasks. However, their robustness against adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. In this paper, we propose a novel attack framework, 'GraphFool', which generates perturbations on the graph structure and node features to mislead GNNs. We demonstrate that GraphFool can significantly degrade the performance of popular GNN architectures, even when they are trained with robustness-enhancing techniques. Furthermore, we develop a defense mechanism that incorporates adversarial training and graph purification to improve the resilience of GNNs against such attacks.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Multi-Modal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: As humans interact with computers using diverse modalities (e.g., voice, gesture, and gaze), effective visualization of system responses is crucial for efficient communication. This paper presents an adaptive visualization framework, 'MVis', which dynamically adjusts visual representation based on user preferences, task complexity, and contextual factors. We introduce a novel multi-modal attention mechanism that leverages machine learning to identify relevant input modalities and adapt visualization strategies accordingly. A user study demonstrates that MVis significantly improves task completion time and user satisfaction in multi-modal human-computer interaction scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Dialogue State Tracking for Multi-Domain Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Conversational AI systems struggle to accurately track dialogue state across multiple domains. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Dialogue State Tracking (HADST) model that incorporates domain-specific and global attention mechanisms. Our approach exploits the hierarchical structure of dialogue state to selectively focus on relevant context and domain knowledge. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in joint goal accuracy and dialogue success rate compared to state-of-the-art models, showcasing the potential of HADST for real-world conversational AI applications.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper presents a novel reinforcement learning approach for autonomous task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. We propose a decentralized framework that enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing task requirements. Our approach leverages a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture that combines both task-level and agent-level decision-making. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various node classification tasks. However, most existing GNNs suffer from limited interpretability, making it challenging to understand the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to disentangle node representations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, showing improved performance and interpretability compared to existing GNNs. Our approach enables the identification of influential nodes and edges, facilitating the understanding of node classification decisions.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality-Based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed gesture recognition, but the underlying cognitive mechanisms remain poorly understood. This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in VR-based gesture recognition, focusing on the interplay between motor control, proprioception, and visual feedback. We designed an immersive VR experiment to investigate how users' motor experiences influence gesture recognition accuracy and gesture variability. Our results show that embodied cognition significantly improves gesture recognition, particularly for complex gestures, and that users' motor control strategies adapt to the VR environment. These findings have implications for the design of VR-based gesture recognition systems and highlight the importance of considering embodied cognition in HCI research.

title: Adaptive Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Hierarchical Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper presents a novel approach to enhancing the explainability of DRL agents by incorporating hierarchical attention mechanisms. Our method, dubbed 'HierExplain', adaptively focuses on relevant state features and action dimensions, generating contextual explanations for the agent's decisions. We empirically demonstrate HierExplain's effectiveness in improving transparency and trustworthiness of DRL models in a range of Atari games and real-world robotics tasks.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph-Based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses significant security risks. This paper proposes a novel graph-based anomaly detection framework, 'GARD', to detect adversarial attacks in DRL. GARD leverages graph neural networks to model the complex relationships between state-action pairs and identifies anomalies based on graph structural properties. We evaluate GARD on several DRL benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting various types of adversarial attacks, including poisoning and evasion attacks.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Visuospatial Ability on Gesture-Based Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way humans interact with digital information. However, the relationship between users' visuospatial abilities and their performance in gesture-based VR interfaces remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining the correlation between visuospatial ability and gesture recognition accuracy in a VR environment. Our results show that individuals with higher visuospatial abilities exhibit improved gesture recognition accuracy and reduced cognitive load. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of more inclusive and efficient VR interfaces.

title: Hybrid Agent-Based Framework for Real-Time Traffic Flow Optimization
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic flow optimization is a complex problem that requires efficient decision-making and adaptability. This paper proposes a hybrid agent-based framework that integrates machine learning and multi-agent systems to optimize traffic signal control. Our approach leverages real-time traffic data and agent-based modeling to learn traffic patterns and make decentralized decisions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework in a simulated urban traffic network, achieving a 23% reduction in travel time and 18% decrease in congestion compared to traditional signal control methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using auctions and Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to be assigned to tasks with different requirements and rewards. We design a novel auction mechanism that incorporates deep reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn bid strategies and adapt to changing task environments. Our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, resource utilization, and overall system efficiency, as demonstrated through extensive simulations on a variety of scenarios.

title: Intelligent Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, 'AgentTasker', learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, tasks' requirements, and environmental factors. We employ a decentralized DRL framework, where each agent learns to make decisions autonomously, while sharing knowledge with other agents through a communication network. Experimental results show that AgentTasker outperforms traditional optimization-based approaches in complex, dynamic environments, and is scalable to large-scale systems.

title: Gaze-Informed Adaptive Interface for Enhancing User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel gaze-informed adaptive interface, 'GazeAdapt', which dynamically adjusts the VR environment based on the user's gaze patterns. Our approach leverages machine learning to identify user interest and adapt the interface in real-time, thereby enhancing user engagement and reducing cognitive load. We evaluate GazeAdapt in a user study and demonstrate significant improvements in user experience and task performance compared to traditional static interfaces.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of graph databases in various domains, there is a growing need for efficient query optimization techniques to support real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph summarization and query rewriting to minimize query latency. We propose a cost-based optimization approach that considers both the structural properties of the graph and the workload characteristics. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale social network dataset demonstrates that GraphOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Bayesian Hypernetworks
paper_abstract: Neural Architecture Search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing methods often rely on expensive and time-consuming searches over large architecture spaces. This paper introduces a novel Bayesian hypernetwork-based NAS framework, 'BayesNAS', which leverages probabilistic modeling to efficiently explore the architecture space. By learning a distribution over hypernetwork weights, BayesNAS can generate high-performing architectures with significantly reduced computational costs. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of BayesNAS in discovering efficient and accurate neural architectures.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for People with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their usability for individuals with dyslexia remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the challenges faced by dyslexic users when interacting with voice assistants. We identify three key areas of difficulty: linguistic complexity, auditory processing, and visual feedback. Based on our findings, we propose a set of design guidelines for creating more accessible conversational interfaces, including the use of simplified language, visual cueing, and adaptive feedback mechanisms. A prototype system incorporating these guidelines is evaluated, showing significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for participants with dyslexia.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability has become a crucial aspect in modern AI systems, particularly in multi-task learning (MTL) where models are prone to task interference. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs) for explainable MTL, which leverage attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant task-specific features. HANs consist of a hierarchical structure of task-agnostic and task-specific attention layers, allowing for interpretable feature importance and attention weights. Our experiments on several benchmark MTL datasets demonstrate that HANs outperform existing state-of-the-art MTL models while providing insightful explanations for task relationships and feature interactions.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies via Constrained Policy Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its deployment in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to enhance the robustness of DRL policies against adversarial perturbations. We introduce a constrained policy optimization framework that incorporates a robustness metric as a regularization term, encouraging the policy to be more resilient to perturbations. Experimental results on several benchmark environments demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the robustness of DRL policies while maintaining their performance.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Graph Attention Networks for Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in knowledge graphs is a crucial step for accurate entity linking and question answering. Existing approaches rely on either hand-crafted features or simple graph-based methods that fail to capture complex contextual relationships. We propose GraphAttentionED, a novel entity disambiguation framework that leverages graph attention networks to learn contextualized entity representations. Our approach effectively integrates both local and global graph structure information, resulting in improved disambiguation accuracy. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of GraphAttentionED over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 4.3%.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in patent retrieval systems, as it aims to augment the original query with relevant terms to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. We design a neural network architecture that incorporates patent-specific knowledge graphs and fine-tunes pre-trained language models to generate dense vector representations of terms. Experimental results on a large patent corpus demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) are increasingly being deployed in complex urban environments, requiring efficient task allocation to maximize their utility. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for task allocation among AVs. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model the spatial relationships between AVs and tasks, and employs a novel communication protocol to facilitate agent-to-agent negotiation. Experimental results on a realistic simulation platform demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced latency compared to centralized optimization methods.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Hop Reasoning
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has gained popularity for modeling complex relationships between entities and their attributes. However, existing KGE methods struggle to capture multi-hop reasoning patterns, which are crucial for question answering and recommendation systems. We propose a novel graph attention network (GAT) based KGE framework, 'MultiHopGAT', that learns to focus on relevant entities and relationships during embedding. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to aggregate information from neighboring entities and incorporate meta-paths for more accurate reasoning. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that MultiHopGAT outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods on multi-hop reasoning tasks.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems rely on bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture complex document structures and relationships. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture for document retrieval, which models documents as graph-structured data and learns to aggregate information from multiple scales. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art IR methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, while providing interpretable document representations.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Self-Supervised Pre-Training
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task in machine learning, particularly when faced with limited labeled data. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'MetaHIer', which leverages self-supervised pre-training to improve adaptation to new tasks. We propose a two-level hierarchical structure, where a base model learns to recognize general features from unlabeled data, and a meta-model learns to adapt to new tasks with few labeled examples. Experimental results on popular benchmarks demonstrate that MetaHIer outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot image classification, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 4.5% on the mini-ImageNet dataset.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but it remains challenging due to the presence of noisy or adversarial nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that learns to selectively focus on informative nodes and filter out noisy ones. Our approach consists of a hierarchical node representation module and a attention-based node classification module. We demonstrate the robustness of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, showing that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in the presence of noise and attacks.

title: Emotional State Recognition from Multimodal Input using Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Affective computing has numerous applications in human-computer interaction, but recognizing emotional states from multimodal input remains a challenging task. This paper presents an approach that leverages transfer learning to improve emotional state recognition from facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals. We fine-tune a pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN) on a large affective dataset and adapt it to our target multimodal dataset using a novel domain adaptation technique. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotional states, achieving an accuracy of 87.2% on the benchmark dataset.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings via Hyperbolic Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings (KGEs) have become a crucial component in various AI applications. However, most existing KGE methods suffer from high computational complexity and limited expressive power. This paper presents a novel approach, Hyperbolic Attention Networks (HAN), which leverages hyperbolic geometry to capture complex relationships in knowledge graphs. HAN employs a hyperbolic attention mechanism that adaptively weights entity and relation representations, enabling efficient and effective KGEs. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of link prediction and triple classification tasks.

title: Efficient Indexing of RDF Graphs using Hybrid Bitap and Trie Data Structures
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs in various applications has led to a growing need for efficient querying and indexing techniques. This paper presents a novel hybrid indexing approach that combines the benefits of bitap and trie data structures for RDF graph indexing. Our proposed method, dubbed 'HybridRDF', leverages the strengths of bitap in filtering out irrelevant patterns and the efficient prefix matching capabilities of trie structures. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that HybridRDF outperforms existing state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query response time and memory usage.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Sparse Document Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel approach to passage retrieval using sparse document representations, which reduce the dimensionality of the document embedding space and enable faster similarity computations. Our method, dubbed 'SparseDPR', leverages a hierarchical clustering algorithm to create a sparse representation of documents, allowing for efficient indexing and retrieval of top-k relevant passages. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that SparseDPR achieves state-of-the-art passage retrieval performance while reducing computational overhead by up to 70% compared to existing dense representation-based methods.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding via Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding has become a crucial task in various AI applications. However, existing methods often suffer from scalability issues and neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in many knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel approach, HierGAT, which leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to efficiently embed knowledge graphs. By recursively applying attention mechanisms at different granularities, HierGAT captures complex relational patterns and outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets. Experimental results demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of HierGAT in various knowledge graph-based applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires efficient coordination among multiple agents. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize the behavior of autonomous vehicles in a multi-agent system. Our framework, 'TrafficMaestro', uses a decentralized deep Q-network to learn adaptive control policies for each agent, taking into account real-time traffic conditions and communication constraints. Simulation results on a realistic urban traffic scenario demonstrate that TrafficMaestro outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing congestion and travel times by up to 30%.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc information retrieval, where the goal is to reformulate an initial query to retrieve more relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'DeepQE', which learns to select optimal expansion terms by maximizing a reward function that balances retrieval effectiveness and query clarity. We leverage a hierarchical encoder-decoder architecture to model the query-document relationship and incorporate a curiosity-driven exploration strategy to adapt to diverse query types. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Enhancing Query Performance in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems struggle with query performance due to the complexity of index management and data distribution. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HierDir', which exploits the hierarchical structure of the dataset to optimize query routing and processing. By dynamically adjusting the indexing granularity and leveraging a two-stage query processing mechanism, HierDir significantly improves query response times and reduces network latency. Experimental results on a large-scale DIR benchmark demonstrate the superiority of HierDir over existing indexing techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Cognitive Load and User Experience
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their usability and accessibility remain concerns, particularly for individuals with disabilities. This study investigates the impact of cognitive load on user experience in voice-based interactions. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, exploring the effects of cognitive load on task performance, user satisfaction, and mental workload. Our results show that personalized voice assistant responses can reduce cognitive load and improve user experience. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the need for adaptive feedback, clear instructions, and error forgiveness.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Columnar Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed columnar databases have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'ColumnRush', which leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and optimize query plans. We introduce a column-aware cost model that captures the unique characteristics of columnar storage and develop a reinforcement learning framework to adapt to changing workload patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that ColumnRush reduces average query latency by up to 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art optimizers.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a massive corpus to answer a given question. Existing dense retriever models, while effective, are computationally expensive and struggle to scale. This paper presents Hierarchical Dense Retrieval (HDR), a novel approach that leverages hierarchical representations to efficiently retrieve passages. HDR employs a lightweight, coarse-grained retriever to identify promising passages, followed by a fine-grained, dense retriever to rank the top candidates. Our experiments on popular ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that HDR achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 75%.

title: Emotionally Intelligent Virtual Assistants for Enhanced User Experience in Affective Computing
paper_abstract: Affective computing has led to the development of virtual assistants that can recognize and respond to users' emotions. However, current systems often lack emotional intelligence, leading to inadequate or even annoying responses. This paper proposes an emotionally intelligent virtual assistant (EIVA) framework that integrates cognitive architectures with multimodal affect recognition. Our approach enables EIVAs to reason about user emotions, empathize, and respond with personalized support. We evaluate our framework through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction and perceived emotional support. The results have implications for designing more effective and empathetic virtual assistants in various applications.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Systems for Efficient Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent system (DMAS) for efficient resource allocation in smart grids. We propose a novel agent-based architecture that enables autonomous decision-making for distributed energy resources, such as solar panels and energy storage systems. Our DMAS framework utilizes a decentralized optimization algorithm to allocate resources in real-time, taking into account dynamic demand and supply profiles. Simulation results demonstrate that our approach achieves a 23% reduction in peak demand and a 17% increase in renewable energy penetration compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has become a crucial component in designing efficient deep learning models. In this paper, we propose a novel graph-based reinforcement learning approach, dubbed 'GraphNAS', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to efficiently explore the vast architecture space. By representing neural architectures as graphs, we can effectively capture their structural relationships and identify promising candidates using a reinforcement learning policy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphNAS achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the search cost by an order of magnitude compared to existing NAS methods.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Learning-based Term Weighting
paper_abstract: Traditional term weighting schemes in information retrieval rely on simple statistics and often fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between terms and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TermRank', which leverages a neural network to learn context-aware term weights that incorporate both local and global document features. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TermRank significantly outperforms state-of-the-art term weighting methods, achieving improved ranking quality and retrieval efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing VR systems often exclude people with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive VR experiences. We conducted participatory design workshops with individuals with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities to identify key accessibility barriers. We then developed and evaluated a set of novel VR interaction techniques, including eye-tracking-based navigation and haptic feedback, that cater to diverse abilities. Our results show that these techniques significantly improve user experience and engagement for participants with disabilities, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in VR.

title: Efficient Indexing for Dynamic Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Dynamic graph databases have become increasingly popular in modern applications, but their efficient indexing remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'GraphSprint', a novel indexing technique that leverages the graph's structural properties to support fast query execution. GraphSprint uses a combination of graph summarization, incremental indexing, and optimized query planning to achieve an average speedup of 3.5x over existing indexing methods. Our experimental evaluation on real-world graph datasets demonstrates the effectiveness of GraphSprint in supporting various graph queries, including node and edge insertions, deletions, and pattern matching.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, most existing NAS methods suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for NAS, which leverages a two-level hierarchy of controllers to efficiently explore the architecture space. Our HRL-NAS approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing the search time by an order of magnitude compared to existing methods. We also provide a thorough analysis of the learned architectures and their transferability across different tasks.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents via Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of coordinating multiple autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) framework that enables agents to learn coordinated policies without explicit communication. Our approach leverages a novel entropy-based reward function that encourages agents to explore and learn from each other's actions. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that Dec-POMDP outperforms existing decentralized methods, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Temporal Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed temporal databases (DTDBs) are increasingly used in various applications, including financial analytics and IoT monitoring. However, query optimization in DTDBs remains a challenging task due to the complexities of temporal data and distributed processing. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'Tempo', which leverages a combination of temporal indexing, partitioning, and parallel processing to minimize query latency. Our experiments on a real-world financial dataset demonstrate that Tempo outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Entity Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval tasks often rely on query expansion to improve retrieval effectiveness. However, existing methods struggle to capture complex contextual relationships between query terms and relevant entities. We propose a novel approach, EntityEmbEx, which leverages neural entity embeddings to enrich query representations. By integrating entity embeddings with traditional query expansion techniques, our method achieves significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 Ad-Hoc Retrieval dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of EntityEmbEx, particularly for queries with low term frequency.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on heuristics or manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'RL-QE', which learns to generate effective expansion terms by maximizing a reward function that balances retrieval accuracy and efficiency. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to model complex query-document relationships and adaptively selects expansion terms based on their expected impact on retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Scalable Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems have become increasingly popular for large-scale data retrieval. However, optimizing query processing in DIR systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DirOpt', which leverages a hierarchical indexing structure and adaptive query routing to minimize communication overhead and improve query response times. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DirOpt on a real-world dataset, achieving an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Comparative Study of Interface Modalities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by accessibility barriers. This study investigates the impact of interface modality on the usability and user experience of voice assistants for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study, comparing three interface modalities: voice-only, visual-only, and multimodal (combining voice and visual cues). Our results show that multimodal interfaces significantly improve task completion rates and user satisfaction, particularly for older adults with hearing or visual impairments. We provide design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants and discuss implications for future research.

title: Efficient Document Re-ranking using Deep Neural Networks for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a critical component in many information retrieval systems, where the goal is to retrieve the most relevant passages from a large document collection given a query. In this paper, we propose a novel deep neural network-based approach for document re-ranking, which leverages the semantic relationships between passages and the query. Our model, called DPRank, uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture the contextual information in passages and computes a ranking score based on the semantic similarity with the query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DPRank outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for analytics workloads, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel cost-based optimizer, 'ColOpt', that leverages statistical models and machine learning techniques to efficiently explore the query plan space. We introduce a hierarchical query representation that captures both logical and physical optimization opportunities, and develop a reinforcement learning-based search strategy that adapts to the underlying data distribution and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms existing state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Learning Models using Gradient-Based Anomaly Scores
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and reliability. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks by analyzing the gradient patterns of the model's loss function. We introduce a gradient-based anomaly score, which captures the deviation of input samples from the expected gradient distribution. Our experiments on various image classification datasets demonstrate that our method can accurately identify adversarial examples, even in the presence of strong attacks and limited training data. The proposed approach can be seamlessly integrated into existing deep learning frameworks, providing an additional layer of security and robustness.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Coordination for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent system for real-time traffic management, which can efficiently coordinate traffic signals and routing to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. Our approach leverages a novel auction-based mechanism to allocate resources and resolve conflicts between agents, ensuring scalability and robustness in large-scale networks. We evaluate our system using a realistic traffic simulator and demonstrate significant improvements in network throughput and travel time reduction compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'RL-TA', which leverages reinforcement learning to allocate tasks to heterogeneous agents. RL-TA uses a decentralized, model-free approach to learn the optimal task allocation policy, taking into account agent capabilities, task requirements, and communication constraints. We evaluate RL-TA on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for multi-agent systems, where agents learn to coordinate their actions through a combination of centralized and decentralized decision-making. Our approach leverages a hierarchical decomposition of the environment and a novel credit assignment mechanism to enable agents to learn effective coordination strategies. Experimental results in a simulated multi-robot warehouse environment demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving high levels of coordination and task completion.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Retrieval of Semi-Structured Documents in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of semi-structured documents in modern information systems has created new challenges for efficient retrieval. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'HybridIR', which combines the benefits of inverted indexing and graph-based indexing to support fast and scalable retrieval of semi-structured documents in distributed information retrieval systems. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HybridIR achieves significant improvements in query response time and retrieval accuracy compared to existing indexing methods, while maintaining a low storage overhead.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Attention-based Policy Distillation
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but its opacity hinders trust and adoption. We propose an attention-based policy distillation approach, 'ExPD', which enables explainable RL by extracting relevant state features and attention weights from a teacher policy. Our method leverages a novel attention mechanism that focuses on critical state aspects and learns to transfer the teacher's policy to a student network with reduced capacity. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate that ExPD achieves competitive performance while providing interpretable insights into the decision-making process.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely heavily on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval performance. Traditional methods, however, often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'NeuQE', which leverages deep neural ranking models to learn semantic query representations. We employ a multi-task learning objective that jointly optimizes query expansion and document ranking, enabling NeuQE to adapt to varying query contexts. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and NDCG@20 over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Visual Feedback on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition is a crucial component of immersive virtual reality (VR) experiences. While machine learning-based approaches have improved recognition accuracy, the role of visual feedback in enhancing user performance remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of real-time visual feedback on gesture recognition in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, comparing three feedback conditions: no feedback, abstract feedback, and realistic feedback. Our results show that realistic feedback significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user confidence, particularly for complex gestures. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR interface design and future research directions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has garnered significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often suffer from scalability issues and limited interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework for MARL, which leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and attention mechanisms to focus on critical relationships. We evaluate HGAT on several cooperative MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance, stability, and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy has become a dominant architecture for cloud-based database systems, where multiple independent tenants share a common infrastructure. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'MTQO', which leverages a combination of static and dynamic analysis to optimize query plans for multiple tenants. Our approach incorporates a tenant-aware cost model, a scalable optimization algorithm, and a runtime adaptation mechanism to handle diverse workload patterns. Experimental results on a commercial database system show that MTQO reduces average query latency by up to 35% and improves system throughput by up to 20% compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Coordinated Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Coordinating traffic signals to minimize congestion and reduce travel times is a challenging problem, especially in large-scale urban networks. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'TrafficSync', that enables real-time coordination among traffic signals. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model spatial relationships between intersections and learns adaptive policies for signal control. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that TrafficSync outperforms traditional fixed-timing and adaptive control methods, reducing average travel times by up to 23%.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant challenges when interacting with gestural interfaces. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible gestural interfaces that accommodate a range of motor abilities. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 participants with motor impairments, resulting in a set of design principles and guidelines for creating accessible gestural interfaces. We then developed and evaluated a prototype system that incorporates these principles, demonstrating improved usability and accessibility for participants with motor impairments. Our findings have important implications for the design of inclusive gestural interfaces in various domains.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Efficient Retrieval in Dynamic Document Collections
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of efficient retrieval in dynamic document collections, where the document set and relevance judgments are subject to frequent updates. We propose an adaptive re-ranking framework, ADR, which combines a neural ranking model with a novel online learning mechanism. ADR incrementally updates the ranking model based on user feedback and document additions/removals, without requiring periodic re-indexing or model retraining. Our experiments on a large-scale news dataset demonstrate that ADR achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, especially in scenarios with high document churn rates.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interaction and Spatial Awareness
paper_abstract: This paper explores the relationship between gestural interaction and spatial awareness in virtual reality (VR) environments. We conducted a user study to investigate how embodied cognition influences users' ability to navigate and understand virtual spaces. Our results show that gestural interaction can significantly enhance spatial awareness, particularly when combined with haptic feedback. We propose a novel framework for designing VR interfaces that leverages embodied cognition principles, and discuss implications for applications in education, training, and entertainment.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to rank documents relevant to a given query.
