While neural ranking models have shown promising results, they often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network architecture, 'HierRank', which leverages a hierarchical representation of documents to reduce computational complexity while improving ranking effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of both efficiency and retrieval quality.

title: Latent Semantic Analysis for Context-Aware Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval systems rely on keyword matching, neglecting the semantic context of user queries. This paper presents a novel approach to document retrieval, leveraging latent semantic analysis (LSA) to capture the contextual relationships between words. We propose a multi-graph neural network (MGN) model that incorporates both local and global context, enabling more accurate query-document matching. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Indexing in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have revolutionized data processing, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization, 'Memoize', which leverages multi-dimensional indexing to minimize query execution times. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that adaptively selects the most efficient indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distributions. Experimental results on a real-world benchmark dataset demonstrate that Memoize reduces query latency by up to 3x compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques, while maintaining high throughput.

title: Revisiting Gesture Recognition for In-Air Hand Tracking using Deep Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In-air hand tracking has numerous applications in Human-Computer Interaction, including virtual and augmented reality, gaming, and sign language recognition. However, existing gesture recognition systems suffer from high latency, limited robustness, and inadequate generalizability. This paper proposes a novel deep convolutional network (DCN) architecture, termed 'AirNet', which leverages a combination of spatial and temporal convolutional layers to recognize hand gestures from skeletal data. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the popular Hand Gesture dataset, with an average recognition accuracy of 95.2% and a latency of 30 ms. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of AirNet in a real-world virtual reality application.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Dementia
paper_abstract: Individuals with dementia often struggle with expressive gestures, leading to communication breakdowns. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive gesture recognition, tailored to the unique needs of older adults with dementia. We propose a multimodal fusion framework that integrates computer vision, machine learning, and cognitive modeling to recognize gestures in real-time. Our system, 'GestureGuide', adapts to the user's abilities and preferences, providing personalized feedback and support. A pilot study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user engagement, highlighting the potential of GestureGuide to enhance communication and quality of life for individuals with dementia.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Existing sentiment analysis models often struggle to capture complex relationships between modalities in multi-modal data. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages explainable AI techniques to identify influential modalities and features. Our proposed HAN model employs a hierarchical structure to learn attention weights at multiple levels, enabling the model to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and interpretability, providing actionable insights into the decision-making process.

title: Deep Relevance Matching for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a fundamental challenge in Information Retrieval (IR). This paper presents a novel approach, 'HierGAT', which leverages hierarchical graph attention to model complex document-query relationships. We propose a deep relevance matching framework that captures both local and global dependencies between entities, phrases, and sentences in the query and document graphs. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art neural ranking models, particularly in cases with limited training data.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with short and ambiguous queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural query graph embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our method, called NeuralQueryExp, represents queries as graphs and learns to embed them in a dense vector space, enabling efficient and effective query expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuralQueryExp outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis with Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to predict sentiment from text, images, and videos. However, existing methods often overlook the uncertainty associated with modalities. This paper introduces HANA, a hierarchical attention network that integrates uncertainty estimation into MSA. HANA employs a Bayesian neural network to model the uncertainty of each modality, and then uses attention weights to fuse the uncertain representations. We evaluate HANA on two benchmark datasets and demonstrate improved performance and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods. Additionally, we provide insights into the uncertainty distributions, highlighting the importance of considering uncertainty in MSA.

title: Efficient Out-of-Distribution Detection using Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to making overconfident predictions on out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, which can be catastrophic in real-world applications. This paper presents a novel self-supervised contrastive learning approach, 'OOD-SSL', that enables efficient OOD detection without requiring labeled OOD data. Our method leverages the similarity between in-distribution and OOD samples in the representation space, and learns to distinguish between them using a contrastive loss. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that OOD-SSL outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in OOD detection, while being computationally efficient and easy to implement.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personality Traits and Conversational Style
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational style often lacks personalization, leading to user frustration. This paper investigates the impact of personality traits on user experience with voice assistants. We conducted a user study with 100 participants, analyzing their interactions with a voice assistant designed to exhibit different personality traits (e.g., extraverted, agreeable, conscientious). Our results show that users with certain personality traits (e.g., introverted, neurotic) prefer a more reserved, empathetic conversational style. We propose a novel framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that adapt to individual personality traits, enhancing user satisfaction and accessibility.

title: Knowledge Graph Embedding for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding method, 'ExplainKG', which incorporates both structural and semantic information from knowledge graphs to provide personalized explanations for recommendations. ExplainKG learns entity and relation embeddings by jointly optimizing a multi-task loss function that combines recommendation and explanation objectives. Experimental results on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate that ExplainKG outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for document retrieval often rely on complex architectures that may not generalize well to diverse query types. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based neural ranking framework, 'HANR', which models the hierarchical structure of documents and queries to improve retrieval accuracy. HANR employs a query-aware attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant document segments and a hierarchical aggregation strategy to capture both local and global contextual information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HANR outperforms existing neural ranking models, especially for long-tail queries and documents with complex structures.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Personalized Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) experiences often rely on visual and auditory cues, neglecting the potential of haptic feedback to enhance user engagement. This study investigates the impact of personalized haptic feedback on user experience in VR environments. We present a novel framework for generating tailored haptic effects based on individual user preferences and behavior. Our user study involving 30 participants shows that personalized haptic feedback significantly increases user engagement, reduces cybersickness, and improves overall VR experience. We discuss implications for VR application design and highlight future research directions.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent Coordination using Blockchain-based Reputation Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, ensuring trust and cooperation among autonomous agents is crucial. Traditional approaches rely on centralized authorities, which can be vulnerable to single points of failure and manipulation. This paper proposes a decentralized reputation system based on blockchain technology, enabling agents to evaluate and update each other's trustworthiness in a transparent and tamper-proof manner. We develop a novel consensus algorithm, 'RepChain', which integrates reputation updates with blockchain transactions, and demonstrate its efficacy in simulations of autonomous vehicles and smart grids.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar-Based Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Fitness Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual fitness environments have become increasingly popular, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the effect of personalized avatar-based feedback on user motivation and exercise adherence. We designed a novel system, 'FitAvatar', which utilizes machine learning-based affect recognition and 3D avatar customization to provide users with realistic, personalized feedback on their exercise form and progress. A user study with 120 participants revealed that FitAvatar significantly improved user engagement, self-efficacy, and exercise adherence compared to traditional virtual fitness platforms. Our results have implications for the design of future virtual fitness systems that aim to promote long-term user engagement and behavior change.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the impact of speech recognition accuracy and cognitive load on the usability of conversational systems for older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65+, comparing two speech recognition systems with varying accuracy levels. Results show that high-accuracy speech recognition significantly reduces cognitive load and improves user experience. We also identify key design recommendations for inclusive conversational interfaces, including adaptive feedback mechanisms and simplified dialogue flows.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short Text Queries using Word Embeddings and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Short text queries are ubiquitous in modern search engines, but their brevity often makes it challenging to accurately capture user intent. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'RL-Embed', which leverages word embeddings and reinforcement learning to generate context-aware expansions. Our approach learns to optimize the trade-off between query similarity and relevance by iteratively refining the expansion process using user feedback. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-Embed outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly for short text queries, and achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Networks
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but they struggle to capture temporal dependencies in dynamic networks. We propose a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that incorporates attention mechanisms at both node and graph levels to model temporal and spatial relationships. Our experiments on several real-world dynamic network datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms existing methods in node classification tasks, especially in scenarios with rapidly changing graph structures.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: As big data analytics continues to grow in scale and complexity, query optimization becomes a critical bottleneck. This paper introduces GraphIndex, a novel graph-based indexing technique that accelerates query execution by up to 5x. By modeling data correlations as a graph, GraphIndex identifies optimal query plans that minimize I/O overhead and leverage parallel processing. We evaluate GraphIndex on a range of real-world datasets and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Neural Retrieval Models for Efficient Query Document Matching in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on accurate query document matching to retrieve relevant documents. This paper presents a neural retrieval model, 'QRN', which leverages a novel query-aware document encoding scheme to improve matching efficiency. QRN uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to focus on salient query terms and document segments, enabling fast and effective retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that QRN outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision while reducing query latency by 30%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI in Medical Imaging
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in medical image analysis tasks, but their lack of transparency hinders trust in AI-driven decision-making. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that generates interpretable explanations for AI-driven diagnoses. Our HAN model recursively applies attention mechanisms to identify relevant regions and features in medical images, enabling the generation of explainable heatmaps and feature importance scores. Experimental results on a large MRI dataset demonstrate that our approach improves model interpretability without sacrificing diagnostic accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for star Schema Benchmarking using Column-Store Indexes
paper_abstract: Optimizing query performance for star schema benchmarking is crucial in data warehousing applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to leverages column-store indexes for efficient query optimization. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that takes into account the unique properties of column-store indexes, enabling the query optimizer to make informed decisions about index selection and join ordering. Experimental results on a real-world star schema benchmark demonstrate that our approach achieves an average query performance improvement of 2.5x compared to traditional row-store based optimization techniques.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial step in many information retrieval applications, but it can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel approach to document representation, called QADE, which learns query-adaptive document embeddings for efficient passage retrieval. QADE uses a neural ranking model to generate query-dependent document representations, allowing for fast and accurate retrieval of relevant passages. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, while also providing insights into the importance of query-document interaction for passage retrieval.

title: Hierarchical Temporal Attention for Efficient Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Multivariate time series forecasting is a fundamental task in many real-world applications, including finance, healthcare, and climate modeling. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical temporal attention mechanism, 'HiTAM', which leverages the hierarchical structure of time series data to selectively focus on relevant variables and time steps. HiTAM achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing computational complexity by up to 30% compared to existing attention-based models. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HiTAM in handling missing data and variable-length time series.

title: Enhancing Search Result Diversity using Hierarchical Clustering and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Search engines often struggle to provide diverse results, leading to user dissatisfaction. This paper proposes a novel approach to enhancing search result diversity using hierarchical clustering and reinforcement learning. We introduce a clustering algorithm that groups similar documents into hierarchies, allowing for more nuanced representations of document similarity. A reinforcement learning framework is then used to optimize the ranking function, encouraging the selection of diverse and relevant documents. Experiments on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate significant improvements in search result diversity and user satisfaction.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Data Analytics in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As data volumes and velocities continue to increase, traditional database systems struggle to keep pace with real-time analytics demands. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'RTQO', designed for distributed databases. RTQO leverages a combination of machine learning-based query prediction, resource-aware query scheduling, and in-memory data caching to minimize latency and maximize throughput. Experimental results on a 50-node distributed database cluster demonstrate that RTQO achieves up to 3x improvement in query response times and 2x increase in system throughput compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Coordinated Exploration for Efficient Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for optimal performance. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated exploration, where agents adaptively allocate tasks based on their individual capabilities and environmental uncertainty. We introduce a decentralized algorithm that leverages reinforcement learning to learn a probabilistic task allocation policy, which is updated through online learning and coordination with neighboring agents. Experimental results in a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to state-of-the-art decentralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Query expansion techniques are essential for improving the retrieval performance of search engines, particularly in specialized domains where users often employ domain-specific terminology. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-SD', which leverages a combination of lexical and semantic features to identify relevant expansion terms. Our approach incorporates a domain-specific thesaurus and a probabilistic topic modeling technique to generate a hierarchical representation of query concepts. Experimental results on a collection of medical and legal documents demonstrate that HQE-SD outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision and recall.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Role Labeling for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval continues to be a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural semantic role labeling (SRL) to better capture the contextual relationships between query terms. Our method, dubbed NeuroQL, uses a pre-trained language model to generate semantic role embeddings, which are then incorporated into a probabilistic relevance feedback framework. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that NeuroQL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Adaptive Negative Sampling
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) is a crucial task in AI, aiming to represent entities and relations in a low-dimensional vector space. However, existing methods often struggle with the problem of negative sampling, which can lead to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes an adaptive negative sampling strategy, dubbed 'AdaNS', that dynamically adjusts the sampling distribution based on the current model's performance. Our approach leverages a reinforcement learning framework to learn the optimal sampling policy, resulting in improved embedding quality and accelerated training. We evaluate AdaNS on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant gains in link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study of Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on gesture-based interaction. We designed a VR system that leverages hand-tracking technology to enable users to manipulate virtual objects using natural gestures. Our user study reveals that participants who used gestures to interact with virtual objects exhibited improved cognitive performance and enhanced sense of presence compared to those using traditional controllers. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more intuitive and engaging VR interfaces.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Navigation for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Individuals with visual impairments face significant challenges when interacting with digital interfaces. This paper presents 'GazeGuide', a novel gaze-based adaptive navigation system designed to facilitate seamless interaction for visually impaired users. By leveraging machine learning-based gaze tracking and adaptive interface manipulation, GazeGuide enables users to efficiently navigate complex interfaces without relying on explicit input. Our user study with 20 visually impaired participants demonstrates a significant reduction in task completion time and improved user satisfaction compared to traditional navigation methods.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Hearing Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but individuals with hearing impairments often struggle to interact with them effectively. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'EasyListen', a voice assistant tailored to the needs of older adults with hearing impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key challenges and developed novel audio processing techniques to enhance speech intelligibility. Our results show that EasyListen improves the overall user experience, reducing errors and increasing user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more inclusive voice interfaces.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Input Preprocessing
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. This paper investigates the effectiveness of input preprocessing techniques in improving the robustness of deep neural networks against such attacks. We propose a novel framework that combines multiple preprocessing methods, including data augmentation, feature scaling, and noise injection. Our experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework can significantly improve the robustness of deep neural networks, with an average increase of 23.4% in accuracy against state-of-the-art attacks.

title: Elastic Retrieval Model for Efficient Query Expansion in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face significant scalability challenges when handling complex queries. This paper presents an Elastic Retrieval Model (ERM) that adaptively expands queries based on real-time document retrieval patterns. ERM leverages a probabilistic graph-based approach to identify relevant terms and phrases, which are then incorporated into the query through a feedback loop. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate that ERM improves retrieval efficiency by up to 30% while maintaining query precision.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for managing large-scale datasets. However, indexing high-dimensional data in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel indexing technique,called Hierarchical Grid Index (HGI), which leverages the hierarchical structure of distributed databases to efficiently index high-dimensional data. HGI uses a combination of grid-based indexing and hierarchical clustering to reduce the number of disk accesses and improve query performance. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HGI outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query speed and storage efficiency.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Avatars in Virtual Reality-Based Social Skills Training
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in social skills training, but the role of embodied avatars in enhancing training effectiveness remains unclear. This study investigates the impact of embodied avatar representation on social skills improvement in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). We designed a VR-based training platform that utilized either an embodied avatar or a non-embodied interface. Results from a mixed-design experiment (N=40) indicate that participants who used the embodied avatar condition showed significant improvements in social skills, particularly in initiating and maintaining conversations, compared to the non-embodied condition. Our findings suggest that embodied avatars can play a crucial role in enhancing the effectiveness of VR-based social skills training for individuals with ASD.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Data Warehousing through Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) enables timely analytics and decision-making, but query processing efficiency remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes 'AdapIndex', a novel adaptive indexing technique that dynamically adjusts to query patterns and data distributions in RTDW systems. AdapIndex combines machine learning-based prediction models with incremental indexing to minimize index maintenance costs. Experimental evaluation on a large-scale RTDW benchmark demonstrates that AdapIndex reduces query latency by up to 40% and improves indexing efficiency by 25% compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gesture-Based Authentication on Touchless Displays
paper_abstract: Touchless displays are increasingly popular in various applications, including public kiosks, smart home devices, and automotive systems. However, securing user authentication on these devices remains an open challenge. This paper investigates the feasibility of using gesture-based authentication on touchless displays. We design and implement a gesture-recognition system using computer vision and machine learning techniques. Our user study with 50 participants evaluates the system's performance under various conditions, including lighting variations, gesture complexity, and user familiarity. The results show that our approach achieves an average accuracy of 92.1% and outperforms existing authentication methods in terms of user experience and security.

title: Ranking-based Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a fundamental challenge in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. This paper proposes a novel ranking-based neural query expansion approach, 'RaNQE', which leverages a neural network to learn semantic query representations. Our approach iteratively expands the query by incorporating relevant terms from the top-ranked documents, while simultaneously refining the query representation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of RaNQE on several benchmark datasets, including TREC-8 and Gov2, and show significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Data Retrieval Using Adaptive Query Optimization in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are crucial for modern data-intensive applications. However, optimizing query execution in DDS remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an adaptive query optimization (AQO) framework that leverages machine learning to dynamically adjust query execution plans based on real-time system performance metrics. AQO incorporates a novel cost-based optimization model that considers data distribution, network latency, and node availability. Experimental results on a large-scale DDS prototype demonstrate that AQO reduces query response times by up to 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Decision Making in Healthcare
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI-driven decision support systems in healthcare has raised concerns about the transparency and explainability of these models. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that provides interpretable explanations for AI-driven decision making in healthcare. Our HAN model leverages attention mechanisms to identify critical patient features and clinical concepts that influence the prediction. We evaluate our approach on a real-world Electronic Health Record (EHR) dataset and demonstrate improved model interpretability and accuracy compared to traditional machine learning models.

title: Exploring Co-Design of Augmented Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technologies have the potential to support older adults with cognitive impairments, but current interfaces often neglect their unique needs. This paper presents a co-design approach that involves older adults with cognitive impairments as active participants in the design process. We conducted a series of workshops and interviews to identify key challenges and opportunities for AR interface design. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, consistency, and personalized feedback in AR interfaces for this population. We also propose a set of design guidelines and recommendations for future AR systems that cater to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: We propose a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous urban traffic management. Our approach, called 'TrafficMAgent', coordinates the actions of multiple traffic agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. Each agent learns to make decisions based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents, while a centralized controller provides high-level guidance. We evaluate TrafficMAgent in a simulated urban traffic scenario and demonstrate improved traffic throughput and reduced travel times compared to traditional traffic management strategies.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of retrieving relevant products from massive catalogs in response to user queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach, which leverages both semantic and syntactic features to disambiguate user intent. Our HQE method incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively expand query terms based on their importance in the product catalog. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision, recall, and query latency.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodied Conversational Agents on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effect of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) on user experience in virtual reality (VR) environments. We designed and implemented a VR-based platform that integrates ECAs with varying levels of anthropomorphism and explored their influence on user engagement, trust, and cognitive load. Our results show that ECAs with moderate anthropomorphism lead to improved user experience, while highly realistic or cartoonish agents negatively impact user interaction. We also identify significant correlations between ECA design and user personality traits, highlighting the need for personalized ECA adaptations in VR applications.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for more natural and efficient human-computer interaction methods. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction in AR, focusing on the analysis of eye movement patterns. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, collecting eye-tracking data and subjective feedback on various gaze-based interaction techniques. Our results show that a combination of dwell-time and gaze-direction-based selection outperforms traditional methods in terms of accuracy and user satisfaction. We also identify key challenges and opportunities for future research in this area.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Augmented Reality in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent in industrial settings, traditional input methods are no longer sufficient. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interface, 'GazeAR', designed specifically for industrial AR applications. By leveraging eye-tracking technology and machine learning algorithms, GazeAR enables users to interact with virtual objects in a natural and intuitive manner. We evaluate the performance and usability of GazeAR in a real-world industrial scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for real-time traffic control using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'TRAFFIC-RL', where each agent learns to adjust traffic signal timings based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach leverages a hierarchical architecture to balance global optimality with local responsiveness, achieving improved traffic flow and reduced congestion. Experiments on a large-scale traffic simulation demonstrate the effectiveness of TRAFFIC-RL in adapting to dynamic traffic patterns and outperforming traditional optimization methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS), optimizing query performance for multiple tenants becomes a crucial challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MultiOpt', which leverages tenant workload patterns and resource utilization to minimize query latency. MultiOpt incorporates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group similar tenant workloads and a cost-based optimizer to select the most efficient query plans. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world DBaaS platform shows that MultiOpt reduces average query latency by up to 35% compared to traditional optimization techniques, while ensuring fairness and isolation among tenants.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Hierarchical Query Rewriting in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data. However, query performance remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of query processing across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Query Rewriting (HQR) framework that optimizes query execution in DIR systems. HQR employs a hierarchical clustering approach to group nodes based on their data distributions, and rewrites queries to minimize communication overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HQR achieves significant improvements in query response time and reduces network traffic by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Planning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning is a challenging task, particularly in complex, dynamic environments. Explainability is crucial for real-world adoption, but most existing methods sacrifice transparency for performance. This paper presents HAN-MAP, a hierarchical attention network that integrates planning and explanation in a unified framework. HAN-MAP leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents, actions, and contexts, generating interpretable plans and explanations. Our experiments on a diverse range of scenarios demonstrate that HAN-MAP achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful explanations, enabling more effective human-agent collaboration.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multimedia Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multimedia retrieval systems often struggle to capture the complexity of user queries, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of both queries and documents. Our method, called 'NeuroQE', combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a recurrent neural network (RNN) to model the visual and textual features of multimedia documents, respectively. Experimental results on a large-scale image dataset demonstrate that NeuroQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, improving mean average precision by up to 23.7%.

title: Sparse Attention Mechanisms for Efficient Deep Learning on Resource-Constrained Devices
paper_abstract: The growing demand for AI applications on resource-constrained devices necessitates the development of efficient deep learning models. This paper proposes a novel sparse attention mechanism, 'SparseAtt', which reduces computational overhead by selectively allocating attention weights to input features. We employ a learnable thresholding function to dynamically prune attention weights, achieving significant memory and computational savings. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that SparseAtt outperforms state-of-the-art efficient attention mechanisms while maintaining comparable accuracy to standard attention-based models.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks with Sparse Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems rely on hand-crafted features and linear models, which struggle to capture complex semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network architecture, 'SparseDoc', that learns sparse embeddings for efficient document retrieval. By leveraging a combination of convolutional and recurrent layers, SparseDoc captures both local and global patterns in document representations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SparseDoc outperforms state-of-the-art IR models in terms of retrieval accuracy and query latency, while reducing the dimensionality of document embeddings by up to 90%.

title: Accelerating Query Processing on Distributed Databases using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Distributed databases face significant query processing overhead due to the need to coordinate data access across multiple nodes. Learned index structures have shown promise in improving query performance on centralized databases. This paper explores the application of learned index structures in distributed database settings. We propose a novel distributed learned index framework, 'DistriLex', which leverages parallel processing and data partitioning to accelerate query execution. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that DistriLex achieves up to 3x query performance gains compared to traditional indexing techniques, while maintaining acceptable storage overhead.

title: Hierarchical Gaussian Process Regression for Uncertainty-Aware Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a crucial task in many applications, but existing methods often neglect uncertainty estimation. This paper introduces Hierarchical Gaussian Process Regression (HGPR), a novel Bayesian approach that models complex temporal dependencies and provides uncertainty quantification. HGPR leverages a hierarchical structure to jointly learn local and global patterns, enabling accurate predictions and uncertainty estimation. We evaluate HGPR on several real-world datasets, demonstrating its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of predictive performance and uncertainty calibration.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Stores using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed column-stores have become increasingly popular for large-scale data analytics. However, query optimization remains a challenging problem due to the complex interactions between storage layouts, query patterns, and resource constraints. This paper proposes a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework, 'DynaOpt', to optimize query execution plans for distributed column-stores. DynaOpt integrates a query simulator, a DRL agent, and a knowledge graph to learn optimal query plans that minimize execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DynaOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x speedup and 2x resource reduction.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of decentralized task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have diverse capabilities and tasks require varying levels of resources. We propose a novel approach based on graph attention networks (GATs) that learns to represent agents and tasks as nodes in a graph, and computes attention weights to capture their relationships. Our decentralized algorithm, 'GAT-Allocator', allows agents to communicate and negotiate task assignments in a distributed manner, while minimizing global objective functions such as makespan and energy consumption. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse logistics scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of GAT-Allocator in achieving near-optimal task allocations compared to centralized solvers.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interface Design
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed human-computer interaction, but the design of intuitive interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the application of embodied cognition theory to gesture-based interface design in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, comparing three interface conditions: gesture-only, gesture-plus-haptic feedback, and gesture-plus-visual cues. Results show that incorporating haptic feedback significantly enhances user performance and reduces cognitive load. We also identified key design implications, including the importance of gesture naturalness and feedback timing. Our findings have implications for the development of more immersive and usable VR interfaces.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic control in urban areas is a complex problem that requires efficient coordination of multiple agents. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for multi-agent systems, where each agent learns to optimize its own reward function while taking into account the actions of other agents. We introduce a novel graph-based representation of the traffic network, which enables efficient communication and coordination between agents. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network show that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized control methods in terms of reducing congestion and travel time.

title: Multi-Task Learning for Few-Shot Intent Detection and Slot Filling in Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Despite advances in conversational AI, few-shot intent detection and slot filling remain challenging tasks, especially when dealing with scarce annotated data. This paper proposes a novel multi-task learning framework, 'FS-IDSF', which jointly learns intent detection and slot filling in a few-shot setting. Our approach leverages a meta-learning strategy to adapt to new intents and slots, and incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to effectively capture context-dependent relationships between intents and slots. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that FS-IDSF outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot intent detection and slot filling, achieving improved accuracy and robustness.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms face significant challenges in optimizing query performance for multiple tenants with diverse workloads. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning (RL) to query optimization in DBaaS environments. We propose a novel RL framework, 'RL-Optimizer', which learns to optimize queries based on feedback from the database and workload characteristics. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world DBaaS platform shows that RL-Optimizer outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality using Deep Learning-based Eye Tracking
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology advances, natural and intuitive interaction mechanisms become crucial. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for AR, leveraging deep learning-based eye tracking. Our approach utilizes a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect and track eye movements, achieving high accuracy and robustness in various lighting conditions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our system through a user study, showcasing improved task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods. The proposed system has significant implications for enhancing the AR experience in various applications, including gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Proximity-Aware Document Ranking with Graph-Based Neural Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document ranking models in information retrieval rely on hand-crafted features and ignore the structural relationships between documents. We propose a novel graph-based neural network approach, ProxRank, which incorporates proximity information and document relationships to improve ranking accuracy. ProxRank models document similarity as a graph and leverages graph convolutional networks to learn a representation that captures both local and global document relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ProxRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational overhead by 30%.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but designing effective user interfaces remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience in VR. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment with 120 participants, using a custom-built VR platform and a range of avatar customization options. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly enhance user engagement, sense of presence, and overall satisfaction. We also identify key design factors influencing these effects, including avatar facial similarity and body type congruence. The findings have important implications for the design of future VR systems and applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Semi-Supervised Node Classification
paper_abstract: Semi-supervised node classification is a fundamental problem in graph-structured data, where a small portion of nodes are labeled. Existing graph neural network (GNN) models often suffer from scalability issues and fail to capture complex hierarchical relationships between nodes. This paper presents HGAN, a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network that leverages a multi-resolution graph representation to efficiently aggregate node features and attention weights. Experimental results on large-scale datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art GNN models in terms of node classification accuracy and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years. However, most ERS methods rely on simplistic user-item interaction graphs, neglecting complex relationships between items. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework, which leverages multi-hop graph attention to capture subtle item relationships and generate personalized recommendations. We introduce a novel explainability module that highlights important item features contributing to the recommendation. Extensive experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of HAGNN in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Contextualized Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the semantic gap between user queries and relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages deep contextualized embeddings to enhance query expansion for ad-hoc retrieval. Our method, dubbed 'EmbEx', utilizes a pre-trained language model to generate contextualized embeddings for query terms and expansion candidates. These embeddings are then used to compute a semantic similarity measure, which is integrated into a ranking model to re-weight the expanded query terms. Experimental results on several standard TREC datasets demonstrate that EmbEx significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a relative improvement of up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Re-ranking and Query Expansion
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel neural re-ranking approach for document retrieval, which leverages query expansion to improve the accuracy of search results. Our method, dubbed 'NeuRank', employs a deep neural network to learn a semantic representation of queries and documents, and then re-ranks the initial retrieval results based on their relevance scores. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuRank outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving significant improvements in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its accessibility for users with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We propose a set of guidelines for VR developers, incorporating insights from accessibility experts, user studies, and cognitive psychology. Our evaluation of three VR applications demonstrates the effectiveness of our framework in improving user experience and reducing barriers for users with disabilities.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often struggle with efficient task allocation due to the complexity of coordinating heterogeneous agents. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities and preferences. Our framework, 'HARVEST', uses a decentralized Q-learning algorithm to learn the optimal task assignments, taking into account the dynamic environment and agent interactions. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that HARVEST significantly outperforms traditional allocation methods, achieving up to 35% reduction in task completion time and 25% increase in overall system efficiency.

title: Towards Efficient Multi-Agent Coordination in Dynamic Environments using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coordinating agents to achieve a common goal is a challenging problem, especially in dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective coordination strategies. We propose a framework that represents the agent-environment interaction as a graph, and uses GNNs to learn agent embeddings that capture their spatial relationships and task dependencies. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, where we demonstrate improved coordination efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions compared to traditional planning-based methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Incentive-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to the decentralized nature of decision-making. This paper proposes an incentive-based mechanism that leverages agents' self-interest to allocate tasks efficiently. We design a novel auction protocol that allows agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. The protocol incorporates a reputation system to promote cooperation and punishes agents for misbehavior. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning on Graph-Structured Data
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning on graph-structured data remains a challenging problem due to the limited availability of labeled data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages the hierarchical structure of graphs to learn more effective representations for few-shot learning tasks. HGAT uses a graph attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges at each hierarchy level, enabling the model to adapt to novel graph structures with limited training data. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot learning on graph-structured data, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Question Embeddings for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant texts for answer extraction. This paper presents a novel hierarchical question embedding (HQE) framework that captures multi-granular semantic relationships between questions and passages. Our approach leverages a transformer-based encoder to generate hierarchical representations of questions, which are then used to retrieve top-k passages from a large corpus. Experimental results on the Natural Questions benchmark demonstrate that HQE-based passage retrieval outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12.3% improvement in top-1 passage accuracy while reducing retrieval time by 30%.

title: Designing Intelligent Gesture Recognition Systems for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents an HCI-driven approach to designing intelligent gesture recognition systems for elderly users with cognitive impairments. We conducted a user-centered design study with 20 participants, identifying key challenges and opportunities for gesture-based interaction. Our system, 'EasyGesture', utilizes machine learning algorithms to recognize and adapt to individual users' gesture patterns, incorporating feedback mechanisms to enhance user confidence and accuracy. Evaluation results show significant improvements in gesture recognition rates and user satisfaction compared to existing systems, highlighting the potential for EasyGesture to support independent living for elderly individuals with cognitive impairments.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Dense Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies heavily on accurate passage retrieval to identify relevant contexts. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical dense representation approach, called HierDPR, which significantly improves the efficiency and effectiveness of passage retrieval. By leveraging a hierarchical architecture and dense passage representations, HierDPR reduces the dimensionality of the search space and enables faster nearest-neighbor search. Experimental results on popular ODQA datasets demonstrate that HierDPR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both retrieval accuracy and query latency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Diverse Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it can significantly impact the quality of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'RL-EXPAND', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the expansion process. RL-EXPAND learns to select the most informative terms to add to the original query, taking into account the diversity of the retrieved documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-EXPAND outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving higher recall and precision while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial technique for AI applications, but existing methods struggle to capture complex relationships between entities. We propose HiGAT, a novel KGE framework that leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to model entity relationships at different granularity levels. HiGAT uses a stacked attention mechanism to aggregate features from neighboring entities, enabling the capture of both local and global structural patterns. Our experiments on benchmark datasets show that HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in link prediction and entity classification tasks, while reducing computational cost.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Deep Learning-based Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Relevance feedback is a powerful technique for improving the accuracy of information retrieval systems. However, existing methods rely on manual user input, which can be time-consuming and labor-intensive. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach that leverages user feedback to automatically refine document filtering. Our model, called 'DeepRF', incorporates a hierarchical neural network that learns to encode user preferences from a small set of labeled examples. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepRF outperforms state-of-the-art filtering methods, achieving a 25% improvement in precision at the top-10 ranked documents.

title: Multi-Task Learning for Efficient Deep Neural Network Pruning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their large size and computational requirements hinder their deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a novel multi-task learning framework for efficient DNN pruning, dubbed 'MTLP'. MTLP jointly optimizes multiple tasks, including the primary task and auxiliary tasks that promote sparsity and regularization. We demonstrate that MTLP outperforms existing pruning methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency on several benchmark datasets. Additionally, we provide theoretical insights into the convergence properties of MTLP.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can manipulate the output of the model. While various defense mechanisms have been proposed, detecting these attacks remains a challenging task. In this paper, we introduce a novel approach that leverages hierarchical graph attention to identify adversarial attacks. Our method represents the DNN as a hierarchical graph, where each node corresponds to a neuron, and uses attention mechanisms to identify suspicious patterns in the graph. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance in detecting adversarial attacks, outperforming existing methods by a significant margin.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in image classification tasks, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that enables explainable image classification. Our approach combines attention modules at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant regions and features, generating attention maps that provide insights into the decision-making process. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate improved accuracy and interpretability compared to existing attention-based models.

title: Scalable Data Integration using Multi-Resolution Histograms for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Data integration across distributed databases is a crucial task in modern data processing. However, it is often hindered by the complexity of data heterogeneity and the lack of scalable integration methods. This paper proposes a novel approach to data integration using multi-resolution histograms (MRHs), which enables efficient and scalable data integration across distributed databases. MRHs allow for flexible data representation at multiple resolutions, enabling efficient data summarization and integration. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through experiments on real-world datasets, showcasing improved data integration performance and reduced computational overhead.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Histograms in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems often struggle with query optimization due to inaccurate data distribution estimates. This paper introduces 'AdaptHist', a novel adaptive histogram approach that dynamically updates data distribution statistics based on query feedback. We present a probabilistic model that captures the uncertainty in data distribution and adaptively refines histogram buckets to minimize query errors. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database setup demonstrate that AdaptHist achieves up to 30% improvement in query performance and 25% reduction in query latency compared to traditional histogram-based approaches.

title: Designing Intuitive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults Using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need to design user interfaces that are accessible and usable for older adults. This paper presents a machine learning-based approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that can adapt to the unique needs and abilities of older adults. We propose a novel gesture recognition system that leverages a probabilistic modeling approach to identify gestures that are most intuitive for older adults. Our user study with 30 older adults reveals that our system achieves a significant reduction in error rates and improves overall user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture recognition systems.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Big Data Analytics
paper_abstract: The increasing scale and complexity of big data analytics necessitate efficient indexing techniques for multi-dimensional range queries. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, 'HierCube', which leverages hierarchical clustering and cube-based indexing to accelerate query processing. HierCube adaptively partitions the data space into dense and sparse regions, reducing the number of candidate points to be evaluated. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HierCube outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 3x faster query performance and 2x better storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used to manage large-scale datasets. However, efficient querying of multi-dimensional data remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'MDR-Tree', which enables fast range queries in DDS. MDR-Tree leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to partition the data space, reducing the number of nodes to be traversed during query execution. Experiments on a real-world climate dataset demonstrate that MDR-Tree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 3x faster query response times and 2x better storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Improving Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and heuristics. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using reinforcement learning (RL), where an agent learns to select the most informative expansion terms by interacting with the retrieval environment. We propose a reward function that incorporates both relevance and diversity metrics, and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets. Our experiments show that the RL-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including those based on word embeddings and topic models.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies via Multi-Agent Games
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable successes in various applications, including game playing and robotics. However, the robustness of DRL policies against adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel framework for enhancing the adversarial robustness of DRL policies via multi-agent games. We introduce a new type of adversary, called the 'robustness tester', which is trained to perturb the environment in a way that maximizes the policy's uncertainty. We show that our approach improves the robustness of DRL policies in various environments, including Atari games and robotic manipulation tasks.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods rely on bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between documents. This paper introduces Hierarchical Neural Document Embeddings (HNDE), a novel approach that leverages hierarchical transformers to learn document representations. HNDE captures both local and global context, enabling efficient and accurate retrieval of relevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods, particularly for long-document retrieval tasks.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines are increasingly used to index large volumes of documents. However, query expansion techniques, which improve retrieval accuracy, can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE', that leverages the parallel processing capabilities of distributed systems. HQE adaptively selects the most informative terms from the query context and reweights them based on their relevance to the original query. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that HQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and accuracy compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults: A Multimodal Approach
paper_abstract: This paper presents a multimodal approach to designing voice-based interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, exploring the impact of cognitive decline on voice interaction. Our findings highlight the importance of incorporating visual and tactile feedback to compensate for declining auditory abilities. We propose a novel interface framework, 'VoiceAssist', which leverages machine learning-based speech recognition, gaze-tracking, and haptic feedback to facilitate intuitive communication. A usability evaluation demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to conventional voice assistants.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on effective passage retrieval to identify relevant contexts for answer extraction. This paper proposes a hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) approach that leverages multi-granular dense representations to efficiently retrieve passages from a large corpus. Our method combines a coarse-grained retriever with a fine-grained ranker, allowing for efficient pruning of irrelevant passages while preserving accuracy. Experimental results on popular ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that HDR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods in terms of both retrieval quality and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become ubiquitous in modern online services, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that incorporates both item-level and user-level graph attention mechanisms. By learning hierarchical representations of user-item interactions, HGAT provides interpretable recommendations while achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in providing personalized explanations for recommended items, improving user satisfaction and trust in the system.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in Information Retrieval (IR) where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Despite the success of traditional ranking models, they often struggle to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network architecture, 'DeepRank', that leverages the strengths of both neural networks and traditional ranking models. DeepRank combines a query-document interaction module with a neural ranking module to learn a robust and efficient ranking function. Our experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DeepRank outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and query processing time.

title: Efficient Concurrency Control for Real-Time Database Systems using Adaptive Transaction Scheduling
paper_abstract: Real-time database systems require efficient concurrency control mechanisms to ensure predictable and timely transaction processing. Traditional locking-based approaches can lead to performance bottlenecks and increased latency. This paper proposes a novel adaptive transaction scheduling framework, 'ARTS', which leverages machine learning-based predictive modeling to dynamically adjust transaction priorities and resource allocation. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world industrial control system dataset demonstrates that ARTS outperforms state-of-the-art concurrency control algorithms in terms of throughput, latency, and fairness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal sentiment analysis, which involves jointly processing textual and visual cues, has become increasingly important in social media analytics. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that captures complex relationships between modalities and sentiment expressions. Our HGAT model consists of two graph attention layers: the first layer aggregates node representations across modalities, while the second layer refines sentiment predictions by modeling relationships between nodes. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of sentiment accuracy and robustness to noisy inputs.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graphs using Parallel Hashing
paper_abstract: The increasing availability of large-scale RDF graphs has created a need for efficient query optimization techniques. This paper presents a novel parallel hashing approach for optimizing SPARQL queries on distributed RDF graphs. Our method leverages the properties of RDF data to minimize data transfer and reduce query execution time. We evaluate our approach using a real-world RDF dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to existing sequential hashing methods. The proposed technique is particularly useful for applications requiring fast querying of large RDF graphs, such as knowledge graphs and linked data.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to rank documents relevant to a given query. This paper proposes a novel approach, HierRank, which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to model the relationships between documents and queries. By incorporating both local and global graph structures, HierRank captures nuanced semantic patterns and improves ranking performance. Experiments on several standard benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of HierRank, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Study on Accessibility and Usability
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their accessibility and usability for older adults remain understudied. This paper presents a participatory study involving 20 older adults (65+ years) in the co-design of an inclusive voice assistant. We employed a mixed-methods approach, combining surveys, interviews, and usability testing to identify key accessibility barriers and design recommendations. Our findings highlight the importance of customization options, clear feedback mechanisms, and consideration of age-related cognitive and sensory changes. We propose a set of guidelines for designing voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults, promoting digital inclusion and independent living.

title: Efficient Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning using Model-Agnostic Saliency Maps
