paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents have achieved remarkable success in complex tasks, but their lack of transparency hinders their deployment in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel, model-agnostic approach to explainability in DRL, leveraging saliency maps to identify the most relevant state features contributing to an agent's decisions. Our method, 'Saliency-RL', is applicable to various DRL architectures and outperforms existing attribution methods in terms of fidelity and computational efficiency. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Saliency-RL in a range of Atari games and a real-world autonomous driving scenario, providing insights into the decision-making processes of DRL agents.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Real-World Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has revolutionized autonomous systems, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders trust and adoption. This paper addresses the challenge of explaining DRL agents' behavior in real-world scenarios. We propose a novel model-agnostic explainability technique, 'RL-X', which leverages attention mechanisms and attribution methods to provide interpretable insights into the agent's policy. Our approach is shown to improve the understanding of DRL agents' decisions in complex environments, such as autonomous driving and robotics, without compromising their performance.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Dense Embeddings
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant context for answering questions. This paper presents a novel approach, DensePass, which leverages dense embeddings to index and search a large corpus of passages. We propose a hierarchical clustering method to construct a compact index, enabling fast and accurate passage retrieval. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that DensePass outperforms existing methods, achieving a 2.5x speedup while maintaining a 95% recall rate.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Multi-Modal Retrieval in E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of retrieving relevant products from large catalogs, often involving multi-modal queries (e.g., text, images). This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'MMR-NRM', which integrates visual and textual features using a hierarchical attention mechanism. MMR-NRM leverages a triplet-based training approach, enabling efficient optimization and improved ranking performance. Experiments on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that MMR-NRM outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of recall, precision, and computational efficiency.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to enhance query expansion. We introduce a neural network architecture that learns to represent queries and documents in a shared semantic space, enabling more effective query expansion through semantic similarity matching. Experimental results on several TREC benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for task allocation in multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'MARL-TA', enables agents to learn coordination strategies and allocate tasks efficiently in dynamic environments. We introduce a decentralized actor-critic architecture that combines local and global rewards to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional optimization methods and achieves significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for real-time task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework that enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task allocation and execution. Our method leverages a multi-agent deep Q-network (MA-DQN) that incorporates a graph neural network (GNN) to model agent interactions and task dependencies. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time, resource utilization, and robustness to agent failures. We validate our approach using a realistic simulation environment and a real-world case study.

title: Efficient Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Graph-based recommendation systems have shown promising results, but their computational complexity hinders their adoption in large-scale applications. We propose a novel graph attention network, 'GraphLite', that leverages sparse attention mechanisms and hierarchical graph pooling to reduce computational overhead. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmark datasets while reducing inference time by up to 75%. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the approximation error of GraphLite and demonstrate its scalability on a real-world e-commerce dataset.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: The growing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has raised concerns about their vulnerability to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). We model the AV's sensor data as a graph and leverage GCNs to learn a robust representation of the vehicle's state. Our approach can detect subtle perturbations in the sensor data, indicative of an adversarial attack. Experimental results on a large-scale AV dataset show that our method outperforms traditional anomaly detection techniques, achieving a detection accuracy of 95.2% with a false positive rate of 2.1%

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Self-Organizing Agents for Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation in dynamic environments, leveraging self-organizing agents that adapt to changing task requirements and resource availability. Our algorithm, SOAT, uses a decentralized, gossip-based protocol to enable agents to autonomously negotiate and allocate tasks, minimizing communication overhead and maximizing system efficiency. We evaluate SOAT in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced response times compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional time series data is a challenging task, particularly when dealing with large datasets. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, 'HiCAD', which leverages the strengths of both self-supervised learning and anomaly detection. HiCAD employs a hierarchical clustering approach to group similar time series segments, and then applies contrastive learning to learn robust representations that distinguish normal patterns from anomalies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiCAD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems are increasingly popular in cloud computing, but they pose significant challenges in terms of query performance optimization. Traditional approaches rely on manual tuning and heuristics, which can be time-consuming and ineffective. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach, 'ML-Optimizer', which uses supervised learning to predict optimal query plans for diverse workloads. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that ML-Optimizer outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Explainable Attributions in Deep Reinforcement Learning via Contrastive Regularization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents have achieved impressive results, but their decision-making processes remain opaque. To address this, we introduce a novel approach, ContraX, which incorporates contrastive regularization into the policy optimization process. ContraX encourages the agent to learn attributions that distinguish between successful and failed trajectories, thereby providing human-interpretable explanations for its actions. We evaluate ContraX on a range of Atari games and demonstrate significant improvements in both policy performance and attribution quality. Our results have important implications for the development of transparent and trustworthy AI systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face the challenge of optimizing query processing across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach using reinforcement learning (RL) to minimize query latency and maximize throughput. Our method, 'RL-Optimizer', learns to select the optimal query plan based on node workload, network latency, and data distribution. We evaluate RL-Optimizer on a large-scale DIR system and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance compared to traditional rule-based optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, but they often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that efficiently generates explanations for recommended items. Our approach leverages a hierarchical self-attention mechanism to identify relevant item features and user preferences, enabling the model to focus on the most important aspects of the recommendation process. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HAN achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing transparent and interpretable explanations for recommended items.

title: Revisiting Mid-Air Gestures for Intelligent Home Automation
paper_abstract: Recent advancements in computer vision and machine learning have revitalized interest in mid-air gesture recognition for intelligent home automation. This paper presents a novel framework, ' GestureHome', which leverages a fusion of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to recognize and interpret complex gestures in real-time. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating a significant reduction in gesture recognition errors and improved user experience compared to existing approaches. Our framework is particularly suited for applications in smart home environments, where intuitive and hands-free control is essential.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with complex queries. This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, 'QueryGraph', which represents queries as graph structures to capture semantic relationships between entities and keywords. By incorporating a graph attention mechanism, QueryGraph can selectively focus on relevant query aspects and effectively aggregate evidence from different document regions. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and efficiency over state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Adaptive Task Allocation for Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating autonomous agents in dynamic environments is a challenging problem due to the uncertainty and variability of task requirements. This paper presents a novel adaptive task allocation framework, 'ATA-E', which leverages machine learning to predict task demands and adjust agent assignments in real-time. Our approach integrates a decentralized Markov decision process (MDP) with a graph neural network (GNN) to facilitate efficient communication and coordination among agents. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that ATA-E outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization, while adapting to changes in the environment.

title: Adaptive Coalition Formation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial task that involves grouping agents to achieve common goals. However, the dynamic nature of real-world environments and the need for adaptability in coalition structures pose significant challenges. This paper presents a novel framework, 'DeepCoal', that leverages deep graph reinforcement learning to enable adaptive coalition formation. Our approach represents the agent interaction graph as a dynamic graph neural network, which learns to predict coalition values and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DeepCoal outperforms traditional graph-based coalition formation methods, achieving higher coalition values and faster adaptation to changing circumstances.

title: Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, as it affects the accuracy of subsequent applications. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GATE', which leverages graph attention networks to disambiguate entities in knowledge graphs. GATE utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global context, allowing it to effectively differentiate between entities with similar names. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GATE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in disambiguation accuracy.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to rank documents in response to a user query. While neural models have shown promise in this area, they often rely on expensive query-document interaction mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel approach, Neural Query Graphs (NQG), which represents queries as graphs and leverages graph neural networks to learn efficient document ranking. NQG significantly reduces the computational cost of query-document interactions while achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. We also explore the interpretability of NQG, demonstrating that the learned query graphs capture meaningful semantic relationships between query terms.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalization Strategies for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their lack of personalization often excludes users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop inclusive voice assistants that cater to diverse abilities. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, including individuals with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive impairments, to identify key challenges and preferences. Our findings inform the design of three personalization strategies: adaptive speech recognition, multimodal output, and customizable feedback mechanisms. We evaluate these strategies through a usability study, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for users with disabilities.

title: Query Expansion via Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with ambiguous or incomplete queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using hierarchical document embeddings. Our method, called HiDE, represents documents as a hierarchy of semantic clusters, which are then used to expand the query through a relevance-based clustering algorithm. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiDE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We propose a novel hierarchical framework for task allocation in multi-agent systems, leveraging deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. Our approach, called HMA-RL, consists of two stages: a high-level task decomposition stage, which partitions tasks into sub-tasks using a hierarchical clustering algorithm, and a low-level task allocation stage, which uses a deep Q-network to assign sub-tasks to agents. Experimental results on a simulated multi-robot scenario demonstrate that HMA-RL outperforms existing task allocation methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and system adaptability to dynamic changes.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Accessible Virtual Reality Navigation
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but existing navigation methods can be inaccessible to people with disabilities. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interface, 'GazeNav', which enables users to navigate virtual environments using only their eye movements. We propose a machine learning model that predicts the user's intended navigation direction based on their gaze patterns and pupil dilation. Our user study with 20 participants shows that GazeNav outperforms traditional joystick-based navigation in terms of accuracy and user satisfaction, and is particularly beneficial for individuals with mobility impairments.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Multimodal Input for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interaction modalities often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a multimodal input framework for voice assistants that incorporates gesture, gaze, and facial expression recognition to enable more inclusive interaction. We conducted a user study with participants with varying abilities and found that our framework improved task completion rates by 30% compared to traditional voice-only input. We discuss the design implications and trade-offs of our approach and provide guidelines for future research on accessible voice assistants.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroXpand', which leverages neural semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and relevant documents. By integrating a pre-trained language model with a custom-designed semantic similarity metric, our method generates high-quality expansion terms that improve retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant gains in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain over state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Task Decomposition for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Stochastic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the problem of task decomposition in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) settings with stochastic environments. We propose a hierarchical task decomposition framework, 'HTD-MARL', which enables agents to learn complex tasks by recursively breaking them down into simpler sub-tasks. Our approach leverages a novel hierarchical graph neural network to model the task dependencies and agent interactions. Experimental results on a suite of challenging MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HTD-MARL achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system efficiency compared to existing MARL methods.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Accurate question answering over knowledge graphs (KGs) has become increasingly important. However, existing methods struggle to handle complex, multi-hop questions. This paper proposes a novel KG embedding approach, 'HierAttKG', which leverages hierarchical attention to model relationships between entities and predicates at different levels of abstraction. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierAttKG outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 10% in terms of answer accuracy, while reducing the number of required model parameters by 30%. We also show that HierAttKG can be easily integrated into existing question answering frameworks, making it a promising solution for real-world applications.

title: Efficient Indexing for Proximity Search in High-Dimensional Spaces
paper_abstract: Proximity search is a fundamental operation in many applications, including recommender systems, computer vision, and data mining. However, as the dimensionality of the data increases, traditional indexing methods suffer from the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, Hierarchical Proximity Tree (HPT), which leverages the properties of hierarchical clustering to efficiently prune the search space. We theoretically analyze the performance of HPT and demonstrate its superiority over existing methods on several real-world datasets.

title: Enhancing Document Representation with Hierarchical Graph Attention for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document representation methods in information retrieval (IR) systems often neglect the complex relationships between entities and concepts. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention (HGA) framework, which models documents as hierarchical graphs to capture both local and global semantic dependencies. Our approach learns to recursively aggregate node representations using attention mechanisms, enabling more accurate retrieval of relevant documents. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, especially for complex queries.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promising results in enhancing learning experiences, but user engagement remains a crucial challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR-based learning environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a customized avatar that reflected their physical appearance, interests, and learning style. Our results indicate that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, motivation, and overall learning outcomes compared to generic avatars. We also identify key factors influencing user-avatar bonding, including avatar likability, realism, and agency. These findings have implications for the design of immersive learning systems that leverage personalized avatars to facilitate deeper user involvement.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for E-commerce Product Search using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: E-commerce product search often relies on simplistic query matching, leading to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HQE-Prod', which leverages deep learning to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and product attributes. HQE-Prod uses a novel attention-based neural network to generate a weighted set of expansion terms, which are then combined using a probabilistic scoring function. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HQE-Prod significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, improving mean average precision by 23.4% and reducing search latency by 15.6%.

title: EyeType: A Gaze-Based Text Entry System for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges in interacting with computers. This paper presents EyeType, a novel gaze-based text entry system that leverages deep learning-based gaze estimation and probabilistic language modeling. EyeType achieves an average text entry rate of 15.6 words per minute with an accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming existing gaze-based systems. We also propose a novel calibration-free approach that adapts to individual eye movement patterns, ensuring high system usability. A user study with 12 participants with motor impairments demonstrates the effectiveness of EyeType in facilitating efficient and accurate text entry.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Enhancing Cognitive Load Management in Interactive Systems
paper_abstract: Cognitive load management is crucial in interactive systems, as excessive load can lead to user frustration and decreased performance. This paper presents a novel framework for adaptive visualization design, 'CogVis', which dynamically adjusts visualization complexity based on real-time user behavior and cognitive load metrics. Our approach integrates EEG-based cognitive load measurement, machine learning-driven visualization optimization, and human-centered design principles. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that CogVis significantly reduces cognitive load, improves task completion time, and enhances user experience in complex data exploration tasks.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Temporal Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex, time-varying graph data. However, optimizing queries on these databases is a challenging problem due to the inherent complexity of temporal graph structures. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach that leverages reinforcement learning to learn efficient query plans. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan. Our experimental results on a real-world temporal graph dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinated exploration in multi-agent systems is crucial for efficient task allocation and decision-making. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to represent agent interactions and environment dynamics. Our method, called CoEx-HGNN, learns to identify informative regions of the state space and allocate agents to explore these areas in a coordinated manner. Experimental results on a variety of multi-agent environments demonstrate that CoEx-HGNN outperforms existing methods in terms of exploration efficiency and task success rate.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, but existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and suboptimal ranking performance. This paper proposes a novel neural approach, Hierarchical Query Expansion Network (HQEN), which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively expand queries based on document relevance. HQEN uses a lightweight neural architecture to model query-document interactions, allowing for efficient ranking and improved retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQEN outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of both ranking quality and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Adaptive Contextualized Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but existing methods often rely on static word embeddings that fail to capture nuanced contextual relationships. This paper proposes ACE-IR, an adaptive contextualized embedding approach that leverages transformer-based language models to encode query terms and their surroundings. ACE-IR dynamically updates the embeddings based on the query context, enabling more effective expansion of relevant terms. Experimental results on the TREC benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, especially for short and ambiguous queries, compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of digital data necessitates efficient information retrieval systems. This paper presents HierRank, a novel neural ranking model for document filtering that scales to large datasets. HierRank adopts a hierarchical architecture, where coarse-grained filtering is performed using a sparse, learned index, and fine-grained ranking is achieved through a dense, neural network-based model. Experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and computational efficiency. We also analyze the performance of HierRank on a large-scale, industrial dataset, showcasing its feasibility in real-world applications.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the lives of users with motor impairments, but current systems often fail to account for the diverse range of abilities and needs within this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for developing accessible gesture recognition systems, incorporating feedback from users with motor impairments and experts in accessibility. We introduce a novel gesture recognition framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to accommodate varying levels of motor function. Our system is evaluated through a series of user studies, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of decentralized coordination in multi-agent systems, where agents with limited communication and perception capabilities need to collaborate to achieve a common goal. We propose a novel approach that combines distributed reinforcement learning with graph neural networks to enable agents to learn cooperative policies in a decentralized manner. Our approach is scalable, flexible, and robust to changes in the environment or agent failures. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient and coordinated agent behavior.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. This paper presents a novel reinforcement learning approach, 'RL-QE', which leverages a Markov decision process to optimize query expansion. Our method learns to select and weight relevant terms from a knowledge graph, outperforming traditional techniques based on statistical analysis. We demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-QE on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CATARINA', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignment among agents. We model the problem as a decentralized Markov decision process and train a neural network to learn coordinated policies for each agent. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that CATARINA outperforms state-of-the-art auction-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization, while adapting to dynamic changes in the environment.

title: Query Optimization for Parallel Processing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing scale of modern datasets has led to a growing need for efficient parallel processing in distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ParaOpt', which leverages a graph-based representation of query plans to identify opportunities for parallel execution. By incorporating a cost-based optimization algorithm and a dynamic task scheduling strategy, ParaOpt achieves significant performance improvements over existing optimization techniques. Experimental results on a real-world cluster setup demonstrate that ParaOpt reduces query execution times by up to 45% for complex analytical workloads.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Multimodal Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of virtual reality (VR) technology, providing effective feedback to users has become crucial for an immersive experience. This paper investigates the role of multimodal feedback (combining visual, auditory, and haptic cues) in enhancing user experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study comparing three feedback conditions: unimodal visual, multimodal, and no feedback. Our results show that multimodal feedback significantly improves user performance and satisfaction in VR tasks, particularly for users with limited VR experience. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Explainable Attention Mechanisms for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has achieved significant success in various applications, but the complexity of learned policies hinders interpretability. This paper introduces a novel explainable attention mechanism, 'XAttention', which provides insights into the decision-making process of MARL agents. XAttention leverages a hierarchical graph attention network to model agent interactions and a feature importance module to highlight relevant state features. Experimental results on the StarCraft II benchmark demonstrate that XAttention improves the transparency of MARL policies while maintaining competitive performance. We also provide visualizations and case studies to illustrate the explainability benefits of XAttention.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in large-scale multi-agent systems, where agents have diverse capabilities and tasks have varying priorities. We propose an auction-based mechanism, called ' ScalAuction', which enables efficient and scalable task allocation. ScalAuction uses a hierarchical auction framework to reduce communication overhead and incorporates a novel bidding strategy that takes into account agents' capabilities and task priorities. Experimental results show that ScalAuction outperforms existing mechanisms in terms of solution quality, computational efficiency, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality Environments Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for more intuitive and natural interaction methods. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for AR environments using deep learning. We propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture that predicts the user's intended target from eye-tracking data. Our approach leverages a large-scale dataset of gaze patterns and achieves state-of-the-art performance in identifying objects of interest. We demonstrate the feasibility of our system in a real-world AR application, showcasing improved user experience and reduced interaction time.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinating heterogeneous agents in complex systems, such as smart grids and traffic networks, to optimize resource allocation. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'Agent Harmony', which learns to coordinate agents with diverse capabilities and objectives. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and incorporates a hierarchical reward structure to balance individual and system-level goals. Experimental results on a real-world energy management scenario demonstrate that Agent Harmony outperforms traditional optimization methods and improves overall system efficiency by up to 25%.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Graph-Based Keyword Correlation for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a widely used technique in ad-hoc retrieval to improve the retrieval performance. However, existing QE methods often rely on simple term co-occurrence or frequency-based approaches, which may not capture complex keyword correlations. This paper proposes a graph-based keyword correlation model (GKC) that leverages graph convolutional networks to learn dense keyword representations. GKC outperforms traditional QE methods by 12.3% in terms of mean average precision on the TREC-8 dataset. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of GKC in handling keyword ambiguity and polysemy.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Transformers for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the heterogeneity and complexity of the input data. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based transformer architecture, 'MERT', which learns to fuse and align features from different modalities. MERT employs a stacked transformer encoder to model intra-modal and inter-modal relationships, and introduces a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that MERT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multimodal emotion recognition tasks, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5%.

title: Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data using Graph-based Autoencoders
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. Existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering or supervised learning, which can be time-consuming and require large labeled datasets. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised approach, Graph-AE, which leverages graph-based autoencoders to learn a compact representation of time-series data. By reconstructing the graph structure, our method detects anomalies as nodes with high reconstruction error. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of Graph-AE in identifying anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforced Semantic Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on simple term co-occurrence or manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'RSGE', which leverages reinforced semantic graph embeddings to learn query-specific expansions. Our method represents queries and documents as graph-structured semantic embeddings, and uses reinforcement learning to optimize the expansion process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RSGE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval in Large-Scale Collections
paper_abstract: The increasing scale of document collections has made efficient retrieval a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HiNeR, which leverages both local and global document representations to improve retrieval efficiency. HiNeR uses a cascade of neural ranking models, each operating on a subset of the collection, to prune irrelevant documents and focus on the most relevant ones. Experimental results on several large-scale collections demonstrate that HiNeR achieves significant improvements in both retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems to perform complex tasks is a challenging problem, particularly in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to adaptively allocate tasks among agents. Our method, dubbed 'MA-RL', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn coordinated policies that maximize task efficiency and minimize conflicts. We evaluate MA-RL on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and agent utility compared to traditional planning-based approaches.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time control systems that can adapt to complex, dynamic environments. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for autonomous vehicle control, which decomposes the control problem into a set of nested, hierarchically organized tasks. Our approach leverages a deep Q-network to learn high-level, strategic decisions, while a separate, low-level controller optimizes vehicle dynamics in real-time. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated urban driving scenario, achieving improved safety and efficiency compared to traditional, monolithic control architectures.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for smart grids using multi-agent reinforcement learning. The framework, called 'SmartAlloc', enables autonomous agents to adaptively allocate tasks in real-time, optimizing energy efficiency and reducing peak demand. We develop a novel, hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture that integrates both local and global reward signals, allowing agents to learn effective task allocation strategies in a decentralized manner. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid environment demonstrate that SmartAlloc outperforms traditional, centralized allocation methods, achieving up to 15% reduction in peak demand and 20% improvement in energy efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Task Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Dialogue management is a crucial component of conversational AI systems, requiring the integration of multiple tasks such as intent detection, slot filling, and response generation. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph-based representations to model complex dialogue structures. Our approach hierarchically aggregates node features and applies attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant dialogue context, enabling efficient multi-task learning. Experimental results on the DSTC2 and MultiWOZ datasets demonstrate that our HGAT model outperforms state-of-the-art dialogue management systems, achieving higher task accuracy and improved response quality.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous urban traffic control demands intelligent decision-making to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for multi-agent traffic control. Our approach decomposes the complex task into a hierarchical structure, consisting of high-level route planning and low-level traffic signal control. We propose a distributed asynchronous advantage actor-critic algorithm that enables efficient learning and adapts to dynamic traffic patterns. Experimental results on a realistic simulator demonstrate that our HRL framework reduces travel times by 23% and decreases congestion by 17% compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Context-Aware Document Ranking using Deep Neural Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional document ranking models often rely on handcrafted features and ignore the rich structural information present in document graphs. This paper proposes a novel context-aware document ranking framework, 'GRAPH- Rank', which leverages deep neural graph embeddings to capture semantic relationships between documents. We introduce a hierarchical graph attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of neighboring documents based on their contextual relevance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and ClueWeb09 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Caching
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems face the challenge of efficiently handling complex queries across a large number of nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical caching approach that significantly reduces query latency and improves system scalability. Our method involves caching query results at multiple levels, including node-level, cluster-level, and global-level caches. We develop a probabilistic caching policy that adaptively adjusts cache sizes based on query patterns and node availability. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that our approach reduces average query latency by 37% compared to existing caching strategies.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document embedding (HDE) framework, which captures both local and global semantic relationships within documents. Our approach leverages a combination of sentence embeddings and graph-based document representations to encode documents at multiple granularities. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDE-based passage retrieval significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of recall and computational efficiency, enabling faster and more accurate ODQA systems.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning and graph attention. We propose a decentralized framework, 'GraphMARL', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies by attending to relevant neighboring agents and their interactions. Our approach integrates a graph neural network with a multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm, allowing agents to adapt to dynamic environments and improve overall system performance. Experimental results on a simulated traffic control scenario demonstrate that GraphMARL outperforms existing methods in terms of global reward and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have become increasingly prevalent in human-computer interaction, but their underlying decision-making processes remain opaque. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for multi-modal dialogue systems, capable of generating interpretable explanations for its responses. Our approach incorporates visual and textual context through multi-modal fusion, and applies attention mechanisms at both utterance and token levels to identify salient features. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that our HAN model achieves state-of-the-art performance in response generation while providing transparent and meaningful explanations.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data using Hybrid Indexing
paper_abstract: Optimizing queries on multi-dimensional data is crucial for many applications, including data warehousing, scientific simulations, and machine learning. Existing indexing techniques, such as R-trees and quadtrees, have limitations in terms of query performance and storage efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'HiDim', which combines the strengths of different indexing methods to achieve faster query execution and reduced storage overhead. We evaluate HiDim on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query performance and storage efficiency.

title: Scalable and Interpretable Few-Shot Learning with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and interpretability. We propose Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), a novel few-shot learning framework that leverages hierarchical clustering to learn prototypical representations. HPN enables efficient inference on large datasets and provides interpretable results by learning a hierarchical structure of prototypes. Our extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HPN achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational cost by up to 75%. We also provide visualizations of the learned prototypes, offering insights into the decision-making process of the model.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Data Warehouses using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed data warehouses (DDWs) are increasingly used to store and process large amounts of data. However, optimizing queries in DDWs remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and query patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL framework that learns to select the optimal query plan based on the feedback from the environment, i.e., the DDW system. Our experimental results on a real-world DDW dataset show that our approach significantly outperforms traditional query optimization techniques in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require task allocation mechanisms to effectively distribute tasks among agents. However, existing approaches can be inflexible, leading to suboptimal performance in dynamic environments. This paper introduces Hierarchical Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning (HTA-DRL), a novel framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in a decentralized manner. HTA-DRL learns to optimize task assignments based on agent capabilities, task priorities, and environmental constraints. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HTA-DRL outperforms traditional task allocation methods in terms of response time, task completion rate, and system adaptability.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document ranking for information retrieval using deep neural networks. Our proposed method, 'DeepRank', leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to learn a robust ranking function that can capture complex contextual relationships between query terms and document content. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepRank outperforms state-of-the-art learning-to-rank models in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the model's performance on different types of queries and document collections.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Motion Planning
paper_abstract: Motion planning for autonomous vehicles requires efficient and adaptive decision-making in complex environments. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that integrates high-level decision-making with low-level motion control. Our approach leverages a hierarchical state representation to decompose the motion planning problem into manageable sub-tasks, enabling the agent to learn a rich set of skills and adapt to diverse scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate improved navigation efficiency and robustness in realistic simulations, outperforming state-of-the-art motion planning methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Star-Schema Data Warehouses using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing queries in star-schema data warehouses is crucial for efficient decision-making. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics and rule-based approaches, which often fall short in handling complex queries. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach, 'LearnOpt', which leverages query execution logs to predict optimal execution plans. We design a graph neural network that captures the structural dependencies between query operators and data distributions, enabling LearnOpt to generalize well to unseen queries. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that LearnOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query execution time, making it a promising solution for large-scale data analytics.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks and Monte Carlo Tree Search
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent planning that leverages hierarchical task networks (HTNs) and Monte Carlo tree search (MCTS). Our method, called HMA-Plan, decomposes complex tasks into smaller, manageable sub-tasks and assigns them to individual agents. We use MCTS to efficiently explore the vast search space of possible plans and prune infeasible solutions. Experimental results on a variety of benchmark domains demonstrate that HMA-Plan scales to large teams of agents and outperforms state-of-the-art planning algorithms in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Indexing
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural indexing approach for efficient document retrieval. Our method, called HNI, leverages a two-level indexing structure to reduce the dimensionality of the document representation space. The first level uses a coarse-grained neural network to cluster similar documents, while the second level employs a fine-grained network to perform similarity search within each cluster. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNI achieves significant improvements in query efficiency and accuracy compared to state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity and ambiguity of patent documents. Query expansion is a widely used technique to improve retrieval effectiveness, but traditional methods often rely on manual tuning and domain expertise. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'Patent2Vec', which leverages neural networks to learn semantic representations of patent queries and expand them with relevant terms. Our experiments on a large patent dataset demonstrate that Patent2Vec outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column Stores using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed column stores have become increasingly popular for large-scale data analytics. However, optimizing query execution plans for these systems remains a complex problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for distributed column stores. We design a Deep Q-Network (DQN) that learns to predict optimal join orders and data placement strategies based on query patterns and system metrics. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate a significant reduction in query latency and improved resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Aware Representations in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in knowledge graphs is crucial for various applications, including question answering and text analysis. However, existing approaches struggle to scale to massive graphs. We propose a novel graph-aware representation learning framework, 'GraphED', which jointly models entity and relation representations in a unified graph neural network. GraphED leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant graph neighborhoods, enabling efficient disambiguation of entities with similar names. Experiments on large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperation in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often struggle to cooperate in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce HGA-Net, a novel hierarchical graph attention network architecture that enables effective cooperation among multiple agents. HGA-Net leverages attention mechanisms to focus on relevant neighboring agents and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results on a variety of multi-agent benchmarks demonstrate that HGA-Net outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of cooperation efficiency, adaptability, and scalability.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Complex Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it directly impacts the relevance and ranking of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning (RL) framework, 'RL-EXPAND', that learns to optimize query expansion for complex IR tasks. RL-EXPAND incorporates a reward function that balances precision, recall, and query term importance, and utilizes a deep Q-network to select the most informative expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that RL-EXPAND outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in both precision and recall.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Adaptive Interfaces
paper_abstract: Personalization in human-computer interaction aims to tailor interfaces to individual users' needs and preferences. While personalization has shown promise in enhancing user engagement, its impact on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of personalization in adaptive interfaces, focusing on its effects on user satisfaction, efficiency, and cognitive load. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, using a novel adaptive interface framework that incorporates machine learning-driven personalization. Our results indicate that personalization significantly improves user satisfaction and efficiency, but may also increase cognitive load in certain contexts. We discuss the implications for HCI design and provide recommendations for balancing personalization with user experience.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: As urban populations grow, efficient traffic management becomes increasingly crucial. This paper presents 'MAATM', a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous traffic signal control. By leveraging graph neural networks and a novel communication protocol, MAATM scales to large networks and adapts to dynamic traffic patterns. Experimental results on a realistic simulation platform demonstrate significant reductions in congestion and travel times, outperforming traditional optimization methods and existing deep reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of optimizing resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that learns to allocate resources effectively in cloud environments. Our approach decomposes the resource allocation problem into a hierarchy of tasks, allowing the HRL agent to focus on high-level decisions while delegating low-level tasks to subordinate agents. We evaluate our framework on a realistic cloud simulator and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a fundamental problem in machine learning, where an instance can be associated with multiple labels simultaneously. Existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and ignore the label dependencies. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that efficiently captures label correlations and improves classification performance. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant labels and features, reducing the computational overhead. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of F1-score and inference time.

title: Scalable Indexing for Time-Series Data Warehouses using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Time-series data warehouses are increasingly used in IoT and financial applications, but indexing large-scale datasets remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'HBIndex', which leverages hierarchical Bloom filters to efficiently query and aggregate time-series data. We demonstrate that HBIndex outperforms existing indexing methods in terms of query latency and storage efficiency, while maintaining high accuracy. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset show that HBIndex can scale to tens of millions of time-series data points with minimal overhead.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on flat document representations, which fail to capture the hierarchical structure of documents. This paper proposes a novel document representation model, 'HiDR', which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to encode documents at multiple granularity levels. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiDR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency, particularly for long documents and sparse queries. We further analyze the effects of hierarchical representation on query-document matching and provide insights into the importance of contextualized representation for IR tasks.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Network-based Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a crucial information retrieval task, where query expansion (QE) is a key technique to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'DNE QE', which leverages deep neural network-based document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. Our method first generates a dense query representation using a pre-trained language model, and then uses a neural ranking model to select the most relevant expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DNE QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: EyeTrackerGAN: A Generative Adversarial Network for Eye Movement Simulation in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Eye movement simulation is crucial for realistic virtual reality (VR) experiences. Existing methods rely on simplistic heuristics or labor-intensive data collection. We propose EyeTrackerGAN, a generative adversarial network (GAN) that learns to simulate eye movements in VR from a small set of user interactions. Our GAN consists of a generator network that produces eye movement patterns and a discriminator network that evaluates their realism. Experimental results on a public VR dataset show that EyeTrackerGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of fixation accuracy and visual attention metrics, enabling more immersive and interactive VR experiences.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on User Experience and Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems are increasingly being used in various domains, but traditional input methods can hinder the overall user experience. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction as a natural and intuitive interface for VR environments. We conducted a user study to investigate the effects of gaze-based interaction on user experience, eye movement patterns, and task performance. Our results show that gaze-based interaction significantly improves user satisfaction and reduces eye movement complexity compared to traditional controller-based input. We also identify key factors influencing gaze behavior in VR, including visual attention and cognitive load.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in knowledge graphs is a challenging task, especially when dealing with ambiguous entities with similar names. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach that incorporates semantic relationships and entity co-occurrences to disambiguate entities. Our approach, called CAQE, leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of contextual entities and expand the query with relevant keywords. Experimental results on the DBpedia dataset show that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art entity disambiguation methods, achieving an average precision of 0.92 and recall of 0.88.

title: Efficient Document Representation via Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have revolutionized Information Retrieval (IR) by learning complex document representations. However, most existing approaches rely on flat, sequential encoding of documents, neglecting their inherent hierarchical structure. This paper proposes Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Ranking (HANR), a novel framework that leverages both local and global context to represent documents. HANR employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant passages, sentences, and words, leading to improved retrieval performance. Experiments on several benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of HANR, outperforming state-of-the-art neural ranking models by a significant margin.

title: Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using context-aware embeddings, which incorporate both semantic and syntactic information from the query context. Our method, dubbed 'EmbedEx', leverages a graph-based neural network to learn contextualized representations of query terms and their relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbedEx significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly in scenarios with ambiguous or underspecified queries.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Intrusion Detection System for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of IoT networks has made them vulnerable to various types of cyber threats. Traditional centralized intrusion detection systems (IDS) are often ineffective in detecting anomalies in real-time, leading to delayed response times. This paper proposes a decentralized agent-based IDS framework, 'DAID', which leverages autonomous agents to monitor and respond to threats in a distributed manner. Each agent is equipped with a machine learning-based anomaly detection module and communicates with its peers to exchange threat intelligence. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that DAID achieves a 30% improvement in detection accuracy and a 50% reduction in response time compared to traditional centralized IDS approaches.

title: Context-Aware Agent-Based Modeling for Smart Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel agent-based modeling approach for smart traffic management, which integrates context-awareness and machine learning techniques to improve traffic flow and reduce congestion. Our approach leverages real-time traffic data and sensor information to model the behavior of individual drivers, pedestrians, and vehicles as autonomous agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through simulations of various traffic scenarios, showing significant reductions in travel time and emissions compared to traditional traffic management systems.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Discovery for Improving Ad-Hoc Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the underlying intent behind a user's query, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised query intent discovery approach, 'IntentMine', which leverages a combination of semantic role labeling and clustering to identify latent intent categories from a large query log. We evaluate IntentMine on a dataset of 100,000 queries and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Additionally, we provide insights into the discovered intent categories and their implications for retrieval system design.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graph Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of large-scale RDF graph databases has led to significant query optimization challenges. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RDFox', which leverages a combination of graph partitioning, caching, and parallel execution to improve query performance in distributed RDF settings. We introduce a cost-based optimization model that takes into account the underlying graph structure, query patterns, and available system resources. Experimental evaluations on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that RDFox outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query throughput and response time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Column Stores
paper_abstract: Distributed column stores have become popular for real-time analytics due to their high storage capacity and query performance. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task, particularly when dealing with complex queries and large datasets. This paper presents 'ColOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to predict optimal query plans. We propose a hybrid approach that combines cost-based optimization with machine learning-based models to adapt to changing data distributions and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that ColOpt achieves an average query performance improvement of 30% compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Designing Adaptive Touch-Based Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Touch-based interfaces are ubiquitous in modern devices, but users with motor impairments often struggle to interact with them effectively. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'AdapTouch', a novel interface framework that dynamically adapts to the abilities and needs of users with motor impairments. We employ a machine learning-based approach to analyze the user's touch behavior and adjust the interface parameters, such as button size and sensitivity, in real-time. Our user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy and speed, as well as enhanced user satisfaction, when using AdapTouch compared to traditional interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Protein-Ligand Binding Affinity Prediction
paper_abstract: Predicting protein-ligand binding affinities is a crucial task in drug discovery and design. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) model that leverages the protein-ligand interaction graph to predict binding affinities. Our model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on critical protein-ligand interactions, and incorporates graph convolutional layers to capture local and global structural patterns. Experimental results on the PDBbind dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean absolute error and Pearson correlation coefficient.

title: Decoupling Representation and Inference for Efficient Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has seen significant advances with the development of meta-learning algorithms. However, these methods often rely on densely parameterized models, leading to high computational costs and memory requirements. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Decouple', that separates the representation learning and inference stages. By leveraging a frozen feature extractor and a lightweight, task-adaptive inference module, Decouple achieves state-of-the-art performance on popular few-shot benchmarks while reducing computational overhead by up to 75%. We analyze the trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency, providing insights into the design of scalable few-shot learning systems.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Comparative Study on Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance on various node classification tasks. However, their robustness against adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the vulnerability of GNNs to adversarial attacks on node attributes and graph structure. We propose a novel attack method, 'GraphFool', which manipulates node features and edge connections to misclassify target nodes. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphFool outperforms existing attacks, and we provide insights into the attack's effectiveness and potential defense strategies.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Dialogue
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational dialogue is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the scarcity of annotated multimodal datasets. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that jointly models acoustic, lexical, and visual features to recognize emotions in dialogue. Our HAN architecture consists of three stacked attention layers, each capturing different levels of abstraction in the input features. We evaluate our approach on the IEMOCAP dataset and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art multimodal fusion models. Our results show that the proposed HAN model can effectively capture subtle emotional cues and outperform human annotators in certain scenarios.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems require efficient task allocation to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model complex agent interactions. Our approach, called GNN-TA, represents the agent network as a graph and uses GNNs to learn a distributed task allocation policy. We evaluate GNN-TA on a variety of scenarios, including search and rescue, and show that it outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization. The proposed framework is scalable, flexible, and can be applied to various real-world applications.

title: EyeGaze+: Enhancing Web Accessibility through Adaptive Gaze-Based Interface
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant barriers when interacting with web applications. This paper presents EyeGaze+, a novel gaze-based interface that leverages machine learning to adapt to the user's abilities and preferences. Our system incorporates a gaze-tracking module, which detects and interprets the user's eye movements to infer their intentions. We propose a probabilistic model that integrates gaze data with keyboard and mouse interactions to predict the user's goals. Evaluation results with 20 participants show that EyeGaze+ outperforms existing gaze-based interfaces, achieving an average accuracy of 92.5% in completing web tasks.

title: EyeGaze+: Enhancing Gaze-Based Interaction with Deep Learning-based Gaze Correction
paper_abstract: Gaze-based interaction has become a popular modality in human-computer interaction, but it is susceptible to errors due to noise in eye-tracking data. This paper presents EyeGaze+, a novel framework that leverages deep learning to correct gaze errors in real-time.
