Our approach uses a convolutional neural network to learn patterns in gaze data and detect anomalies, which are then corrected using a probabilistic model. We evaluate EyeGaze+ on a publicly available eye-tracking dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in gaze accuracy and interaction performance. Our framework has implications for enhancing accessibility and usability in various applications, including virtual reality, gaming, and assistive technologies.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular in modern data-intensive applications. However, query optimization in such systems is a complex task due to the large search space and dynamic nature of the data distribution. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our method, called 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan based on the system's performance metrics. We evaluate RL-Optimizer on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: A Hybrid Retrieval Model for Cold Start Problem in Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Cold start problem is a long-standing challenge in recommendation systems, where user-item interactions are scarce. This paper proposes a hybrid retrieval model, 'HybCR', that combines the strengths of collaborative filtering and content-based filtering. HybCR leverages a graph neural network to learn user and item representations from their attributes, and then employs a dense retrieval mechanism to generate recommendations. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HybCR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in cold start scenarios, achieving an average improvement of 23.1% in recall and 17.4% in normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Dialogue
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational dialogue is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of multi-modal cues. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages linguistic, acoustic, and visual features to recognize emotions in conversational dialogue. Our HAN model consists of two stages: a feature attention stage that weights the importance of each modality, and a conversation attention stage that models the temporal dynamics of emotions within a conversation. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and MELD datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multitenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: With the growing adoption of cloud-based Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms, multitenancy has become a key concern. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MTQO', designed specifically for multitenant DBaaS environments. MTQO leverages a probabilistic model to predict query execution times and adapts to workload changes in real-time. We propose a hierarchical optimization approach that combines static analysis, runtime profiling, and machine learning-based prediction to minimize query latency and improve resource utilization. Experimental results on a production-scale DBaaS platform show that MTQO reduces average query response times by up to 35% compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Cooperation via Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems have numerous applications in areas like robotics, traffic control, and smart grids. However, as the number of agents increases, the complexity of cooperation strategies grows exponentially. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture for scalable multi-agent cooperation. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions, while hierarchical pooling enables efficient information aggregation across different spatial and temporal scales. Experimental results on a variety of benchmarks demonstrate that HGAN significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of cooperation efficiency and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Diverse Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines aim to provide users with diverse and relevant product results. However, traditional ranking models often struggle to balance diversity and relevance. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'DiverseRank', which integrates a multi-task learning framework with a neural-based diversification module. Our approach leverages both explicit and implicit feedback signals to jointly optimize ranking and diversification objectives. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that DiverseRank outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of both relevance and diversity metrics, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has shown great promise in various real-world applications, but the curse of dimensionality in large state and action spaces hinders its efficiency. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and features in the environment. Our approach reduces the complexity of MARL problems by learning a hierarchical representation of the agents' states and actions. Experimental results on a range of cooperative MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HAN achieves significant improvements in learning speed and final performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Voice-Based Assistants
paper_abstract: Voice-based assistants, such as Amazon Alexa and Google Assistant, have become increasingly popular, but their ability to personalize responses remains limited. This study explores the effects of personalization on user engagement in voice-based assistants. We designed and implemented a personalized conversational agent that incorporates user preferences, habits, and context into its responses. Our user study (N=100) revealed that personalized responses significantly improve user satisfaction, perceived usefulness, and overall engagement. We also analyzed the linguistic features of user interactions and found that personalized agents elicit more conversational and exploratory user behavior.

title: Coordinated Exploration of Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating the behavior of multiple agents in complex, partially observable environments remains a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper introduces a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to enable effective exploration and coordination among agents. Our method, dubbed 'MA-DEEP', employs a decentralized architecture where each agent learns to balance individual exploration and coordination with its peers. We demonstrate the efficacy of MA-DEEP in several benchmark domains, including robotic soccer and autonomous driving, and show that it outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of cumulative reward and coordination efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Data Streams in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Real-time data streams have become ubiquitous in modern applications, posing significant challenges for distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'StreamIX', designed to efficiently process high-velocity data streams in distributed settings. StreamIX leverages a combination of in-memory indexing, adaptive sampling, and parallel query processing to minimize latency and maximize throughput. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale distributed database cluster demonstrates that StreamIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time and 2x in terms of data ingestion rate.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Graph Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. This paper presents a novel QE approach, leveraging deep learning-based semantic graph embeddings to model complex relationships between query terms and concepts. Our proposed method, GraphQE, incorporates a heterogeneous graph neural network to jointly learn query and document representations, enabling more effective term weighting and expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, outperforming state-of-the-art QE techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Bayesian Learning in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'BLANT', which leverages Bayesian learning to adapt to dynamic environments. Each agent maintains a probabilistic model of task requirements and agent capabilities, and updates its model through local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We show that BLANT outperforms existing decentralized algorithms in terms of task completion rate and communication overhead. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of BLANT in adapting to changing task priorities and agent availability.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Analytics on IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential growth in sensor data, posing significant challenges for real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'RTIndex', designed specifically for IoT sensor data. RTIndex leverages a combination of spatial and temporal locality to optimize query performance, while also incorporating a probabilistic filtering mechanism to reduce false positives. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that RTIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for multi-agent reinforcement learning, which tackles the problem of scalable and efficient decision-making in complex environments. Our HAN framework consists of two levels of attention: intra-agent attention for individual policy learning and inter-agent attention for cooperative behavior modeling. Experimental results on a variety of multi-agent benchmarks demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of learning speed, policy adaptation, and overall task performance.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to optimize query plans. We model the database schema as a graph and utilize GNNs to learn a representation of the query graph. Our approach, called GQN, outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by adapting to the complex dependencies between query operators and database schema. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GQN reduces query execution time by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-robot interaction (HRI) is crucial for developing socially intelligent robots. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates facial, vocal, and linguistic cues to recognize emotions in HRI. Our HAN model utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, outperforming state-of-the-art multi-modal fusion approaches. Experimental results on the SEMAINE database demonstrate improved emotion recognition accuracy and robustness to noisy or missing modalities.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems in environments with incomplete information is a challenging problem. Traditional methods rely on explicit communication or domain-specific knowledge, limiting their applicability. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn coordination strategies in decentralized partial-observation Markov decision processes. Our method, called 'Dec-PPO', combines decentralized policy optimization with a neural network architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms to handle incomplete information. Experimental results on a range of benchmarks demonstrate that Dec-PPO outperforms state-of-the-art methods in achieving efficient coordination in multi-agent systems.

title: Multi-Aspect Relevance Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a fundamental challenge in Information Retrieval (IR). This paper presents a novel deep learning approach, 'MAR-DNN', which models multiple relevance aspects to improve ad-hoc retrieval performance. Our approach leverages a multi-task learning framework, where separate neural networks are trained to predict different relevance aspects, including topical, semantic, and contextual relevance. We demonstrate that MAR-DNN outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models on several benchmark datasets, including TREC and ClueWeb09. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned relevance aspects, shedding light on the strengths and limitations of our approach.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking with Graph-based Neural Models for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval systems often rely on bag-of-words representations, ignoring the rich contextual relationships between query terms and document contents. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural re-ranking model, 'GraphRerank', which leverages the graph structure of query-document interactions to improve retrieval efficiency. By adaptively weighting term importance and capturing semantic dependencies, GraphRerank achieves significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and reduces computational overhead. Experimental results on the TREC 2020 dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art neural re-ranking models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Real-time Traffic Prediction
paper_abstract: Accurate real-time traffic prediction is crucial for intelligent transportation systems. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global traffic patterns to predict traffic flow. HGAT consists of a hierarchical graph encoder that captures traffic dynamics at different spatial and temporal scales, and an attention-based fusion module that adaptively combines the encoded features. Experiments on a large-scale traffic dataset show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and computational efficiency, making it suitable for real-time traffic management applications.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Neural Query Optimization in Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Traditional query optimization techniques rely on Exhaustive Search (ES) or Heuristics, which can be inefficient for complex queries. This paper proposes a novel Neural Query Optimization (NQO) framework that leverages deep learning to predict optimal query plans. NQO integrates a Graph Neural Network (GNN) to model query structures and a Reinforcement Learning (RL) component to learn optimization strategies. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark demonstrate that NQO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 3.2x for complex queries.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-robot interaction (HRI) is crucial for robots to understand and respond to users' emotional states. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for multimodal emotion recognition, incorporating facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals. Our HAN model learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, improving emotion recognition accuracy compared to existing multimodal fusion methods. We evaluate our approach on a large HRI dataset, demonstrating improved recognition of emotions such as joy, sadness, and frustration, and explore its potential applications in HRI scenarios.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Real-time Object Detection on Edge Devices
paper_abstract: Real-time object detection is crucial for various applications, including autonomous vehicles, surveillance systems, and augmented reality. However, existing neural architecture search (NAS) methods are computationally expensive and may not generalize well to edge devices. This paper proposes a novel, efficient NAS framework, 'EdgeNAS', which leverages a differentiable search space and a novel, hardware-aware reward function to optimize object detection models for edge devices. Our experiments demonstrate that EdgeNAS can discover models that achieve state-of-the-art performance on COCO and Pascal VOC datasets while requiring only 10% of the computation time and 20% of the energy consumption compared to existing NAS methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media has led to an exponential growth in large-scale, semi-structured data. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, called 'LexiSort', specifically designed for real-time analytics on column-oriented NoSQL databases. LexiSort leverages a combination of lexical sorting and adaptive sampling to efficiently identify and retrieve relevant data blocks. Our experimental evaluation on a commercial NoSQL database demonstrates up to 3x improvement in query performance and 2x reduction in storage overhead compared to existing indexing techniques.

title: Designing Proxemic-Aware Voice Assistants for Inclusive Smart Homes
paper_abstract: As voice assistants become ubiquitous in smart homes, it is essential to ensure their accessibility and usability for diverse user populations. This paper presents a novel proxemic-aware voice assistant system that adaptively adjusts its interaction modalities based on the user's physical proximity, body orientation, and movement patterns. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, including individuals with disabilities, and found that our system improves the overall user experience, reduces errors, and enhances user satisfaction. Our approach has significant implications for designing inclusive and context-aware interactive systems in smart home environments.

title: Robustness Evaluation of Deep Neural Networks using Adversarial Attacks on Graph-Structured Data
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have demonstrated impressive performance on graph-structured data, but their robustness to adversarial attacks remains a concern. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the robustness of graph neural networks (GNNs) to various types of adversarial attacks, including node injection, edge perturbation, and feature manipulation. We propose a novel attack method, Graph-FGSM, which combines the Fast Gradient Sign Method with graph-based optimization techniques to generate highly effective adversarial examples. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the vulnerability of GNNs to these attacks and provide insights into the design of more robust models.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient decision-making to navigate complex scenarios. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'ADAPT', which decomposes the decision-making process into task-oriented sub-goals. ADAPT leverages a high-level planner to generate sub-goals and a low-level learner to adapt to changing environmental conditions. We demonstrate ADAPT's effectiveness in simulating various driving scenarios, showcasing improved efficiency and adaptability compared to flat reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must cooperate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph attention networks (GATs) to learn effective task allocation strategies. We model the agent-agent interactions as a graph and use GATs to learn attention weights that capture the strengths of relationships between agents. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphTask', outperforms state-of-the-art methods in simulations of autonomous agents performing tasks in a warehouse management scenario. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of GraphTask and demonstrate its applicability to real-world scenarios.

title: Efficient Data Replication in Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems require efficient data replication strategies to ensure high availability and fault tolerance. However, existing approaches often rely on manual configuration and static replication policies. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach to data replication, which leverages graph neural networks to predict data access patterns and optimize replication decisions. Our experiments on a large-scale distributed database show that the proposed approach achieves up to 30% improvement in read performance and 25% reduction in replication overhead compared to traditional methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gaze-based interaction for augmented reality (AR) applications using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a neural network architecture that learns to predict the user's intended gaze target in real-time, allowing for seamless interaction with virtual objects in AR environments. Our approach leverages a combination of eye-tracking data and scene context to improve the accuracy and robustness of the gaze prediction model. Experimental results demonstrate a significant reduction in interaction latency and error rates compared to traditional gaze-based interaction methods, enabling more intuitive and efficient AR experiences.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for storing and processing large-scale data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, called 'GraphOpt', which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query execution plans. GraphOpt uses a hierarchical indexing scheme to prune unnecessary subqueries and reduce the search space for optimal plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: EyeGazeFlow: A Multimodal Approach to Predicting User Intent in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: In virtual reality (VR) environments, understanding user intent is crucial for designing intuitive and efficient interfaces. This paper presents EyeGazeFlow, a novel multimodal fusion framework that combines eye gaze, head movements, and controller inputs to predict user intentions in VR. Our approach leverages a graph-based neural network to model the relationships between these modalities and outputs a probabilistic distribution over possible user intents. We evaluate EyeGazeFlow on a dataset of 30 users performing various tasks in a VR shopping scenario, achieving an average accuracy of 85.2% in intent prediction and outperforming state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Graph-Based Entity Disambiguation for Large-Scale Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in building and maintaining large-scale knowledge graphs. However, existing approaches struggle to scale to massive graphs with millions of entities. This paper proposes a novel graph-based entity disambiguation framework, 'GEDGE', which leverages structural graph features and entity contextual information to disambiguate entities efficiently. We introduce a new graph attention mechanism that adaptively weights neighboring entities based on their relevance to the disambiguation task. Experimental results on three large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that GEDGE outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies with Temporal Logic Specifications
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable successes in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns. This paper investigates attacks on DRL policies with temporal logic specifications, which specify constraints on the behavior of the agent. We propose a novel attack framework, 'TL-Attack', that crafts perturbations to the environment such that the policy violates the temporal logic specifications. Our experiments on several DRL benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of TL-Attack in inducing undesired behavior. We also propose a defense mechanism based on adversarial training with temporal logic regularization, which significantly improves the robustness of DRL policies.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of autonomous systems, where Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents need to make transparent decisions. We propose a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) framework that learns to focus on relevant state features and abstract representations, thereby providing insights into the decision-making process. Our method, called Explainable-HAN (E-HAN), consists of a hierarchical attention mechanism and a novel explainability module that generates human-readable explanations for the RL agent's actions. Experimental results on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate that E-HAN outperforms state-of-the-art RL methods in terms of both performance and explainability.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Recent advancements in autonomous vehicles rely heavily on reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize control policies. However, existing RL methods struggle to scale to complex, multi-agent scenarios. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'MARL-Ctrl', which leverages decentralized, multi-agent RL to learn cooperative control policies for autonomous vehicles. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that combines graph neural networks with off-policy RL to efficiently learn optimal control strategies. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation demonstrate MARL-Ctrl's ability to improve traffic flow and reduce congestion in urban environments.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) learning environments have shown promise in enhancing user engagement and learning outcomes. This study explores the impact of personalization on user experience in VR learning environments. We designed and implemented a personalized VR system that adaptively adjusts the learning content, pace, and feedback based on individual users' learning styles, preferences, and performance. Our user study with 120 participants reveals that personalized VR experiences lead to significant increases in user engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to non-personalized VR and traditional learning environments. We also identify key factors that influence the effectiveness of personalization in VR learning.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Cultural Sensitivity and Emotional Intelligence
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their lack of cultural sensitivity and emotional intelligence can lead to frustrating and alienating user experiences. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that acknowledges the diversity of users' cultural backgrounds and emotional needs. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving surveys, interviews, and usability testing to identify key factors influencing users' trust and satisfaction with voice assistants. Our findings suggest that incorporating cultural sensitivity and emotional intelligence into voice assistant design can significantly improve user experience and foster more inclusive human-computer interaction.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a pressing issue, and adaptive traffic signal control can significantly alleviate it. We propose a deep reinforcement learning framework, 'AgentSync', that coordinates heterogeneous agents (traffic signals, autonomous vehicles, and pedestrian crossings) to optimize real-time traffic flow. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic networks and incorporates multi-agent reinforcement learning to adapt to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that AgentSync reduces congestion by up to 30% and travel time by up to 25% compared to traditional fixed-time signal control.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing has become a ubiquitous paradigm for on-demand resource provisioning, but efficient resource allocation remains a critical challenge. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'CloudOpt', that learns to optimize resource allocation in complex cloud environments. CloudOpt leverages a hierarchical architecture to decompose the resource allocation problem into smaller sub-problems, which are then solved using a combination of deep Q-networks and graph neural networks. Extensive experiments on a realistic cloud simulator demonstrate that CloudOpt outperforms state-of-the-art heuristics by up to 30% in terms of resource utilization and application performance.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model complex agent interactions and optimize task assignments. We propose a coordinated task allocation framework, 'CAT-GNN', which integrates GNNs with a decentralized optimization algorithm to allocate tasks in a distributed manner. Our experiments on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that CAT-GNN outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time, resource utilization, and overall system performance.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Mechanisms for Autonomous Agent Coalitions in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of distributed renewable energy sources in smart grids necessitates the development of autonomous agent-based control systems. This paper introduces a novel decentralized negotiation mechanism, 'CoalitionNet', which enables autonomous agents to form coalitions and negotiate energy trading agreements in a scalable and efficient manner. We leverage a combination of game-theoretic and machine learning techniques to design a multi-round negotiation protocol that adapts to changing grid conditions and agent preferences. Experimental results using real-world smart grid data demonstrate that CoalitionNet outperforms existing decentralized optimization methods in terms of negotiation efficiency and energy trading outcomes.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible technology that accommodates older adults with motor impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating gestural interfaces that cater to this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving participatory design workshops and usability testing to inform the development of a gesture recognition system tailored to older adults with motor impairments. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptive gesture recognition, personalized feedback, and multimodal interaction. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through a proof-of-concept system that achieved a 30% reduction in gesture recognition errors compared to existing systems.

title: Investigating the Effect of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems aim to provide immersive experiences, but the lack of haptic feedback can lead to a sense of disconnection from the virtual environment. This paper presents a study on the impact of haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We designed and implemented a custom VR system with a haptic feedback device and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user engagement, presence, and overall satisfaction in VR. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including the type of haptic cue and the level of vibration intensity.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Graph-based models have shown promising results in document retrieval tasks, but they often suffer from high computational complexity and scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that efficiently models complex document relationships and retrieves relevant documents. Our approach uses a hierarchical graph structure to capture both local and global document features, and employs attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Skew-Tolerant Hashing
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of real-time data warehousing, efficient indexing techniques are crucial for supporting fast query processing. This paper presents STASH, a novel indexing approach that leverages skew-tolerant hashing to mitigate the impact of data skew on query performance. Our method adapts to the underlying data distribution and dynamically adjusts the hash function to minimize collisions, ensuring efficient query execution even in the presence of highly skewed data. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate a significant speedup in query processing time compared to traditional indexing techniques, making STASH an attractive solution for real-time data warehousing applications.

title: Deep Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Image Segmentation
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in image segmentation tasks, but their computational complexity and memory requirements hinder deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) method, 'SegNAS', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the search process for efficient image segmentation models. SegNAS explores a vast search space of potential architectures and identifies a family of models that achieve competitive performance to state-of-the-art models while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computations. We evaluate SegNAS on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in finding efficient and accurate image segmentation models.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Assistants for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities face significant barriers when interacting with virtual assistants. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system, 'EyeVA', which enables users to control virtual assistants using only their gaze. Our approach leverages a combination of machine learning-based gaze tracking and natural language processing to infer user intent. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with motor disabilities and demonstrated significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional speech-based interfaces. The results have important implications for improving accessibility and independence in daily life.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous graphs is a challenging task due to the presence of multiple node types and edge relationships. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages the graph structure to learn node representations. HGAT uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and edge types, enabling the model to capture complex relationships between nodes. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art node classification methods, particularly in graphs with high heterogeneity.

title: Designing Tactile Feedback for Gesture-Based Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Gesture-based virtual reality (VR) interfaces often rely on visual and auditory cues, neglecting the tactile sense. This paper presents a novel framework for designing tactile feedback for VR gestures, enhancing user experience and immersion. We conducted a user study to identify key gesture categories and developed a tactile feedback vocabulary based on haptic rendering and vibration patterns. Our evaluation shows that the proposed framework improves gesture recognition accuracy and reduces user fatigue. We also provide guidelines for integrating tactile feedback into VR interface design, promoting a more multisensory and engaging experience.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy in cloud-based database systems has led to increased resource sharing and reduced costs. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel distributed query optimization framework, 'MQO', which leverages a hierarchical, multi-agent architecture to optimize query plans across multiple tenants. MQO incorporates a decentralized reinforcement learning approach to adapt to dynamic workloads and varying resource availability. Our experimental results on a real-world cloud database platform demonstrate a 30% improvement in query response time and a 25% reduction in resource utilization compared to traditional, centralized query optimization techniques.

title: Scalable Graph Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships between entities. However, optimizing graph queries remains a challenging problem due to the vast search space of possible execution plans. This paper proposes a novel approach to graph query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a graph query optimizer, 'GROQL', that learns to select efficient execution plans through trial and error. Our approach leverages a Markov decision process to model the query optimization problem and employs deep Q-networks to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on several real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GROQL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Investigating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but limitations in haptic feedback hinder immersion and user experience. This study explores the effects of different haptic feedback modalities on user perception, engagement, and task performance in VR. We designed a VR environment with varying levels of haptic feedback, including vibration, force feedback, and thermal feedback. Our user study (N = 40) reveals that multimodal haptic feedback significantly enhances user experience, reduces cognitive load, and improves task accuracy compared to visual-only or single-modal haptic feedback. The findings have implications for the design of haptic interfaces in VR applications.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality interfaces
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience is crucial. This study investigates the effects of haptic feedback on user engagement, presence, and task performance in VR interfaces. We conducted a within-subjects experiment with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform with varying levels of haptic feedback. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user experience, particularly in terms of presence and task accuracy, but also increases cognitive load. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of haptic-enabled VR interfaces and identify avenues for future research.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Collections
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often struggle with heterogeneous document collections, where diverse formats and modalities hinder effective retrieval. We propose a novel deep learning-based approach, 'HetQEx', which leverages multimodal embeddings to expand queries and adapt to the collection's heterogeneity. Our method incorporates a dynamic weighting scheme to balance the contributions of different modalities and reduce the impact of noisy or irrelevant features. Experimental results on a large-scale, heterogeneous document collection demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency over state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Scalable Transactional Support for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As distributed databases continue to scale, ensuring consistency and concurrency control becomes increasingly challenging. This paper presents 'MVCC-Scale', a novel multi-version concurrency control protocol that leverages a combination of timestamp-based and value-based validation to reduce contention and abort rates in distributed transactions. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that delegates validation to local nodes, reducing the load on the central coordinator. Experimental results on a 100-node cluster demonstrate that MVCC-Scale achieves up to 3x throughput improvement over existing MVCC protocols while maintaining strong consistency guarantees.

title: Enhancing Query Intent Understanding with Hierarchical Attention Networks for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture to better understand query intent. Our approach leverages both local and global contextual features from query phrases and product descriptions, enabling the model to differentiate between ambiguous query terms. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search accuracy and relevance compared to state-of-the-art intent modeling techniques.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Graph Attention Networks for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) over knowledge graphs (KGs) has garnered significant attention in recent years. However, existing methods often rely on shallow representations of KGs, which may not capture complex relationships between entities. We propose a novel framework, 'GATE', that leverages graph attention networks to learn dense entity and relation embeddings. Our experiments on the popular Wikidata5M dataset demonstrate that GATE outperforms state-of-the-art QA models, achieving a 12% improvement in F1-score. Furthermore, we show that GATE can be easily adapted to different QA tasks with minimal fine-tuning.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces: A Study on Voice Assistant Personalization for Older Adults
paper_abstract: As voice assistants become increasingly prevalent in older adults' daily lives, there is a growing need to design inclusive conversational interfaces that cater to their unique needs and preferences. This study investigates the effects of personalization on the user experience of older adults interacting with voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, using a customized voice assistant platform that incorporated personalized prompts, feedback, and error handling. Our results show that personalized voice assistants can significantly improve user satisfaction, reduce frustration, and increase task completion rates among older adults. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more accessible and user-centered voice assistants.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults, but existing systems often fail to account for their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a participatory design approach to creating accessible conversational agents for older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers, identifying key design requirements and preferences. Our findings inform the development of a prototype conversational agent that incorporates features such as simplified language, visual cues, and adaptive dialogue management. We evaluate the prototype through a usability study, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to existing systems.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Enhancing Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Search engines often struggle to retrieve diverse results, leading to a poor user experience. This paper presents a novel neural query expansion method, 'NQE-Div', which incorporates a diversity-promoting regularizer into the training objective. Our approach leverages a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query similarity and document diversity. Experiments on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that NQE-Div significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of novelty and diversity metrics, while maintaining comparable relevance scores.

title: Query Optimization for Scalable RDFTriple Stores using Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: RDF triple stores have become a crucial component in various data-intensive applications, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using graph embeddings. We propose a neural network-based model, 'RDFEmb', which learns a dense representation of RDF graphs and exploits these embeddings to identify optimal query plans. Experimental results on popular RDF benchmarks demonstrate that RDFEmb outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, reducing query execution time by up to 40% and improving scalability for large-scale RDF datasets.

title: Scalable Indexing of RDF Graphs using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: The increasing size and complexity of RDF graphs have rendered traditional indexing techniques inefficient. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach based on hierarchical Bloom filters, which enables scalable and efficient querying of RDF data. Our approach partitions the RDF graph into smaller subgraphs and constructs a hierarchical index using Bloom filters. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through experiments on real-world RDF datasets, showing improved query performance and reduced memory usage compared to existing indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Reinforcement Learning for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, aimed at reformulating user queries to improve retrieval accuracy. This paper presents a novel approach, 'RL-QE', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query expansion. RL-QE treats query expansion as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select relevant expansion terms based on user feedback. We propose a reward function that incorporates both relevance and novelty metrics, and demonstrate significant improvements over traditional query expansion techniques on several benchmark datasets. Our experiments show that RL-QE achieves higher precision, recall, and F1-score compared to state-of-the-art methods, while reducing the computational overhead.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to cooperative task allocation for multi-agent systems, leveraging reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments and improve system performance. Our approach, called CATARL, combines a decentralized Markov decision process with a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework to enable agents to learn and adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that CATARL outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency, making it a promising solution for real-world applications such as disaster response and search and rescue operations.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improved Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a widely adopted paradigm for open-domain question answering. However, DPR systems often struggle to retrieve relevant passages when the query does not contain sufficient keywords. We propose a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which generates synthetic passages that capture the semantic context of the query. Our experiments demonstrate that QDE significantly improves the retrieval performance of a state-of-the-art DPR system, particularly for queries with limited contextual information. We also show that QDE can be seamlessly integrated with existing DPR architectures, making it a practical solution for real-world applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of graph datasets has led to a surge in the development of distributed graph databases. However, the complexity of graph queries poses significant challenges to query optimization in these systems. This paper presents a novel optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph rewiring, query decomposition, and adaptive indexing to minimize query latency and resource utilization. We evaluate GraphOpt on a suite of real-world graph datasets and demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Query Expansion via Phrase Embeddings for Scientific Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Scientific document retrieval often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, dubbed 'PhraseEmb', which leverages phrase embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and document phrases. We demonstrate that PhraseEmb outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, such as Rocchio and Latent Semantic Analysis, on a benchmark dataset of scientific articles. Furthermore, we show that PhraseEmb is particularly effective when combined with a neural ranking model, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the TREC-COVID dataset.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) often operate in dynamic environments, where agents must adapt to changing circumstances to achieve their goals. This paper introduces a novel negotiation framework for MAS, which leverages machine learning to learn adaptive strategies for agents in dynamic environments. Our approach, called AdaptNeg, uses a hybrid approach combining reinforcement learning and game-theoretic analysis to enable agents to negotiate effectively in the face of uncertainty. Experimental results demonstrate that AdaptNeg significantly outperforms existing negotiation strategies in a variety of dynamic scenarios, including resource allocation and task assignment problems.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents must coordinate to optimize task execution. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to learn effective task allocation strategies. Our method, 'AgentCoor', uses a decentralized, multi-agent reinforcement learning framework to train agents to coordinate their actions and adapt to changing task dynamics. We evaluate AgentCoor on a simulated logistics scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization compared to traditional, hand-crafted allocation strategies.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to the complexity of agent interactions and task dependencies. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep graph reinforcement learning to coordinate task allocation among agents. Our method, called GraphMAT, represents the agent-task graph as a Markov decision process and learns a policy to allocate tasks that maximizes system efficiency and minimizes conflicts. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that GraphMAT outperforms existing approaches in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Human-AI Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As human-AI collaboration becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding the cognitive and behavioral factors that influence human performance is crucial. This study explores the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, where users interact with AI agents using gestures and body language. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, analyzing their problem-solving strategies and communication patterns in VR. Our results show that embodied cognition significantly enhances human-AI collaboration, improving task efficiency and reducing errors. We discuss the implications for designing more effective and intuitive human-AI interfaces, highlighting the potential of VR-based training for complex tasks.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agent Teams using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation for heterogeneous agent teams in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent interactions and task dependencies. Our approach enables agents to learn effective task allocation strategies in real-time, without requiring explicit communication or centralized control. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our GNN-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion efficiency and team adaptability.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Commonsense Reasoning
paper_abstract: Commonsense reasoning (CSR) is a fundamental AI capability that enables machines to reason about everyday situations. Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) is a key technique for CSR, but existing methods struggle with scalability and capturing hierarchical relationships. We propose a novel KGE framework, 'HierAtt', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between entities and concepts. Our experiments on the ConceptNet dataset demonstrate that HierAtt outperforms state-of-the-art methods in CSR tasks, achieving a 12.5% improvement in accuracy while reducing computational overhead by 30%.

title: Towards Efficient and Effective Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have shown promising results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but their computational cost and memory requirements limit their applicability to large-scale search engines. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking architecture, 'EffiRank', which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism and a knowledge distillation strategy to reduce the model's complexity while preserving its retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that EffiRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of both efficiency and effectiveness, making it a viable solution for real-world search engines.

title: Hierarchical Entity Disambiguation with Graph Attention Networks for Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph embedding, as it affects the accuracy of subsequent applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical entity disambiguation approach, 'HED-GAT', which leverages graph attention networks to model complex relationships between entities. HED-GAT employs a hierarchical architecture to capture both local and global context, enabling more accurate disambiguation of entities with ambiguous names. Our experiments on the YAGO and DBpedia datasets demonstrate that HED-GAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in entity disambiguation, leading to improved knowledge graph embedding and subsequent question answering performance.

title: Enhancing Query Term Weighting with Deep Neural Relevance Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in Information Retrieval (IR), particularly when dealing with ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to query term weighting by integrating deep neural relevance models into the traditional retrieval framework. We introduce a neural query term scorer that leverages contextualized embeddings and attention mechanisms to capture nuanced term dependencies. Experiments on several TREC datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including those based on BM25 and query expansion. Our analysis reveals that the neural scorer effectively identifies and weights informative query terms, leading to improved retrieval performance.

title: Learning to Rank with Hierarchical Document Graphs for Efficient Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional learning-to-rank models rely on flat document representations, ignoring the inherent hierarchical structure of documents. This paper proposes a novel graph-based ranking approach, HierRank, which leverages document graphs to capture semantic relationships between entities, sections, and sentences. By incorporating graph neural networks and a hierarchical attention mechanism, HierRank achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness on benchmark datasets. We demonstrate the scalability of our approach through experiments on large-scale document collections.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Recognition for Intelligent Assistive Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent assistive systems (IAS) have the potential to significantly improve the quality of life for individuals with disabilities. However, current IAS interfaces often rely on explicit user input, which can be cumbersome and limiting. This paper presents a novel gaze-based intention recognition framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to infer user intentions from gaze patterns. Our approach achieves an average accuracy of 92.5% in recognizing user intentions in a controlled laboratory setting, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods. We discuss the implications of our framework for the development of more intuitive and user-friendly IAS interfaces.

title: transactions with Efficient Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but ensuring consistency and concurrency control remains a significant challenge. We present 'DynaLock', a novel concurrency control protocol that combines optimistic locking with transactional re-execution to minimize aborts and improve system throughput. Our approach dynamically adjusts the locking granularity based on transaction conflict rates, reducing lock contention and wait times. Evaluation on a distributed database benchmark shows that DynaLock outperforms existing protocols, achieving up to 30% higher throughput and 25% lower latency.

title: Efficient Object Detection using Hierarchical Attention-based Transformers
paper_abstract: Object detection remains a challenging task in computer vision, particularly in scenarios with multiple objects and varying scales. This paper proposes a novel transformer-based architecture, 'Hierarchical Attention Detector' (HAD), which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant regions and scales. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the COCO dataset, outperforming existing detectors by 2.5% in terms of mean average precision. We also demonstrate the efficiency of HAD, which reduces computational cost by 30% compared to existing transformer-based detectors.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using hierarchical document embeddings, dubbed 'HDQE'. By leveraging a hierarchical clustering of document representations, HDQE identifies semantically cohesive clusters that are used to generate expanded queries. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HDQE outperforms existing query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Robot Task Planning
paper_abstract: In complex robotic task planning, explainability is crucial for human-robot collaboration and trust. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates symbolic planning with deep learning. HAN learns to attend to relevant task constraints and object affordances, generating interpretable plans. We evaluate our approach on a benchmark robotic task planning dataset, demonstrating improved plan quality and explainability compared to state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, we provide a visual analytics tool to facilitate human understanding of the planning process.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various industries, but user experience remains a significant barrier to widespread adoption. This paper explores the effect of personalized haptic feedback on user experience in VR environments. We propose a novel framework that incorporates machine learning-based models to predict user preferences and adapt haptic feedback accordingly. Our user study involving 30 participants shows that personalized haptic feedback significantly enhances user satisfaction, reduces motion sickness, and improves overall engagement. The results have important implications for the design of immersive VR experiences.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Participatory Approach to Improving Accessibility for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to improve the accessibility of voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted co-design workshops with 15 older adults to identify pain points and elicit design requirements. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and concise voice prompts, personalized feedback mechanisms, and intuitive error recovery strategies. We propose a set of design guidelines and demonstrate their feasibility through a prototype implementation. Our approach has implications for the development of more inclusive and supportive voice assistants that can empower older adults in their daily lives.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Graph Embeddings for Knowledge Graph Search
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph search often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. However, existing methods suffer from high computational costs and limited semantic understanding of query entities. We propose a novel approach, 'GraphExpan', which leverages deep graph embeddings to capture complex relationships between entities and expand queries effectively. Our method uses a graph neural network to learn entity representations, which are then used to generate expanded queries. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Networks with Attention-based Query Embeddings
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel neural ranking model for information retrieval, which leverages attention-based query embeddings to capture complex contextual relationships between queries and documents. Our proposed architecture, 'AttentiveRank', combines a deep neural network with a multi-head attention mechanism to encode queries and documents, allowing for more effective matching and scoring. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AttentiveRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in terms of NDCG and ERR metrics.

title: Efficient Approximation of Boolean Retrieval Models using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Boolean retrieval models are fundamental to many information retrieval systems, but their exact evaluation can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a neural approximation approach to efficiently estimate the retrieval scores of Boolean models. Our method, called Neural Boolean Approximation (NBA), leverages deep neural networks to learn a continuous representation of the Boolean query and document features. We demonstrate that NBA achieves significant speedups over exact evaluation while maintaining retrieval effectiveness. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that NBA outperforms state-of-the-art approximation methods and is robust to varying query complexities.

title: Adversarial Training with Hierarchical Latent Variables for Robust Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which significantly degrade their performance. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training approach that leverages hierarchical latent variables to improve the robustness of image classification models. Our method, dubbed 'HLV-Adv', incorporates a hierarchical Bayesian neural network that learns disentangled and interpretable representations of the input data. We show that HLV-Adv outperforms state-of-the-art adversarial training methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving higher classification accuracy and improved robustness against diverse types of attacks.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Supervised Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to document retrieval using supervised neural ranking models. We introduce a deep learning architecture that jointly learns to represent documents and queries in a shared semantic space, enabling accurate retrieval of relevant documents. Our method leverages a large-scale dataset of labeled query-document pairs to train a neural ranking model that outperforms traditional retrieval methods. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain over state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence, particularly in dynamic environments with complex constraints. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to efficiently compute near-optimal paths for multiple agents. Our method, called MAP-RL, uses a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn cooperative policies that minimize collisions and reduce overall travel time. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MAP-RL in various scenarios, including warehouse robotics and autonomous vehicle routing, and show significant improvements over traditional graph-based methods.

title: Neural Ranking Models with Hierarchical Attention for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for document retrieval rely on dense, fixed-size representations of documents and queries. However, this approach can be computationally expensive and may not effectively capture the nuances of complex queries. We propose a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant document segments and query terms, reducing the computational overhead while improving retrieval accuracy. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing neural ranking models in terms of both efficiency and effectiveness.

title: Gaze-based Intention Recognition for Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Multimodal human-computer interaction (HCI) systems that incorporate gaze-based input can enhance user experience and accessibility. This paper presents a novel intention recognition framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to decode users' gaze patterns and infer their intentions in real-time. Our approach integrates a probabilistic gaze estimation model with a neural network-based intention classifier, achieving a recognition accuracy of 92.5% on a diverse dataset of users. We demonstrate the feasibility of our approach through a proof-of-concept HCI system that enables gaze-controlled navigation and selection in a virtual environment.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Individuals with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but they often overlook the needs of individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible conversational systems that cater to users with visual, hearing, motor, or cognitive impairments. We introduce a user-centered approach that incorporates inclusive design principles, multimodal interaction, and personalized accommodations. A comprehensive evaluation with 30 participants demonstrates that our approach significantly improves the usability, accessibility, and overall user experience for individuals with disabilities, paving the way for more inclusive human-computer interaction.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to create more intuitive and engaging user experiences. We propose a gesture-based interaction framework that leverages the cognitive benefits of bodily engagement to improve user performance and satisfaction in VR environments. Our study employs a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative measurements of user behavior with qualitative assessments of user experience. Results show that our framework significantly enhances user engagement, spatial awareness, and task performance compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Video Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Video anomaly detection is a crucial task in surveillance and monitoring applications. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and limited generalizability. We propose a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, 'HiCAD', which learns to detect anomalies in videos by contrasting hierarchical representations of normal and anomalous patterns. HiCAD leverages a multi-resolution feature fusion strategy to capture both local and global contextual information, enabling efficient detection of anomalies at various scales. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiCAD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Gaze-Based Cognitive Load Measurement for Intelligent Adaptive Interfaces
paper_abstract: Cognitive load is a critical factor in human-computer interaction, as excessive mental effort can lead to fatigue and decreased performance. This paper presents a novel approach to measuring cognitive load using gaze-based features, which are extracted from eye-tracking data. We propose a machine learning model that leverages these features to predict cognitive load in real-time, enabling intelligent adaptive interfaces to adjust their complexity and support accordingly. Our evaluation on a dataset of 30 participants performing a problem-solving task shows that our approach outperforms existing methods in accuracy and latency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Temporal Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Temporal graph embeddings are crucial for modeling complex relationships in dynamic networks. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAT) that leverages both node and graph-level attention mechanisms to efficiently capture temporal dependencies. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAT achieves state-of-the-art performance in temporal link prediction and node classification tasks while reducing computation time by up to 40% compared to existing methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decentralized task allocation is a challenging problem due to the need to balance individual agent objectives with global system efficiency. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We introduce a hierarchical framework that combines a graph neural network for agent communication with a deep Q-network for task allocation. Our approach is evaluated on a variety of simulated scenarios and demonstrates improved system performance and robustness compared to traditional distributed constraint optimization methods.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Column-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented databases have gained popularity in big data analytics, but their performance is often bottlenecked by inefficient indexing strategies. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing approach, 'AIIX', which dynamically adjusts the indexing configuration based on query patterns and data distributions. AIIX leverages a cost-based optimization framework to select the most effective indexing strategy for each query, considering factors such as data skew, query frequency, and storage constraints. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that AIIX achieves up to 3x query performance improvement compared to traditional indexing methods, with minimal overhead in terms of storage and maintenance costs.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Adaptive Negotiation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'AdaNeg', which leverages adaptive negotiation strategies to optimize task assignments among agents. AdaNeg incorporates a reinforcement learning-based mechanism that enables agents to adapt their negotiation policies based on dynamic system conditions and task requirements. Experimental results demonstrate that AdaNeg outperforms existing allocation algorithms in terms of task completion time, resource utilization, and system robustness.

title: Efficient Query Optimization using Machine Learning-based Cardinality Estimation for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the inherent complexity of distributed systems. This paper proposes a novel approach to cardinality estimation using machine learning techniques, which can significantly improve query optimization. We develop a neural network-based model that learns the relationship between query features and cardinality estimates, and integrate it with a cost-based optimizer. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional methods by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hybrid Semantic Indexing for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: The exponential growth of digital documents necessitates efficient and effective information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a hybrid semantic indexing framework that integrates lexical, syntactic, and semantic features to facilitate fast and accurate document retrieval.
