We introduce a novel graph-based indexing scheme that captures document relationships and optimizes query processing. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale document collection demonstrates a significant reduction in query latency and improvement in retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Designing Augmented Reality Interfaces for Enhancing Cognitive Load Management in Older Adults
paper_abstract: Older adults often experience cognitive load management difficulties, leading to decreased performance and increased frustration in various tasks. This paper presents an innovative AR-based system, 'CogLoadAR', designed to mitigate cognitive load in older adults. CogLoadAR utilizes a novel combination of visual and auditory cues to facilitate task segmentation, reduce working memory demands, and provide personalized feedback. A user study with 30 older adults demonstrates that CogLoadAR significantly improves task completion time, accuracy, and subjective workload compared to traditional interfaces. Our findings have implications for the development of inclusive, accessible AR systems that support healthy aging.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Load Balancing for Distributed Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Distributed cloud computing environments face significant challenges in load balancing, leading to reduced system efficiency and increased latency. This paper proposes an autonomous agent-based load balancing framework, 'AALB', which leverages intelligent agents to dynamically allocate workload and resources. AALB integrates a decentralized decision-making mechanism, where agents negotiate and adapt to changing workload patterns, and a reinforcement learning-based policy optimization module to improve system performance. Experimental results on a large-scale cloud computing testbed demonstrate that AALB outperforms traditional load balancing strategies in terms of response time, throughput, and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Autonomous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous multi-agent systems rely on trust relationships between agents to ensure coordination and cooperation. However, managing trust in decentralized settings is challenging due to the lack of central authority and limited communication. This paper proposes a novel decentralized trust management framework, 'TrustNet', which leverages blockchain and distributed ledger technology to establish and update trust relationships between agents. We introduce a reputation-based trust model that incorporates both direct and indirect trust evidence, and demonstrate its effectiveness in simulated scenarios of cooperative robotics and smart grids. TrustNet provides a scalable and resilient solution for trust management in autonomous multi-agent systems.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities need to work together to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network-based approach for coordinated task allocation, which learns to identify relevant agent-agent and agent-task relationships. Our method, called GATask, integrates task features, agent capabilities, and communication constraints to generate optimal task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that GATask outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Semantically Relevant Documents using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems rely on keyword-based matching, which fails to capture the semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel IR framework that leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to model document semantics. Our approach represents documents as nodes in a graph, where edges capture semantic relationships learned from a large corpus of text. We develop an efficient retrieval algorithm that traverses the graph to retrieve documents relevant to a given query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art IR methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting models often struggle to provide interpretable insights into their predictions. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global dependencies in time series data to improve forecasting accuracy and explainability. Our HAN model uses a novel attention mechanism that adaptively selects the most relevant segments and features at multiple scales, enabling the model to focus on the most informative parts of the input data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of forecasting accuracy and provides more informative feature importance scores.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility features for users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to the needs of visually impaired users. We conducted a comprehensive user study to identify the key challenges and requirements for accessible VR interactions. Based on our findings, we developed a set of guidelines and a prototype system that leverages 3D audio, haptic feedback, and voice commands to provide an immersive and interactive VR experience. Our evaluation results show that our approach significantly improves the usability and enjoyment of VR for visually impaired users.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Emotional Speech Synthesis for Individuals with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their emotional speech synthesis capabilities often neglect the needs of individuals with disabilities. This paper presents an exploratory study on designing inclusive voice assistants that can adapt to the emotional and social needs of users with disabilities. We develop and evaluate a novel emotional speech synthesis framework that incorporates disability-specific requirements, such as accommodating varying emotional intensity and speech patterns. Our user study with 30 participants from diverse disability groups demonstrates improved user satisfaction and emotional engagement with our proposed framework.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates textual, visual, and acoustic features for sentiment analysis. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on salient features and modalities, providing explicit explanations for sentiment predictions. We conduct extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets, demonstrating that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods while providing insightful explanations for multimodal sentiment analysis.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Diverse Documents using Adaptive Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, called AdaptiveDiverRank, which learns to retrieve diverse and relevant documents from a large corpus. Our approach incorporates a self-attention mechanism to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. We also introduce a novel objective function that optimizes for both relevance and diversity, allowing the model to adapt to varying query types and user preferences. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaptiveDiverRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and diversity metrics.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to distributed task allocation using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our framework, 'MARL-TA', enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task assignment in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce a decentralized reward function that incorporates both local and global performance metrics, promoting efficient task allocation while respecting agent capabilities and resource constraints. Experimental results demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods in large-scale task allocation scenarios, achieving significant improvements in overall system throughput and robustness.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and real-time analytics applications has created a pressing need for efficient indexing and querying of time-series data in distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'TS-Tree', which leverages a combination of spatial and temporal locality to reduce query latency and improve data freshness. We evaluate TS-Tree on a large-scale distributed database system and demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing indexing methods, achieving up to 3x faster query times and 2x better data freshness.

title: Enhancing Context-Aware Retrieval with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Context-aware retrieval systems aim to capture complex relationships between query and document entities. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that models both local and global contextual dependencies. HGAT employs a hierarchical structure to encode query and document graphs, and attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant entities and their relationships. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, and provides interpretable insights into the contextual reasoning process.

title: Indexing Techniques for Efficient Query Processing in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented NoSQL databases have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to handle large-scale data analytics workloads. However, query processing remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, called 'ColIndex', that leverages the columnar storage layout to accelerate query execution. ColIndex uses a combination of in-memory indexing and disk-based storage to achieve low query latency and high throughput. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval using Graph-based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often rely on traditional text-based query expansion techniques that neglect the semantic relationships between different modalities. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding approach that jointly models the textual and visual features of a query to generate a more comprehensive and effective expansion. Our method leverages a heterogeneous graph neural network to capture the intricate relationships between words, images, and their corresponding entities, resulting in a more accurate and robust query expansion. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate the superior performance of our approach over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing for Distributed Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face scalability challenges as they process increasingly large query volumes. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing framework, 'AIx', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and document distributions. Our approach leverages machine learning models to predict query frequencies and optimize index creation, resulting in improved query performance and reduced storage overhead. Experiments on a large-scale DIR testbed demonstrate AIx's ability to achieve up to 30% query latency reduction and 25% index size reduction compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it helps disambiguate user queries and retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and document content. Our method, dubbed 'SemExpan', uses a multi-task learning framework to jointly learn term embeddings and query-document similarity metrics. Experimental results on benchmark IR datasets demonstrate that SemExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Explainable Reasoning for Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-agent dialogue systems require effective reasoning mechanisms to generate coherent and context-dependent responses. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based framework, 'HARE', which integrates symbolic reasoning with neural networks to provide interpretable explanations for dialogue decisions. We introduce a multi-level attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant dialogue history, agent roles, and context features to infer implicit intentions and goals. Experimental results on a challenging dialogue benchmark demonstrate that HARE outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of response accuracy and explanation quality, while enabling transparent and trustworthy decision-making in human-agent interactions.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Big Data Analytics using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and velocity of big data pose significant challenges to query performance in data analytics. This paper presents an adaptive indexing framework, 'AIQ', which dynamically adjusts indexing strategies based on query patterns and data distributions. AIQ employs a cost-based optimization model that considers both storage and computation overhead, allowing for efficient index creation and maintenance. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that AIQ outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems are crucial for building trust in AI-driven decision-making. We propose a novel hierarchical attention graph neural network (HAGN) model that incorporates both user-item interactions and item relationships. HAGN leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant item features and relationships, generating personalized explanations for each recommendation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGN outperforms state-of-the-art models in both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Adaptation to Accented Speech
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their performance degrades significantly when interacting with users having non-standard accents. This paper presents a comprehensive study on adapting voice assistants to accented speech, focusing on the Indian English accent. We propose a novel accent adaptation framework, 'AccentAware', which leverages transfer learning and multi-task learning to improve speech recognition accuracy. Our experiments demonstrate that AccentAware outperforms state-of-the-art models, achieving a relative improvement of 23.4% in word error rate. We also conduct a user study, revealing that AccentAware's adaptations lead to increased user satisfaction and trust in voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Semi-Supervised Node Classification
paper_abstract: Semi-supervised node classification on graph-structured data remains a challenging problem, especially when dealing with large, sparse graphs. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages both node features and structural information to improve classification accuracy. HGAN learns to selectively focus on relevant nodes and their neighborhoods, enabling the model to capture long-range dependencies and contextual information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant gains in accuracy and F1-score.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) over knowledge graphs (KGs) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing methods struggle to effectively integrate multi-modal information from KGs, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based model, 'HAT-QA', which learns to jointly embed KG entities, relations, and modalities in a shared vector space. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant KG components and modalities, enabling more accurate QA. Experimental results on the MultiModalQA benchmark demonstrate that HAT-QA outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 12.5% in terms of average F1-score.

title: Towards Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management. However, optimizing query execution in such systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and network topology. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database system and receiving rewards based on execution time and resource utilization. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Scalable Incremental View Maintenance for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Materialized views are essential for fast query processing in data warehousing, but maintaining them incrementally as the underlying data changes is a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'IVM-RT', which leverages a hybrid data structure combining trie-based indexing and bloom filters to efficiently identify and update affected view tuples. Our experiments on a real-world benchmark dataset demonstrate that IVM-RT outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods by up to 3x in terms of update latency and 2x in terms of space efficiency, making it suitable for real-time data warehousing applications.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly prevalent in modern data processing, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based reinforcement learning approach to optimize query plans in distributed databases. Our method, called 'GraphQLearn', represents the database schema as a graph and uses reinforcement learning to learn the optimal query plan based on the query workload and system configuration. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that GraphQLearn outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Graph-Based Term Dependencies
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have revolutionized information retrieval, but their query processing capabilities are often limited by the quality of the query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'GraphQE', that leverages graph-based term dependencies to improve the retrieval of relevant documents. By modeling term co-occurrences as a graph, we identify the most informative terms and their relationships, enabling more accurate query expansion. Experimental results on the TREC benchmarks show that GraphQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but the lack of transparency and explainability hinders its widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HAT-DRL', which integrates hierarchical attention mechanisms into DRL agents to provide interpretable explanations for their decision-making processes. Our method leverages the inherent hierarchy of tasks and sub-tasks in DRL to selectively focus on relevant state features, resulting in improved explainability without compromising policy performance. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of HAT-DRL in generating faithful and actionable explanations.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models for document retrieval rely on static features and scoring functions, which may not adapt well to changing user preferences and query distributions. This paper proposes an adaptive re-ranking framework that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize the ranking policy based on user interactions. Our approach, called 'AdaRank', uses a deep Q-network to learn a ranking policy that balances exploration and exploitation of relevant documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that AdaRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Embeddings
paper_abstract: Learning effective embeddings from multi-modal data (e.g., images, text, audio) is crucial for various AI applications. However, existing methods often rely on computationally expensive fusion strategies or suffer from modality imbalance. We propose HAtten, a hierarchical attention network that adaptively integrates modality-specific features using a novel, self-supervised attention mechanism. HAtten learns to focus on relevant modalities and capture complex relationships between them, resulting in improved performance on various downstream tasks. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate the efficiency and effectiveness of HAtten compared to state-of-the-art multi-modal embedding methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and query patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to optimize query execution plans in distributed relational databases. Our method, called GNN-QO, represents the database schema and query graph as a heterogeneous graph, and uses GNNs to learn a compact representation of the query optimization problem. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark show that GNN-QO outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Motion Planning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Motion planning for autonomous vehicles (AVs) in dynamic environments is a challenging problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to learn motion policies for AVs. We propose a hierarchical framework that integrates a high-level planner with a low-level controller, both trained using a DRL algorithm. The planner generates a sequence of waypoints, while the controller executes the motion plan using a model predictive control (MPC) strategy. We evaluate our approach in a simulated urban environment and demonstrate improved performance compared to traditional model-based planning methods.

title: SQL-Scalpel: A Novel Indexing Technique for Efficient Query Optimization in Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial aspect of relational database management systems. Despite significant advances, existing indexing techniques often struggle to efficiently handle complex queries. This paper introduces SQL-Scalpel, a novel indexing technique that leverages machine learning-based pattern recognition to identify and optimize critical query paths. By dynamically adapting to query workloads, SQL-Scalpel reduces query latency by up to 40% and improves overall system throughput. We evaluate SQL-Scalpel using the TPC-H benchmark and demonstrate its effectiveness in real-world database applications.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Semantic Hashing for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval systems face the challenge of efficiently filtering out irrelevant documents from large collections. This paper proposes a novel approach, Deep Semantic Hashing (DSH), which leverages deep neural networks to learn compact binary representations of documents. By preserving semantic similarity in the hash space, DSH enables fast and accurate filtering of documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DSH outperforms existing hashing methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and high-velocity data streams has created a pressing need for real-time analytics on large-scale datasets. Column-oriented NoSQL databases have emerged as a promising solution, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and query rewriting techniques to minimize latency and improve throughput. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrates that ColOpt achieves up to 3x speedup over state-of-the-art query optimizers for column-oriented NoSQL databases.

title: Investigating the Effect of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, randomly assigning them to either a personalized avatar condition or a generic avatar condition. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, presence, and enjoyment, while also reducing symptoms of VR-induced sickness. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and future research directions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent from a single query. Pseudo-relevance feedback (PRF) is a well-known technique to improve retrieval performance by incorporating feedback from top-ranked documents. However, existing PRF methods can be computationally expensive and may not effectively leverage the feedback. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'PRF-Boost', which adaptively selects and weights PRF terms based on their semantic relevance to the original query. Our experiments on the TREC ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, with PRF-Boost outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Rethinking Join Order Optimization for Modern Database Systems
paper_abstract: Join order optimization is a crucial component of modern database query optimization. However, existing approaches rely on outdated cost models and fail to account for the complexities of contemporary database systems. This paper presents a novel join order optimization framework, 'JOOX', which leverages machine learning and query workload analysis to adapt to diverse database environments. We introduce a probabilistic cost model that incorporates factors such as CPU and I/O resource utilization, data distribution, and query concurrency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that JOOX improves query performance by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Transformers for Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Transformer-based models have achieved state-of-the-art results in various natural language processing (NLP) tasks. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about their reliability in real-world applications. This paper investigates the robustness of transformer-based models to adversarial attacks, focusing on sentence classification and machine translation tasks. We propose a novel attack method, 'TFool', which generates perturbed input sequences that deceive the model while preserving semantic meaning. Experimental results show that TFool outperforms existing attacks in terms of success rate and transferability across different models and tasks. We also explore strategies for improving adversarial robustness, including data augmentation and adversarial training.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Interaction for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but existing systems often neglect the importance of gaze-based input. This paper presents 'GazeAdapt', a novel framework that leverages eye-tracking data to adapt VR interactions to individual users' behavior. Our approach combines machine learning-based gaze prediction with real-time scene analysis to generate personalized interaction profiles. We evaluate GazeAdapt in a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction. The results have implications for designing more inclusive and efficient VR experiences.

title: Robustness of Graph Convolutional Networks against Adversarial Attacks on Node Attributes
paper_abstract: Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) have been widely used for graph-structured data analysis. However, their robustness against adversarial attacks on node attributes has not been thoroughly investigated. In this paper, we propose a novel attack method, called AttrAttack, which modifies node attributes to mislead GCNs. We also develop a defense mechanism, called RobustGCN, which incorporates an attention-based module to detect and correct attribute perturbations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that AttrAttack significantly degrades GCN performance, while RobustGCN improves robustness against attribute-based attacks.

title: Designing Emotional Intelligence in Voice Assistants for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their lack of emotional intelligence can lead to user frustration and dissatisfaction. This paper presents an affective computing framework, 'EmpaVA', designed to endow voice assistants with emotional intelligence. Our approach combines natural language processing, sentiment analysis, and machine learning to enable voice assistants to recognize and respond empathetically to users' emotional states. We evaluated EmpaVA in a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction, trust, and overall experience. Our findings have implications for the design of more empathetic and human-centered voice assistants.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Accessibility
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their accessibility limitations persist, excluding individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a multimodal framework, 'IncluVA', which integrates computer vision, natural language processing, and human-computer interaction principles to create a more inclusive voice assistant. We propose a novel gesture recognition system that enables users to interact with the assistant using sign language, and a personalized error correction mechanism that adapts to individual users' speech patterns. Our user study with participants with disabilities demonstrates significant improvements in accessibility, usability, and user satisfaction.

title: Query-Focused Neural Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems struggle to effectively retrieve relevant documents from a large corpus, leading to suboptimal answer extraction. This paper introduces QFNR, a neural retrieval model that incorporates query-focused attention mechanisms to selectively retrieve passages most likely to contain the answer. Our approach leverages a hierarchical encoder to jointly model query-document interactions and passage-level relevance. Experimental results on the Natural Questions benchmark demonstrate that QFNR significantly outperforms existing retrieval methods, achieving a 12.1% improvement in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing demand for real-time analytics in distributed database systems (DDS) necessitates efficient query optimization techniques. We propose 'RTOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages a combination of machine learning-based cost estimation and dynamic reordering of query operators to minimize response time. Our approach takes into account DDS-specific characteristics, such as node heterogeneity and network latency, to optimize query execution plans. Experimental results on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate that RTOpt reduces average query response time by up to 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it aims to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion, which leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'SemExp', learns dense vector representations of words and phrases from large-scale text corpora and integrates them into a probabilistic retrieval framework. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SemExp significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving substantial improvements in precision and recall.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) tasks require models to fuse information from both visual and textual inputs. However, existing multimodal fusion methods often incur high computational costs or neglect the asymmetric relationships between modalities. We propose a novel attention mechanism, 'ModalCross', which adaptively weighs the importance of each modality based on the question context. Our approach leverages a hierarchical graph-based structure to model interactions between objects, regions, and questions. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 benchmark demonstrate that ModalCross outperforms state-of-the-art methods while reducing computational overhead by 30%

title: Hierarchical Neural Network Retrieval for Efficient Query Expansion in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in ad-hoc search to enhance retrieval effectiveness. However, existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering or expensive computational resources. This paper proposes a hierarchical neural network retrieval (HNRR) framework that learns to expand queries in a hierarchical manner, capturing both local and global semantic relationships between terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNRR outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and reciprocal rank while reducing computational overhead.

title: Decentralized Agent Coordination with Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordination among multiple agents. This paper proposes a decentralized framework for traffic signal control using reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'TrafficAgent', consists of a network of autonomous agents that learn to optimize traffic flow by interacting with their environment. We employ a multi-agent deep Q-network to model the agents' decision-making process and demonstrate improved traffic efficiency and reduced congestion in a simulated urban scenario. The proposed framework is scalable, adaptive, and can be easily integrated with existing traffic management systems.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Multimodal Fusion for Enhanced User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) applications often struggle to provide an immersive user experience due to the complexity of integrating multiple sensory inputs. This paper presents a novel approach to multimodal fusion that leverages gaze tracking to adaptively weight and combine visual, auditory, and haptic cues in real-time. Our system, called 'GazeFusion', uses a machine learning model to analyze the user's gaze patterns and dynamically adjust the modality fusion weights to optimize the user experience. We evaluate GazeFusion in a VR gaming scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in user engagement and task performance compared to traditional multimodal fusion approaches.
